quoteText:
I can tell you nothing, Aunt Juley. I know no more than you do. We
met--we only met the father and mother abroad last spring. I know so
little that I didn t even know their son s name. It s all so--
subQuotationList: ['I can tell you nothing, Aunt Juley. I know no more than you do. We\nmet--we only met the father and mother abroad last spring. I know so\nlittle that I didn t even know their son s name. It s all so--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: In that case it is far too sudden.
subQuotationList: ['In that case it is far too sudden.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Who knows, Aunt Juley, who knows?
subQuotationList: ['Who knows, Aunt Juley, who knows?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
But, Margaret, dear, I mean, we mustn t be unpractical now that we ve
come to facts. It is too sudden, surely.
subQuotationList: ['But, Margaret, dear, I mean, we mustn t be unpractical now that we ve\ncome to facts. It is too sudden, surely.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Who knows!
subQuotationList: ['Who knows!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But, Margaret, dear--
subQuotationList: ['But, Margaret, dear--']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
I ll go for her other letters, No, I won t, I ll
finish my breakfast. In fact, I haven t them. We met the Wilcoxes on an
awful expedition that we made from Heidelberg to Speyer. Helen and I
had got it into our heads that there was a grand old cathedral at
Speyer--the Archbishop of Speyer was one of the seven electors--you
know-- Speyer, Maintz, and Koln.  Those three sees once commanded the
Rhine Valley and got it the name of Priest Street.
subQuotationList:
['I ll go for her other letters,', 'No, I won t, I ll
finish my breakfast. In fact, I haven t them. We met the Wilcoxes on an
awful expedition that we made from Heidelberg to Speyer. Helen and I
had got it into our heads that there was a grand old cathedral at
Speyer--the Archbishop of Speyer was one of the seven electors--you
know-- Speyer, Maintz, and Koln.  Those three sees once commanded the
Rhine Valley and got it the name of Priest Street.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I still feel quite uneasy about this business, Margaret.
subQuotationList: ['I still feel quite uneasy about this business, Margaret.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
The train crossed by a bridge of boats, and at first sight it looked
quite fine. But oh, in five minutes we had seen the whole thing. The
cathedral had been ruined, absolutely ruined, by restoration; not an
inch left of the original structure. We wasted a whole day, and came
across the Wilcoxes as we were eating our sandwiches in the public
gardens. They too, poor things, had been taken in--they were actually
stopping at Speyer--and they rather liked Helen s insisting that they
must fly with us to Heidelberg. As a matter of fact, they did come on
next day. We all took some drives together. They knew us well enough to
ask Helen to come and see them--at least, I was asked too, but Tibby s
illness prevented me, so last Monday she went alone. That s all. You
know as much as I do now. It s a young man out of the unknown. She was
to have come back Saturday, but put off till Monday, perhaps on account
of--I don t know.
subQuotationList:
['The train crossed by a bridge of boats, and at first sight it looked
quite fine. But oh, in five minutes we had seen the whole thing. The
cathedral had been ruined, absolutely ruined, by restoration; not an
inch left of the original structure. We wasted a whole day, and came
across the Wilcoxes as we were eating our sandwiches in the public
gardens. They too, poor things, had been taken in--they were actually
stopping at Speyer--and they rather liked Helen s insisting that they
must fly with us to Heidelberg. As a matter of fact, they did come on
next day. We all took some drives together. They knew us well enough to
ask Helen to come and see them--at least, I was asked too, but Tibby s
illness prevented me, so last Monday she went alone. That s all. You
know as much as I do now. It s a young man out of the unknown. She was
to have come back Saturday, but put off till Monday, perhaps on account
of--I don t know.']
speaker: Margaret
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Margaret', 'Helen'], ['Margaret', 'Helen'], ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Margaret', 'Helen'], ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Henry', 'Ruth'], ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Helen'], ['Margaret', 'Helen'], ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Margaret', 'Helen'], ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Margaret', 'Helen'], ['Helen'], ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Tibby'], ['Helen'], ['Aunt Juley'], ['Paul'], ['Helen']]]

quoteText:
The Germans, are too
thorough, and this is all very well sometimes, but at other times it
does not do.
subQuotationList: ['The Germans,', 'are too\nthorough, and this is all very well sometimes, but at other times it\ndoes not do.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Exactly, Germans are too thorough.
subQuotationList: ['Exactly,', 'Germans are too thorough.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Of course I regard you Schlegels as English, English to the backbone.
subQuotationList: ['Of course I regard you Schlegels as English,', 'English to the backbone.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: And that reminds me--Helen s letter.
subQuotationList: ['And that reminds me--Helen s letter.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Oh yes, Aunt Juley, I am thinking all right about Helen s letter. I
know--I must go down and see her. I am thinking about her all right. I
am meaning to go down.
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes, Aunt Juley, I am thinking all right about Helen s letter. I\nknow--I must go down and see her. I am thinking about her all right. I\nam meaning to go down.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
But go with some plan, Margaret, if I may interfere, don t be taken by
surprise. What do you think of the Wilcoxes? Are they our sort? Are they
likely people? Could they appreciate Helen, who is to my mind a very
special sort of person? Do they care about Literature and Art? That is
most important when you come to think of it. Literature and Art. Most
important. How old would the son be? She says  younger son.  Would he
be in a position to marry? Is he likely to make Helen happy? Did you
gather--
subQuotationList:
['But go with some plan,', 'Margaret, if I may interfere, don t be taken by
surprise. What do you think of the Wilcoxes? Are they our sort? Are they
likely people? Could they appreciate Helen, who is to my mind a very
special sort of person? Do they care about Literature and Art? That is
most important when you come to think of it. Literature and Art. Most
important. How old would the son be? She says  younger son.  Would he
be in a position to marry? Is he likely to make Helen happy? Did you
gather--']
speaker: Aunt Juley
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Margaret'], ['Margaret'], ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Helen'], ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Margaret'], ['Paul'], ['Helen'], ['Paul'], ['Paul'], ['Helen'], ['Margaret']]]

quoteText: I gathered nothing.
subQuotationList: ['I gathered nothing.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Then in that case--
subQuotationList: ['Then in that case--']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: In that case I can make no plans, don t you see.
subQuotationList: ['In that case I can make no plans, don t you see.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: On the contrary--
subQuotationList: ['On the contrary--']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: I hate plans. I hate lines of action. Helen isn t a baby.
subQuotationList: ['I hate plans. I hate lines of action. Helen isn t a baby.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Then in that case, my dear, why go down?
subQuotationList: ['Then in that case, my dear, why go down?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
I consider you odd girls, and very wonderful
girls, and in many ways far older than your years. But--you won t be
offended? frankly, I feel you are not up to this business. It requires
an older person. Dear, I have nothing to call me back to Swanage. I am all at your disposal. Let me go down to
this house whose name I forget instead of you.
subQuotationList:
['I consider you odd girls,', 'and very wonderful
girls, and in many ways far older than your years. But--you won t be
offended? frankly, I feel you are not up to this business. It requires
an older person. Dear, I have nothing to call me back to Swanage.', 'I am all at your disposal. Let me go down to
this house whose name I forget instead of you.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Aunt Juley
subQuotationList: ['Aunt Juley']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I must, must go to Howards
End myself. You don t exactly understand, though I can never thank you
properly for offering.
subQuotationList: ['I must, must go to Howards\nEnd myself. You don t exactly understand, though I can never thank you\nproperly for offering.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I do understand, I go
down in no spirit of interference, but to make inquiries. Inquiries are
necessary. Now, I am going to be rude. You would say the wrong thing; to
a certainty you would. In your anxiety for Helen s happiness you would
offend the whole of these Wilcoxes by asking one of your impetuous
questions--not that one minds offending them.
subQuotationList:
['I do understand,', 'I go
down in no spirit of interference, but to make inquiries. Inquiries are
necessary. Now, I am going to be rude. You would say the wrong thing; to
a certainty you would. In your anxiety for Helen s happiness you would
offend the whole of these Wilcoxes by asking one of your impetuous
questions--not that one minds offending them.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
I shall ask no questions. I have it in Helen s writing that she and
a man are in love. There is no question to ask as long as she keeps to
that. All the rest isn t worth a straw. A long engagement if you like,
but inquiries, questions, plans, lines of action--no, Aunt Juley, no.
subQuotationList:
['I shall ask no questions. I have it in Helen s writing that she and
a man are in love. There is no question to ask as long as she keeps to
that. All the rest isn t worth a straw. A long engagement if you like,
but inquiries, questions, plans, lines of action--no, Aunt Juley, no.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
If Helen had written the same to me about a shop assistant or a
penniless clerk--
subQuotationList: ['If Helen had written the same to me about a shop assistant or a\npenniless clerk--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Dear Margaret, do come into the library and shut the door. Your good
maids are dusting the banisters.
subQuotationList: ['Dear Margaret, do come into the library and shut the door. Your good\nmaids are dusting the banisters.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
--or if she had wanted to marry the man who calls for Carter Paterson,
I should have said the same. Though
in the case of Carter Paterson I should want it to be a very long
engagement indeed, I must say.
subQuotationList:
['--or if she had wanted to marry the man who calls for Carter Paterson,
I should have said the same.', 'Though
in the case of Carter Paterson I should want it to be a very long
engagement indeed, I must say.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I should think so, and, indeed, I can scarcely
follow you. Now, just imagine if you said anything of that sort to the
Wilcoxes. I understand it, but most good people would think you mad.
Imagine how disconcerting for Helen! What is wanted is a person who will
go slowly, slowly in this business, and see how things are and where
they are likely to lead to.
subQuotationList:
['I should think so,', 'and, indeed, I can scarcely
follow you. Now, just imagine if you said anything of that sort to the
Wilcoxes. I understand it, but most good people would think you mad.
Imagine how disconcerting for Helen! What is wanted is a person who will
go slowly, slowly in this business, and see how things are and where
they are likely to lead to.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: But you implied just now that the engagement must be broken off.
subQuotationList: ['But you implied just now that the engagement must be broken off.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I think probably it must; but slowly.
subQuotationList: ['I think probably it must; but slowly.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Can you break an engagement off slowly?
subQuotationList: ['Can you break an engagement off slowly?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
What s an
engagement made of, do you suppose? I think it s made of some hard stuff
that may snap, but can t break. It is different to the other ties of
life. They stretch or bend. They admit of degree. They re different.
subQuotationList:
['What s an
engagement made of, do you suppose? I think it s made of some hard stuff
that may snap, but can t break. It is different to the other ties of
life. They stretch or bend. They admit of degree. They re different.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Exactly so. But won t you let me just run down to Howards House, and
save you all the discomfort? I will really not interfere, but I do so
thoroughly understand the kind of thing you Schlegels want that one
quiet look round will be enough for me.
subQuotationList:
['Exactly so. But won t you let me just run down to Howards House, and
save you all the discomfort? I will really not interfere, but I do so
thoroughly understand the kind of thing you Schlegels want that one
quiet look round will be enough for me.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Yes, I have changed my mind; I do wish that you would go.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I have changed my mind; I do wish that you would go.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
You will remember, Aunt Juley, not to be drawn into discussing the
engagement. Give my letter to Helen, and say whatever you feel yourself,
but do keep clear of the relatives. We have scarcely got their names
straight yet, and, besides, that sort of thing is so uncivilised and
wrong.
subQuotationList:
['You will remember, Aunt Juley, not to be drawn into discussing the
engagement. Give my letter to Helen, and say whatever you feel yourself,
but do keep clear of the relatives. We have scarcely got their names
straight yet, and, besides, that sort of thing is so uncivilised and
wrong.']
speaker: Margaret
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Aunt Juley'], ['Aunt Juley'], ['Helen'], ['Aunt Juley'], ['Mr. Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Paul'], ['Aunt Juley', 'Margaret'], ['Mr. Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Paul']]]

quoteText: So uncivilised?
subQuotationList: ['So uncivilised?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Oh, I used an affected word. I only meant would you please talk the
thing over only with Helen.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I used an affected word. I only meant would you please talk the\nthing over only with Helen.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Only with Helen.
subQuotationList: ['Only with Helen.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Because--
subQuotationList: ['Because--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Then we should be together, dear.
subQuotationList: ['Then we should be together, dear.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
I did
manage that, at all events. When the smash comes poor Margaret will have
a nest-egg to fall back upon.
subQuotationList: ['I did\nmanage that, at all events. When the smash comes poor Margaret will have\na nest-egg to fall back upon.']
speaker: Aunt Juley
referringExpression: Mrs Munt never ceased to rejoice and to say

quoteText:
I want a house, Its name is Howards
Lodge. Do you know where it is?
subQuotationList: ['I want a house,', 'Its name is Howards\nLodge. Do you know where it is?']
speaker: Aunt Juley
referringExpression: she confided to the ticket boy

quoteText: Mr. Wilcox!
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Wilcox!']
speaker: The Ticket Boy

quoteText: She s wanting Howards End.
subQuotationList: ['She s wanting Howards End.']
speaker: The Ticket Boy

quoteText:
Excuse me asking,
but are you the younger Mr. Wilcox or the elder?
subQuotationList: ['Excuse me asking,\nbut are you the younger Mr. Wilcox or the elder?']
speaker: Aunt Juley
referringExpression: she had the sense to say to him

quoteText: The younger. Can I do anything for you?
subQuotationList: ['The younger. Can I do anything for you?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Oh, well
subQuotationList: ['Oh, well']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Really. Are you?
I--
subQuotationList: ['Really. Are you?\nI--']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
I am
Miss Schlegel s aunt. I ought to introduce myself, oughtn t I? My name
is Mrs. Munt.
subQuotationList: ['I am\nMiss Schlegel s aunt. I ought to introduce myself, oughtn t I? My name\nis Mrs. Munt.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Oh,
rather; Miss Schlegel is stopping with us. Did you want to see her?
subQuotationList: ['Oh,\nrather; Miss Schlegel is stopping with us. Did you want to see her?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox
referringExpression: he raised his cap and said

quoteText: Possibly.
subQuotationList: ['Possibly.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: I ll call you a cab. No; wait a mo--
subQuotationList: ['I ll call you a cab. No; wait a mo--']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
Our motor s here.
I ll run you up in it.
subQuotationList: ['Our motor s here.\nI ll run you up in it.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: That is very kind.
subQuotationList: ['That is very kind.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Not at all, if you ll just wait till they bring out a parcel from the
office. This way.
subQuotationList: ['Not at all, if you ll just wait till they bring out a parcel from the\noffice. This way.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: My niece is not with you by any chance?
subQuotationList: ['My niece is not with you by any chance?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
No; I came over with my father. He has gone on north in your train.
You ll see Miss Schlegel at lunch. You re coming up to lunch, I hope?
subQuotationList: ['No; I came over with my father. He has gone on north in your train.\nYou ll see Miss Schlegel at lunch. You re coming up to lunch, I hope?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: I should like to come UP,
subQuotationList: ['I should like to come UP,']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: In front or behind? Which do you prefer? It may be windy in front.
subQuotationList: ['In front or behind? Which do you prefer? It may be windy in front.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: In front if I may; then we can talk.
subQuotationList: ['In front if I may; then we can talk.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
But excuse me one moment--I can t think what they re doing with that
parcel. Hi! hi, you there! Are you going to keep me waiting all day? Parcel for
Wilcox, Howards End. Just look sharp!
subQuotationList: ['But excuse me one moment--I can t think what they re doing with that\nparcel.', 'Hi! hi, you there! Are you going to keep me waiting all day? Parcel for\nWilcox, Howards End. Just look sharp!']
speaker: Charles Wilcox
referringExpression: He strode into the bookingoffice and called

quoteText:
This station s abominably
organised; if I had my way, the whole lot of  em should get the sack.
May I help you in?
subQuotationList: ['This station s abominably\norganised; if I had my way, the whole lot of  em should get the sack.\nMay I help you in?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: This is very good of you,
subQuotationList: ['This is very good of you,']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Very good indeed,
subQuotationList: ['Very good indeed,']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: It is just what I should have wished.
subQuotationList: ['It is just what I should have wished.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Very good of you to say so, I was just tooling my father over to catch the down train.
subQuotationList: ['Very good of you to say so,', 'I was just tooling my father over to catch the down train.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: You see, we heard from Helen this morning.
subQuotationList: ['You see, we heard from Helen this morning.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
The mater will be very
glad to see you,
subQuotationList: ['The mater will be very\nglad to see you,']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
Hi! I say. Parcel. Parcel for Howards
End. Bring it out. Hi!
subQuotationList: ['Hi! I say. Parcel. Parcel for Howards\nEnd. Bring it out. Hi!']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
Sign, must I? Why the -- should I sign after all this bother?
Not even got a pencil on you? Remember next time I report you to the
station-master. My time s of value, though yours mayn t be. Here
subQuotationList: ['Sign, must I? Why the -- should I sign after all this bother?\nNot even got a pencil on you? Remember next time I report you to the\nstation-master. My time s of value, though yours mayn t be. Here']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Extremely sorry, Mrs. Munt.
subQuotationList: ['Extremely sorry, Mrs. Munt.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Not at all, Mr. Wilcox.
subQuotationList: ['Not at all, Mr. Wilcox.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
And do you object to going through the village? It is rather a longer
spin, but I have one or two commissions.
subQuotationList: ['And do you object to going through the village? It is rather a longer\nspin, but I have one or two commissions.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
I should love going through the village. Naturally I am very anxious to
talk things over with you.
subQuotationList: ['I should love going through the village. Naturally I am very anxious to\ntalk things over with you.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
You can well imagine, that the news was a
great shock to us.
subQuotationList: ['You can well imagine,', 'that the news was a\ngreat shock to us.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: What news?
subQuotationList: ['What news?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
Mr. Wilcox, Margaret has told me
everything--everything. I have seen Helen s letter.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Wilcox,', 'Margaret has told me\neverything--everything. I have seen Helen s letter.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
I beg your pardon; I
didn t catch.
subQuotationList: ['I beg your pardon; I\ndidn t catch.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox
referringExpression: he inclined his head in her direction and said

quoteText:
About Helen. Helen, of course. Helen is a very exceptional person--I
am sure you will let me say this, feeling towards her as you do--indeed,
all the Schlegels are exceptional. I come in no spirit of interference,
but it was a great shock.
subQuotationList:
['About Helen. Helen, of course. Helen is a very exceptional person--I
am sure you will let me say this, feeling towards her as you do--indeed,
all the Schlegels are exceptional. I come in no spirit of interference,
but it was a great shock.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
I wonder when they ll learn wisdom and tar the
roads,
subQuotationList: ['I wonder when they ll learn wisdom and tar the\nroads,']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
Margaret could not come herself, on account of poor Tibby, so I am here
to represent her and to have a good talk.
subQuotationList: ['Margaret could not come herself, on account of poor Tibby, so I am here\nto represent her and to have a good talk.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: I m sorry to be so dense, But I still haven t quite understood.
subQuotationList: ['I m sorry to be so dense,', 'But I still haven t quite understood.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Helen, Mr. Wilcox--my niece and you.
subQuotationList: ['Helen, Mr. Wilcox--my niece and you.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Miss Schlegel and myself?
subQuotationList: ['Miss Schlegel and myself?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
I trust there has been no misunderstanding, Her
letter certainly read that way.
subQuotationList: ['I trust there has been no misunderstanding,', 'Her\nletter certainly read that way.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: What way?
subQuotationList: ['What way?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: That you and she--
subQuotationList: ['That you and she--']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
I think I catch your meaning, What an extraordinary
mistake!
subQuotationList: ['I think I catch your meaning,', 'What an extraordinary\nmistake!']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Then you didn t the least--
subQuotationList: ['Then you didn t the least--']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Scarcely, as I am already engaged to another lady. Oh,
good God! Don t tell me it s some silliness of Paul s.
subQuotationList: ['Scarcely, as I am already engaged to another lady.', 'Oh,\ngood God! Don t tell me it s some silliness of Paul s.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox
referringExpression: he caught his breath and exploded with

quoteText: But you are Paul.
subQuotationList: ['But you are Paul.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: I m not.
subQuotationList: ['I m not.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Then why did you say so at the station?
subQuotationList: ['Then why did you say so at the station?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: I said nothing of the sort.
subQuotationList: ['I said nothing of the sort.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: I beg your pardon, I did not. My name is Charles.
subQuotationList: ['I beg your pardon, I did not. My name is Charles.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Do you mean to tell me that Paul--
subQuotationList: ['Do you mean to tell me that Paul--']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Do you mean to tell me that Paul and your niece--
subQuotationList: ['Do you mean to tell me that Paul and your niece--']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
Yes,
they care for one another very much indeed, I dare say they
will tell you about it by-and-by. We heard this morning.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,\nthey care for one another very much indeed,', 'I dare say they\nwill tell you about it by-and-by. We heard this morning.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
The idiot, the idiot, the
little fool!
subQuotationList: ['The idiot, the idiot, the\nlittle fool!']
speaker: Charles Wilcox
referringExpression: Charles clenched his fist and cried

quoteText:
If that is your
attitude, Mr. Wilcox, I prefer to walk.
subQuotationList: ['If that is your\nattitude, Mr. Wilcox, I prefer to walk.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
I beg you will do no such thing. I take you up this moment to the
house. Let me tell you the thing s impossible, and must be stopped.
subQuotationList: ['I beg you will do no such thing. I take you up this moment to the\nhouse. Let me tell you the thing s impossible, and must be stopped.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
I quite
agree, sir. The thing is impossible, and I will come up and stop it. My
niece is a very exceptional person, and I am not inclined to sit still
while she throws herself away on those who will not appreciate her.
subQuotationList:
['I quite
agree, sir. The thing is impossible, and I will come up and stop it. My
niece is a very exceptional person, and I am not inclined to sit still
while she throws herself away on those who will not appreciate her.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Considering she has only known your brother since Wednesday, and only
met your father and mother at a stray hotel--
subQuotationList: ['Considering she has only known your brother since Wednesday, and only\nmet your father and mother at a stray hotel--']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Could you possibly lower your voice? The shopman will overhear.
subQuotationList: ['Could you possibly lower your voice? The shopman will overhear.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: I warn you: Paul hasn t a penny; it s useless.
subQuotationList: ['I warn you: Paul hasn t a penny; it s useless.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
No need to warn us, Mr. Wilcox, I assure you. The warning is all the
other way. My niece has been very foolish, and I shall give her a good
scolding and take her back to London with me.
subQuotationList: ['No need to warn us, Mr. Wilcox, I assure you. The warning is all the\nother way. My niece has been very foolish, and I shall give her a good\nscolding and take her back to London with me.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
He has to make his way out in Nigeria. He couldn t think of marrying
for years, and when he does it must be a woman who can stand the
climate, and is in other ways--Why hasn t he told us? Of course he s
ashamed. He knows he s been a fool. And so he has--a downright fool.
subQuotationList:
['He has to make his way out in Nigeria. He couldn t think of marrying
for years, and when he does it must be a woman who can stand the
climate, and is in other ways--Why hasn t he told us? Of course he s
ashamed. He knows he s been a fool. And so he has--a downright fool.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Whereas Miss Schlegel has lost no time in publishing the news.
subQuotationList: ['Whereas Miss Schlegel has lost no time in publishing the news.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
If I were a man, Mr. Wilcox, for that last remark I d box your ears.
You re not fit to clean my niece s boots, to sit in the same room with
her, and you dare--you actually dare--I decline to argue with such a
person.
subQuotationList:
['If I were a man, Mr. Wilcox, for that last remark I d box your ears.
You re not fit to clean my niece s boots, to sit in the same room with
her, and you dare--you actually dare--I decline to argue with such a
person.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
All I know is, she s spread the thing and he hasn t, and my father s
away and I--
subQuotationList: ['All I know is, she s spread the thing and he hasn t, and my father s\naway and I--']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: And all that I know is--
subQuotationList: ['And all that I know is--']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Might I finish my sentence, please?
subQuotationList: ['Might I finish my sentence, please?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: No.
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Aunt Juley, I have just had a telegram from Margaret; I--I meant to
stop your coming. It isn t--it s over.
subQuotationList: ['Aunt Juley, I have just had a telegram from Margaret; I--I meant to\nstop your coming. It isn t--it s over.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Aunt Juley dear, don t. Don t let them know I ve been so silly. It
wasn t anything. Do bear up for my sake.
subQuotationList: ['Aunt Juley dear, don t. Don t let them know I ve been so silly. It\nwasn t anything. Do bear up for my sake.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Paul,
subQuotationList: ['Paul,']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Don t let them know. They are never to know.
subQuotationList: ['Don t let them know. They are never to know.']
speaker: Helen
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Mr. Wilcox']]]

quoteText: Oh, my darling Helen--
subQuotationList: ['Oh, my darling Helen--']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Paul! Paul!
subQuotationList: ['Paul! Paul!']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Paul, is there any truth in this?
subQuotationList: ['Paul, is there any truth in this?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: I didn t--I don t--
subQuotationList: ['I didn t--I don t--']
speaker: Paul

quoteText:
Yes or no, man; plain question, plain answer. Did or didn t Miss
Schlegel--
subQuotationList: ['Yes or no, man; plain question, plain answer. Did or didn t Miss\nSchlegel--']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
Charles, dear, Charles, dear Charles,
one doesn t ask plain questions. There aren t such things.
subQuotationList: ['Charles, dear,', 'Charles, dear Charles,\none doesn t ask plain questions. There aren t such things.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
Miss Schlegel, would you take your aunt up to your room or
to my room, whichever you think best. Paul, do find Evie, and tell her
lunch for six, but I m not sure whether we shall all be downstairs for
it.
subQuotationList:
['Miss Schlegel, would you take your aunt up to your room or
to my room, whichever you think best. Paul, do find Evie, and tell her
lunch for six, but I m not sure whether we shall all be downstairs for
it.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
Mother, are you aware that Paul has been playing the fool
again?
subQuotationList: ['Mother,', 'are you aware that Paul has been playing the fool\nagain?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: It is all right, dear. They have broken off the engagement.
subQuotationList: ['It is all right, dear. They have broken off the engagement.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Engagement--!
subQuotationList: ['Engagement--!']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: They do not love any longer, if you prefer it put that way,
subQuotationList: ['They do not love any longer, if you prefer it put that way,']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
Thank goodness, poor Margaret is saved this! It had to be gone
through by some one, The one time I really did help Emily s girls was over the Wilcox
business.
subQuotationList: ['Thank goodness, poor Margaret is saved this!', 'It had to be gone\nthrough by some one,', 'The one time I really did help Emily s girls was over the Wilcox\nbusiness.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Why
be so polite to servants? they don t understand it,
subQuotationList: ['Why\nbe so polite to servants? they don t understand it,']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
I am swathed in
cant, and it is good for me to be stripped of it.
subQuotationList: ['I am swathed in\ncant,', 'and it is good for me to be stripped of it.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
This girl
would let you kiss her; you might not have such a chance again.
subQuotationList: ['This girl\nwould let you kiss her; you might not have such a chance again.']
speaker: Paul

quoteText:
I
love you
subQuotationList: ['I\nlove you']
speaker: Paul

quoteText:
I understand, at least, I understand as much as ever
is understood of these things. Tell me now what happened on the Monday
morning.
subQuotationList: ['I understand,', 'at least, I understand as much as ever\nis understood of these things. Tell me now what happened on the Monday\nmorning.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It was over at once.
subQuotationList: ['It was over at once.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: How, Helen?
subQuotationList: ['How, Helen?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I was still happy while I dressed, but as I came downstairs I got
nervous, and when I went into the dining-room I knew it was no good.
There was Evie--I can t explain--managing the tea-urn, and Mr. Wilcox
reading the Times.
subQuotationList:
['I was still happy while I dressed, but as I came downstairs I got
nervous, and when I went into the dining-room I knew it was no good.
There was Evie--I can t explain--managing the tea-urn, and Mr. Wilcox
reading the Times.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Was Paul there?
subQuotationList: ['Was Paul there?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Yes; and Charles was talking to him about stocks and shares, and he
looked frightened.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; and Charles was talking to him about stocks and shares, and he\nlooked frightened.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Somehow, when that kind of man looks frightened it is too awful. It is
all right for us to be frightened, or for men of another sort--father,
for instance; but for men like that! When I saw all the others so
placid, and Paul mad with terror in case I said the wrong thing, I felt
for a moment that the whole Wilcox family was a fraud, just a wall of
newspapers and motor-cars and golf-clubs, and that if it fell I should
find nothing behind it but panic and emptiness.
subQuotationList:
['Somehow, when that kind of man looks frightened it is too awful. It is
all right for us to be frightened, or for men of another sort--father,
for instance; but for men like that! When I saw all the others so
placid, and Paul mad with terror in case I said the wrong thing, I felt
for a moment that the whole Wilcox family was a fraud, just a wall of
newspapers and motor-cars and golf-clubs, and that if it fell I should
find nothing behind it but panic and emptiness.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I don t think that. The Wilcoxes struck me as being genuine people,
particularly the wife.
subQuotationList: ['I don t think that. The Wilcoxes struck me as being genuine people,\nparticularly the wife.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
No, I don t really think that. But Paul was so broad-shouldered; all
kinds of extraordinary things made it worse, and I knew that it would
never do--never. I said to him after breakfast, when the others were
practising strokes,
subQuotationList:
['No, I don t really think that. But Paul was so broad-shouldered; all
kinds of extraordinary things made it worse, and I knew that it would
never do--never. I said to him after breakfast, when the others were
practising strokes,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
and he looked better
at once, though frightfully ashamed. He began a speech about having no
money to marry on, but it hurt him to make it, and I stopped him. Then
he said,
subQuotationList:
['and he looked better
at once, though frightfully ashamed. He began a speech about having no
money to marry on, but it hurt him to make it, and I stopped him. Then
he said,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: And I said,
subQuotationList: ['And I said,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
And then we parted--at least, until I remembered that I had
written straight off to tell you the night before, and that frightened
him again. I asked him to send a telegram for me, for he knew you would
be coming or something; and he tried to get hold of the motor, but
Charles and Mr. Wilcox wanted it to go to the station; and Charles
offered to send the telegram for me, and then I had to say that the
telegram was of no consequence, for Paul said Charles might read it, and
though I wrote it out several times, he always said people would suspect
something. He took it himself at last, pretending that he must walk down
to get cartridges, and, what with one thing and the other, it was not
handed in at the post-office until too late. It was the most terrible
morning. Paul disliked me more and more, and Evie talked cricket
averages till I nearly screamed. I cannot think how I stood her all the
other days. At last Charles and his father started for the station, and
then came your telegram warning me that Aunt Juley was coming by that
train, and Paul--oh, rather horrible--said that I had muddled it. But
Mrs. Wilcox knew.
subQuotationList:
['And then we parted--at least, until I remembered that I had
written straight off to tell you the night before, and that frightened
him again. I asked him to send a telegram for me, for he knew you would
be coming or something; and he tried to get hold of the motor, but
Charles and Mr. Wilcox wanted it to go to the station; and Charles
offered to send the telegram for me, and then I had to say that the
telegram was of no consequence, for Paul said Charles might read it, and
though I wrote it out several times, he always said people would suspect
something. He took it himself at last, pretending that he must walk down
to get cartridges, and, what with one thing and the other, it was not
handed in at the post-office until too late. It was the most terrible
morning. Paul disliked me more and more, and Evie talked cricket
averages till I nearly screamed. I cannot think how I stood her all the
other days. At last Charles and his father started for the station, and
then came your telegram warning me that Aunt Juley was coming by that
train, and Paul--oh, rather horrible--said that I had muddled it. But
Mrs. Wilcox knew.']
speaker: Helen
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Paul', 'Helen'], ['Margaret'], ['Paul'], ['Paul'], ['Paul'], ['Margaret'], ['Paul'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Mr. Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Paul'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Paul'], ['Paul'], ['Paul'], ['Paul'], ['Evie'], ['Evie'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Mr. Wilcox'], ['Margaret'], ['Aunt Juley'], ['Paul'], ['Mrs. Wilcox']]]

quoteText: Knew what?
subQuotationList: ['Knew what?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Everything; though we neither of us told her a word, and she had known
all along, I think.
subQuotationList: ['Everything; though we neither of us told her a word, and she had known\nall along, I think.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Oh, she must have overheard you.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, she must have overheard you.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I suppose so, but it seemed wonderful. When Charles and Aunt Juley
drove up, calling each other names, Mrs. Wilcox stepped in from the
garden and made everything less terrible. Ugh! but it has been a
disgusting business. To think that--
subQuotationList:
['I suppose so, but it seemed wonderful. When Charles and Aunt Juley
drove up, calling each other names, Mrs. Wilcox stepped in from the
garden and made everything less terrible. Ugh! but it has been a
disgusting business. To think that--']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
To think that because you and a young man meet for a moment, there must
be all these telegrams and anger,
subQuotationList: ['To think that because you and a young man meet for a moment, there must\nbe all these telegrams and anger,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I ve often thought about it, Helen. It s one of the most interesting
things in the world. The truth is that there is a great outer life that
you and I have never touched--a life in which telegrams and anger count.
Personal relations, that we think supreme, are not supreme there. There
love means marriage settlements, death, death duties. So far I m clear.
But here my difficulty. This outer life, though obviously horrid; often
seems the real one--there s grit in it. It does breed character. Do
personal relations lead to sloppiness in the end?
subQuotationList:
['I ve often thought about it, Helen. It s one of the most interesting
things in the world. The truth is that there is a great outer life that
you and I have never touched--a life in which telegrams and anger count.
Personal relations, that we think supreme, are not supreme there. There
love means marriage settlements, death, death duties. So far I m clear.
But here my difficulty. This outer life, though obviously horrid; often
seems the real one--there s grit in it. It does breed character. Do
personal relations lead to sloppiness in the end?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Oh, Meg--, that s what I felt, only not so clearly, when the Wilcoxes
were so competent, and seemed to have their hands on all the ropes.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Meg--, that s what I felt, only not so clearly, when the Wilcoxes\nwere so competent, and seemed to have their hands on all the ropes.']
speaker: Helen
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Margaret'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox']]]

quoteText: Don t you feel it now?
subQuotationList: ['Don t you feel it now?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I remember Paul at breakfast, I shall never
forget him. He had nothing to fall back upon. I know that personal
relations are the real life, for ever and ever.
subQuotationList: ['I remember Paul at breakfast,', 'I shall never\nforget him. He had nothing to fall back upon. I know that personal\nrelations are the real life, for ever and ever.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Amen!
subQuotationList: ['Amen!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Do you imply that we Germans are
stupid, Uncle Ernst?
subQuotationList: ['Do you imply that we Germans are\nstupid, Uncle Ernst?']
speaker: A Haughty And Magnificent Nephew
referringExpression: exclaimed a haughty and magnificent nephew

quoteText:
To my mind. You use the intellect, but you no longer
care about it. That I call stupidity.
subQuotationList: ['To my mind. You use the intellect, but you no longer\ncare about it. That I call stupidity.']
speaker: Uncle Ernst

quoteText:
You only care about the things that you can use,
and therefore arrange them in the following order: Money, supremely
useful; intellect, rather useful; imagination, of no use at all.
No your Pan-Germanism is no more
imaginative than is our Imperialism over here. It is the vice of a
vulgar mind to be thrilled by bigness, to think that a thousand square
miles are a thousand times more wonderful than one square mile, and
that a million square miles are almost the same as heaven. That is
not imagination. No, it kills it. When their poets over here try to
celebrate bigness they are dead at once, and naturally. Your poets
too are dying, your philosophers, your musicians, to whom Europe has
listened for two hundred years. Gone. Gone with the little courts that
nurtured them--gone with Esterhazy and Weimar. What? What s that? Your
universities? Oh yes, you have learned men, who collect more facts
than do the learned men of England. They collect facts, and facts, and
empires of facts. But which of them will rekindle the light within?
subQuotationList:
['You only care about the things that you can use,
and therefore arrange them in the following order: Money, supremely
useful; intellect, rather useful; imagination, of no use at all.
No', 'your Pan-Germanism is no more
imaginative than is our Imperialism over here. It is the vice of a
vulgar mind to be thrilled by bigness, to think that a thousand square
miles are a thousand times more wonderful than one square mile, and
that a million square miles are almost the same as heaven. That is
not imagination. No, it kills it. When their poets over here try to
celebrate bigness they are dead at once, and naturally. Your poets
too are dying, your philosophers, your musicians, to whom Europe has
listened for two hundred years. Gone. Gone with the little courts that
nurtured them--gone with Esterhazy and Weimar. What? What s that? Your
universities? Oh yes, you have learned men, who collect more facts
than do the learned men of England. They collect facts, and facts, and
empires of facts. But which of them will rekindle the light within?']
speaker: Uncle Ernst

quoteText:
Papa, why will they not
discuss this most clear question?
subQuotationList: ['Papa,', 'why will they not\ndiscuss this most clear question?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
To me one of two things is very clear; either
God does not know his own mind about England and Germany, or else these
do not know the mind of God.
subQuotationList: ['To me one of two things is very clear; either\nGod does not know his own mind about England and Germany, or else these\ndo not know the mind of God.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Whom is Margaret talking to?
subQuotationList: ['Whom is Margaret talking to?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Would it be some young man or other whom she takes an interest in?
subQuotationList: ['Would it be some young man or other whom she takes an interest in?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: I expect so,
subQuotationList: ['I expect so,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
You girls are so wonderful in always having--Oh dear! one mustn t
talk.
subQuotationList: ['You girls are so wonderful in always having--Oh dear! one mustn t\ntalk.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
How awful to marry a
man like those Cupids!
subQuotationList: ['How awful to marry a\nman like those Cupids!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Now comes the wonderful movement: first of all
the goblins, and then a trio of elephants dancing
subQuotationList: ['Now comes the wonderful movement: first of all\nthe goblins, and then a trio of elephants dancing']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: On the what, dear?
subQuotationList: ['On the what, dear?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: On the drum, Aunt Juley.
subQuotationList: ['On the drum, Aunt Juley.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
No; look out for the part where you think you have done with the
goblins and they come back,
subQuotationList: ['No; look out for the part where you think you have done with the\ngoblins and they come back,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Margaret, is Helen all right?
subQuotationList: ['Margaret,', 'is Helen all right?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Oh yes.
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: She is always going away in the middle of a programme,
subQuotationList: ['She is always going away in the middle of a programme,']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: The music has evidently moved her deeply,
subQuotationList: ['The music has evidently moved her deeply,']
speaker: Fraulein Mosebach

quoteText:
Excuse me, but that lady has, quite inadvertently, taken my
umbrella.
subQuotationList: ['Excuse me,', 'but that lady has, quite inadvertently, taken my\numbrella.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Oh, good gracious me!--I am so sorry. Tibby, run after Helen.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, good gracious me!--I am so sorry. Tibby, run after Helen.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I shall miss the Four Serious Songs if I do.
subQuotationList: ['I shall miss the Four Serious Songs if I do.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: Tibby, love, you must go.
subQuotationList: ['Tibby, love, you must go.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It isn t of any consequence,
subQuotationList: ['It isn t of any consequence,']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: But of course it is. Tibby! Tibby!
subQuotationList: ['But of course it is. Tibby! Tibby!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: My sister is so careless,
subQuotationList: ['My sister is so careless,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Not at all,
subQuotationList: ['Not at all,']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: If you would give me your address--
subQuotationList: ['If you would give me your address--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, not at all, not at all;
subQuotationList: ['Oh, not at all, not at all;']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
That is where
we live; if you preferred, you could call for the umbrella after the
concert, but I didn t like to trouble you when it has all been our
fault.
subQuotationList:
['That is where
we live; if you preferred, you could call for the umbrella after the
concert, but I didn t like to trouble you when it has all been our
fault.']
speaker: Margaret
referringExpression: she gave him her card and said

quoteText:
It s a fine programme
this afternoon, is it not?
subQuotationList: ['It s a fine programme\nthis afternoon, is it not?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
The Beethoven s fine, I don t like the Brahms, though, nor the Mendelssohn
that came first and ugh! I don t like this Elgar that s coming.
subQuotationList: ['The Beethoven s fine,', 'I don t like the Brahms, though, nor the Mendelssohn\nthat came first and ugh! I don t like this Elgar that s coming.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
What, what? The  Pomp and
Circumstance  will not be fine?
subQuotationList: ['What, what?', 'The  Pomp and\nCircumstance  will not be fine?']
speaker: Herr Liesecke

quoteText: Oh, Margaret, you tiresome girl!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Margaret, you tiresome girl!']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Here have I been persuading Herr Liesecke to stop for  Pomp and
Circumstance,  and you are undoing all my work. I am so anxious for him
to hear what WE are doing in music. Oh,--you musn t run down our English
composers, Margaret.
subQuotationList:
['Here have I been persuading Herr Liesecke to stop for  Pomp and
Circumstance,  and you are undoing all my work. I am so anxious for him
to hear what WE are doing in music. Oh,--you musn t run down our English
composers, Margaret.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: For my part, I have heard the composition at Stettin, on two occasions. It is dramatic, a little.
subQuotationList: ['For my part, I have heard the composition at Stettin,', 'on two occasions. It is dramatic, a little.']
speaker: Fraulein Mosebach

quoteText:
Frieda, you despise English music. You know you do. And English art.
And English literature, except Shakespeare, and he s a German. Very
well, Frieda, you may go.
subQuotationList: ['Frieda, you despise English music. You know you do. And English art.\nAnd English literature, except Shakespeare, and he s a German. Very\nwell, Frieda, you may go.']
speaker: Aunt Juley
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fraulein Mosebach'], ['Fraulein Mosebach'], ['Fraulein Mosebach'], ['Fraulein Mosebach'], ['Fraulein Mosebach'], ['Fraulein Mosebach']]]

quoteText: We have this call to pay in Finsbury Circus, it is true,
subQuotationList: ['We have this call to pay in Finsbury Circus, it is true,']
speaker: Herr Liesecke

quoteText: Margaret--
subQuotationList: ['Margaret--']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Margaret, Margaret! Fraulein Mosebach has left her beautiful little bag
behind her on the seat.
subQuotationList: ['Margaret, Margaret! Fraulein Mosebach has left her beautiful little bag\nbehind her on the seat.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Oh, what a bother--what a family we are! Fr--frieda!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, what a bother--what a family we are! Fr--frieda!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But it s the number they want in Finsbury Circus.
subQuotationList: ['But it s the number they want in Finsbury Circus.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Might I--couldn t I--
subQuotationList: ['Might I--couldn t I--']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Oh, I would be so grateful.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I would be so grateful.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
We live quite near; I
am going there now. Could you walk round with me, and we ll find your
umbrella?
subQuotationList: ['We live quite near; I\nam going there now. Could you walk round with me, and we ll find your\numbrella?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Thank you,
subQuotationList: ['Thank you,']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: How tired one gets after music!
subQuotationList: ['How tired one gets after music!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Do you find the atmosphere of Queen s Hall oppressive?
subQuotationList: ['Do you find the atmosphere of Queen s Hall oppressive?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Yes, horribly.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, horribly.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But surely the atmosphere of Covent Garden is even more oppressive.
subQuotationList: ['But surely the atmosphere of Covent Garden is even more oppressive.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Do you go there much?
subQuotationList: ['Do you go there much?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: When my work permits, I attend the gallery for the Royal Opera.
subQuotationList: ['When my work permits, I attend the gallery for the Royal Opera.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: This year I have been three times--to  Faust,   Tosca,  and--
subQuotationList: ['This year I have been three times--to  Faust,   Tosca,  and--']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
I do in a WAY remember the passage, Tibby, but when every instrument is
so beautiful, it is difficult to pick out one thing rather than another.
I am sure that you and Helen take me to the very nicest concerts. Not a
dull note from beginning to end. I only wish that our German friends had
stayed till it finished.
subQuotationList:
['I do in a WAY remember the passage, Tibby, but when every instrument is
so beautiful, it is difficult to pick out one thing rather than another.
I am sure that you and Helen take me to the very nicest concerts. Not a
dull note from beginning to end. I only wish that our German friends had
stayed till it finished.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
But surely you haven t forgotten the drum steadily beating on the low
C, Aunt Juley? No one could. It s unmistakable.
subQuotationList: ['But surely you haven t forgotten the drum steadily beating on the low\nC, Aunt Juley?', 'No one could. It s unmistakable.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
A specially loud part? Of course I do not go
in for being musical, I only care for
music--a very different thing. But still I will say this for myself--I
do know when I like a thing and when I don t. Some people are the same
about pictures. They can go into a picture gallery--Miss Conder can--and
say straight off what they feel, all round the wall. I never could do
that. But music is so different from pictures, to my mind. When it comes
to music I am as safe as houses, and I assure you, Tibby, I am by no
means pleased by everything. There was a thing--something about a faun
in French--which Helen went into ecstasies over, but I thought it most
tinkling and superficial, and said so, and I held to my opinion too.
subQuotationList:
['A specially loud part?', 'Of course I do not go
in for being musical,', 'I only care for
music--a very different thing. But still I will say this for myself--I
do know when I like a thing and when I don t. Some people are the same
about pictures. They can go into a picture gallery--Miss Conder can--and
say straight off what they feel, all round the wall. I never could do
that. But music is so different from pictures, to my mind. When it comes
to music I am as safe as houses, and I assure you, Tibby, I am by no
means pleased by everything. There was a thing--something about a faun
in French--which Helen went into ecstasies over, but I thought it most
tinkling and superficial, and said so, and I held to my opinion too.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Do you agree? Do you think music is so different from
pictures?
subQuotationList: ['Do you agree?', 'Do you think music is so different from\npictures?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I--I should have thought so, kind of,
subQuotationList: ['I--I should have thought so, kind of,']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
So should I. Now, my sister declares they re just the same. We have
great arguments over it. She says I m dense; I say she s sloppy. Now, doesn t it seem absurd to you? What
is the good of the Arts if they re interchangeable? What is the good
of the ear if it tells you the same as the eye? Helen s one aim is to
translate tunes into the language of painting, and pictures into the
language of music. It s very ingenious, and she says several pretty
things in the process, but what s gained, I d like to know? Oh, it s
all rubbish, radically false. If Monet s really Debussy, and Debussy s
really Monet, neither gentleman is worth his salt--that s my opinion. Now, this very symphony that we ve just been having--she won t let it
alone. She labels it with meanings from start to finish; turns it into
literature. I wonder if the day will ever return when music will be
treated as music. Yet I don t know. There s my brother--behind us. He
treats music as music, and oh, my goodness! He makes me angrier than any
one, simply furious. With him I daren t even argue. But, of course, the real villain is Wagner. He has done more than any
man in the nineteenth century towards the muddling of the arts. I
do feel that music is in a very serious state just now, though
extraordinarily interesting. Every now and then in history there do
come these terrible geniuses, like Wagner, who stir up all the wells of
thought at once. For a moment it s splendid. Such a splash as never
was. But afterwards--such a lot of mud; and the wells--as it were, they
communicate with each other too easily now, and not one of them will run
quite clear. That s what Wagner s done.
subQuotationList:
['So should I. Now, my sister declares they re just the same. We have
great arguments over it. She says I m dense; I say she s sloppy.', 'Now, doesn t it seem absurd to you? What

language of music. It s very ingenious, and she says several pretty

really Monet, neither gentleman is worth his salt--that s my opinion.', 'Now, this very symphony that we ve just been having--she won t let it
alone. She labels it with meanings from start to finish; turns it into
literature. I wonder if the day will ever return when music will be
treated as music. Yet I don t know. There s my brother--behind us. He
treats music as music, and oh, my goodness! He makes me angrier than any
one, simply furious. With him I daren t even argue.', 'But, of course, the real villain is Wagner. He has done more than any
man in the nineteenth century towards the muddling of the arts. I
do feel that music is in a very serious state just now, though
extraordinarily interesting. Every now and then in history there do
come these terrible geniuses, like Wagner, who stir up all the wells of
thought at once. For a moment it s splendid. Such a splash as never
was. But afterwards--such a lot of mud; and the wells--as it were, they
communicate with each other too easily now, and not one of them will run
quite clear. That s what Wagner s done.']

quoteText:
I suppose my
umbrella will be all right, I don t really mind about
it. I will think about music instead. I suppose my umbrella will be all
right.
subQuotationList:
['I suppose my
umbrella will be all right,', 'I don t really mind about
it. I will think about music instead. I suppose my umbrella will be all
right.']

quoteText: Shall I try to do without a programme?
subQuotationList: ['Shall I try to do without a programme?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Don t you think so? don t
you feel the same?
subQuotationList: ['Don t you think so? don t\nyou feel the same?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Oh, do interrupt
me!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, do interrupt\nme!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I do hope that
you ll come in and have some tea. We should be so glad. I have dragged
you so far out of your way.
subQuotationList: ['I do hope that\nyou ll come in and have some tea. We should be so glad. I have dragged\nyou so far out of your way.']

quoteText: Helen! Let us in!

speaker: Margaret

quoteText: All right,
subQuotationList: ['All right,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: You ve been taking this gentleman s umbrella.
subQuotationList: ['You ve been taking this gentleman s umbrella.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Taken a what? Oh, what s that? Do come
in! How do you do?
subQuotationList: ['Taken a what?', 'Oh, what s that? Do come\nin! How do you do?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Helen, you must not be so ramshackly. You took this gentleman s
umbrella away from Queen s Hall, and he has had the trouble of coming
round for it.
subQuotationList: ['Helen, you must not be so ramshackly. You took this gentleman s\numbrella away from Queen s Hall, and he has had the trouble of coming\nround for it.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Oh, I am so sorry! I do nothing but steal umbrellas. I am so very
sorry! Do come in and choose one. Is yours a hooky or a nobbly? Mine s a
nobbly--at least, I THINK it is.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I am so sorry!', 'I do nothing but steal umbrellas. I am so very\nsorry! Do come in and choose one. Is yours a hooky or a nobbly? Mine s a\nnobbly--at least, I THINK it is.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Don t you talk, Meg! You stole an old gentleman s silk top-hat. Yes,
she did, Aunt Juley. It is a positive fact. She thought it was a muff.
Oh, heavens! I ve knocked the In-and-Out card down. Where s Frieda?
Tibby, why don t you ever--No, I can t remember what I was going to say.
That wasn t it, but do tell the maids to hurry tea up. What about this
umbrella?
subQuotationList:
['Don t you talk, Meg! You stole an old gentleman s silk top-hat. Yes,
she did, Aunt Juley. It is a positive fact. She thought it was a muff.
Oh, heavens! I ve knocked the In-and-Out card down. Where s Frieda?
Tibby, why don t you ever--No, I can t remember what I was going to say.
That wasn t it, but do tell the maids to hurry tea up. What about this
umbrella?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
No, it s all gone along the seams. It s an
appalling umbrella. It must be mine.
subQuotationList: ['No, it s all gone along the seams. It s an\nappalling umbrella. It must be mine.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
But if you will stop-- Now, Helen, how stupid you ve
been!
subQuotationList: ['But if you will stop--', 'Now, Helen, how stupid you ve\nbeen!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Whatever have I done?
subQuotationList: ['Whatever have I done?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Don t you see that you ve frightened him away? I meant him to stop to
tea. You oughtn t to talk about stealing or holes in an umbrella. I saw
his nice eyes getting so miserable. No, it s not a bit of good now.
subQuotationList: ['Don t you see that you ve frightened him away? I meant him to stop to\ntea. You oughtn t to talk about stealing or holes in an umbrella. I saw\nhis nice eyes getting so miserable. No, it s not a bit of good now.']

referringExpression: Helen had darted out into the street shouting

quoteText:
I dare say it is all for the best, We know nothing
about the young man, Margaret, and your drawing-room is full of very
tempting little things.
subQuotationList: ['I dare say it is all for the best,', 'We know nothing\nabout the young man, Margaret, and your drawing-room is full of very\ntempting little things.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Aunt Juley, how can you! You make me more and more
ashamed. I d rather he had been a thief and taken all the apostle spoons
than that I--Well, I must shut the front-door, I suppose. One more
failure for Helen.
subQuotationList:
['Aunt Juley, how can you! You make me more and more
ashamed. I d rather he had been a thief and taken all the apostle spoons
than that I--Well, I must shut the front-door, I suppose. One more
failure for Helen.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Yes, I think the apostle spoons could have gone as rent, You
remember  rent ? It was one of father s words--Rent to the ideal, to his
own faith in human nature. You remember how he would trust strangers,
and if they fooled him he would say,  It s better to be fooled than to
be suspicious --that the confidence trick is the work of man, but the
want-of-confidence trick is the work of the devil.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, I think the apostle spoons could have gone as rent,', 'You
remember  rent ? It was one of father s words--Rent to the ideal, to his
own faith in human nature. You remember how he would trust strangers,
and if they fooled him he would say,  It s better to be fooled than to
be suspicious --that the confidence trick is the work of man, but the
want-of-confidence trick is the work of the devil.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I remember something of the sort now,
subQuotationList: ['I remember something of the sort now,']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
It was lucky that your father married a wife
with money.
subQuotationList: ['It was lucky that your father married a wife\nwith money.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Why,
he might have stolen the little Ricketts picture as well.
subQuotationList: ['Why,\nhe might have stolen the little Ricketts picture as well.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Better that he had,
subQuotationList: ['Better that he had,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
No, I agree with Aunt Juley, I d rather mistrust
people than lose my little Ricketts. There are limits.
subQuotationList: ['No, I agree with Aunt Juley,', 'I d rather mistrust\npeople than lose my little Ricketts. There are limits.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: All right, Auntie Tibby,
subQuotationList: ['All right, Auntie Tibby,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
In a way, I wish we had a real boy in the house--the kind
of boy who cares for men. It would make entertaining so much easier.
subQuotationList: ['In a way, I wish we had a real boy in the house--the kind\nof boy who cares for men. It would make entertaining so much easier.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
So do I, Tibby only cares for cultured females
singing Brahms.
subQuotationList: ['So do I,', 'Tibby only cares for cultured females\nsinging Brahms.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Why
didn t you make that young man welcome, Tibby? You must do the host a
little, you know. You ought to have taken his hat and coaxed him into
stopping, instead of letting him be swamped by screaming women.
subQuotationList:
['Why
didn t you make that young man welcome, Tibby? You must do the host a
little, you know. You ought to have taken his hat and coaxed him into
stopping, instead of letting him be swamped by screaming women.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Oh, it s no good looking superior. I mean what I say.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, it s no good looking superior. I mean what I say.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: Leave Tibby alone!
subQuotationList: ['Leave Tibby alone!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Here s the house a regular hen-coop!
subQuotationList: ['Here s the house a regular hen-coop!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Oh, my dear! How can you say such dreadful
things! The number of men you get here has always astonished me. If
there is any danger it s the other way round.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, my dear!', 'How can you say such dreadful\nthings! The number of men you get here has always astonished me. If\nthere is any danger it s the other way round.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Yes, but it s the wrong sort of men, Helen means.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, but it s the wrong sort of men, Helen means.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
No, I don t, We get the right sort of man, but the
wrong side of him, and I say that s Tibby s fault. There ought to be a
something about the house--an--I don t know what.
subQuotationList: ['No, I don t,', 'We get the right sort of man, but the\nwrong side of him, and I say that s Tibby s fault. There ought to be a\nsomething about the house--an--I don t know what.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: A touch of the W s, perhaps?
subQuotationList: ['A touch of the W s, perhaps?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Who are the W s?
subQuotationList: ['Who are the W s?']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
The W s are things I and Meg and Aunt Juley know about and you don t,
so there!
subQuotationList: ['The W s are things I and Meg and Aunt Juley know about and you don t,\nso there!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I suppose that ours is a female house, and one must
just accept it. No, Aunt Juley, I don t mean that this house is full of
women. I am trying to say something much more clever. I mean that it
was irrevocably feminine, even in father s time. Now I m sure you
understand! Well, I ll give you another example. It ll shock you, but
I don t care. Suppose Queen Victoria gave a dinner-party, and that
the guests had been Leighton, Millais, Swinburne, Rossetti, Meredith,
Fitzgerald, etc. Do you suppose that the atmosphere of that dinner would
have been artistic? Heavens, no! The very chairs on which they sat would
have seen to that. So with our house--it must be feminine, and all we
can do is to see that it isn t effeminate. Just as another house that
I can mention, but won t, sounded irrevocably masculine, and all its
inmates can do is to see that it isn t brutal.

['I suppose that ours is a female house,', 'and one must

don t you think it. And on the other hand, I don t the least mind if

case. Give me a cigarette.

reeks of smoke.

speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
If you smoked too, the house might suddenly turn masculine. Atmosphere
is probably a question of touch and go. Even at Queen Victoria s
dinner-party--if something had been just a little Different--perhaps if
she d worn a clinging Liberty tea-gown instead of a magenta satin.
subQuotationList:
['If you smoked too, the house might suddenly turn masculine. Atmosphere

subQuotationList: ['How\ninconceivable it would be if the Royal Family cared about Art.']

firmly set in the wall. I am really distressed that he had no tea.

quoteText:
I can t have you ask me that again, I ve promised to marry you when I m of age, and that s
enough. My word s my word. I ve promised to marry you as soon as ever
I m twenty-one, and I can t keep on being worried. I ve worries enough.
It isn t likely I d throw you over, let alone my word, when I ve spent
all this money. Besides, I m an Englishman, and I never go back on my
word. Jacky, do be reasonable. Of course I ll marry you. Only do stop
badgering me.
subQuotationList:
['I can t have you ask me that again,', 'I ve promised to marry you when I m of age, and that s
enough. My word s my word. I ve promised to marry you as soon as ever
I m twenty-one, and I can t keep on being worried. I ve worries enough.

all this money. Besides, I m an Englishman, and I never go back on my
word. Jacky, do be reasonable. Of course I ll marry you. Only do stop

speaker: Leonard

quoteText: When s your birthday, Len?
subQuotationList: ['When s your birthday, Len?']
speaker: Mrs. Bast

quoteText:
I ve told you again and again, the eleventh of November next. Now get
off my knee a bit; some one must get supper, I suppose.
subQuotationList: ['I ve told you again and again, the eleventh of November next. Now get\noff my knee a bit; some one must get supper, I suppose.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
It really is too bad when a fellow isn t trusted. It makes one feel so
wild, when I ve pretended to the people here that you re my wife--all
right, all right, you SHALL be my wife--and I ve bought you the ring to
wear, and I ve taken this flat furnished, and it s far more than I can
afford, and yet you aren t content, and I ve also not told the truth
when I ve written home. He d stop it. My brother d stop
it. I m going against the whole world, Jacky. That s what I am, Jacky. I don t take any heed of what any one says. I
just go straight forward, I do. That s always been my way. I m not one
of your weak knock-kneed chaps. If a woman s in trouble, I don t leave
her in the lurch. That s not my street. No, thank you. I ll tell you another thing too. I care a good deal about improving
myself by means of Literature and Art, and so getting a wider outlook.
For instance, when you came in I was reading Ruskin s Stones of Venice.
I don t say this to boast, but just to show you the kind of man I am. I
can tell you, I enjoyed that classical concert this afternoon.

quoteText:
Oh, Margaret, such a most unfortunate
thing has happened. I could not get you alone.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Margaret,', 'such a most unfortunate\nthing has happened. I could not get you alone.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: coming up, no doubt, in the hope of getting into London society.
subQuotationList: ['coming up, no doubt, in the hope of getting into London society.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
What! a hundred
and twenty for a basement? You ll never get it!
subQuotationList: ['What! a hundred\nand twenty for a basement? You ll never get it!']
speaker: Aunt Juley
referringExpression: She would stroll across and make friends with the porters and inquire what the rents were exclaiming

quoteText:
Oh, but Helen isn t a girl with no interests, She has
plenty of other things and other people to think about. She made a false
start with the Wilcoxes, and she ll be as willing as we are to have
nothing more to do with them.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, but Helen isn t a girl with no interests,', 'She has
plenty of other things and other people to think about. She made a false
start with the Wilcoxes, and she ll be as willing as we are to have
nothing more to do with them.']
speaker: Margaret
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Helen']], [['Helen'], ['Helen'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Helen'], ['Aunt Juley', 'Margaret'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox']]]

quoteText:
For a clever girl, dear, how very oddly you do talk. Helen ll HAVE to
have something more to do with them, now that they re all opposite. She
may meet that Paul in the street. She cannot very well not bow.
subQuotationList: ['For a clever girl, dear, how very oddly you do talk. Helen ll HAVE to\nhave something more to do with them, now that they re all opposite. She\nmay meet that Paul in the street. She cannot very well not bow.']
speaker: Aunt Juley
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Margaret'], ['Margaret'], ['Helen'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Helen'], ['Paul'], ['Helen']]]

quoteText:
Of course she must bow. But look here; let s do the flowers. I was
going to say, the will to be interested in him has died, and what else
matters? I look on that disastrous episode (over which you were so
kind) as the killing of a nerve in Helen. It s dead, and she ll never be
troubled with it again. The only things that matter are the things
that interest one. Bowing, even calling and leaving cards, even a
dinner-party--we can do all those things to the Wilcoxes, if they find
it agreeable; but the other thing, the one important thing--never again.
Don t you see?
subQuotationList:
['Of course she must bow. But look here; let s do the flowers. I was
going to say, the will to be interested in him has died, and what else
matters? I look on that disastrous episode (over which you were so
kind) as the killing of a nerve in Helen. It s dead, and she ll never be
troubled with it again. The only things that matter are the things
that interest one. Bowing, even calling and leaving cards, even a
dinner-party--we can do all those things to the Wilcoxes, if they find
it agreeable; but the other thing, the one important thing--never again.
Don t you see?']
speaker: Margaret
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Helen'], ['Aunt Juley', 'Margaret'], ['Paul'], ['Aunt Juley'], ['Helen'], ['Helen'], ['Aunt Juley', 'Tibby', 'Margaret', 'Helen'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Aunt Juley']]]

quoteText:
I also have the honour to inform you that the Wilcoxes are bored with
us. I didn t tell you at the time--it might have made you angry, and you
had enough to worry you--but I wrote a letter to Mrs. W, and apologised
for the trouble that Helen had given them. She didn t answer it.
subQuotationList:
['I also have the honour to inform you that the Wilcoxes are bored with
us. I didn t tell you at the time--it might have made you angry, and you
had enough to worry you--but I wrote a letter to Mrs. W, and apologised
for the trouble that Helen had given them. She didn t answer it.']
speaker: Margaret

speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: I wonder. Or was it sensible?

speaker: Margaret

quoteText: No, Margaret, most rude.
subQuotationList: ['No, Margaret, most rude.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

subQuotationList: ['In either case one can class it as reassuring.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But you will be careful, won t you?
subQuotationList: ['But you will be careful, won t you?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Oh, certainly. Fiendishly careful.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, certainly. Fiendishly careful.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: And Helen must be careful, too.
subQuotationList: ['And Helen must be careful, too.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Careful over what?
subQuotationList: ['Careful over what?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Nothing
subQuotationList: ['Nothing']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Careful over what, Aunt Juley?
subQuotationList: ['Careful over what, Aunt Juley?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
It is only that a certain family,
whom we know by name but do not mention, as you said yourself last
night after the concert, have taken the flat opposite from the
Mathesons--where the plants are in the balcony.
subQuotationList:
['It is only that a certain family,
whom we know by name but do not mention, as you said yourself last
night after the concert, have taken the flat opposite from the

speaker: Aunt Juley

What,
Helen, you don t mind them coming, do you?
subQuotationList: ['What,\nHelen, you don t mind them coming, do you?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Of course I don t mind, It is that you
and Meg are both so absurdly grave about it, when there s nothing to be
grave about at all.
subQuotationList: ['Of course I don t mind,', 'It is that you\nand Meg are both so absurdly grave about it, when there s nothing to be\ngrave about at all.']
speaker: Helen

speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Well, you look grave; doesn t she, Frieda?
subQuotationList: ['Well, you look grave; doesn t she, Frieda?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I don t feel grave, that s all I can say; you re going quite on the
wrong tack.
subQuotationList: ['I don t feel grave, that s all I can say; you re going quite on the\nwrong tack.']

quoteText:
No, she does not feel grave, I can bear witness to
that. She disagrees--
subQuotationList: ['No, she does not feel grave,', 'I can bear witness to\nthat. She disagrees--']

quoteText:
Did you say the Mathesons  flat, Aunt Juley? How wonderful you are!
I never knew that the name of the woman who laced too tightly was
Matheson.

quoteText: Helen cannot deceive me. She does mind.

speaker: Aunt Juley
