quoteText:
Oh, hush! Frieda ll hear you, and she can be so
tiresome.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, hush!', 'Frieda ll hear you, and she can be so\ntiresome.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
She minds, I knew she d
mind--and I m sure a girl ought to! Such an experience! Such awful
coarse-grained people! I know more about them than you do, which you
forget, and if Charles had taken you that motor drive--well, you d have
reached the house a perfect wreck. Oh, Margaret, you don t know what
you are in for! They re all bottled up against the drawing-room window.
There s Mrs. Wilcox--I ve seen her. There s Paul. There s Evie, who is a
minx. There s Charles--I saw him to start with. And who would an elderly
man with a moustache and a copper-coloured face be?
subQuotationList:
['She minds,', 'I knew she d
mind--and I m sure a girl ought to! Such an experience! Such awful

There s Mrs. Wilcox--I ve seen her. There s Paul. There s Evie, who is a
minx. There s Charles--I saw him to start with. And who would an elderly
man with a moustache and a copper-coloured face be?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Mr. Wilcox, possibly.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Wilcox, possibly.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I knew it. And there s Mr. Wilcox.
subQuotationList: ['I knew it. And there s Mr. Wilcox.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
It s a shame to call his face copper colour, He
has a remarkably good complexion for a man of his age.
subQuotationList: ['It s a shame to call his face copper colour,', 'He\nhas a remarkably good complexion for a man of his age.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Helen did not take the news quite as I expected, but the Wilcox nerve
is dead in her really, so there s no need for plans.
subQuotationList: ['Helen did not take the news quite as I expected, but the Wilcox nerve\nis dead in her really, so there s no need for plans.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It s as well to be prepared.
subQuotationList: ['It s as well to be prepared.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: No--it s as well not to be prepared.
subQuotationList: ['No--it s as well not to be prepared.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Why?
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Because--
subQuotationList: ['Because--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Because I d
sooner risk it,
subQuotationList: ['Because I d\nsooner risk it,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
But imagine the evenings, Turn the electric light on here
or there, and it s almost the same room. One evening they may forget to
draw their blinds down, and you ll see them; and the next, you yours,
and they ll see you. Impossible to sit out on the balconies. Impossible
to water the plants, or even speak. Imagine going out of the front-door,
and they come out opposite at the same moment. And yet you tell me that
plans are unnecessary, and you d rather risk it.
subQuotationList:
['But imagine the evenings,', 'Turn the electric light on here
or there, and it s almost the same room. One evening they may forget to

and they ll see you. Impossible to sit out on the balconies. Impossible

quoteText: I hope to risk things all my life.
subQuotationList: ['I hope to risk things all my life.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, Margaret, most dangerous.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Margaret, most dangerous.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
But after all, there s never any great
risk as long as you have money.
subQuotationList: ['But after all,', 'there s never any great\nrisk as long as you have money.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, shame! What a shocking speech!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, shame! What a shocking speech!']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Money pads the edges of things, God help those
who have none.
subQuotationList: ['Money pads the edges of things,', 'God help those\nwho have none.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But this is something quite new!
subQuotationList: ['But this is something quite new!']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
New for me; sensible people have acknowledged it for years. You and I
and the Wilcoxes stand upon money as upon islands. It is so firm beneath
our feet that we forget its very existence. It s only when we see some
one near us tottering that we realise all that an independent income
means. Last night, when we were talking up here round the fire, I began
to think that the very soul of the world is economic, and that the
lowest abyss is not the absence of love, but the absence of coin.
subQuotationList:
['New for me; sensible people have acknowledged it for years. You and I
and the Wilcoxes stand upon money as upon islands. It is so firm beneath
our feet that we forget its very existence. It s only when we see some
one near us tottering that we realise all that an independent income
means. Last night, when we were talking up here round the fire, I began
to think that the very soul of the world is economic, and that the
lowest abyss is not the absence of love, but the absence of coin.']
speaker: Margaret
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Aunt Juley'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Margaret'], ['Margaret', 'Aunt Juley', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Paul', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Mr. Wilcox', 'Evie'], ['Margaret', 'Aunt Juley'], ['Margaret', 'Aunt Juley'], ['Margaret', 'Aunt Juley'], ['Margaret', 'Aunt Juley']]]

quoteText: I call that rather cynical.
subQuotationList: ['I call that rather cynical.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
So do I. But Helen and I, we ought to remember, when we are tempted to
criticise others, that we are standing on these islands, and that most
of the others are down below the surface of the sea. The poor cannot
always reach those whom they want to love, and they can hardly ever
escape from those whom they love no longer. We rich can. Imagine the
tragedy last June, if Helen and Paul Wilcox had been poor people, and
couldn t invoke railways and motor-cars to part them.
subQuotationList:
['So do I. But Helen and I, we ought to remember, when we are tempted to
criticise others, that we are standing on these islands, and that most
of the others are down below the surface of the sea. The poor cannot
always reach those whom they want to love, and they can hardly ever
escape from those whom they love no longer. We rich can. Imagine the
tragedy last June, if Helen and Paul Wilcox had been poor people, and
couldn t invoke railways and motor-cars to part them.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: That s more like Socialism,
subQuotationList: ['That s more like Socialism,']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Call it what you like. I call it going through life with one s hand
spread open on the table. I m tired of these rich people who pretend
to be poor, and think it shows a nice mind to ignore the piles of money
that keep their feet above the waves. I stand each year upon six hundred
pounds, and Helen upon the same, and Tibby will stand upon eight, and as
fast as our pounds crumble away into the sea they are renewed--from
the sea, yes, from the sea. And all our thoughts are the thoughts of
six-hundred-pounders, and all our speeches; and because we don t want to
steal umbrellas ourselves, we forget that below the sea people do want
to steal them and do steal them sometimes, and that what s a joke up
here is down there reality.
subQuotationList:
['Call it what you like. I call it going through life with one s hand
spread open on the table. I m tired of these rich people who pretend
to be poor, and think it shows a nice mind to ignore the piles of money
that keep their feet above the waves. I stand each year upon six hundred
pounds, and Helen upon the same, and Tibby will stand upon eight, and as
fast as our pounds crumble away into the sea they are renewed--from
the sea, yes, from the sea. And all our thoughts are the thoughts of
six-hundred-pounders, and all our speeches; and because we don t want to
steal umbrellas ourselves, we forget that below the sea people do want
to steal them and do steal them sometimes, and that what s a joke up
here is down there reality.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
There they go--there goes Fraulein Mosebach. Really, for a German she
does dress charmingly. Oh!--
subQuotationList: ['There they go--there goes Fraulein Mosebach. Really, for a German she\ndoes dress charmingly. Oh!--']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: What is it?
subQuotationList: ['What is it?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Helen was looking up at the Wilcoxes  flat.

speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Why shouldn t she?

speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I beg your pardon, I interrupted you. What was it you were saying about

subQuotationList: ['I beg your pardon, I interrupted you. What was it you were saying about\nreality?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: I had worked round to myself, as usual,
subQuotationList: ['I had worked round to myself, as usual,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Do tell me this, at all events. Are you for the rich or for the poor?
subQuotationList: ['Do tell me this, at all events. Are you for the rich or for the poor?']

quoteText:
Too difficult. Ask me another. Am I for poverty or for riches? For
riches. Hurrah for riches!
subQuotationList: ['Too difficult. Ask me another. Am I for poverty or for riches? For\nriches. Hurrah for riches!']

quoteText: For riches!

quoteText: Yes. For riches. Money for ever!

quoteText:
So am I, and so, I am afraid, are most of my acquaintances at Swanage,
but I am surprised that you agree with us.

quoteText:
Thank you so much, Aunt Juley. While I have talked theories, you have
done the flowers.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you so much, Aunt Juley. While I have talked theories, you have\ndone the flowers.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Not at all, dear. I wish you would let me help you in more important
things.

registry office? There s a housemaid who won t say yes but doesn t say
no.

quoteText: Really?

quoteText: Really.

I shan t mind if Paul points at our house and

subQuotationList: ['I shan t mind if Paul points at our house and\nsays,  There lives the girl who tried to catch me.  But she might.']
speaker: Helen
mentionTextsList: [['Paul', 'our', 'the girl who tried to catch me', 'she']]

quoteText:
If even that worries you, we could arrange something. There s no reason
we should be near people who displease us or whom we displease, thanks
to our money. We might even go away for a little.
subQuotationList: ['If even that worries you, we could arrange something. There s no reason\nwe should be near people who displease us or whom we displease, thanks\nto our money. We might even go away for a little.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Well, I am going away. Frieda s just asked me to Stettin, and I shan t
be back till after the New Year. Will that do? Or must I fly the country
altogether? Really, Meg, what has come over you to make such a fuss?
subQuotationList: ['Well, I am going away. Frieda s just asked me to Stettin, and I shan t\nbe back till after the New Year. Will that do? Or must I fly the country\naltogether? Really, Meg, what has come over you to make such a fuss?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Oh, I m getting an old maid, I suppose. I thought I minded nothing, but
really I--I should be bored if you fell in love with the same man twice
and
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I m getting an old maid, I suppose. I thought I minded nothing, but\nreally I--I should be bored if you fell in love with the same man twice\nand']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
you did go red, you know, when Aunt Juley
attacked you this morning. I shouldn t have referred to it otherwise.
subQuotationList: ['you did go red, you know, when Aunt Juley\nattacked you this morning. I shouldn t have referred to it otherwise.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Helen! his mother has forgiven you!
subQuotationList: ['Helen!', 'his mother has forgiven you!']
speaker: Fraulein Mosebach

quoteText:
Bother the whole family! Helen, stop giggling and
pirouetting, and go and finish your packing. Why can t the woman leave
us alone?
subQuotationList: ['Bother the whole family!', 'Helen, stop giggling and\npirouetting, and go and finish your packing. Why can t the woman leave\nus alone?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I don t know what I shall do with Meg, She s got Wilcox and Box upon the brain. Meg, Meg, I don t
love the young gentleman; I don t love the young gentleman, Meg, Meg.
Can a body speak plainer?
subQuotationList: ['I don t know what I shall do with Meg,', 'She s got Wilcox and Box upon the brain. Meg, Meg, I don t\nlove the young gentleman; I don t love the young gentleman, Meg, Meg.\nCan a body speak plainer?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Most certainly her love has died,
subQuotationList: ['Most certainly her love has died,']
speaker: Fraulein Mosebach

quoteText:
Most certainly it has, Frieda, but that will not prevent me from being
bored with the Wilcoxes if I return the call.
subQuotationList: ['Most certainly it has, Frieda, but that will not prevent me from being\nbored with the Wilcoxes if I return the call.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Oh, boo hoo! boo hoo hoo! Meg s
going to return the call, and I can t.  Cos why?  Cos I m going to
German-eye.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, boo hoo! boo hoo hoo! Meg s\ngoing to return the call, and I can t.  Cos why?  Cos I m going to\nGerman-eye.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
If you are going to Germany, go and pack; if you aren t, go and call on
the Wilcoxes instead of me.
subQuotationList: ['If you are going to Germany, go and pack; if you aren t, go and call on\nthe Wilcoxes instead of me.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
But, Meg, Meg, I don t love the young gentleman; I don t love the
young--O lud, who s that coming down the stairs? I vow  tis my brother.
O crimini!
subQuotationList: ['But, Meg, Meg, I don t love the young gentleman; I don t love the\nyoung--O lud, who s that coming down the stairs? I vow  tis my brother.\nO crimini!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
It is all right--she does not love the young
man--he has not been worthy of her.
subQuotationList: ['It is all right--she does not love the young\nman--he has not been worthy of her.']
speaker: Fraulein Mosebach
referringExpression: Fraulein Mosebach followed her but lingered to say heavily over the banisters to Margaret

quoteText: Yes, I know; thanks very much.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I know; thanks very much.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I thought I did right to tell you.
subQuotationList: ['I thought I did right to tell you.']
speaker: Fraulein Mosebach

quoteText: Ever so many thanks.
subQuotationList: ['Ever so many thanks.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What s that?
subQuotationList: ['What s that?']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
Oh, Mrs. Wilcox, I have made the baddest blunder. I am more, more
ashamed and sorry than I can say.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Mrs. Wilcox, I have made the baddest blunder. I am more, more\nashamed and sorry than I can say.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I knew he was going to India in November, but I forgot.
subQuotationList: ['I knew he was going to India in November, but I forgot.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: He sailed on the 17th for Nigeria, in Africa.
subQuotationList: ['He sailed on the 17th for Nigeria, in Africa.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
I knew--I know. I have been too absurd all through. I am very much
ashamed.
subQuotationList: ['I knew--I know. I have been too absurd all through. I am very much\nashamed.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I am more sorry than I can say, and I hope that you will forgive me.
subQuotationList: ['I am more sorry than I can say, and I hope that you will forgive me.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
It doesn t matter, Miss Schlegel. It is good of you to have come round
so promptly.
subQuotationList: ['It doesn t matter, Miss Schlegel. It is good of you to have come round\nso promptly.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
It does matter, I have been rude to you; and my
sister is not even at home, so there was not even that excuse.
subQuotationList: ['It does matter,', 'I have been rude to you; and my\nsister is not even at home, so there was not even that excuse.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Indeed?
subQuotationList: ['Indeed?']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: She has just gone to Germany.
subQuotationList: ['She has just gone to Germany.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
She gone as well, Yes, certainly, it is quite
safe--safe, absolutely, now.
subQuotationList: ['She gone as well,', 'Yes, certainly, it is quite\nsafe--safe, absolutely, now.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
You ve been worrying too! How perfectly
extraordinary! I can see that you have. You felt as I do; Helen mustn t
meet him again.
subQuotationList: ['You ve been worrying too!', 'How perfectly\nextraordinary! I can see that you have. You felt as I do; Helen mustn t\nmeet him again.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I did think it best.
subQuotationList: ['I did think it best.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Now why?
subQuotationList: ['Now why?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
That s a most difficult question, I think you put it best in
your letter--it was an instinct, which may be wrong.
subQuotationList: ['That s a most difficult question,', 'I think you put it best in\nyour letter--it was an instinct, which may be wrong.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: It wasn t that your son still--
subQuotationList: ['It wasn t that your son still--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh no; he often--my Paul is very young, you see.
subQuotationList: ['Oh no; he often--my Paul is very young, you see.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Then what was it?
subQuotationList: ['Then what was it?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: An instinct which may be wrong.
subQuotationList: ['An instinct which may be wrong.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
In other words, they belong to types that can fall in love, but
couldn t live together. That s dreadfully probable. I m afraid that in
nine cases out of ten Nature pulls one way and human nature another.
subQuotationList: ['In other words, they belong to types that can fall in love, but\ncouldn t live together. That s dreadfully probable. I m afraid that in\nnine cases out of ten Nature pulls one way and human nature another.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
These are indeed  other words, I had nothing so
coherent in my head. I was merely alarmed when I knew that my boy cared
for your sister.
subQuotationList: ['These are indeed  other words,', 'I had nothing so\ncoherent in my head. I was merely alarmed when I knew that my boy cared\nfor your sister.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
Ah, I have always been wanting to ask you. How DID you know? Helen
was so surprised when our aunt drove up, and you stepped forward and
arranged things. Did Paul tell you?
subQuotationList: ['Ah, I have always been wanting to ask you. How DID you know? Helen\nwas so surprised when our aunt drove up, and you stepped forward and\narranged things. Did Paul tell you?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: There is nothing to be gained by discussing that,
subQuotationList: ['There is nothing to be gained by discussing that,']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
Mrs. Wilcox, were you very angry with us last June? I wrote you a
letter and you didn t answer it.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Wilcox, were you very angry with us last June? I wrote you a\nletter and you didn t answer it.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I was certainly against taking Mrs. Matheson s flat. I knew it was
opposite your house.
subQuotationList: ['I was certainly against taking Mrs. Matheson s flat. I knew it was\nopposite your house.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: But it s all right now?
subQuotationList: ['But it s all right now?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I think so.
subQuotationList: ['I think so.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
You only think? You aren t sure? I do love these little muddles tidied
up?
subQuotationList: ['You only think? You aren t sure? I do love these little muddles tidied\nup?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Oh yes, I m sure, I always sound uncertain over things. It is my way of
speaking.
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes, I m sure,', 'I always sound uncertain over things. It is my way of\nspeaking.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: That s all right, and I m sure, too.
subQuotationList: ['That s all right, and I m sure, too.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I must say good-bye now--you will be getting up.
subQuotationList: ['I must say good-bye now--you will be getting up.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
No--please stop a little longer--I am taking a day in bed. Now and then
I do.
subQuotationList: ['No--please stop a little longer--I am taking a day in bed. Now and then\nI do.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: I thought of you as one of the early risers.
subQuotationList: ['I thought of you as one of the early risers.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: At Howards End--yes; there is nothing to get up for in London.
subQuotationList: ['At Howards End--yes; there is nothing to get up for in London.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
Nothing to get up for? When there are
all the autumn exhibitions, and Ysaye playing in the afternoon! Not to
mention people.
subQuotationList: ['Nothing to get up for?', 'When there are\nall the autumn exhibitions, and Ysaye playing in the afternoon! Not to\nmention people.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
The truth is, I am a little tired. First came the wedding, and then
Paul went off, and, instead of resting yesterday, I paid a round of
calls.
subQuotationList: ['The truth is, I am a little tired. First came the wedding, and then\nPaul went off, and, instead of resting yesterday, I paid a round of\ncalls.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: A wedding?
subQuotationList: ['A wedding?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes; Charles, my elder son, is married.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; Charles, my elder son, is married.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Indeed!
subQuotationList: ['Indeed!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
We took the flat chiefly on that account, and also that Paul could get
his African outfit. The flat belongs to a cousin of my husband s, and
she most kindly offered it to us. So before the day came we were able to
make the acquaintance of Dolly s people, which we had not yet done.
subQuotationList:
['We took the flat chiefly on that account, and also that Paul could get
his African outfit. The flat belongs to a cousin of my husband s, and
she most kindly offered it to us. So before the day came we were able to
make the acquaintance of Dolly s people, which we had not yet done.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Paul'], ['Paul'], ['Mr. Wilcox'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Dolly'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox']]]

quoteText:
Fussell. The father is in the Indian army--retired; the brother is in
the army. The mother is dead.
subQuotationList: ['Fussell. The father is in the Indian army--retired; the brother is in\nthe army. The mother is dead.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
Charles and Albert Fussell have known one another some time. They
belong to the same club, and are both devoted to golf. Dolly plays
golf too, though I believe not so well; and they first met in a mixed
foursome. We all like her, and are very much pleased. They were married
on the 11th, a few days before Paul sailed. Charles was very anxious to
have his brother as best man, so he made a great point of having it on
the 11th. The Fussells would have preferred it after Christmas, but they
were very nice about it. There is Dolly s photograph--in that double
frame.
subQuotationList:
['Charles and Albert Fussell have known one another some time. They
belong to the same club, and are both devoted to golf. Dolly plays
golf too, though I believe not so well; and they first met in a mixed
foursome. We all like her, and are very much pleased. They were married
on the 11th, a few days before Paul sailed. Charles was very anxious to
have his brother as best man, so he made a great point of having it on
the 11th. The Fussells would have preferred it after Christmas, but they
were very nice about it. There is Dolly s photograph--in that double
frame.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Charles Wilcox'], ['Dolly'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Paul', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Dolly'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Paul'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Paul'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Dolly']]]

quoteText: Are you quite certain that I m not interrupting, Mrs. Wilcox?
subQuotationList: ['Are you quite certain that I m not interrupting, Mrs. Wilcox?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes, quite.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, quite.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Then I will stay. I m enjoying this.
subQuotationList: ['Then I will stay. I m enjoying this.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: They have gone to Naples for their honeymoon.
subQuotationList: ['They have gone to Naples for their honeymoon.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Lucky people!
subQuotationList: ['Lucky people!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I can hardly imagine Charles in Italy.
subQuotationList: ['I can hardly imagine Charles in Italy.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Doesn t he care for travelling?
subQuotationList: ['Doesn t he care for travelling?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
He likes travel, but he does see through foreigners so. What he enjoys
most is a motor tour in England, and I think that would have carried the
day if the weather had not been so abominable. His father gave him a car
for a wedding present, which for the present is being stored at Howards
End.
subQuotationList:
['He likes travel, but he does see through foreigners so. What he enjoys
most is a motor tour in England, and I think that would have carried the
day if the weather had not been so abominable. His father gave him a car
for a wedding present, which for the present is being stored at Howards
End.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: I suppose you have a garage there?
subQuotationList: ['I suppose you have a garage there?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Yes. My husband built a little one only last month, to the west of the
house, not far from the wych-elm, in what used to be the paddock for the
pony.
subQuotationList: ['Yes. My husband built a little one only last month, to the west of the\nhouse, not far from the wych-elm, in what used to be the paddock for the\npony.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Where s the pony gone?
subQuotationList: ['Where s the pony gone?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: The pony? Oh, dead, ever so long ago.
subQuotationList: ['The pony? Oh, dead, ever so long ago.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: The wych-elm I remember. Helen spoke of it as a very splendid tree.
subQuotationList: ['The wych-elm I remember. Helen spoke of it as a very splendid tree.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
It is the finest wych-elm in Hertfordshire. Did your sister tell you
about the teeth?
subQuotationList: ['It is the finest wych-elm in Hertfordshire. Did your sister tell you\nabout the teeth?']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: No.
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Oh, it might interest you. There are pigs  teeth stuck into the trunk,
about four feet from the ground. The country people put them in long
ago, and they think that if they chew a piece of the bark, it will cure
the toothache. The teeth are almost grown over now, and no one comes to
the tree.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, it might interest you. There are pigs  teeth stuck into the trunk,
about four feet from the ground. The country people put them in long
ago, and they think that if they chew a piece of the bark, it will cure
the toothache. The teeth are almost grown over now, and no one comes to
the tree.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: I should. I love folklore and all festering superstitions.
subQuotationList: ['I should. I love folklore and all festering superstitions.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Do you think that the tree really did cure toothache, if one believed
in it?
subQuotationList: ['Do you think that the tree really did cure toothache, if one believed\nin it?']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Of course it did. It would cure anything--once.
subQuotationList: ['Of course it did. It would cure anything--once.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Certainly I remember cases--you see I lived at Howards End long, long
before Mr. Wilcox knew it. I was born there.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly I remember cases--you see I lived at Howards End long, long\nbefore Mr. Wilcox knew it. I was born there.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
Good-bye, Miss Schlegel, good-bye. Thank you for coming. You have
cheered me up.
subQuotationList: ['Good-bye, Miss Schlegel, good-bye. Thank you for coming. You have\ncheered me up.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: I m so glad!
subQuotationList: ['I m so glad!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I--I wonder whether you ever think about yourself?
subQuotationList: ['I--I wonder whether you ever think about yourself?']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: I think of nothing else,
subQuotationList: ['I think of nothing else,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I wonder. I wondered at Heidelberg.
subQuotationList: ['I wonder. I wondered at Heidelberg.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: I M sure!
subQuotationList: ['I M sure!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I almost think--
subQuotationList: ['I almost think--']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Yes?
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I almost think you forget you re a girl.
subQuotationList: ['I almost think you forget you re a girl.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: I m twenty-nine, That s not so wildly girlish.
subQuotationList: ['I m twenty-nine,', 'That s not so wildly girlish.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What makes you say that? Do you mean that I have been gauche and rude?
subQuotationList: ['What makes you say that? Do you mean that I have been gauche and rude?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I only meant that I am fifty-one, and that to
me both of you--Read it all in some book or other; I cannot put things
clearly.
subQuotationList: ['I only meant that I am fifty-one, and that to\nme both of you--Read it all in some book or other; I cannot put things\nclearly.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
Oh, I ve got it--inexperience. I m no better than Helen, you mean, and
yet I presume to advise her.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I ve got it--inexperience. I m no better than Helen, you mean, and\nyet I presume to advise her.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes. You have got it. Inexperience is the word.
subQuotationList: ['Yes. You have got it. Inexperience is the word.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Inexperience,
subQuotationList: ['Inexperience,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Of course, I have everything to learn--absolutely everything--just
as much as Helen. Life s very difficult and full of surprises. At all
events, I ve got as far as that. To be humble and kind, to go
straight ahead, to love people rather than pity them, to remember the
submerged--well, one can t do all these things at once, worse luck,
because they re so contradictory. It s then that proportion comes in--to
live by proportion. Don t BEGIN with proportion. Only prigs do that.
Let proportion come in as a last resource, when the better things have
failed, and a deadlock--Gracious me, I ve started preaching!
subQuotationList:
['Of course, I have everything to learn--absolutely everything--just
as much as Helen. Life s very difficult and full of surprises. At all
events, I ve got as far as that. To be humble and kind, to go
straight ahead, to love people rather than pity them, to remember the
submerged--well, one can t do all these things at once, worse luck,
because they re so contradictory. It s then that proportion comes in--to
live by proportion. Don t BEGIN with proportion. Only prigs do that.
Let proportion come in as a last resource, when the better things have
failed, and a deadlock--Gracious me, I ve started preaching!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Indeed, you put the difficulties of life splendidly, It is just what I should
have liked to say about them myself.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed, you put the difficulties of life splendidly,', 'It is just what I should\nhave liked to say about them myself.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: I hope that your sister is safe in Germany by now.
subQuotationList: ['I hope that your sister is safe in Germany by now.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressees: ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

quoteText: Yes, thank you; I heard on Tuesday.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, thank you; I heard on Tuesday.']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

quoteText:
Only on Tuesday, for they live right away at Stettin. Did you ever know
any one living at Stettin?
subQuotationList: ['Only on Tuesday, for they live right away at Stettin. Did you ever know\nany one living at Stettin?']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

quoteText: Never,
subQuotationList: ['Never,']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressees: ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

quoteText:
People at Stettin drop things into boats out of overhanging warehouses.
At least, our cousins do, but aren t particularly rich. The town isn t
interesting, except for a clock that rolls its eyes, and the view of the
Oder, which truly is something special. Oh, Mrs. Wilcox, you would
love the Oder! The river, or rather rivers--there seem to be dozens
of them--are intense blue, and the plain they run through an intensest
green.
subQuotationList:
['People at Stettin drop things into boats out of overhanging warehouses.
At least, our cousins do, but aren t particularly rich. The town isn t
interesting, except for a clock that rolls its eyes, and the view of the
Oder, which truly is something special. Oh, Mrs. Wilcox, you would
love the Oder! The river, or rather rivers--there seem to be dozens
of them--are intense blue, and the plain they run through an intensest
green.']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

quoteText: Indeed! That sounds like a most beautiful view, Miss Schlegel.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed! That sounds like a most beautiful view, Miss Schlegel.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressees: ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

quoteText:
So I say, but Helen, who will muddle things, says no, it s like music.
The course of the Oder is to be like music. It s obliged to remind her
of a symphonic poem. The part by the landing-stage is in B minor, if I
remember rightly, but lower down things get extremely mixed. There is a
slodgy theme in several keys at once, meaning mud-banks, and another for
the navigable canal, and the exit into the Baltic is in C sharp major,
pianissimo.
subQuotationList:
['So I say, but Helen, who will muddle things, says no, it s like music.
The course of the Oder is to be like music. It s obliged to remind her
of a symphonic poem. The part by the landing-stage is in B minor, if I
remember rightly, but lower down things get extremely mixed. There is a
slodgy theme in several keys at once, meaning mud-banks, and another for
the navigable canal, and the exit into the Baltic is in C sharp major,
pianissimo.']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

quoteText: What do the overhanging warehouses make of that?
subQuotationList: ['What do the overhanging warehouses make of that?']
speaker: A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office

quoteText:
They make a great deal of it, I think it s affectation to compare the Oder to
music, and so do you, but the overhanging warehouses of Stettin take
beauty seriously, which we don t, and the average Englishman doesn t,
and despises all who do. Now don t say  Germans have no taste,  or I
shall scream. They haven t. But--but--such a tremendous but!--they take
poetry seriously. They do take poetry seriously.
subQuotationList:
['They make a great deal of it,', 'I think it s affectation to compare the Oder to
music, and so do you, but the overhanging warehouses of Stettin take
beauty seriously, which we don t, and the average Englishman doesn t,
and despises all who do. Now don t say  Germans have no taste,  or I
shall scream. They haven t. But--but--such a tremendous but!--they take
poetry seriously. They do take poetry seriously.']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

quoteText: Is anything gained by that?
subQuotationList: ['Is anything gained by that?']
speaker: A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office

quoteText:
Yes, yes. The German is always on the lookout for beauty. He may miss
it through stupidity, or misinterpret it, but he is always asking
beauty to enter his life, and I believe that in the end it will come. At
Heidelberg I met a fat veterinary surgeon whose voice broke with sobs as
he repeated some mawkish poetry. So easy for me to laugh--I, who never
repeat poetry, good or bad, and cannot remember one fragment of verse
to thrill myself with. My blood boils--well, I m half German, so put
it down to patriotism--when I listen to the tasteful contempt of the
average islander for things Teutonic, whether they re Bocklin or my
veterinary surgeon.  Oh, Bocklin,  they say;  he strains after beauty,
he peoples Nature with gods too consciously.  Of course Bocklin strains,
because he wants something--beauty and all the other intangible gifts
that are floating about the world. So his landscapes don t come off, and
Leader s do.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, yes. The German is always on the lookout for beauty. He may miss
it through stupidity, or misinterpret it, but he is always asking
beauty to enter his life, and I believe that in the end it will come. At
Heidelberg I met a fat veterinary surgeon whose voice broke with sobs as
he repeated some mawkish poetry. So easy for me to laugh--I, who never
repeat poetry, good or bad, and cannot remember one fragment of verse
to thrill myself with. My blood boils--well, I m half German, so put
it down to patriotism--when I listen to the tasteful contempt of the
average islander for things Teutonic, whether they re Bocklin or my
veterinary surgeon.  Oh, Bocklin,  they say;  he strains after beauty,
he peoples Nature with gods too consciously.  Of course Bocklin strains,
because he wants something--beauty and all the other intangible gifts
that are floating about the world. So his landscapes don t come off, and
Leader s do.']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

quoteText: I am not sure that I agree. Do you?
subQuotationList: ['I am not sure that I agree. Do you?']
speaker: A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office

quoteText: I think Miss Schlegel puts everything splendidly;
subQuotationList: ['I think Miss Schlegel puts everything splendidly;']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressees: ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

quoteText:
Oh, Mrs. Wilcox, say something nicer than that. It s such a snub to be
told you put things splendidly.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Mrs. Wilcox, say something nicer than that. It s such a snub to be\ntold you put things splendidly.']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

quoteText:
I do not mean it as a snub. Your last speech interested me so much.
Generally people do not seem quite to like Germany. I have long wanted
to hear what is said on the other side.
subQuotationList: ['I do not mean it as a snub. Your last speech interested me so much.\nGenerally people do not seem quite to like Germany. I have long wanted\nto hear what is said on the other side.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressees: ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

quoteText: The other side? Then you do disagree. Oh, good! Give us your side.
subQuotationList: ['The other side? Then you do disagree. Oh, good! Give us your side.']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Wilcox'], ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret'], ['Mrs. Wilcox']]]

quoteText: I have no side. But my husband
subQuotationList: ['I have no side. But my husband']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressees: ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

quoteText:
has very little faith in the Continent, and our children
have all taken after him.
subQuotationList: ['has very little faith in the Continent, and our children\nhave all taken after him.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressees: ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

quoteText: On what grounds? Do they feel that the Continent is in bad form?
subQuotationList: ['On what grounds? Do they feel that the Continent is in bad form?']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

quoteText:
You will admit, though, that the Continent--it seems silly to speak of
 the Continent,  but really it is all more like itself than any part of
it is like England. England is unique. Do have another jelly first. I
was going to say that the Continent, for good or for evil, is interested
in ideas. Its Literature and Art have what one might call the kink of
the unseen about them, and this persists even through decadence and
affectation. There is more liberty of action in England, but for liberty
of thought go to bureaucratic Prussia. People will there discuss with
humility vital questions that we here think ourselves too good to touch
with tongs.
subQuotationList:
['You will admit, though, that the Continent--it seems silly to speak of
 the Continent,  but really it is all more like itself than any part of
it is like England. England is unique. Do have another jelly first. I
was going to say that the Continent, for good or for evil, is interested
in ideas. Its Literature and Art have what one might call the kink of
the unseen about them, and this persists even through decadence and
affectation. There is more liberty of action in England, but for liberty
of thought go to bureaucratic Prussia. People will there discuss with
humility vital questions that we here think ourselves too good to touch
with tongs.']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['A Girl Opposite', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

quoteText:
I do not want to go to Prussia, not even to see
that interesting view that you were describing. And for discussing with
humility I am too old. We never discuss anything at Howards End.
subQuotationList: ['I do not want to go to Prussia,', 'not even to see\nthat interesting view that you were describing. And for discussing with\nhumility I am too old. We never discuss anything at Howards End.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressees: ['A Girl Opposite', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

quoteText:
Then you ought to! Discussion keeps a house alive. It
cannot stand by bricks and mortar alone.
subQuotationList: ['Then you ought to!', 'Discussion keeps a house alive. It\ncannot stand by bricks and mortar alone.']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['A Girl Opposite', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

quoteText:
It cannot stand without them, It cannot stand without
them, and I sometimes think--But I cannot expect your generation to
agree, for even my daughter disagrees with me here.
subQuotationList: ['It cannot stand without them,', 'It cannot stand without\nthem, and I sometimes think--But I cannot expect your generation to\nagree, for even my daughter disagrees with me here.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressees: ['A Girl Opposite', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Margaret', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'A Girl Opposite'], ['Evie']]]

quoteText: Never mind us or her. Do say!
subQuotationList: ['Never mind us or her. Do say!']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['A Girl Opposite', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret'], ['Evie']]]

quoteText:
I sometimes think that it is wiser to leave action and discussion to
men.
subQuotationList: ['I sometimes think that it is wiser to leave action and discussion to\nmen.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressees: ['A Girl Opposite', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

quoteText:
One admits that the arguments against the suffrage ARE extraordinarily
strong,
subQuotationList: ['One admits that the arguments against the suffrage ARE extraordinarily\nstrong,']
speaker: A Girl Opposite
addressees: ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Margaret']

quoteText:
Are they? I never follow any arguments. I am only too thankful not to
have a vote myself.
subQuotationList: ['Are they? I never follow any arguments. I am only too thankful not to\nhave a vote myself.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressees: ['A Girl Opposite', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

quoteText:
We didn t mean the vote, though, did we? Aren t
we differing on something much wider, Mrs. Wilcox? Whether women are to
remain what they have been since the dawn of history; or whether, since
men have moved forward so far, they too may move forward a little now. I
say they may. I would even admit a biological change.
subQuotationList:
['We didn t mean the vote, though, did we?', 'Aren t
we differing on something much wider, Mrs. Wilcox? Whether women are to
remain what they have been since the dawn of history; or whether, since
men have moved forward so far, they too may move forward a little now. I
say they may. I would even admit a biological change.']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['A Girl Opposite', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

quoteText: I don t know, I don t know.
subQuotationList: ['I don t know, I don t know.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressees: ['A Girl Opposite', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

quoteText: I must be getting back to my overhanging warehouse, They ve turned disgracefully strict.
subQuotationList: ['I must be getting back to my overhanging warehouse,', 'They ve turned disgracefully strict.']
speaker: A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office

quoteText:
Oh, but come upstairs for a little. Miss Quested plays. Do you like
MacDowell? Do you mind his only having two noises? If you must really
go, I ll see you out. Won t you even have coffee?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, but come upstairs for a little. Miss Quested plays. Do you like\nMacDowell? Do you mind his only having two noises? If you must really\ngo, I ll see you out. Won t you even have coffee?']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['A Girl Opposite', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

quoteText:
What an interesting life you
all lead in London!
subQuotationList: ['What an interesting life you\nall lead in London!']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
No, we don t, We lead the
lives of gibbering monkeys. Mrs. Wilcox--really--We have something quiet
and stable at the bottom. We really have. All my friends have. Don t
pretend you enjoyed lunch, for you loathed it, but forgive me by coming
again, alone, or by asking me to you.
subQuotationList:
['No, we don t,', 'We lead the
lives of gibbering monkeys. Mrs. Wilcox--really--We have something quiet
and stable at the bottom. We really have. All my friends have. Don t
pretend you enjoyed lunch, for you loathed it, but forgive me by coming
again, alone, or by asking me to you.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I am used to young people, I hear a great deal of
chatter at home, for we, like you, entertain a great deal. With us it
is more sport and politics, but--I enjoyed my lunch very much, Miss
Schlegel, dear, and am not pretending, and only wish I could have joined
in more. For one thing, I m not particularly well just to-day. For
another, you younger people move so quickly that it dazes me. Charles
is the same, Dolly the same. But we are all in the same boat, old and
young. I never forget that.
subQuotationList:
['I am used to young people,', 'I hear a great deal of
chatter at home, for we, like you, entertain a great deal. With us it
is more sport and politics, but--I enjoyed my lunch very much, Miss
Schlegel, dear, and am not pretending, and only wish I could have joined
in more. For one thing, I m not particularly well just to-day. For
another, you younger people move so quickly that it dazes me. Charles
is the same, Dolly the same. But we are all in the same boat, old and
young. I never forget that.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Margaret'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Margaret'], ['Margaret'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Dolly'], ['Margaret', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Dolly']]]

quoteText:
First of all, we must make a list and tick off the
people s names. My aunt always does, and this fog may thicken up any
moment. Have you any ideas?
subQuotationList: ['First of all,', 'we must make a list and tick off the\npeople s names. My aunt always does, and this fog may thicken up any\nmoment. Have you any ideas?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I thought we would go to Harrods or the Haymarket Stores, Everything is sure to be there. I am not a
good shopper. The din is so confusing, and your aunt is quite right--one
ought to make a list. Take my notebook, then, and write your own name at
the top of the page.
subQuotationList:
['I thought we would go to Harrods or the Haymarket Stores,', 'Everything is sure to be there. I am not a
good shopper. The din is so confusing, and your aunt is quite right--one
ought to make a list. Take my notebook, then, and write your own name at
the top of the page.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
Oh, hooray! How very kind of you to start
with me!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, hooray!', 'How very kind of you to start\nwith me!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I don t really want a Yuletide
gift, though. In fact, I d rather not.
subQuotationList: ['I don t really want a Yuletide\ngift, though. In fact, I d rather not.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Why?
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
Because I ve odd ideas about Christmas. Because I have all that money
can buy. I want more people, but no more things.
subQuotationList: ['Because I ve odd ideas about Christmas. Because I have all that money\ncan buy. I want more people, but no more things.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I should like to give you something worth your acquaintance, Miss
Schlegel, in memory of your kindness to me during my lonely fortnight.
It has so happened that I have been left alone, and you have stopped me
from brooding. I am too apt to brood.
subQuotationList:
['I should like to give you something worth your acquaintance, Miss
Schlegel, in memory of your kindness to me during my lonely fortnight.
It has so happened that I have been left alone, and you have stopped me
from brooding. I am too apt to brood.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
If that is so, if I have happened to be of use to you,
which I didn t know, you cannot pay me back with anything tangible.
subQuotationList: ['If that is so,', 'if I have happened to be of use to you,\nwhich I didn t know, you cannot pay me back with anything tangible.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I suppose not, but one would like to. Perhaps I shall think of
something as we go about.
subQuotationList: ['I suppose not, but one would like to. Perhaps I shall think of\nsomething as we go about.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
We always give the
servants money.
subQuotationList: ['We always give the\nservants money.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Yes, do you, yes, much easier,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, do you, yes, much easier,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
No, I do like Christmas on the whole, In its clumsy
way, it does approach Peace and Goodwill. But oh, it is clumsier every
year.
subQuotationList: ['No, I do like Christmas on the whole,', 'In its clumsy\nway, it does approach Peace and Goodwill. But oh, it is clumsier every\nyear.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Is it? I am only used to country Christmases.
subQuotationList: ['Is it? I am only used to country Christmases.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
We are usually in London, and play the game with vigour--carols at
the Abbey, clumsy midday meal, clumsy dinner for the maids, followed by
Christmas-tree and dancing of poor children, with songs from Helen.
The drawing-room does very well for that. We put the tree in the
powder-closet, and draw a curtain when the candles are lighted, and with
the looking-glass behind it looks quite pretty. I wish we might have
a powder-closet in our next house. Of course, the tree has to be very
small, and the presents don t hang on it. No; the presents reside in a
sort of rocky landscape made of crumpled brown paper.
subQuotationList:
['We are usually in London, and play the game with vigour--carols at
the Abbey, clumsy midday meal, clumsy dinner for the maids, followed by
Christmas-tree and dancing of poor children, with songs from Helen.
The drawing-room does very well for that. We put the tree in the
powder-closet, and draw a curtain when the candles are lighted, and with
the looking-glass behind it looks quite pretty. I wish we might have
a powder-closet in our next house. Of course, the tree has to be very
small, and the presents don t hang on it. No; the presents reside in a
sort of rocky landscape made of crumpled brown paper.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
You spoke of your  next house,  Miss Schlegel. Then are you leaving
Wickham Place?
subQuotationList: ['You spoke of your  next house,  Miss Schlegel. Then are you leaving\nWickham Place?']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Yes, in two or three years, when the lease expires. We must.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, in two or three years, when the lease expires. We must.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Have you been there long?
subQuotationList: ['Have you been there long?']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: All our lives.
subQuotationList: ['All our lives.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: You will be very sorry to leave it.
subQuotationList: ['You will be very sorry to leave it.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: I suppose so. We scarcely realise it yet. My father--
subQuotationList: ['I suppose so. We scarcely realise it yet. My father--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: If possible, something distinctive,
subQuotationList: ['If possible, something distinctive,']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
My husband and our daughter are
motoring.
subQuotationList: ['My husband and our daughter are\nmotoring.']
speaker: A Friend Of Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Bertha, too? Oh, fancy, what a coincidence!
subQuotationList: ['Bertha, too? Oh, fancy, what a coincidence!']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
Do you know, I ll wait. On
second thoughts, I ll wait. There s plenty of time still, isn t there,
and I shall be able to get Evie s opinion.
subQuotationList: ['Do you know, I ll wait. On\nsecond thoughts, I ll wait. There s plenty of time still, isn t there,\nand I shall be able to get Evie s opinion.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: But couldn t you get it renewed?
subQuotationList: ['But couldn t you get it renewed?']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: I beg your pardon?
subQuotationList: ['I beg your pardon?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: The lease, I mean.
subQuotationList: ['The lease, I mean.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
Oh, the lease! Have you been thinking of that all the time? How very
kind of you!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, the lease! Have you been thinking of that all the time? How very\nkind of you!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Surely something could be done.
subQuotationList: ['Surely something could be done.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
No; values have risen too enormously. They mean to pull down Wickham
Place, and build flats like yours.
subQuotationList: ['No; values have risen too enormously. They mean to pull down Wickham\nPlace, and build flats like yours.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But how horrible!
subQuotationList: ['But how horrible!']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Landlords are horrible.
subQuotationList: ['Landlords are horrible.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
It is monstrous, Miss Schlegel; it isn t
right. I had no idea that this was hanging over you. I do pity you from
the bottom of my heart. To be parted from your house, your father s
house--it oughtn t to be allowed. It is worse than dying. I would rather
die than--Oh, poor girls! Can what they call civilisation be right, if
people mayn t die in the room where they were born? My dear, I am so
sorry.
subQuotationList:
['It is monstrous, Miss Schlegel; it isn t
right. I had no idea that this was hanging over you. I do pity you from
the bottom of my heart. To be parted from your house, your father s
house--it oughtn t to be allowed. It is worse than dying. I would rather
die than--Oh, poor girls! Can what they call civilisation be right, if
people mayn t die in the room where they were born? My dear, I am so
sorry.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Howards End was nearly pulled down once. It would have killed me.
subQuotationList: ['Howards End was nearly pulled down once. It would have killed me.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
I--Howards End must be a very different house to ours. We are fond of
ours, but there is nothing distinctive about it. As you saw, it is an
ordinary London house. We shall easily find another.
subQuotationList: ['I--Howards End must be a very different house to ours. We are fond of\nours, but there is nothing distinctive about it. As you saw, it is an\nordinary London house. We shall easily find another.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: So you think.
subQuotationList: ['So you think.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
Again my lack of experience, I suppose! I can t say anything when you take up that line, Mrs.
Wilcox. I wish I could see myself as you see me--foreshortened into a
backfisch. Quite the ingenue. Very charming--wonderfully well read for
my age, but incapable--
subQuotationList:
['Again my lack of experience, I suppose!', 'I can t say anything when you take up that line, Mrs.
Wilcox. I wish I could see myself as you see me--foreshortened into a
backfisch. Quite the ingenue. Very charming--wonderfully well read for
my age, but incapable--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Come down with me to Howards End
now, I want you to see it. You
have never seen it. I want to hear what you say about it, for you do put
things so wonderfully.
subQuotationList:
['Come down with me to Howards End
now,', 'I want you to see it. You
have never seen it. I want to hear what you say about it, for you do put
things so wonderfully.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
Later on I should love it, but it s hardly
the weather for such an expedition, and we ought to start when we re
fresh. Isn t the house shut up, too?
subQuotationList: ['Later on I should love it,', 'but it s hardly\nthe weather for such an expedition, and we ought to start when we re\nfresh. Isn t the house shut up, too?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Might I come some other day?
subQuotationList: ['Might I come some other day?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Back to Wickham Place,
please!
subQuotationList: ['Back to Wickham Place,\nplease!']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
referringExpression: was her order to the coachman

quoteText: A thousand thanks, Miss Schlegel, for all your help.
subQuotationList: ['A thousand thanks, Miss Schlegel, for all your help.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Not at all.
subQuotationList: ['Not at all.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
It is such a comfort to get the presents off my mind--the
Christmas-cards especially. I do admire your choice.
subQuotationList: ['It is such a comfort to get the presents off my mind--the\nChristmas-cards especially. I do admire your choice.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
My husband and Evie will be back the day after to-morrow. That is why
I dragged you out shopping to-day. I stayed in town chiefly to shop,
but got through nothing, and now he writes that they must cut their
tour short, the weather is so bad, and the police-traps have been so
bad--nearly as bad as in Surrey. Ours is such a careful chauffeur, and
my husband feels it particularly hard that they should be treated like
road-hogs.
subQuotationList:
['My husband and Evie will be back the day after to-morrow. That is why
I dragged you out shopping to-day. I stayed in town chiefly to shop,
but got through nothing, and now he writes that they must cut their
tour short, the weather is so bad, and the police-traps have been so
bad--nearly as bad as in Surrey. Ours is such a careful chauffeur, and
my husband feels it particularly hard that they should be treated like
road-hogs.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Why?
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Well, naturally he--he isn t a road-hog.
subQuotationList: ['Well, naturally he--he isn t a road-hog.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
He was exceeding the speed-limit, I conclude. He must expect to suffer
with the lower animals.
subQuotationList: ['He was exceeding the speed-limit, I conclude. He must expect to suffer\nwith the lower animals.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I will come if I still may,
subQuotationList: ['I will come if I still may,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
You are coming to sleep, dear, too. It is in the morning that my house
is most beautiful. You are coming to stop. I cannot show you my meadow
properly except at sunrise. These fogs
subQuotationList: ['You are coming to sleep, dear, too. It is in the morning that my house\nis most beautiful. You are coming to stop. I cannot show you my meadow\nproperly except at sunrise. These fogs']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
never spread far. I dare say they are sitting in the sun in
Hertfordshire, and you will never repent joining them.
subQuotationList: ['never spread far. I dare say they are sitting in the sun in\nHertfordshire, and you will never repent joining them.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: I shall never repent joining you.
subQuotationList: ['I shall never repent joining you.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It is the same.
subQuotationList: ['It is the same.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Mother! mother!
subQuotationList: ['Mother! mother!']
speaker: Evie

quoteText: Evie! Evie, my pet--
subQuotationList: ['Evie!', 'Evie, my pet--']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: Father! I say! look who s here.
subQuotationList: ['Father! I say! look who s here.']
speaker: Evie

quoteText: Evie, dearest girl, why aren t you in Yorkshire?
subQuotationList: ['Evie, dearest girl, why aren t you in Yorkshire?']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText: No--motor smash--changed plans--father s coming.
subQuotationList: ['No--motor smash--changed plans--father s coming.']
speaker: Evie

quoteText:
Why, Ruth! what in the name of all
that s wonderful are you doing here, Ruth?
subQuotationList: ['Why, Ruth!', 'what in the name of all\nthat s wonderful are you doing here, Ruth?']
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

quoteText:
Oh, Henry dear!--here s a lovely surprise--but let me introduce--but I
think you know Miss Schlegel.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Henry dear!--here s a lovely surprise--but let me introduce--but I\nthink you know Miss Schlegel.']
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

quoteText:
Oh yes, But how s yourself,
Ruth?
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes,', 'But how s yourself,\nRuth?']
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

quoteText: Fit as a fiddle,

I was saying that this fool of a driver, as the policeman himself

--But as we ve insured against third party risks, it won t so much

Henry, why

I am sure that if the mothers of various nations could meet,

a more inward light, not so much for myself as for

They had no business to be pollarding those elms

my new car s been driven!

quoteText:
Yes, and whoever s driven it hasn t

quoteText: Charles--
subQuotationList: ['Charles--']

quoteText:
One minute, I m busy. Well, Crane, who s been driving it, do you

speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
Don t know, I m sure, sir. No one s driven it since I ve been back,
but, of course, there s the fortnight I ve been away with the other car
in Yorkshire.
subQuotationList: ['Don t know, I m sure, sir. No one s driven it since I ve been back,\nbut, of course, there s the fortnight I ve been away with the other car\nin Yorkshire.']

quoteText:
Charles, your father s down. Something s happened. He wants you in the
house at once. Oh, Charles!
subQuotationList: ['Charles, your father s down. Something s happened. He wants you in the\nhouse at once. Oh, Charles!']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
Wait, dear, wait a minute. Who had the key of the garage while you were
away, Crane?
subQuotationList: ['Wait, dear, wait a minute. Who had the key of the garage while you were\naway, Crane?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: The gardener, sir.
subQuotationList: ['The gardener, sir.']
speaker: His Father'S Chauffeur

quoteText: Do you mean to tell me that old Penny can drive a motor?
subQuotationList: ['Do you mean to tell me that old Penny can drive a motor?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: No, sir; no one s had the motor out, sir.
subQuotationList: ['No, sir; no one s had the motor out, sir.']

speaker: Charles Wilcox

I can t, of course, say for the time I ve been in Yorkshire. No more
mud now, sir.

speaker: His Father'S Chauffeur

Howards End? Now, Crane, just don t forget to put on the Stepney

quoteText: No, sir.

Got what? What the dickens are you

come in at once to father. He s had a

subQuotationList: ['Come in, all three of you!']

I told you not to go out to the garage. I ve heard you all shouting in
the garden. I won t have it. Come in.

speaker: Mr. Wilcox

quoteText:
Into the dining-room, every one of you. We can t discuss private
matters in the middle of all the servants. Here, Charles, here; read
these. See what you make.
subQuotationList: ['Into the dining-room, every one of you. We can t discuss private\nmatters in the middle of all the servants. Here, Charles, here; read\nthese. See what you make.']
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

quoteText: I suppose we re going to have a talk about this?
subQuotationList: ['I suppose we re going to have a talk about this?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

subQuotationList: ['Certainly. I was coming out to you when Dolly--']
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

quoteText: Well, let s sit down.
subQuotationList: ['Well, let s sit down.']

quoteText: Come, Evie, don t waste time, sit--down.

quoteText:
A note in my mother s
handwriting, in an envelope addressed to my father, sealed. Inside: No date, no
signature. Forwarded through the matron of that nursing home. Now, the
question is--
subQuotationList:

handwriting, in an envelope addressed to my father, sealed. Inside:', 'No date, no

quoteText:
But I say that note isn t legal. Houses ought to
be done by a lawyer, Charles, surely.
subQuotationList: ['But I say that note isn t legal. Houses ought to\nbe done by a lawyer, Charles, surely.']

quoteText: Give it her.

referringExpression: his father for permission who said

Why, it s only in pencil! I said so. Pencil never
counts.

speaker: Dolly
referringExpression: She seized it and at once exclaimed

quoteText:
We know that it is not legally binding, Dolly, We are aware of that. Legally, I
should be justified in tearing it up and throwing it into the fire. Of
course, my dear, we consider you as one of the family, but it will be
better if you do not interfere with what you do not understand.
subQuotationList:
['We know that it is not legally binding, Dolly,', 'We are aware of that. Legally, I

quoteText:
The
question is-- The
question is whether Miss Schlegel, during the fortnight we were all
away, whether she unduly--

['The
question is--', 'The
question is whether Miss Schlegel, during the fortnight we were all
away, whether she unduly--']
speaker: Charles Wilcox
referringExpression: Charles vexed both with his father and his wife then repeated

subQuotationList: ['I don t think that,']

quoteText: Don t think what?
subQuotationList: ['Don t think what?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
That she would have--that it is a case of undue influence. No, to
my mind the question is the--the invalid s condition at the time she
wrote.
subQuotationList: ['That she would have--that it is a case of undue influence. No, to\nmy mind the question is the--the invalid s condition at the time she\nwrote.']
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

quoteText:
My dear father, consult an expert if you like, but I don t admit it is
my mother s writing.
subQuotationList: ['My dear father, consult an expert if you like, but I don t admit it is\nmy mother s writing.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Why, you just said it was!
subQuotationList: ['Why, you just said it was!']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: Never mind if I did, and hold your tongue.
subQuotationList: ['Never mind if I did,', 'and hold your tongue.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
Ah, well! I shouldn t have
thought it possible.
subQuotationList: ['Ah, well!', 'I shouldn t have\nthought it possible.']
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

quoteText: Mother couldn t have meant it,
subQuotationList: ['Mother couldn t have meant it,']

quoteText: No, my girl, of course not.
subQuotationList: ['No, my girl, of course not.']
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

quoteText:
Mother believed so in ancestors too--it isn t like her to leave
anything to an outsider, who d never appreciate.
subQuotationList: ['Mother believed so in ancestors too--it isn t like her to leave\nanything to an outsider, who d never appreciate.']
speaker: Evie

quoteText:
The whole thing is unlike her, If Miss Schlegel had
been poor, if she had wanted a house, I could understand it a little.
But she has a house of her own. Why should she want another? She
wouldn t have any use for Howards End.
subQuotationList:
['The whole thing is unlike her,', 'If Miss Schlegel had
been poor, if she had wanted a house, I could understand it a little.
But she has a house of her own. Why should she want another? She
wouldn t have any use for Howards End.']
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

quoteText: That time may prove,
subQuotationList: ['That time may prove,']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: How?
speaker: Evie

quoteText:
Presumably she knows--mother will have told her. She got twice or three
times into the nursing home. Presumably she is awaiting developments.
subQuotationList: ['Presumably she knows--mother will have told her. She got twice or three\ntimes into the nursing home. Presumably she is awaiting developments.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: What a horrid woman!
subQuotationList: ['What a horrid woman!']
speaker: Evie

quoteText:
Why, she
may be coming down to turn us out now!
subQuotationList: ['Why, she\nmay be coming down to turn us out now!']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
I wish she would, I could
then deal with her.
subQuotationList: ['I wish she would,', 'I could\nthen deal with her.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
So could I, I could deal
with her, if she comes, but she won t come. You re all a bit hard on
Miss Schlegel.
subQuotationList: ['So could I,', 'I could deal\nwith her, if she comes, but she won t come. You re all a bit hard on\nMiss Schlegel.']
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

quoteText: That Paul business was pretty scandalous, though.
subQuotationList: ['That Paul business was pretty scandalous, though.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
I want no more of the Paul business, Charles, as I said at the time,
and besides, it is quite apart from this business. Margaret Schlegel has
been officious and tiresome during this terrible week, and we have
all suffered under her, but upon my soul she s honest. She s NOT in
collusion with the matron. I m absolutely certain of it. Nor was she
with the doctor, I m equally certain of that. She did not hide anything
from us, for up to that very afternoon she was as ignorant as we are.
She, like ourselves, was a dupe--
subQuotationList:
['I want no more of the Paul business, Charles, as I said at the time,
and besides, it is quite apart from this business. Margaret Schlegel has
been officious and tiresome during this terrible week, and we have
all suffered under her, but upon my soul she s honest. She s NOT in
collusion with the matron. I m absolutely certain of it. Nor was she
with the doctor, I m equally certain of that. She did not hide anything
from us, for up to that very afternoon she was as ignorant as we are.
She, like ourselves, was a dupe--']
speaker: Mr. Wilcox
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Paul'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Margaret'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Margaret'], ['Margaret'], ['Margaret'], ['Margaret'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Margaret'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Margaret']]]

quoteText:
You see,
Charles, in her terrible pain your mother put us all in false positions.
Paul would not have left England, you would not have gone to Italy, nor
Evie and I into Yorkshire, if only we had known. Well, Miss Schlegel s
position has been equally false. Take all in all, she has not come out
of it badly.
subQuotationList:
['You see,
Charles, in her terrible pain your mother put us all in false positions.
Paul would not have left England, you would not have gone to Italy, nor

position has been equally false. Take all in all, she has not come out

speaker: Mr. Wilcox
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Charles Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Paul'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Evie'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Margaret'], ['Margaret']]]

quoteText: But those chrysanthemums--
subQuotationList: ['But those chrysanthemums--']
speaker: Evie

quoteText: Or coming down to the funeral at all--
subQuotationList: ['Or coming down to the funeral at all--']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
Why shouldn t she come down? She had the right to, and she stood far
back among the Hilton women. The flowers--certainly we should not have
sent such flowers, but they may have seemed the right thing to her,
Evie, and for all you know they may be the custom in Germany.
subQuotationList:
['Why shouldn t she come down? She had the right to, and she stood far
back among the Hilton women. The flowers--certainly we should not have
sent such flowers, but they may have seemed the right thing to her,

speaker: Mr. Wilcox

quoteText:
Oh, I forget she isn t really English, That would explain
a lot.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I forget she isn t really English,', 'That would explain\na lot.']
speaker: Evie

quoteText:
She s a cosmopolitan, I admit I m
rather down on cosmopolitans. My fault, doubtless. I cannot stand them,
and a German cosmopolitan is the limit. I think that s about all, isn t
it? I want to run down and see Chalkeley. A bicycle will do. And, by the
way, I wish you d speak to Crane some time. I m certain he s had my new
car out.
subQuotationList:
['She s a cosmopolitan,', 'I admit I m
rather down on cosmopolitans. My fault, doubtless. I cannot stand them,

quoteText: Has he done it any harm?
subQuotationList: ['Has he done it any harm?']
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

quoteText: No.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: In that case I shall let it pass. It s not worth while having a row.
subQuotationList: ['In that case I shall let it pass. It s not worth while having a row.']
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

quoteText: loved superstition.
subQuotationList: ['loved superstition.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, how lovely! That s the place for me!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, how lovely! That s the place for me!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I have a message, dear Helen,
subQuotationList: ['I have a message, dear Helen,']
speaker: Fraulein Mosebach

quoteText:
And there will even be some one for Tibby, There now, Tibby, think of that; Frieda is saving up a little
girl for you, in pig-tails and white worsted stockings but the feet
of the stockings are pink as if the little girl had trodden in
strawberries. I ve talked too much. My head aches. Now you talk.
subQuotationList:
['And there will even be some one for Tibby,', 'There now, Tibby, think of that; Frieda is saving up a little
girl for you, in pig-tails and white worsted stockings but the feet
