quoteText: Helen, I told you about poor Mrs. Wilcox; that sad business?
subQuotationList: ['Helen, I told you about poor Mrs. Wilcox; that sad business?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I have had a correspondence with her son. He was winding up the estate,
and wrote to ask me whether his mother had wanted me to have anything.
I thought it good of him, considering I knew her so little. I said that
she had once spoken of giving me a Christmas present, but we both forgot
about it afterwards.
subQuotationList:
['I have had a correspondence with her son. He was winding up the estate,
and wrote to ask me whether his mother had wanted me to have anything.
I thought it good of him, considering I knew her so little. I said that
she had once spoken of giving me a Christmas present, but we both forgot
about it afterwards.']
speaker: Margaret
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Charles Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'Margaret']]]

quoteText: I hope Charles took the hint.
subQuotationList: ['I hope Charles took the hint.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Yes--that is to say, her husband wrote later on, and thanked me for
being a little kind to her, and actually gave me her silver vinaigrette.
Don t you think that is extraordinarily generous? It has made me
like him very much. He hopes that this will not be the end of our
acquaintance, but that you and I will go and stop with Evie some time in
the future. I like Mr. Wilcox. He is taking up his work--rubber--it is
a big business. I gather he is launching out rather. Charles is in it,
too. Charles is married--a pretty little creature, but she doesn t seem
wise. They took on the flat, but now they have gone off to a house of
their own.
subQuotationList:
['Yes--that is to say, her husband wrote later on, and thanked me for
being a little kind to her, and actually gave me her silver vinaigrette.
Don t you think that is extraordinarily generous? It has made me
like him very much. He hopes that this will not be the end of our
acquaintance, but that you and I will go and stop with Evie some time in
the future. I like Mr. Wilcox. He is taking up his work--rubber--it is
a big business. I gather he is launching out rather. Charles is in it,
too. Charles is married--a pretty little creature, but she doesn t seem
wise. They took on the flat, but now they have gone off to a house of
their own.']
speaker: Margaret
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox'], ['Helen'], ['Mr. Wilcox'], ['Mr. Wilcox'], ['Helen'], ['Evie'], ['Mr. Wilcox'], ['Mr. Wilcox'], ['Mr. Wilcox'], ['Mr. Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Dolly'], ['Dolly'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Dolly']]]

quoteText: I was thinking of Mr. Vyse. He never strikes me as particularly happy.
subQuotationList: ['I was thinking of Mr. Vyse. He never strikes me as particularly happy.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Ye--es.
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
But Mr. Vyse is rather a wretched, weedy man, don t you think? Then
there s Guy. That was a pitiful business. Besides
subQuotationList: ['But Mr. Vyse is rather a wretched, weedy man, don t you think? Then\nthere s Guy. That was a pitiful business. Besides']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: every one is the better for some regular work.
subQuotationList: ['every one is the better for some regular work.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I shall stick to it, I am not saying it
to educate you; it is what I really think. I believe that in the last
century men have developed the desire for work, and they must not starve
it. It s a new desire. It goes with a great deal that s bad, but in
itself it s good, and I hope that for women, too,  not to work  will
soon become as shocking as  not to be married  was a hundred years ago.
subQuotationList:
['I shall stick to it,', 'I am not saying it
to educate you; it is what I really think. I believe that in the last
century men have developed the desire for work, and they must not starve
it. It s a new desire. It goes with a great deal that s bad, but in
itself it s good, and I hope that for women, too,  not to work  will
soon become as shocking as  not to be married  was a hundred years ago.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I have no experience of this profound desire to which you allude,
subQuotationList: ['I have no experience of this profound desire to which you allude,']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
Then we ll leave the subject till you do. I m not going to rattle you
round. Take your time. Only do think over the lives of the men you like
most, and see how they ve arranged them.
subQuotationList: ['Then we ll leave the subject till you do. I m not going to rattle you\nround. Take your time. Only do think over the lives of the men you like\nmost, and see how they ve arranged them.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I like Guy and Mr. Vyse most,
subQuotationList: ['I like Guy and Mr. Vyse most,']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
And don t think I m not serious because I don t use the traditional
arguments--making money, a sphere awaiting you, and so on--all of which
are, for various reasons, cant.
subQuotationList: ['And don t think I m not serious because I don t use the traditional\narguments--making money, a sphere awaiting you, and so on--all of which\nare, for various reasons, cant.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I m only your sister.
I haven t any authority over you, and I don t want to have any. Just
to put before you what I think the Truth. You see
subQuotationList: ['I m only your sister.\nI haven t any authority over you, and I don t want to have any. Just\nto put before you what I think the Truth. You see']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
in a few years we shall be
the same age practically, and I shall want you to help me. Men are so
much nicer than women.
subQuotationList: ['in a few years we shall be\nthe same age practically, and I shall want you to help me. Men are so\nmuch nicer than women.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Labouring under such a delusion, why do you not marry?
subQuotationList: ['Labouring under such a delusion, why do you not marry?']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: I sometimes jolly well think I would if I got the chance.
subQuotationList: ['I sometimes jolly well think I would if I got the chance.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Has nobody arst you?
subQuotationList: ['Has nobody arst you?']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: Only ninnies.
subQuotationList: ['Only ninnies.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Do people ask Helen?
subQuotationList: ['Do people ask Helen?']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: Plentifully.
subQuotationList: ['Plentifully.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Tell me about them.
subQuotationList: ['Tell me about them.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: No.
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Tell me about your ninnies, then.
subQuotationList: ['Tell me about your ninnies, then.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
They were men who had nothing better to do, So take warning; you must
work, or else you must pretend to work, which is what I do. Work, work,
work if you d save your soul and your body. It is honestly a necessity,
dear boy. Look at the Wilcoxes, look at Mr. Pembroke. With all their
defects of temper and understanding, such men give me more pleasure than
many who are better equipped, and I think it is because they have worked
regularly and honestly.
subQuotationList:
['They were men who had nothing better to do,', 'So take warning; you must
work, or else you must pretend to work, which is what I do. Work, work,
work if you d save your soul and your body. It is honestly a necessity,
dear boy. Look at the Wilcoxes, look at Mr. Pembroke. With all their
defects of temper and understanding, such men give me more pleasure than
many who are better equipped, and I think it is because they have worked
regularly and honestly.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Spare me the Wilcoxes,
subQuotationList: ['Spare me the Wilcoxes,']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: I shall not. They are the right sort.
subQuotationList: ['I shall not. They are the right sort.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, goodness me, Meg--!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, goodness me, Meg--!']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: Well, they re as near the right sort as you can imagine.
subQuotationList: ['Well, they re as near the right sort as you can imagine.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: No, no--oh, no!
subQuotationList: ['No, no--oh, no!']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
I was thinking of the younger son, whom I once classed as a ninny,
but who came back so ill from Nigeria. He s gone out there again, Evie
Wilcox tells me--out to his duty.
subQuotationList: ['I was thinking of the younger son, whom I once classed as a ninny,\nbut who came back so ill from Nigeria. He s gone out there again, Evie\nWilcox tells me--out to his duty.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
He doesn t want the money, it is work he wants, though it is beastly
work--dull country, dishonest natives, an eternal fidget over fresh
water and food... A nation that can produce men of that sort may well be
proud. No wonder England has become an Empire.
subQuotationList:
['He doesn t want the money, it is work he wants, though it is beastly
work--dull country, dishonest natives, an eternal fidget over fresh
water and food... A nation that can produce men of that sort may well be
proud. No wonder England has become an Empire.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: EMPIRE!
subQuotationList: ['EMPIRE!']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
I can t bother over results, They are
too difficult for me. I can only look at the men. An Empire bores me,
so far, but I can appreciate the heroism that builds it up. London
bores me, but what thousands of splendid people are labouring to make
London--
subQuotationList:
['I can t bother over results,', 'They are
too difficult for me. I can only look at the men. An Empire bores me,
so far, but I can appreciate the heroism that builds it up. London
bores me, but what thousands of splendid people are labouring to make
London--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What it is,
subQuotationList: ['What it is,']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
What it is, worse luck. I want activity without civilisation. How
paradoxical! Yet I expect that is what we shall find in heaven.
subQuotationList: ['What it is, worse luck. I want activity without civilisation. How\nparadoxical! Yet I expect that is what we shall find in heaven.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
And I, want civilisation without activity, which, I
expect, is what we shall find in the other place.
subQuotationList: ['And I,', 'want civilisation without activity, which, I\nexpect, is what we shall find in the other place.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
You needn t go as far as the other place, Tibbikins, if you want that.
You can find it at Oxford.
subQuotationList: ['You needn t go as far as the other place, Tibbikins, if you want that.\nYou can find it at Oxford.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Stupid--
subQuotationList: ['Stupid--']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
If I m stupid, get me back to the house-hunting. I ll even live in
Oxford if you like--North Oxford. I ll live anywhere except Bournemouth,
Torquay, and Cheltenham. Oh yes, or Ilfracombe and Swanage and Tunbridge
Wells and Surbiton and Bedford. There on no account.
subQuotationList:
['If I m stupid, get me back to the house-hunting. I ll even live in
Oxford if you like--North Oxford. I ll live anywhere except Bournemouth,
Torquay, and Cheltenham. Oh yes, or Ilfracombe and Swanage and Tunbridge
Wells and Surbiton and Bedford. There on no account.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: London, then.
subQuotationList: ['London, then.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
I agree, but Helen rather wants to get away from London. However,
there s no reason we shouldn t have a house in the country and also a
flat in town, provided we all stick together and contribute. Though of
course--Oh, how one does maunder on and to think, to think of the people
who are really poor. How do they live? Not to move about the world would
kill me.
subQuotationList:
['I agree, but Helen rather wants to get away from London. However,
there s no reason we shouldn t have a house in the country and also a
flat in town, provided we all stick together and contribute. Though of
course--Oh, how one does maunder on and to think, to think of the people
who are really poor. How do they live? Not to move about the world would
kill me.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Oh, my dears, what do you think? You ll never guess. A woman s been
here asking me for her husband. Her WHAT?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, my dears, what do you think? You ll never guess. A woman s been\nhere asking me for her husband. Her WHAT?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Yes, for her husband, and it really is so.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, for her husband, and it really is so.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Not anything to do with Bracknell?
subQuotationList: ['Not anything to do with Bracknell?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I offered Bracknell, and he was rejected. So was Tibby. (Cheer up,
Tibby!) It s no one we know. I said,
subQuotationList: ['I offered Bracknell, and he was rejected. So was Tibby. (Cheer up,\nTibby!) It s no one we know. I said,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Oh, and she so magnificently dressed
and tinkling like a chandelier.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, and she so magnificently dressed\nand tinkling like a chandelier.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Now, Helen, what did really happen?
subQuotationList: ['Now, Helen, what did really happen?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
What I say. I was, as it were, orating my speech. Annie opens the door
like a fool, and shows a female straight in on me, with my mouth open.
Then we began--very civilly.
subQuotationList: ['What I say. I was, as it were, orating my speech. Annie opens the door\nlike a fool, and shows a female straight in on me, with my mouth open.\nThen we began--very civilly.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
No--how unjust one is. She said  whom,  not  what. 
She got it perfectly. So I said,
subQuotationList: ['No--how unjust one is. She said  whom,  not  what. \nShe got it perfectly. So I said,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: and she said,
subQuotationList: ['and she said,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: and there we were.
subQuotationList: ['and there we were.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Lan?
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Lan or Len. We were not nice about our vowels. Lanoline.
subQuotationList: ['Lan or Len. We were not nice about our vowels. Lanoline.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: But what an extraordinary--
subQuotationList: ['But what an extraordinary--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I said,  My good Mrs. Lanoline, we have some grave misunderstanding
here. Beautiful as I am, my modesty is even more remarkable than my
beauty, and never, never has Mr. Lanoline rested his eyes on mine.
subQuotationList: ['I said,  My good Mrs. Lanoline, we have some grave misunderstanding\nhere. Beautiful as I am, my modesty is even more remarkable than my\nbeauty, and never, never has Mr. Lanoline rested his eyes on mine.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I hope you were pleased,
subQuotationList: ['I hope you were pleased,']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
Of course, A perfectly delightful experience.
Oh, Mrs. Lanoline s a dear--she asked for a husband as if he were
an umbrella. She mislaid him Saturday afternoon--and for a long time
suffered no inconvenience. But all night, and all this morning her
apprehensions grew. Breakfast didn t seem the same--no, no more did
lunch, and so she strolled up to 2 Wickham Place as being the most
likely place for the missing article.
subQuotationList:
['Of course,', 'A perfectly delightful experience.
Oh, Mrs. Lanoline s a dear--she asked for a husband as if he were
an umbrella. She mislaid him Saturday afternoon--and for a long time
suffered no inconvenience. But all night, and all this morning her
apprehensions grew. Breakfast didn t seem the same--no, no more did
lunch, and so she strolled up to 2 Wickham Place as being the most
likely place for the missing article.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: But how on earth--
subQuotationList: ['But how on earth--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Don t begin how on earthing.
subQuotationList: ['Don t begin how on earthing.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
she kept repeating,
not uncivilly, but with extreme gloom. In vain I asked her what she did
know. Some knew what others knew, and others didn t, and then others
again had better be careful. Oh dear, she was incompetent! She had
a face like a silkworm, and the dining-room reeks of orris-root. We
chatted pleasantly a little about husbands, and I wondered where hers
was too, and advised her to go to the police. She thanked me. We agreed
that Mr. Lanoline s a notty, notty man, and hasn t no business to go
on the lardy-da. But I think she suspected me up to the last. Bags I
writing to Aunt Juley about this. Now, Meg, remember--bags I.
subQuotationList:
['she kept repeating,
not uncivilly, but with extreme gloom. In vain I asked her what she did
know. Some knew what others knew, and others didn t, and then others
again had better be careful. Oh dear, she was incompetent! She had
a face like a silkworm, and the dining-room reeks of orris-root. We
chatted pleasantly a little about husbands, and I wondered where hers
was too, and advised her to go to the police. She thanked me. We agreed
that Mr. Lanoline s a notty, notty man, and hasn t no business to go
on the lardy-da. But I think she suspected me up to the last. Bags I
writing to Aunt Juley about this. Now, Meg, remember--bags I.']
speaker: Helen
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Bast'], ['Mrs. Bast'], ['Mrs. Bast'], ['Mrs. Bast'], ['Mrs. Bast'], ['Helen', 'Mrs. Bast'], ['Mrs. Bast'], ['Mrs. Bast'], ['Mrs. Bast'], ['Helen', 'Mrs. Bast'], ['Leonard'], ['Mrs. Bast'], ['Aunt Juley'], ['Margaret']]]

quoteText:
Bag it by all means, I m
not sure that this is so funny, Helen. It means some horrible volcano
smoking somewhere, doesn t it?
subQuotationList: ['Bag it by all means,', 'I m\nnot sure that this is so funny, Helen. It means some horrible volcano\nsmoking somewhere, doesn t it?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I don t think so--she doesn t really mind. The admirable creature isn t
capable of tragedy.
subQuotationList: ['I don t think so--she doesn t really mind. The admirable creature isn t\ncapable of tragedy.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Her husband may be, though,
subQuotationList: ['Her husband may be, though,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Oh no, not likely. No one capable of tragedy could have married Mrs.
Lanoline.
subQuotationList: ['Oh no, not likely. No one capable of tragedy could have married Mrs.\nLanoline.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Was she pretty?
subQuotationList: ['Was she pretty?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Her figure may have been good once.
subQuotationList: ['Her figure may have been good once.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Tibby and I have again been wondering where we ll live next September,
subQuotationList: ['Tibby and I have again been wondering where we ll live next September,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Tibby had better first wonder what he ll do,
subQuotationList: ['Tibby had better first wonder what he ll do,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Cheers, children! It s Mrs. Lanoline.
subQuotationList: ['Cheers, children!', 'It s Mrs. Lanoline.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: You wouldn t remember giving me this, Miss Schlegel?
subQuotationList: ['You wouldn t remember giving me this, Miss Schlegel?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: No; I can t say I do.
subQuotationList: ['No; I can t say I do.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Well, that was how it happened, you see.
subQuotationList: ['Well, that was how it happened, you see.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Where did we meet, Mr. Bast? For the minute I don t remember.
subQuotationList: ['Where did we meet, Mr. Bast? For the minute I don t remember.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
It was a concert at the Queen s Hall. I think you will recollect, when I tell you that it included a performance of
the Fifth Symphony of Beethoven.
subQuotationList: ['It was a concert at the Queen s Hall. I think you will recollect,', 'when I tell you that it included a performance of\nthe Fifth Symphony of Beethoven.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
We hear the Fifth practically every time it s done, so I m not sure--do
you remember, Helen?
subQuotationList: ['We hear the Fifth practically every time it s done, so I m not sure--do\nyou remember, Helen?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Was it the time the sandy cat walked round the balustrade?
subQuotationList: ['Was it the time the sandy cat walked round the balustrade?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Then I don t remember. That s the only Beethoven I ever remember
specially.
subQuotationList: ['Then I don t remember. That s the only Beethoven I ever remember\nspecially.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
And you, if I may say so, took away my umbrella, inadvertently of
course.
subQuotationList: ['And you, if I may say so, took away my umbrella, inadvertently of\ncourse.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Likely enough, for I steal umbrellas even oftener than
I hear Beethoven. Did you get it back?
subQuotationList: ['Likely enough,', 'for I steal umbrellas even oftener than\nI hear Beethoven. Did you get it back?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Yes, thank you, Miss Schlegel.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, thank you, Miss Schlegel.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: The mistake arose out of my card, did it?
subQuotationList: ['The mistake arose out of my card, did it?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes, the mistake arose--it was a mistake.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, the mistake arose--it was a mistake.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
The lady who called here yesterday thought that you were calling too,
and that she could find you?
subQuotationList: ['The lady who called here yesterday thought that you were calling too,\nand that she could find you?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: That s so, calling too--a mistake.
subQuotationList: ['That s so, calling too--a mistake.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Then why--?
subQuotationList: ['Then why--?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I said to my wife, I said to Mrs. Bast, and Mrs. Bast said to me, While I was gone, however, she wanted me on important business, and
thought I had come here, owing to the card, and so came after me, and I
beg to tender my apologies, and hers as well, for any inconvenience we
may have inadvertently caused you.
subQuotationList:
['I said to my wife,', 'I said to Mrs. Bast,', 'and Mrs. Bast said to me,', 'While I was gone, however, she wanted me on important business, and
thought I had come here, owing to the card, and so came after me, and I
beg to tender my apologies, and hers as well, for any inconvenience we
may have inadvertently caused you.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: No inconvenience, but I still don t understand.
subQuotationList: ['No inconvenience,', 'but I still don t understand.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I still
don t understand. When did you say you paid this call?
subQuotationList: ['I still\ndon t understand. When did you say you paid this call?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Call? What call?
subQuotationList: ['Call? What call?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: This afternoon call.
subQuotationList: ['This afternoon call.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: In the afternoon, of course!
subQuotationList: ['In the afternoon, of course!']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Saturday
afternoon or Sunday afternoon?
subQuotationList: ['Saturday\nafternoon or Sunday afternoon?']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: S--Saturday.
subQuotationList: ['S--Saturday.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Really! and you were still calling on Sunday, when your
wife came here. A long visit.
subQuotationList: ['Really!', 'and you were still calling on Sunday, when your\nwife came here. A long visit.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I don t call that fair, I know what you mean, and it isn t so.
subQuotationList: ['I don t call that fair,', 'I know what you mean, and it isn t so.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Oh, don t let us mind,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, don t let us mind,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It was something else, I was somewhere else to what you think, so there!
subQuotationList: ['It was something else,', 'I was somewhere else to what you think, so there!']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
It was good of you to come and explain, The rest is
naturally no concern of ours.
subQuotationList: ['It was good of you to come and explain,', 'The rest is\nnaturally no concern of ours.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Yes, but I want--I wanted--have you ever read The Ordeal of Richard
Feverel?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, but I want--I wanted--have you ever read The Ordeal of Richard\nFeverel?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
It s a beautiful book. I wanted to get back to the earth, don t you
see, like Richard does in the end. Or have you ever read Stevenson s
Prince Otto?
subQuotationList: ['It s a beautiful book. I wanted to get back to the earth, don t you\nsee, like Richard does in the end. Or have you ever read Stevenson s\nPrince Otto?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
That s another beautiful book. You get back to the earth in that. I
wanted--
subQuotationList: ['That s another beautiful book. You get back to the earth in that. I\nwanted--']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: I walked all the Saturday night, I walked.
subQuotationList: ['I walked all the Saturday night,', 'I walked.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
No doubt it s another beautiful book, but I d rather hear
about your road.
subQuotationList: ['No doubt it s another beautiful book, but I d rather hear\nabout your road.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Oh, I walked.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I walked.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: How far?
subQuotationList: ['How far?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I don t know, nor for how long. It got too dark to see my watch.
subQuotationList: ['I don t know, nor for how long. It got too dark to see my watch.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Were you walking alone, may I ask?
subQuotationList: ['Were you walking alone, may I ask?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Yes, but we d been talking it over at
the office. There s been a lot of talk at the office lately about these
things. The fellows there said one steers by the Pole Star, and I looked
it up in the celestial atlas, but once out of doors everything gets so
mixed.
subQuotationList:
['Yes,', 'but we d been talking it over at
the office. There s been a lot of talk at the office lately about these
things. The fellows there said one steers by the Pole Star, and I looked
it up in the celestial atlas, but once out of doors everything gets so
mixed.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Don t talk to me about the Pole Star, I know its little ways. It goes round and round,
and you go round after it.
subQuotationList: ['Don t talk to me about the Pole Star,', 'I know its little ways. It goes round and round,\nand you go round after it.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Well, I lost it entirely. First of all the street lamps, then the
trees, and towards morning it got cloudy.
subQuotationList: ['Well, I lost it entirely. First of all the street lamps, then the\ntrees, and towards morning it got cloudy.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Where did you start from? Do tell us more.
subQuotationList: ['Where did you start from?', 'Do tell us more.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I took the Underground to Wimbledon. As I came out of the office I said
to myself,  I must have a walk once in a way. If I don t take this walk
now, I shall never take it.  I had a bit of dinner at Wimbledon, and
then--
subQuotationList:
['I took the Underground to Wimbledon. As I came out of the office I said
to myself,  I must have a walk once in a way. If I don t take this walk
now, I shall never take it.  I had a bit of dinner at Wimbledon, and
then--']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: But not good country there, is it?
subQuotationList: ['But not good country there, is it?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
It was gas-lamps for hours. Still, I had all the night, and being out
was the great thing. I did get into woods, too, presently.
subQuotationList: ['It was gas-lamps for hours. Still, I had all the night, and being out\nwas the great thing. I did get into woods, too, presently.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Yes, go on,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, go on,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: You ve no idea how difficult uneven ground is when it s dark.
subQuotationList: ['You ve no idea how difficult uneven ground is when it s dark.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Did you actually go off the roads?
subQuotationList: ['Did you actually go off the roads?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Oh yes. I always meant to go off the roads, but the worst of it is that
it s more difficult to find one s way.
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes. I always meant to go off the roads, but the worst of it is that\nit s more difficult to find one s way.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Mr. Bast, you re a born adventurer, No professional
athlete would have attempted what you ve done. It s a wonder your walk
didn t end in a broken neck. Whatever did your wife say?
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Bast, you re a born adventurer,', 'No professional\nathlete would have attempted what you ve done. It s a wonder your walk\ndidn t end in a broken neck. Whatever did your wife say?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Professional athletes never move without lanterns and compasses, Besides, they can t walk. It tires them. Go on.
subQuotationList: ['Professional athletes never move without lanterns and compasses,', 'Besides, they can t walk. It tires them. Go on.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I felt like R. L. S. You probably remember how in Virginibus.
subQuotationList: ['I felt like R. L. S. You probably remember how in Virginibus.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Yes, but the wood. This  ere wood. How did you get out of it?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, but the wood. This  ere wood. How did you get out of it?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I managed one wood, and found a road the other side which went a good
bit uphill. I rather fancy it was those North Downs, for the road went
off into grass, and I got into another wood. That was awful, with gorse
bushes. I did wish I d never come, but suddenly it got light--just while
I seemed going under one tree. Then I found a road down to a station,
and took the first train I could back to London.
subQuotationList:
['I managed one wood, and found a road the other side which went a good
bit uphill. I rather fancy it was those North Downs, for the road went
off into grass, and I got into another wood. That was awful, with gorse
bushes. I did wish I d never come, but suddenly it got light--just while
I seemed going under one tree. Then I found a road down to a station,
and took the first train I could back to London.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: But was the dawn wonderful?
subQuotationList: ['But was the dawn wonderful?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: No.
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: The dawn was only grey, it was nothing to mention.
subQuotationList: ['The dawn was only grey, it was nothing to mention.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Just a grey evening turned upside down. I know.
subQuotationList: ['Just a grey evening turned upside down. I know.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
--and I was too tired to lift up my head to look at it, and so cold
too. I m glad I did it, and yet at the time it bored me more than I can
say. And besides--you can believe me or not as you choose--I was very
hungry. That dinner at Wimbledon--I meant it to last me all night
like other dinners. I never thought that walking would make such a
difference. Why, when you re walking you want, as it were, a breakfast
and luncheon and tea during the night as well, and I d nothing but a
packet of Woodbines. Lord, I did feel bad! Looking back, it wasn t what
you may call enjoyment. It was more a case of sticking to it. I did
stick. I--I was determined. Oh, hang it all! what s the good--I mean,
the good of living in a room for ever? There one goes on day after day,
same old game, same up and down to town, until you forget there is any
other game. You ought to see once in a way what s going on outside, if
it s only nothing particular after all.
subQuotationList:
['--and I was too tired to lift up my head to look at it, and so cold
too. I m glad I did it, and yet at the time it bored me more than I can

speaker: Leonard

quoteText: I should just think you ought,
subQuotationList: ['I should just think you ought,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Curious it should all come about from reading something of Richard
Jefferies.
subQuotationList: ['Curious it should all come about from reading something of Richard\nJefferies.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Excuse me, Mr. Bast, but you re wrong there. It didn t. It came from
something far greater.
subQuotationList: ['Excuse me, Mr. Bast, but you re wrong there. It didn t. It came from\nsomething far greater.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Then you don t think I was foolish?
subQuotationList: ['Then you don t think I was foolish?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Heavens, no!
subQuotationList: ['Heavens, no!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Heaven help us if we do!
subQuotationList: ['Heaven help us if we do!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I m very glad you say that. Now, my wife would never understand--not if
I explained for days.
subQuotationList: ['I m very glad you say that. Now, my wife would never understand--not if\nI explained for days.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
No, it wasn t foolish! You ve pushed
back the boundaries; I think it splendid of you.
subQuotationList: ['No, it wasn t foolish!', 'You ve pushed\nback the boundaries; I think it splendid of you.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: You ve not been content to dream as we have--
subQuotationList: ['You ve not been content to dream as we have--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Though we have walked, too--
subQuotationList: ['Though we have walked, too--']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I must show you a picture upstairs--
subQuotationList: ['I must show you a picture upstairs--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Oh, bother, not to say dash--I had forgotten we were dining out; but
do, do, come round again and have a talk.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, bother, not to say dash--I had forgotten we were dining out; but\ndo, do, come round again and have a talk.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Yes, you must--do,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, you must--do,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
No, I shall not. It s better
like this.
subQuotationList: ['No, I shall not. It s better\nlike this.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Why better?
subQuotationList: ['Why better?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
No, it is better not to risk a second interview. I shall always look
back on this talk with you as one of the finest things in my life.
Really. I mean this. We can never repeat. It has done me real good, and
there we had better leave it.
subQuotationList:
['No, it is better not to risk a second interview. I shall always look
back on this talk with you as one of the finest things in my life.
Really. I mean this. We can never repeat. It has done me real good, and
there we had better leave it.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: That s rather a sad view of life, surely.
subQuotationList: ['That s rather a sad view of life, surely.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Things so often get spoiled.
subQuotationList: ['Things so often get spoiled.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: I know, but people don t.
subQuotationList: ['I know,', 'but people don t.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Go, then; perhaps you know
best; but never forget you re better than Jefferies.
subQuotationList: ['Go, then; perhaps you know\nbest; but never forget you re better than Jefferies.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
What s
that card, eh?
subQuotationList: ['What s\nthat card, eh?']
speaker: Jacky
referringExpression: Jacky found it and then began

quoteText: Yes, don t you wish you knew what that card was?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, don t you wish you knew what that card was?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Len,
who s Miss Schlegel?
subQuotationList: ['Len,\nwho s Miss Schlegel?']
speaker: Jacky

quoteText:
Well, at all events, she
doesn t know about that card. Yah! done her there!
subQuotationList: ['Well, at all events, she\ndoesn t know about that card. Yah! done her there!']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Well? I know
where you ve been, but you don t know where I ve been.
subQuotationList: ['Well?', 'I know\nwhere you ve been, but you don t know where I ve been.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Len, I do think you might explain,
subQuotationList: ['Len, I do think you might explain,']
speaker: Jacky

quoteText:
Order, order, Miss Schlegel! You are
here, I understand, to advise me in the interests of the Society for the
Preservation of Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty. I cannot
have you speaking out of your role. It makes my poor head go round, and
I think you forget that I am very ill.
subQuotationList:
['Order, order, Miss Schlegel!', 'You are
here, I understand, to advise me in the interests of the Society for the
Preservation of Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty. I cannot
have you speaking out of your role. It makes my poor head go round, and
I think you forget that I am very ill.']
speaker: The Reader Of The Paper
referringExpression: said the reader of the paper

quoteText:
Your head won t go round if only you ll listen to my argument, Why not give him the money itself? You re supposed to have
about thirty thousand a year.
subQuotationList: ['Your head won t go round if only you ll listen to my argument,', 'Why not give him the money itself? You re supposed to have\nabout thirty thousand a year.']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['The Reader Of The Paper', 'An Earnest Girl', 'Helen']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Reader Of The Paper'], ['The Reader Of The Paper']], [['The Reader Of The Paper']]]

quoteText: Have I? I thought I had a million.
subQuotationList: ['Have I? I thought I had a million.']
speaker: The Reader Of The Paper

quoteText:
Wasn t a million your capital? Dear me! we ought to have settled that.
Still, it doesn t matter. Whatever you ve got, I order you to give as
many poor men as you can three hundred a year each.
subQuotationList: ['Wasn t a million your capital? Dear me! we ought to have settled that.\nStill, it doesn t matter. Whatever you ve got, I order you to give as\nmany poor men as you can three hundred a year each.']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['The Reader Of The Paper', 'An Earnest Girl', 'Helen']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Reader Of The Paper'], ['The Reader Of The Paper'], ['The Reader Of The Paper'], ['The Reader Of The Paper']]]

quoteText: But that would be pauperising them,
subQuotationList: ['But that would be pauperising them,']
speaker: An Earnest Girl

quoteText:
Not if you gave them so much. A big windfall would not pauperise a man.
It is these little driblets, distributed among too many, that do the
harm. Money s educational. It s far more educational than the things
it buys. In a sense, Well, isn t the most civilized thing going, the man
who has learnt to wear his income properly?
subQuotationList:
['Not if you gave them so much. A big windfall would not pauperise a man.
It is these little driblets, distributed among too many, that do the
harm. Money s educational. It s far more educational than the things
it buys.', 'In a sense,', 'Well, isn t the most civilized thing going, the man
who has learnt to wear his income properly?']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['The Reader Of The Paper', 'An Earnest Girl', 'Helen']

quoteText:
Give them a chance. Give them money. Don t dole them out poetry-books
and railway-tickets like babies. Give them the wherewithal to buy these
things. When your Socialism comes it may be different, and we may think
in terms of commodities instead of cash. Till it comes give people
cash, for it is the warp of civilisation, whatever the woof may be. The
imagination ought to play upon money and realise it vividly, for it s
the--the second most important thing in the world. It is so slurred over
and hushed up, there is so little clear thinking--oh, political economy,
of course, but so few of us think clearly about our own private incomes,
and admit that independent thoughts are in nine cases out of ten the
result of independent means. Money: give Mr. Bast money, and don t
bother about his ideals. He ll pick up those for himself.
subQuotationList:
['Give them a chance. Give them money. Don t dole them out poetry-books
and railway-tickets like babies. Give them the wherewithal to buy these
things. When your Socialism comes it may be different, and we may think
in terms of commodities instead of cash. Till it comes give people
cash, for it is the warp of civilisation, whatever the woof may be. The
imagination ought to play upon money and realise it vividly, for it s
the--the second most important thing in the world. It is so slurred over
and hushed up, there is so little clear thinking--oh, political economy,
of course, but so few of us think clearly about our own private incomes,
and admit that independent thoughts are in nine cases out of ten the
result of independent means. Money: give Mr. Bast money, and don t
bother about his ideals. He ll pick up those for himself.']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['The Reader Of The Paper', 'An Earnest Girl', 'Helen']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['An Earnest Girl'], ['An Earnest Girl', 'Margaret', 'Helen', 'The Reader Of The Paper'], ['An Earnest Girl', 'Margaret', 'Helen', 'The Reader Of The Paper'], ['Leonard'], ['Leonard'], ['Leonard']]]

quoteText:
Nothing, but he would not gain his soul until
he had gained a little of the world.
subQuotationList: ['Nothing, but he would not gain his soul until\nhe had gained a little of the world.']
speaker: Margaret
addressees: ['The Reader Of The Paper', 'An Earnest Girl', 'Helen']

quoteText:
personal
supervision and mutual help,
subQuotationList: ['personal\nsupervision and mutual help,']
speaker: An Earnest Girl

quoteText: Cold?
subQuotationList: ['Cold?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: No.
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Tired?
subQuotationList: ['Tired?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Doesn t matter.
subQuotationList: ['Doesn t matter.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I say, Helen--
subQuotationList: ['I say, Helen--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Well?
subQuotationList: ['Well?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Are we really going to follow up Mr. Bast?
subQuotationList: ['Are we really going to follow up Mr. Bast?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I don t know.
subQuotationList: ['I don t know.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I think we won t.
subQuotationList: ['I think we won t.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: As you like.
subQuotationList: ['As you like.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
It s no good, I think, unless you really mean to know people. The
discussion brought that home to me. We got on well enough with him in a
spirit of excitement, but think of rational intercourse. We mustn t play
at friendship. No, it s no good.
subQuotationList:
['It s no good, I think, unless you really mean to know people. The
discussion brought that home to me. We got on well enough with him in a
spirit of excitement, but think of rational intercourse. We mustn t play
at friendship. No, it s no good.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: There s Mrs. Lanoline, too, So dull.
subQuotationList: ['There s Mrs. Lanoline, too,', 'So dull.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Just so, and possibly worse than dull.
subQuotationList: ['Just so, and possibly worse than dull.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I should like to know how he got hold of your card.
subQuotationList: ['I should like to know how he got hold of your card.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: But he said--something about a concert and an umbrella.
subQuotationList: ['But he said--something about a concert and an umbrella.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Then did the card see the wife--
subQuotationList: ['Then did the card see the wife--']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Helen, come to bed.
subQuotationList: ['Helen, come to bed.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
No, just a little longer, it is so beautiful. Tell me; oh yes; did you
say money is the warp of the world?
subQuotationList: ['No, just a little longer, it is so beautiful. Tell me; oh yes; did you\nsay money is the warp of the world?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Then what s the woof?
subQuotationList: ['Then what s the woof?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Very much what one chooses, It s something that isn t
money--one can t say more.
subQuotationList: ['Very much what one chooses,', 'It s something that isn t\nmoney--one can t say more.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Walking at night?
subQuotationList: ['Walking at night?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Probably.
subQuotationList: ['Probably.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: For Tibby, Oxford?
subQuotationList: ['For Tibby, Oxford?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: It seems so.
subQuotationList: ['It seems so.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: For you?
subQuotationList: ['For you?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Now that we have to leave Wickham Place, I begin to think it s that.
For Mrs. Wilcox it was certainly Howards End.
subQuotationList: ['Now that we have to leave Wickham Place, I begin to think it s that.\nFor Mrs. Wilcox it was certainly Howards End.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
It is sad to suppose that places may ever be more important than
people,
subQuotationList: ['It is sad to suppose that places may ever be more important than\npeople,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Why, Meg? They re so much nicer generally. I d rather think of that
forester s house in Pomerania than of the fat Herr Forstmeister who
lived in it.
subQuotationList: ['Why, Meg? They re so much nicer generally. I d rather think of that\nforester s house in Pomerania than of the fat Herr Forstmeister who\nlived in it.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I believe we shall come to care about people less and less, Helen. The
more people one knows the easier it becomes to replace them. It s one
of the curses of London. I quite expect to end my life caring most for a
place.
subQuotationList:
['I believe we shall come to care about people less and less, Helen. The
more people one knows the easier it becomes to replace them. It s one
of the curses of London. I quite expect to end my life caring most for a
place.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
How do you do? I thought I recognised your voices. Whatever
are you both doing down here?
subQuotationList: ['How do you do?', 'I thought I recognised your voices. Whatever\nare you both doing down here?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
What an age it is since I ve seen you, Mr. Wilcox. I met Evie in the
Tube, though, lately. I hope you have good news of your son.
subQuotationList: ['What an age it is since I ve seen you, Mr. Wilcox. I met Evie in the\nTube, though, lately. I hope you have good news of your son.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Paul? Oh, Paul s all right. We had a line from Madeira. He ll
be at work again by now.
subQuotationList: ['Paul?', 'Oh, Paul s all right. We had a line from Madeira. He ll\nbe at work again by now.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Ugh--
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I beg your pardon?
subQuotationList: ['I beg your pardon?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Isn t the climate of Nigeria too horrible?
subQuotationList: ['Isn t the climate of Nigeria too horrible?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Some one s got to go, England will never keep her
trade overseas unless she is prepared to make sacrifices. Unless we get
firm in West Africa, Ger--untold complications may follow. Now tell me
all your news.
subQuotationList:
['Some one s got to go,', 'England will never keep her
trade overseas unless she is prepared to make sacrifices. Unless we get
firm in West Africa, Ger--untold complications may follow. Now tell me
all your news.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Oh, we ve had a splendid evening, We belong to a kind of club that reads papers,
Margaret and I--all women, but there is a discussion after. This evening
it was on how one ought to leave one s money--whether to one s family,
or to the poor, and if so how--oh, most interesting.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, we ve had a splendid evening,', 'We belong to a kind of club that reads papers,
Margaret and I--all women, but there is a discussion after. This evening
it was on how one ought to leave one s money--whether to one s family,
or to the poor, and if so how--oh, most interesting.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Sounds a most original entertainment! I wish Evie would go to that sort of thing. But she
hasn t the time. She s taken to breeding Aberdeen terriers--jolly little
dogs.
subQuotationList: ['Sounds a most original entertainment!', 'I wish Evie would go to that sort of thing. But she\nhasn t the time. She s taken to breeding Aberdeen terriers--jolly little\ndogs.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I expect we d better be doing the same, really.
subQuotationList: ['I expect we d better be doing the same, really.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
We pretend we re improving ourselves, you see, We suppose it a good thing to
waste an evening once a fortnight over a debate, but, as my sister says,
it may be better to breed dogs.
subQuotationList: ['We pretend we re improving ourselves, you see,', 'We suppose it a good thing to\nwaste an evening once a fortnight over a debate, but, as my sister says,\nit may be better to breed dogs.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Not at all. I don t agree with your sister. There s nothing like a
debate to teach one quickness. I often wish I had gone in for them when
I was a youngster. It would have helped me no end.
subQuotationList: ['Not at all. I don t agree with your sister. There s nothing like a\ndebate to teach one quickness. I often wish I had gone in for them when\nI was a youngster. It would have helped me no end.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Quickness--?
subQuotationList: ['Quickness--?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Yes. Quickness in argument. Time after time I ve missed scoring a point
because the other man has had the gift of the gab and I haven t. Oh, I
believe in these discussions.
subQuotationList: ['Yes. Quickness in argument. Time after time I ve missed scoring a point\nbecause the other man has had the gift of the gab and I haven t. Oh, I\nbelieve in these discussions.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Oh yes, it doesn t much matter what subject you take,
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes, it doesn t much matter what subject you take,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
But this is going to be far better than the
debate itself.
subQuotationList: ['But this is going to be far better than the\ndebate itself.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
No, I won t go
on, I ll just put our special case to Mr. Wilcox.
subQuotationList: ['No, I won t go\non,', 'I ll just put our special case to Mr. Wilcox.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: About Mr. Bast? Yes, do. He ll be more lenient to a special case.
subQuotationList: ['About Mr. Bast? Yes, do. He ll be more lenient to a special case.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
But, Mr. Wilcox, do first light another cigarette. It s this. We ve
just come across a young fellow, who s evidently very poor, and who
seems interest--
subQuotationList: ['But, Mr. Wilcox, do first light another cigarette. It s this. We ve\njust come across a young fellow, who s evidently very poor, and who\nseems interest--']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: What s his profession?
subQuotationList: ['What s his profession?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Clerk.
subQuotationList: ['Clerk.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: What in?
subQuotationList: ['What in?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Do you remember, Margaret?
subQuotationList: ['Do you remember, Margaret?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Porphyrion Fire Insurance Company.
subQuotationList: ['Porphyrion Fire Insurance Company.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Oh yes; the nice people who gave Aunt Juley a new hearth rug. He seems
interesting, in some ways very, and one wishes one could help him. He is
married to a wife whom he doesn t seem to care for much. He likes books,
and what one may roughly call adventure, and if he had a chance--But he
is so poor. He lives a life where all the money is apt to go on nonsense
and clothes. One is so afraid that circumstances will be too strong
for him and that he will sink. Well, he got mixed up in our debate. He
wasn t the subject of it, but it seemed to bear on his point. Suppose
a millionaire died, and desired to leave money to help such a man. How
should he be helped? Should he be given three hundred pounds a year
direct, which was Margaret s plan? Most of them thought this would
pauperise him. Should he and those like him be given free libraries?
I said  No!  He doesn t want more books to read, but to read books
rightly. My suggestion was he should be given something every year
towards a summer holiday, but then there is his wife, and they said she
would have to go too. Nothing seemed quite right! Now what do you think?
Imagine that you were a millionaire, and wanted to help the poor. What
would you do?
subQuotationList:

I said  No!  He doesn t want more books to read, but to read books
rightly. My suggestion was he should be given something every year
towards a summer holiday, but then there is his wife, and they said she
would have to go too. Nothing seemed quite right! Now what do you think?
Imagine that you were a millionaire, and wanted to help the poor. What
would you do?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
My dear Miss Schlegel, I will not rush
in where your sex has been unable to tread. I will not add another plan
to the numerous excellent ones that have been already suggested. My only
contribution is this: let your young friend clear out of the Porphyrion
Fire Insurance Company with all possible speed.
subQuotationList:
['My dear Miss Schlegel, I will not rush
in where your sex has been unable to tread. I will not add another plan
to the numerous excellent ones that have been already suggested. My only
contribution is this: let your young friend clear out of the Porphyrion
Fire Insurance Company with all possible speed.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Why?
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
This is between friends. It ll be in the
Receiver s hands before Christmas. It ll smash,
subQuotationList: ['This is between friends. It ll be in the\nReceiver s hands before Christmas. It ll smash,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Dear me, Helen, listen to that. And he ll have to get another place!
subQuotationList: ['Dear me, Helen, listen to that. And he ll have to get another place!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
WILL have? Let him leave the ship before it sinks. Let him get one
now.
subQuotationList: ['WILL have? Let him leave the ship before it sinks. Let him get one\nnow.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Rather than wait, to make sure?
subQuotationList: ['Rather than wait, to make sure?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Decidedly.
subQuotationList: ['Decidedly.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Why s that?
subQuotationList: ['Why s that?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Naturally the man
who s in a situation when he applies stands a better chance, is in a
stronger position, that the man who isn t. It looks as if he s worth
something. I know by myself--(this is letting you into the State
secrets)--it affects an employer greatly. Human nature, I m afraid.
subQuotationList:
['Naturally the man
who s in a situation when he applies stands a better chance, is in a
stronger position, that the man who isn t. It looks as if he s worth
something. I know by myself--(this is letting you into the State
secrets)--it affects an employer greatly. Human nature, I m afraid.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I hadn t thought of that,
subQuotationList: ['I hadn t thought of that,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Our
human nature appears to be the other way round. We employ people because
they re unemployed. The boot man, for instance.
subQuotationList: ['Our\nhuman nature appears to be the other way round. We employ people because\nthey re unemployed. The boot man, for instance.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: And how does he clean the boots?
subQuotationList: ['And how does he clean the boots?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Not well,
subQuotationList: ['Not well,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: There you are!
subQuotationList: ['There you are!']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Then do you really advise us to tell this youth--?
subQuotationList: ['Then do you really advise us to tell this youth--?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I advise nothing, I oughtn t to have
spoken--but I happen to know, being more or less behind the scenes. The
Porphyrion s a bad, bad concern--Now, don t say I said so. It s outside
the Tariff Ring.
subQuotationList:
['I advise nothing,', 'I oughtn t to have
spoken--but I happen to know, being more or less behind the scenes. The
Porphyrion s a bad, bad concern--Now, don t say I said so. It s outside
the Tariff Ring.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Certainly I won t say. In fact, I don t know what that means.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly I won t say. In fact, I don t know what that means.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I thought an insurance company never smashed, Don t the others always run in and save them?
subQuotationList: ['I thought an insurance company never smashed,', 'Don t the others always run in and save them?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
You re thinking of reinsurance, It is exactly
there that the Porphyrion is weak. It has tried to undercut, has been
badly hit by a long series of small fires, and it hasn t been able to
reinsure. I m afraid that public companies don t save one another for
love.
subQuotationList:
['You re thinking of reinsurance,', 'It is exactly
there that the Porphyrion is weak. It has tried to undercut, has been
badly hit by a long series of small fires, and it hasn t been able to
reinsure. I m afraid that public companies don t save one another for
love.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Human nature,  I suppose,
subQuotationList: ['Human nature,  I suppose,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Yes, extremely,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, extremely,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: And how s Howards End looking?
subQuotationList: ['And how s Howards End looking?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It s let.
subQuotationList: ['It s let.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Really. And you wandering homeless in longhaired Chelsea? How strange
are the ways of Fate!
subQuotationList: ['Really. And you wandering homeless in longhaired Chelsea? How strange\nare the ways of Fate!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: No; it s let unfurnished. We ve moved.
subQuotationList: ['No; it s let unfurnished. We ve moved.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Why, I thought of you both as anchored there for ever. Evie never told
me.
subQuotationList: ['Why, I thought of you both as anchored there for ever. Evie never told\nme.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I dare say when you met Evie the thing wasn t settled. We only moved
a week ago. Paul has rather a feeling for the old place, and we held on
for him to have his holiday there; but, really, it is impossibly small.
Endless drawbacks. I forget whether you ve been up to it?
subQuotationList:
['I dare say when you met Evie the thing wasn t settled. We only moved
a week ago. Paul has rather a feeling for the old place, and we held on
for him to have his holiday there; but, really, it is impossibly small.
Endless drawbacks. I forget whether you ve been up to it?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: As far as the house, never.
subQuotationList: ['As far as the house, never.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Well, Howards End is one of those converted farms. They don t really
do, spend what you will on them. We messed away with a garage all among
the wych-elm roots, and last year we enclosed a bit of the meadow and
attempted a rockery. Evie got rather keen on Alpine plants. But it
didn t do--no, it didn t do. You remember, your sister will remember,
the farm with those abominable guinea-fowls, and the hedge that the old
woman never would cut properly, so that it all went thin at the
bottom. And, inside the house, the beams--and the staircase through a
door--picturesque enough, but not a place to live in.
subQuotationList:
['Well, Howards End is one of those converted farms. They don t really
do, spend what you will on them. We messed away with a garage all among
the wych-elm roots, and last year we enclosed a bit of the meadow and
attempted a rockery. Evie got rather keen on Alpine plants. But it
didn t do--no, it didn t do. You remember, your sister will remember,
the farm with those abominable guinea-fowls, and the hedge that the old
woman never would cut properly, so that it all went thin at the
bottom. And, inside the house, the beams--and the staircase through a
door--picturesque enough, but not a place to live in.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Full tide. And the position wasn t right
either. The neighbourhood s getting suburban. Either be in London or out
of it, I say; so we ve taken a house in Ducie Street, close to Sloane
Street, and a place right down in Shropshire--Oniton Grange. Ever heard
of Oniton? Do come and see us--right away from everywhere, up towards
Wales.
subQuotationList:
['Full tide. And the position wasn t right
either. The neighbourhood s getting suburban. Either be in London or out
of it, I say; so we ve taken a house in Ducie Street, close to Sloane
Street, and a place right down in Shropshire--Oniton Grange. Ever heard
of Oniton? Do come and see us--right away from everywhere, up towards
Wales.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
What a change! I can t imagine Howards End or Hilton
without you.
subQuotationList: ['What a change!', 'I can t imagine Howards End or Hilton\nwithout you.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Hilton isn t without us, Charles is there still.
subQuotationList: ['Hilton isn t without us,', 'Charles is there still.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Still? But I
thought he was still at Epsom. They were furnishing that Christmas--one
Christmas. How everything alters! I used to admire Mrs. Charles from our
windows very often. Wasn t it Epsom?
subQuotationList:
['Still?', 'But I
thought he was still at Epsom. They were furnishing that Christmas--one
Christmas. How everything alters! I used to admire Mrs. Charles from our
windows very often. Wasn t it Epsom?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes, but they moved eighteen months ago. Charles, the good chap
subQuotationList: ['Yes, but they moved eighteen months ago. Charles, the good chap']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
thought I should be lonely. I didn t want him to move,
but he would, and took a house at the other end of Hilton, down by
the Six Hills. He had a motor, too. There they all are, a very jolly
party--he and she and the two grandchildren.
subQuotationList:
['thought I should be lonely. I didn t want him to move,
but he would, and took a house at the other end of Hilton, down by
the Six Hills. He had a motor, too. There they all are, a very jolly
party--he and she and the two grandchildren.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I manage other people s affairs so much better than they manage them
themselves, When you moved out of
Howards End, I should have moved Mr. Charles Wilcox into it. I should
have kept so remarkable a place in the family.
subQuotationList:
['I manage other people s affairs so much better than they manage them
themselves,', 'When you moved out of
Howards End, I should have moved Mr. Charles Wilcox into it. I should
have kept so remarkable a place in the family.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: So it is, I haven t sold it, and don t mean to.
subQuotationList: ['So it is,', 'I haven t sold it, and don t mean to.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: No; but none of you are there.
subQuotationList: ['No; but none of you are there.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Oh, we ve got a splendid tenant--Hamar Bryce, an invalid. If
Charles ever wanted it--but he won t. Dolly is so dependent on modern
conveniences. No, we have all decided against Howards End. We like it in
a way, but now we feel that it is neither one thing nor the other. One
must have one thing or the other.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, we ve got a splendid tenant--Hamar Bryce, an invalid. If
Charles ever wanted it--but he won t. Dolly is so dependent on modern
conveniences. No, we have all decided against Howards End. We like it in
a way, but now we feel that it is neither one thing nor the other. One
must have one thing or the other.']
speaker: Henry
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Henry', 'Evie', 'Dolly'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Dolly'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Henry', 'Evie', 'Dolly'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Henry', 'Evie', 'Dolly'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Henry', 'Evie', 'Dolly']]]

quoteText:
And some people are lucky enough to have both. You re doing yourself
proud, Mr. Wilcox. My congratulations.
subQuotationList: ['And some people are lucky enough to have both. You re doing yourself\nproud, Mr. Wilcox. My congratulations.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: And mine,
subQuotationList: ['And mine,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Do remind Evie to come and see us--2 Wickham Place. We shan t be there
very long, either.
subQuotationList: ['Do remind Evie to come and see us--2 Wickham Place. We shan t be there\nvery long, either.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: You, too, on the move?
subQuotationList: ['You, too, on the move?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Next September,
subQuotationList: ['Next September,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Every one moving! Good-bye.
subQuotationList: ['Every one moving! Good-bye.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
What a prosperous vulgarian Mr. Wilcox has
grown! I have very little use for him in these days. However, he did
tell us about the Porphyrion. Let us write to Mr. Bast as soon as ever
we get home, and tell him to clear out of it at once.
subQuotationList:
['What a prosperous vulgarian Mr. Wilcox has
grown! I have very little use for him in these days. However, he did
tell us about the Porphyrion. Let us write to Mr. Bast as soon as ever
we get home, and tell him to clear out of it at once.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Do; yes, that s worth doing. Let us.
subQuotationList: ['Do; yes, that s worth doing. Let us.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Sugar?
subQuotationList: ['Sugar?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Cake? The big cake or the little deadlies? I m afraid
you thought my letter rather odd, but we ll explain--we aren t odd,
really--nor affected, really. We re over-expressive--that s all.
subQuotationList: ['Cake?', 'The big cake or the little deadlies? I m afraid\nyou thought my letter rather odd, but we ll explain--we aren t odd,\nreally--nor affected, really. We re over-expressive--that s all.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
The
more a lady has to say, the better,
subQuotationList: ['The\nmore a lady has to say, the better,']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Oh yes,
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Ladies brighten--
subQuotationList: ['Ladies brighten--']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Yes, I know. The darlings are regular sunbeams. Let me give you a
plate.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I know. The darlings are regular sunbeams. Let me give you a\nplate.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: How do you like your work?
subQuotationList: ['How do you like your work?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, well enough,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, well enough,']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Your company is the Porphyrion, isn t it?
subQuotationList: ['Your company is the Porphyrion, isn t it?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes, that s so.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, that s so.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
It s funny how things get
round.
subQuotationList: ['It s funny how things get\nround.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Why funny? It was written as large as life on your card, and considering we wrote
to you there, and that you replied on the stamped paper--
subQuotationList: ['Why funny?', 'It was written as large as life on your card, and considering we wrote\nto you there, and that you replied on the stamped paper--']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Would you call the Porphyrion one of the big Insurance Companies?
subQuotationList: ['Would you call the Porphyrion one of the big Insurance Companies?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It depends on what you call big.
subQuotationList: ['It depends on what you call big.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
I mean by big, a solid, well-established concern, that offers a
reasonably good career to its employes.
subQuotationList: ['I mean by big, a solid, well-established concern, that offers a\nreasonably good career to its employes.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I couldn t say--some would tell you one thing and others another, For my own part I only
believe half I hear. Not that even; it s safer. Those clever ones come
to the worse grief, I ve often noticed. Ah, you can t be too careful.
subQuotationList: ['I couldn t say--some would tell you one thing and others another,', 'For my own part', 'I only\nbelieve half I hear. Not that even; it s safer. Those clever ones come\nto the worse grief, I ve often noticed. Ah, you can t be too careful.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
I quite agree, and that s why I was curious to know; is it a solid,
well-established concern?
subQuotationList: ['I quite agree, and that s why I was curious to know; is it a solid,\nwell-established concern?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
We were told the Porphyrion s no go, We wanted to tell
you; that s why we wrote.
subQuotationList: ['We were told the Porphyrion s no go,', 'We wanted to tell\nyou; that s why we wrote.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: A friend of ours did think that it is insufficiently reinsured,
subQuotationList: ['A friend of ours did think that it is insufficiently reinsured,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: You can tell your friend, that he s quite wrong.
subQuotationList: ['You can tell your friend,', 'that he s quite wrong.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Oh, good!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, good!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Wrong, so to speak,
subQuotationList: ['Wrong, so to speak,']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: How  so to speak ?
subQuotationList: ['How  so to speak ?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I mean I wouldn t say he s right altogether.
subQuotationList: ['I mean I wouldn t say he s right altogether.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Then he is right partly,
subQuotationList: ['Then he is right partly,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Mr. Bast, I don t understand business, and I dare say my questions are
stupid, but can you tell me what makes a concern  right  or  wrong ?
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Bast, I don t understand business, and I dare say my questions are\nstupid, but can you tell me what makes a concern  right  or  wrong ?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Our friend, who is also a business man, was so positive. He said before
Christmas--
subQuotationList: ['Our friend, who is also a business man, was so positive. He said before\nChristmas--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
And advised you to clear out of it, But I don t see
why he should know better than you do.
subQuotationList: ['And advised you to clear out of it,', 'But I don t see\nwhy he should know better than you do.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
One can but see, as Ibsen says,  things
happen.
subQuotationList: ['One can but see,', 'as Ibsen says,  things\nhappen.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: So YOU like Carlyle
subQuotationList: ['So YOU like Carlyle']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, the dears! Oh, Evie, how too impossibly sweet!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, the dears! Oh, Evie, how too impossibly sweet!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: We brought the little fellows round,
subQuotationList: ['We brought the little fellows round,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I bred  em myself.
subQuotationList: ['I bred  em myself.']
speaker: Evie

quoteText: Oh, really! Mr. Bast, come and play with puppies.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, really! Mr. Bast, come and play with puppies.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I ve got to be going now,
subQuotationList: ['I ve got to be going now,']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: But play with puppies a little first.
subQuotationList: ['But play with puppies a little first.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: This is Ahab, that s Jezebel,
subQuotationList: ['This is Ahab, that s Jezebel,']
speaker: Evie

quoteText: I ve got to be going.
subQuotationList: ['I ve got to be going.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Mr. Wilcox, Mr. Ba--Must you be really? Good-bye!
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Wilcox, Mr. Ba--Must you be really? Good-bye!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Come again,
subQuotationList: ['Come again,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: No, I shan t; I knew it would be a failure.
subQuotationList: ['No, I shan t; I knew it would be a failure.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
I
call that a very rude remark. What do you want to turn on me like that
for?
subQuotationList: ['I\ncall that a very rude remark. What do you want to turn on me like that\nfor?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: You ask me why I turn on you?
subQuotationList: ['You ask me why I turn on you?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Helen

quoteText: What do you want to have me here for?
subQuotationList: ['What do you want to have me here for?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: To help you, you silly boy! And don t shout.
subQuotationList: ['To help you, you silly boy!', 'And don t shout.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I don t want your patronage. I don t want your tea. I was quite happy.
What do you want to unsettle me for?
subQuotationList: ['I don t want your patronage. I don t want your tea. I was quite happy.\nWhat do you want to unsettle me for?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
I put it
to this gentleman. I ask you, sir, am I to have my brain picked?
subQuotationList: ['I put it\nto this gentleman. I ask you, sir, am I to have my brain picked?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Are we intruding, Miss Schlegel? Can we be of
any use, or shall we go?
subQuotationList: ['Are we intruding, Miss Schlegel? Can we be of\nany use, or shall we go?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I m connected with a leading insurance company, sir. I receive what I
take to be an invitation from these--ladies
subQuotationList: ['I m connected with a leading insurance company, sir. I receive what I\ntake to be an invitation from these--ladies']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
I
come, and it s to have my brain picked. I ask you, is it fair?
subQuotationList: ['I\ncome, and it s to have my brain picked. I ask you, is it fair?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Highly unfair,
subQuotationList: ['Highly unfair,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
There, you hear that? Most unfair, the gentleman says. There! Not
content with
subQuotationList: ['There, you hear that? Most unfair, the gentleman says. There! Not\ncontent with']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: you can t deny it.
subQuotationList: ['you can t deny it.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
But as
soon as I m useful it s a very different thing.  Oh yes, send for him.
Cross-question him. Pick his brains.  Oh yes. Now, take me on the whole,
I m a quiet fellow: I m law-abiding, I don t wish any unpleasantness;
but I--I--
subQuotationList:
['But as
soon as I m useful it s a very different thing.  Oh yes, send for him.
Cross-question him. Pick his brains.  Oh yes. Now, take me on the whole,
I m a quiet fellow: I m law-abiding, I don t wish any unpleasantness;
but I--I--']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: You, you--you--
subQuotationList: ['You,', 'you--you--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: You are the man who tried to walk by the Pole Star.
subQuotationList: ['You are the man who tried to walk by the Pole Star.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: You saw the sunrise.
subQuotationList: ['You saw the sunrise.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
You tried to get away from the fogs that are stifling us all--away past
books and houses to the truth. You were looking for a real home.
subQuotationList: ['You tried to get away from the fogs that are stifling us all--away past\nbooks and houses to the truth. You were looking for a real home.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I fail to see the connection,
subQuotationList: ['I fail to see the connection,']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: So do I.
subQuotationList: ['So do I.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
You were that last Sunday--you are this
to-day. Mr. Bast! I and my sister have talked you over. We wanted to
help you; we also supposed you might help us. We did not have you here
out of charity--which bores us--but because we hoped there would be a
connection between last Sunday and other days. What is the good of your
stars and trees, your sunrise and the wind, if they do not enter into
our daily lives? They have never entered into mine, but into yours,
we thought--Haven t we all to struggle against life s daily greyness,
against pettiness, against mechanical cheerfulness, against suspicion?
I struggle by remembering my friends; others I have known by remembering
some place--some beloved place or tree--we thought you one of these.
subQuotationList:
['You were that last Sunday--you are this
to-day. Mr. Bast! I and my sister have talked you over. We wanted to
help you; we also supposed you might help us. We did not have you here
out of charity--which bores us--but because we hoped there would be a
connection between last Sunday and other days. What is the good of your
stars and trees, your sunrise and the wind, if they do not enter into
our daily lives? They have never entered into mine, but into yours,
we thought--Haven t we all to struggle against life s daily greyness,
against pettiness, against mechanical cheerfulness, against suspicion?
I struggle by remembering my friends; others I have known by remembering
some place--some beloved place or tree--we thought you one of these.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Of course, if there s been any misunderstanding, all
I can do is to go. But I beg to state-- You were picking my
brain for official information--I can prove it--I--
subQuotationList: ['Of course, if there s been any misunderstanding,', 'all\nI can do is to go. But I beg to state--', 'You were picking my\nbrain for official information--I can prove it--I--']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Can I help you now? May I have
one quiet word with him in the hall?
subQuotationList: ['Can I help you now?', 'May I have\none quiet word with him in the hall?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Helen, go after him--do anything--anything--to make the noodle
understand.
subQuotationList: ['Helen, go after him--do anything--anything--to make the noodle\nunderstand.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But really-- Ought she to?
subQuotationList: ['But really--', 'Ought she to?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I would have chimed in, but I felt that you could polish
him off for yourselves--I didn t interfere. You were splendid, Miss
Schlegel--absolutely splendid. You can take my word for it, but there
are very few women who could have managed him.
subQuotationList:
['I would have chimed in, but I felt that you could polish
him off for yourselves--I didn t interfere. You were splendid, Miss
Schlegel--absolutely splendid. You can take my word for it, but there
are very few women who could have managed him.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Oh yes,
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Bowling him over with those long sentences was what fetched me,
subQuotationList: ['Bowling him over with those long sentences was what fetched me,']
speaker: Evie

quoteText:
Yes, indeed, all that part about  mechanical
cheerfulness --oh, fine!
subQuotationList: ['Yes, indeed,', 'all that part about  mechanical\ncheerfulness --oh, fine!']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I m very sorry, He s a nice
creature really. I cannot think what set him off. It has been most
unpleasant for you.
