subQuotationList: ['I m very sorry,', 'He s a nice\ncreature really. I cannot think what set him off. It has been most\nunpleasant for you.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, I didn t mind.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I didn t mind.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Oughtn t you
really to be more careful?
subQuotationList: ['Oughtn t you\nreally to be more careful?']
speaker: Henry
referringExpression: He asked if he might speak as an old friend and permission given said

quoteText:
Do you
realise that it s all your fault? You re responsible.
subQuotationList: ['Do you\nrealise that it s all your fault?', 'You re responsible.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I?
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
This is the young man whom we were to warn against the Porphyrion. We
warn him, and--look!
subQuotationList: ['This is the young man whom we were to warn against the Porphyrion. We\nwarn him, and--look!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I hardly consider that a fair deduction,
subQuotationList: ['I hardly consider that a fair deduction,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Obviously unfair, I was only thinking how tangled
things are. It s our fault mostly--neither yours nor his.
subQuotationList: ['Obviously unfair,', 'I was only thinking how tangled\nthings are. It s our fault mostly--neither yours nor his.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Not his?
subQuotationList: ['Not his?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: No.
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Miss Schlegel, you are too kind.
subQuotationList: ['Miss Schlegel, you are too kind.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Yes, indeed,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, indeed,']
speaker: Evie

quoteText:
You behave much too well to people, and then they impose on you. I know
the world and that type of man, and as soon as I entered the room I saw
you had not been treating him properly. You must keep that type at a
distance. Otherwise they forget themselves. Sad, but true. They aren t
our sort, and one must face the fact.
subQuotationList:
['You behave much too well to people, and then they impose on you. I know
the world and that type of man, and as soon as I entered the room I saw
you had not been treating him properly. You must keep that type at a
distance. Otherwise they forget themselves. Sad, but true. They aren t
our sort, and one must face the fact.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Ye--es.
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Do admit that we should never have had the outburst if he was a
gentleman.
subQuotationList: ['Do admit that we should never have had the outburst if he was a\ngentleman.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I admit it willingly, A gentleman would have kept his suspicions to himself.
subQuotationList: ['I admit it willingly,', 'A gentleman would have kept his suspicions to himself.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What did he suspect you of?
subQuotationList: ['What did he suspect you of?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Of wanting to make money out of him.
subQuotationList: ['Of wanting to make money out of him.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Intolerable brute! But how were you to benefit?
subQuotationList: ['Intolerable brute! But how were you to benefit?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Exactly. How indeed! Just horrible, corroding suspicion. One touch of
thought or of goodwill would have brushed it away. Just the senseless
fear that does make men intolerable brutes.
subQuotationList: ['Exactly. How indeed! Just horrible, corroding suspicion. One touch of\nthought or of goodwill would have brushed it away. Just the senseless\nfear that does make men intolerable brutes.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I come back to my original point. You ought to be more careful, Miss
Schlegel. Your servants ought to have orders not to let such people in.
subQuotationList: ['I come back to my original point. You ought to be more careful, Miss\nSchlegel. Your servants ought to have orders not to let such people in.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Let me explain exactly why we like this man,
and want to see him again.
subQuotationList: ['Let me explain exactly why we like this man,\nand want to see him again.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: That s your clever way of talking. I shall never believe you like him.
subQuotationList: ['That s your clever way of talking. I shall never believe you like him.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I do. Firstly, because he cares for physical adventure, just as you
do. Yes, you go motoring and shooting; he would like to go camping out.
Secondly, he cares for something special IN adventure. It is quickest to
call that special something poetry--
subQuotationList:
['I do. Firstly, because he cares for physical adventure, just as you
do. Yes, you go motoring and shooting; he would like to go camping out.
Secondly, he cares for something special IN adventure. It is quickest to
call that special something poetry--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, he s one of that writer sort.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, he s one of that writer sort.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
No--oh no! I mean he may be, but it would be loathsome stuff. His brain
is filled with the husks of books, culture--horrible; we want him to
wash out his brain and go to the real thing. We want to show him how
he may get upsides with life. As I said, either friends or the country,
some
subQuotationList:
['No--oh no! I mean he may be, but it would be loathsome stuff. His brain
is filled with the husks of books, culture--horrible; we want him to
wash out his brain and go to the real thing. We want to show him how
he may get upsides with life. As I said, either friends or the country,
some']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
either some very dear person or some very dear
place seems necessary to relieve life s daily grey, and to show that it
is grey. If possible, one should have both.
subQuotationList: ['either some very dear person or some very dear\nplace seems necessary to relieve life s daily grey, and to show that it\nis grey. If possible, one should have both.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Your mistake is this, and it is a very common mistake. This young
bounder has a life of his own. What right have you to conclude it is an
unsuccessful life, or, as you call it,  grey ?
subQuotationList: ['Your mistake is this, and it is a very common mistake. This young\nbounder has a life of his own. What right have you to conclude it is an\nunsuccessful life, or, as you call it,  grey ?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Because--
subQuotationList: ['Because--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
One minute. You know nothing about him. He probably has his own
joys and interests--wife, children, snug little home. That s where we
practical fellows
subQuotationList: ['One minute. You know nothing about him. He probably has his own\njoys and interests--wife, children, snug little home. That s where we\npractical fellows']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
are more tolerant than you intellectuals.
We live and let live, and assume that things are jogging on fairly well
elsewhere, and that the ordinary plain man may be trusted to look after
his own affairs. I quite grant--I look at the faces of the clerks in my
own office, and observe them to be dull, but I don t know what s going
on beneath. So, by the way, with London. I have heard you rail against
London, Miss Schlegel, and it seems a funny thing to say but I was very
angry with you. What do you know about London? You only see civilisation
from the outside. I don t say in your case, but in too many cases that
attitude leads to morbidity, discontent, and Socialism.
subQuotationList:
['are more tolerant than you intellectuals.
We live and let live, and assume that things are jogging on fairly well
elsewhere, and that the ordinary plain man may be trusted to look after
his own affairs. I quite grant--I look at the faces of the clerks in my
own office, and observe them to be dull, but I don t know what s going
on beneath. So, by the way, with London. I have heard you rail against
London, Miss Schlegel, and it seems a funny thing to say but I was very
angry with you. What do you know about London? You only see civilisation
from the outside. I don t say in your case, but in too many cases that
attitude leads to morbidity, discontent, and Socialism.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
His wife is an old bore, He never came home last
Saturday night because he wanted to be alone, and she thought he was
with us.
subQuotationList: ['His wife is an old bore,', 'He never came home last\nSaturday night because he wanted to be alone, and she thought he was\nwith us.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: With YOU?
subQuotationList: ['With YOU?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
He hasn t got the cosy home that you assumed. He
needs outside interests.
subQuotationList: ['He hasn t got the cosy home that you assumed. He\nneeds outside interests.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Naughty young man!
subQuotationList: ['Naughty young man!']
speaker: Evie

quoteText:
Naughty? When
you re married Miss Wilcox, won t you want outside interests?
subQuotationList: ['Naughty?', 'When\nyou re married Miss Wilcox, won t you want outside interests?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: He has apparently got them,
subQuotationList: ['He has apparently got them,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Yes, indeed, father.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, indeed, father.']
speaker: Evie

quoteText: He was tramping in Surrey, if you mean that,
subQuotationList: ['He was tramping in Surrey, if you mean that,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, I dare say!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I dare say!']
speaker: Evie

quoteText: Miss Wilcox, he was!
subQuotationList: ['Miss Wilcox, he was!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: He said so, and about such a thing he wouldn t lie.
subQuotationList: ['He said so, and about such a thing he wouldn t lie.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
That s where I differ from you. Men lie about their positions and
prospects, but not about a thing of that sort.
subQuotationList: ['That s where I differ from you. Men lie about their positions and\nprospects, but not about a thing of that sort.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Miss Schlegel, excuse me, but I know the type.
subQuotationList: ['Miss Schlegel, excuse me, but I know the type.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I said before--he isn t a type. He cares about adventures rightly. He s
certain that our smug existence isn t all. He s vulgar and hysterical
and bookish, but don t think that sums him up. There s manhood in him as
well. Yes, that s what I m trying to say. He s a real man.
subQuotationList:
['I said before--he isn t a type. He cares about adventures rightly. He s
certain that our smug existence isn t all. He s vulgar and hysterical
and bookish, but don t think that sums him up. There s manhood in him as
well. Yes, that s what I m trying to say. He s a real man.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Miss Schlegel, you re a pair of dear creatures, but you really MUST be
careful in this uncharitable world. What does your brother say?
subQuotationList: ['Miss Schlegel, you re a pair of dear creatures, but you really MUST be\ncareful in this uncharitable world. What does your brother say?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I forget.
subQuotationList: ['I forget.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Surely he has some opinion?
subQuotationList: ['Surely he has some opinion?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: He laughs, if I remember correctly.
subQuotationList: ['He laughs, if I remember correctly.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: He s very clever, isn t he?
subQuotationList: ['He s very clever, isn t he?']
speaker: Evie

quoteText: Yes, pretty well--but I wonder what Helen s doing.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, pretty well--but I wonder what Helen s doing.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: She is very young to undertake this sort of thing,
subQuotationList: ['She is very young to undertake this sort of thing,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Helen!
subQuotationList: ['Helen!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes!
speaker: Helen

quoteText: You in there?
subQuotationList: ['You in there?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes--he s gone some time.
subQuotationList: ['Yes--he s gone some time.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Why, you re all alone,
subQuotationList: ['Why, you re all alone,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes--it s all right, Meg. Poor, poor creature--
subQuotationList: ['Yes--it s all right, Meg. Poor, poor creature--']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Come back to the Wilcoxes and tell me later--Mr. W much concerned, and
slightly titillated.
subQuotationList: ['Come back to the Wilcoxes and tell me later--Mr. W much concerned, and\nslightly titillated.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Oh, I ve no patience with him. I hate him. Poor dear Mr. Bast! he
wanted to talk literature, and we would talk business. Such a muddle of
a man, and yet so worth pulling through. I like him extraordinarily.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I ve no patience with him. I hate him. Poor dear Mr. Bast! he\nwanted to talk literature, and we would talk business. Such a muddle of\na man, and yet so worth pulling through. I like him extraordinarily.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Well done, but come into the drawing-room
now, and don t talk about him to the Wilcoxes. Make light of the whole
thing.
subQuotationList: ['Well done,', 'but come into the drawing-room\nnow, and don t talk about him to the Wilcoxes. Make light of the whole\nthing.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: He s gone with my blessing, and now for puppies.
subQuotationList: ['He s gone with my blessing,', 'and now for puppies.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I am really concerned at the way those girls go on. They are as clever
as you make  em, but unpractical--God bless me! One of these days
they ll go too far. Girls like that oughtn t to live alone in London.
Until they marry, they ought to have some one to look after them. We
must look in more often--we re better than no one. You like them, don t
you, Evie?
subQuotationList:
['I am really concerned at the way those girls go on. They are as clever
as you make  em, but unpractical--God bless me! One of these days
they ll go too far. Girls like that oughtn t to live alone in London.
Until they marry, they ought to have some one to look after them. We
must look in more often--we re better than no one. You like them, don t
you, Evie?']
speaker: Henry
referringExpression: Mr Wilcox said to his daughter

quoteText:
Helen s right enough, but I can t stand the toothy one.
And I shouldn t have called either of them girls.
subQuotationList: ['Helen s right enough, but I can t stand the toothy one.\nAnd I shouldn t have called either of them girls.']
speaker: Evie

quoteText: simply must,
subQuotationList: ['simply must,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I thought I d get round if I could, Evie told me of her
little plan, so I just slipped in and secured a table. Always secure
a table first. Evie, don t pretend you want to sit by your old father,
because you don t. Miss Schlegel, come in my side, out of pity. My
goodness, but you look tired! Been worrying round after your young
clerks?
subQuotationList:
['I thought I d get round if I could,', 'Evie told me of her
little plan, so I just slipped in and secured a table. Always secure
a table first. Evie, don t pretend you want to sit by your old father,
because you don t. Miss Schlegel, come in my side, out of pity. My
goodness, but you look tired! Been worrying round after your young
clerks?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
No, after houses, I m
hungry, not tired; I want to eat heaps.
subQuotationList: ['No, after houses,', 'I m\nhungry, not tired; I want to eat heaps.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: That s good. What ll you have?
subQuotationList: ['That s good. What ll you have?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Fish pie,
subQuotationList: ['Fish pie,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Fish pie! Fancy coming for fish pie to Simpson s. It s not a bit the
thing to go for here.
subQuotationList: ['Fish pie! Fancy coming for fish pie to Simpson s. It s not a bit the\nthing to go for here.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Go for something for me, then,
subQuotationList: ['Go for something for me, then,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Saddle of mutton, and cider to
drink. That s the type of thing. I like this place, for a joke, once in
a way. It is so thoroughly Old English. Don t you agree?
subQuotationList: ['Saddle of mutton,', 'and cider to\ndrink. That s the type of thing. I like this place, for a joke, once in\na way. It is so thoroughly Old English. Don t you agree?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Yes,
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It s a golden rule to tip the carver. Tip everywhere s my motto.
subQuotationList: ['It s a golden rule to tip the carver. Tip everywhere s my motto.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Perhaps it does make life more human.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps it does make life more human.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Then the fellows know one again. Especially in the East, if you tip,
they remember you from year s end to year s end.
subQuotationList: ['Then the fellows know one again. Especially in the East, if you tip,\nthey remember you from year s end to year s end.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Have you been in the East?
subQuotationList: ['Have you been in the East?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Oh, Greece and the Levant. I used to go out for sport and business to
Cyprus; some military society of a sort there. A few piastres, properly
distributed, help to keep one s memory green. But you, of course, think
this shockingly cynical. How s your discussion society getting on? Any
new Utopias lately?
subQuotationList:
['Oh, Greece and the Levant. I used to go out for sport and business to
Cyprus; some military society of a sort there. A few piastres, properly
distributed, help to keep one s memory green. But you, of course, think
this shockingly cynical. How s your discussion society getting on? Any
new Utopias lately?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
No, I m house-hunting, Mr. Wilcox, as I ve already told you once. Do
you know of any houses?
subQuotationList: ['No, I m house-hunting, Mr. Wilcox, as I ve already told you once. Do\nyou know of any houses?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Afraid I don t.
subQuotationList: ['Afraid I don t.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Well, what s the point of being practical if you can t find two
distressed females a house? We merely want a small house with large
rooms, and plenty of them.
subQuotationList: ['Well, what s the point of being practical if you can t find two\ndistressed females a house? We merely want a small house with large\nrooms, and plenty of them.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Evie, I like that! Miss Schlegel expects me to turn house-agent for
her!
subQuotationList: ['Evie, I like that! Miss Schlegel expects me to turn house-agent for\nher!']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: What s that, father?
subQuotationList: ['What s that, father?']
speaker: Evie

quoteText: I want a new home in September, and some one must find it. I can t.
subQuotationList: ['I want a new home in September, and some one must find it. I can t.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Percy, do you know of anything?
subQuotationList: ['Percy, do you know of anything?']
speaker: Evie

quoteText: I can t say I do,
subQuotationList: ['I can t say I do,']
speaker: Mr. Cahill

quoteText: How like you! You re never any good.
subQuotationList: ['How like you! You re never any good.']
speaker: Evie

quoteText: Never any good. Just listen to her! Never any good. Oh, come!
subQuotationList: ['Never any good. Just listen to her! Never any good. Oh, come!']
speaker: Mr. Cahill

quoteText: Well, you aren t. Miss Schlegel, is he?
subQuotationList: ['Well, you aren t. Miss Schlegel, is he?']
speaker: Evie

quoteText:
Next time, you
shall come to lunch with me at Mr. Eustace Miles s.
subQuotationList: ['Next time,', 'you\nshall come to lunch with me at Mr. Eustace Miles s.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: With pleasure.
subQuotationList: ['With pleasure.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
No, you d hate it, It s all proteids and body buildings, and people come up to
you and beg your pardon, but you have such a beautiful aura.
subQuotationList: ['No, you d hate it,', 'It s all proteids and body buildings, and people come up to\nyou and beg your pardon, but you have such a beautiful aura.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: A what?
subQuotationList: ['A what?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Never heard of an aura? Oh, happy, happy man! I scrub at mine for
hours. Nor of an astral plane?
subQuotationList: ['Never heard of an aura? Oh, happy, happy man! I scrub at mine for\nhours. Nor of an astral plane?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Just so. Luckily it was Helen s aura, not mine, and she had to
chaperone it and do the politenesses. I just sat with my handkerchief in
my mouth till the man went.
subQuotationList: ['Just so. Luckily it was Helen s aura, not mine, and she had to\nchaperone it and do the politenesses. I just sat with my handkerchief in\nmy mouth till the man went.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Funny experiences seem to come to you two girls. No one s ever asked me
about my--what d ye call it? Perhaps I ve not got one.
subQuotationList: ['Funny experiences seem to come to you two girls. No one s ever asked me\nabout my--what d ye call it? Perhaps I ve not got one.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
You re bound to have one, but it may be such a terrible colour that no
one dares mention it.
subQuotationList: ['You re bound to have one, but it may be such a terrible colour that no\none dares mention it.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Tell me, though, Miss Schlegel, do you really believe in the
supernatural and all that?
subQuotationList: ['Tell me, though, Miss Schlegel, do you really believe in the\nsupernatural and all that?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Too difficult a question.
subQuotationList: ['Too difficult a question.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Why s that? Gruyere or Stilton?
subQuotationList: ['Why s that? Gruyere or Stilton?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Gruyere, please.
subQuotationList: ['Gruyere, please.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Better have Stilton.
subQuotationList: ['Better have Stilton.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Stilton. Because, though I don t believe in auras, and think
Theosophy s only a halfway-house--
subQuotationList: ['Stilton. Because, though I don t believe in auras, and think\nTheosophy s only a halfway-house--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: --Yet there may be something in it all the same,
subQuotationList: ['--Yet there may be something in it all the same,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Not even that. It may be halfway in the wrong direction. I can t
explain. I don t believe in all these fads, and yet I don t like saying
that I don t believe in them.
subQuotationList: ['Not even that. It may be halfway in the wrong direction. I can t\nexplain. I don t believe in all these fads, and yet I don t like saying\nthat I don t believe in them.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
So you wouldn t give me your word that
you DON T hold with astral bodies and all the rest of it?
subQuotationList: ['So you wouldn t give me your word that\nyou DON T hold with astral bodies and all the rest of it?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I could, Indeed, I will. When I talked about scrubbing my aura, I was
only trying to be funny. But why do you want this settled?
subQuotationList: ['I could,', 'Indeed, I will. When I talked about scrubbing my aura, I was\nonly trying to be funny. But why do you want this settled?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I don t know.
subQuotationList: ['I don t know.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Now, Mr. Wilcox, you do know.
subQuotationList: ['Now, Mr. Wilcox, you do know.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: How s your house?
subQuotationList: ['How s your house?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Much the same as when you honoured it last week.
subQuotationList: ['Much the same as when you honoured it last week.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I don t mean Ducie Street. Howards End, of course.
subQuotationList: ['I don t mean Ducie Street. Howards End, of course.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Why  of course ?
subQuotationList: ['Why  of course ?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Can t you turn out your tenant and let it to us? We re nearly demented.
subQuotationList: ['Can t you turn out your tenant and let it to us? We re nearly demented.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Let me think. I wish I could help you. But I thought you wanted to be
in town. One bit of advice: fix your district, then fix your price, and
then don t budge. That s how I got both Ducie Street and Oniton. I said
to myself,  I mean to be exactly here,  and I was, and Oniton s a place
in a thousand.
subQuotationList:
['Let me think. I wish I could help you. But I thought you wanted to be
in town. One bit of advice: fix your district, then fix your price, and
then don t budge. That s how I got both Ducie Street and Oniton. I said
to myself,  I mean to be exactly here,  and I was, and Oniton s a place
in a thousand.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
But I do budge. Gentlemen seem to mesmerise houses--cow them with an
eye, and up they come, trembling. Ladies can t. It s the houses that are
mesmerising me. I ve no control over the saucy things. Houses are alive.
No?
subQuotationList:
['But I do budge. Gentlemen seem to mesmerise houses--cow them with an
eye, and up they come, trembling. Ladies can t. It s the houses that are
mesmerising me. I ve no control over the saucy things. Houses are alive.
No?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I m out of my depth, Didn t you talk rather like
that to your office boy?
subQuotationList: ['I m out of my depth,', 'Didn t you talk rather like\nthat to your office boy?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Did I?--I mean I did, more or less. I talk the same way to every
one--or try to.
subQuotationList: ['Did I?--I mean I did, more or less. I talk the same way to every\none--or try to.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes, I know. And how much of it do you suppose he understood?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I know. And how much of it do you suppose he understood?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
That s his lookout. I don t believe in suiting my conversation to my
company. One can doubtless hit upon some medium of exchange that seems
to do well enough, but it s no more like the real thing than money
is like food. There s no nourishment in it. You pass it to the lower
classes, and they pass it back to you, and this you call  social
intercourse  or  mutual endeavour,  when it s mutual priggishness if
it s anything. Our friends at Chelsea don t see this. They say one ought
to be at all costs intelligible, and sacrifice--
subQuotationList:
['That s his lookout. I don t believe in suiting my conversation to my
company. One can doubtless hit upon some medium of exchange that seems
to do well enough, but it s no more like the real thing than money
is like food. There s no nourishment in it. You pass it to the lower
classes, and they pass it back to you, and this you call  social
intercourse  or  mutual endeavour,  when it s mutual priggishness if
it s anything. Our friends at Chelsea don t see this. They say one ought
to be at all costs intelligible, and sacrifice--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Lower classes, Well, you do admit that there are rich and poor.
That s something.
subQuotationList: ['Lower classes,', 'Well, you do admit that there are rich and poor.\nThat s something.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
You do admit that, if wealth was divided up equally, in a few years
there would be rich and poor again just the same. The hard-working man
would come to the top, the wastrel sink to the bottom.
subQuotationList: ['You do admit that, if wealth was divided up equally, in a few years\nthere would be rich and poor again just the same. The hard-working man\nwould come to the top, the wastrel sink to the bottom.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Every one admits that.
subQuotationList: ['Every one admits that.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Your Socialists don t.
subQuotationList: ['Your Socialists don t.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
My Socialists do. Yours mayn t; but I strongly suspect yours of being
not Socialists, but ninepins, which you have constructed for your own
amusement. I can t imagine any living creature who would bowl over quite
so easily.
subQuotationList:
['My Socialists do. Yours mayn t; but I strongly suspect yours of being
not Socialists, but ninepins, which you have constructed for your own
amusement. I can t imagine any living creature who would bowl over quite
so easily.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I don t care. You ve made two damaging admissions, and I m
heartily with you in both.
subQuotationList: ['I don t care. You ve made two damaging admissions, and I m\nheartily with you in both.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: You needn t go though--
subQuotationList: ['You needn t go though--']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
I needn t, but hadn t I better? It s really getting rather serious. We
let chance after chance slip, and the end of it is we shall be bundled
out bag and baggage into the street. We don t know what we WANT, that s
the mischief with us--
subQuotationList:
['I needn t, but hadn t I better? It s really getting rather serious. We
let chance after chance slip, and the end of it is we shall be bundled
out bag and baggage into the street. We don t know what we WANT, that s
the mischief with us--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: No, we have no real ties,
subQuotationList: ['No, we have no real ties,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Shan t I go up to town to-day, take the house if it s the least
possible, and then come down by the afternoon train to-morrow, and start
enjoying myself. I shall be no fun to myself or to others until this
business is off my mind.
subQuotationList:
['Shan t I go up to town to-day, take the house if it s the least
possible, and then come down by the afternoon train to-morrow, and start
enjoying myself. I shall be no fun to myself or to others until this
business is off my mind.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But you won t do anything rash, Margaret?
subQuotationList: ['But you won t do anything rash, Margaret?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: There s nothing rash to do.
subQuotationList: ['There s nothing rash to do.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Who ARE the Wilcoxes?
subQuotationList: ['Who ARE the Wilcoxes?']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
I don t MANAGE the Wilcoxes; I don t see where they come
IN.
subQuotationList: ['I don t MANAGE the Wilcoxes; I don t see where they come\nIN.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
No more do I, It s funny that we just don t lose sight
of them. Out of all our hotel acquaintances, Mr. Wilcox is the only one
who has stuck. It is now over three years, and we have drifted away from
far more interesting people in that time.
subQuotationList:
['No more do I,', 'It s funny that we just don t lose sight
of them. Out of all our hotel acquaintances, Mr. Wilcox is the only one
who has stuck. It is now over three years, and we have drifted away from
far more interesting people in that time.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Interesting people don t get one houses.
subQuotationList: ['Interesting people don t get one houses.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Meg, if you start in your honest-English vein, I shall throw the
treacle at you.
subQuotationList: ['Meg, if you start in your honest-English vein, I shall throw the\ntreacle at you.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
It s a better vein than the cosmopolitan, Now, children, which is it to be? You know the Ducie Street house.
Shall I say yes or shall I say no? Tibby love--which? I m specially
anxious to pin you both.
subQuotationList: ['It s a better vein than the cosmopolitan,', 'Now, children, which is it to be? You know the Ducie Street house.\nShall I say yes or shall I say no? Tibby love--which? I m specially\nanxious to pin you both.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It depends on nothing of the sort. Say  yes.
subQuotationList: ['It depends on nothing of the sort. Say  yes.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I think, that our
race is degenerating. We cannot settle even this little thing; what will
it be like when we have to settle a big one?
subQuotationList: ['I think,', 'that our\nrace is degenerating. We cannot settle even this little thing; what will\nit be like when we have to settle a big one?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It will be as easy as eating,
subQuotationList: ['It will be as easy as eating,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I was thinking of father. How could he settle to leave Germany as he
did, when he had fought for it as a young man, and all his feelings
and friends were Prussian? How could he break loose with Patriotism and
begin aiming at something else? It would have killed me. When he was
nearly forty he could change countries and ideals--and we, at our age,
can t change houses. It s humiliating.
subQuotationList:
['I was thinking of father. How could he settle to leave Germany as he
did, when he had fought for it as a young man, and all his feelings
and friends were Prussian? How could he break loose with Patriotism and
begin aiming at something else? It would have killed me. When he was
nearly forty he could change countries and ideals--and we, at our age,
can t change houses. It s humiliating.']
speaker: Margaret
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Ernst'], ['Uncle Ernst'], ['Uncle Ernst'], ['Uncle Ernst'], ['Uncle Ernst'], ['Uncle Ernst'], ['Uncle Ernst'], ['Uncle Ernst'], ['Margaret', 'Tibby', 'Helen']]]

quoteText:
Your father may have been able to change countries, and that may or may not be a good thing. But he could
change houses no better than you can, in fact, much worse. Never shall I
forget what poor Emily suffered in the move from Manchester.
subQuotationList: ['Your father may have been able to change countries,', 'and that may or may not be a good thing. But he could\nchange houses no better than you can, in fact, much worse. Never shall I\nforget what poor Emily suffered in the move from Manchester.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
I knew it, I told you so. It is the little things one
bungles at. The big, real ones are nothing when they come.
subQuotationList: ['I knew it,', 'I told you so. It is the little things one\nbungles at. The big, real ones are nothing when they come.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Bungle, my dear! You are too little to recollect--in fact, you weren t
there. But the furniture was actually in the vans and on the move
before the lease for Wickham Place was signed, and Emily took train with
baby--who was Margaret then--and the smaller luggage for London, without
so much as knowing where her new home would be. Getting away from that
house may be hard, but it is nothing to the misery that we all went
through getting you into it.
subQuotationList:
['Bungle, my dear! You are too little to recollect--in fact, you weren t
there. But the furniture was actually in the vans and on the move
before the lease for Wickham Place was signed, and Emily took train with
baby--who was Margaret then--and the smaller luggage for London, without
so much as knowing where her new home would be. Getting away from that
house may be hard, but it is nothing to the misery that we all went
through getting you into it.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
And that s the man who beat the Austrians, and the Danes, and the
French, and who beat the Germans that were inside himself. And we re
like him.
subQuotationList: ['And that s the man who beat the Austrians, and the Danes, and the\nFrench, and who beat the Germans that were inside himself. And we re\nlike him.']
speaker: Helen
referringExpression: Helen with her mouth full cried

quoteText:
Speak for yourself, Remember that I am cosmopolitan,
please.
subQuotationList: ['Speak for yourself,', 'Remember that I am cosmopolitan,\nplease.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: Helen may be right.
subQuotationList: ['Helen may be right.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Of course she s right,
subQuotationList: ['Of course she s right,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
This is awfully kind of you, but I m afraid it s not going
to do. The house has not been built that suits the Schlegel family.
subQuotationList: ['This is awfully kind of you,', 'but I m afraid it s not going\nto do. The house has not been built that suits the Schlegel family.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What! Have you come up determined not to deal?
subQuotationList: ['What! Have you come up determined not to deal?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Not exactly.
subQuotationList: ['Not exactly.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Not exactly? In that case let s be starting.
subQuotationList: ['Not exactly? In that case let s be starting.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Presumably it s very beautiful, How do you like it, Crane?
subQuotationList: ['Presumably it s very beautiful,', 'How do you like it, Crane?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Come, let s be starting, How on earth did you know
that my chauffeur was called Crane?
subQuotationList: ['Come, let s be starting,', 'How on earth did you know\nthat my chauffeur was called Crane?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Why, I know Crane; I ve been for a drive with Evie once. I know that
you ve got a parlourmaid called Milton. I know all sorts of things.
subQuotationList: ['Why, I know Crane; I ve been for a drive with Evie once. I know that\nyou ve got a parlourmaid called Milton. I know all sorts of things.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Evie! You won t see her. She s gone out
with Cahill. It s no fun, I can tell you, being left so much alone. I ve
got my work all day--indeed, a great deal too much of it--but when I
come home in the evening, I tell you, I can t stand the house.
subQuotationList:
['Evie!', 'You won t see her. She s gone out
with Cahill. It s no fun, I can tell you, being left so much alone. I ve
got my work all day--indeed, a great deal too much of it--but when I
come home in the evening, I tell you, I can t stand the house.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
In my absurd way, I m lonely too, It s
heart-breaking to leave one s old home. I scarcely remember anything
before Wickham Place, and Helen and Tibby were born there. Helen says--
subQuotationList: ['In my absurd way, I m lonely too,', 'It s\nheart-breaking to leave one s old home. I scarcely remember anything\nbefore Wickham Place, and Helen and Tibby were born there. Helen says--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: You, too, feel lonely?
subQuotationList: ['You, too, feel lonely?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Horribly. Hullo, Parliament s back!
subQuotationList: ['Horribly. Hullo, Parliament s back!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes, they are talking again, But you were going to say--
subQuotationList: ['Yes, they are talking again,', 'But you were going to say--']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Only some rubbish about furniture. Helen says it alone endures while
men and houses perish, and that in the end the world will be a desert of
chairs and sofas--just imagine it!--rolling through infinity with no one
to sit upon them.
subQuotationList:
['Only some rubbish about furniture. Helen says it alone endures while
men and houses perish, and that in the end the world will be a desert of
chairs and sofas--just imagine it!--rolling through infinity with no one
to sit upon them.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Your sister always likes her little joke.
subQuotationList: ['Your sister always likes her little joke.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
She says  Yes,  my brother says `No,  to Ducie Street. It s no fun
helping us, Mr. Wilcox, I assure you.
subQuotationList: ['She says  Yes,  my brother says `No,  to Ducie Street. It s no fun\nhelping us, Mr. Wilcox, I assure you.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: You are not as unpractical as you pretend. I shall never believe it.
subQuotationList: ['You are not as unpractical as you pretend. I shall never believe it.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: At all events you responded to my telegram promptly,
subQuotationList: ['At all events you responded to my telegram promptly,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Oh, even I know a good thing when I see it.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, even I know a good thing when I see it.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I m glad you don t despise the goods of this world.
subQuotationList: ['I m glad you don t despise the goods of this world.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Heavens, no! Only idiots and prigs do that.
subQuotationList: ['Heavens, no! Only idiots and prigs do that.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I am glad, very glad, There is so much cant talked in
would-be intellectual circles. I am glad you don t share it. Self-denial
is all very well as a means of strengthening the character. But I can t
stand those people who run down comforts. They have usually some axe to
grind. Can you?
subQuotationList:
['I am glad, very glad,', 'There is so much cant talked in
would-be intellectual circles. I am glad you don t share it. Self-denial
is all very well as a means of strengthening the character. But I can t
stand those people who run down comforts. They have usually some axe to
grind. Can you?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Comforts are of two kinds, those we can share with others, like fire, weather, or music; and
those we can t--food, food, for instance. It depends.
subQuotationList: ['Comforts are of two kinds,', 'those we can share with others, like fire, weather, or music; and\nthose we can t--food, food, for instance. It depends.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I mean reasonable comforts, of course. I shouldn t like to think that
you--
subQuotationList: ['I mean reasonable comforts, of course. I shouldn t like to think that\nyou--']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I want to go over the whole house, As soon as I get back to Swanage, which will be to-morrow afternoon,
I ll talk it over once more with Helen and Tibby, and wire you  yes  or
 no.
subQuotationList: ['I want to go over the whole house,', 'As soon as I get back to Swanage, which will be to-morrow afternoon,\nI ll talk it over once more with Helen and Tibby, and wire you  yes  or\n no.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Right. The dining-room.
subQuotationList: ['Right. The dining-room.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Now the entrance-hall.
subQuotationList: ['Now the entrance-hall.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Here we fellows smoke.
subQuotationList: ['Here we fellows smoke.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Oh, jolly!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, jolly!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
You do like it? It s all rubbish not making
oneself comfortable. Isn t it?
subQuotationList: ['You do like it?', 'It s all rubbish not making\noneself comfortable. Isn t it?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Ye--es. Semi-rubbish. Are those Cruikshanks?
subQuotationList: ['Ye--es. Semi-rubbish. Are those Cruikshanks?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Gillrays. Shall we go on upstairs?
subQuotationList: ['Gillrays. Shall we go on upstairs?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Does all this furniture come from Howards End?
subQuotationList: ['Does all this furniture come from Howards End?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: The Howards End furniture has all gone to Oniton.
subQuotationList: ['The Howards End furniture has all gone to Oniton.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Does--However, I m concerned with the house, not the furniture. How big
is this smoking-room?
subQuotationList: ['Does--However, I m concerned with the house, not the furniture. How big\nis this smoking-room?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Thirty by fifteen. No, wait a minute. Fifteen and a half.
subQuotationList: ['Thirty by fifteen. No, wait a minute. Fifteen and a half.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Ah, well. Mr. Wilcox, aren t you ever amused at the solemnity with
which we middle classes approach the subject of houses?
subQuotationList: ['Ah, well. Mr. Wilcox, aren t you ever amused at the solemnity with\nwhich we middle classes approach the subject of houses?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Miss Schlegel
subQuotationList: ['Miss Schlegel']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I have had you up on false
pretences. I want to speak about a much more serious matter than a
house.
subQuotationList: ['I have had you up on false\npretences. I want to speak about a much more serious matter than a\nhouse.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Could you be induced to share my--is it probable--
subQuotationList: ['Could you be induced to share my--is it probable--']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Oh, Mr. Wilcox! I see, I see. I will write to you afterwards if I may.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Mr. Wilcox!', 'I see, I see. I will write to you afterwards if I may.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Miss Schlegel--Margaret you don t understand.
subQuotationList: ['Miss Schlegel--Margaret you don t understand.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Oh yes! Indeed, yes!
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes! Indeed, yes!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I am asking you to be my wife.
subQuotationList: ['I am asking you to be my wife.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: You aren t offended, Miss Schlegel?
subQuotationList: ['You aren t offended, Miss Schlegel?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: How could I be offended?
subQuotationList: ['How could I be offended?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Good-bye, You will have a letter from me--I am going
back to Swanage to-morrow.
subQuotationList: ['Good-bye,', 'You will have a letter from me--I am going\nback to Swanage to-morrow.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Thank you.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Good-bye, and it s you I thank.
subQuotationList: ['Good-bye, and it s you I thank.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I may order the motor round, mayn t I?
subQuotationList: ['I may order the motor round, mayn t I?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: That would be most kind.
subQuotationList: ['That would be most kind.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I wish I had written. Ought I to have written?
subQuotationList: ['I wish I had written. Ought I to have written?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Not at all.
subQuotationList: ['Not at all.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: There s just one question--
subQuotationList: ['There s just one question--']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: And your English lakes--Vindermere, Grasmere they, then, unhealthy?
subQuotationList: ['And your English lakes--Vindermere, Grasmere they, then, unhealthy?']
speaker: Frieda

quoteText:
No, Frau Liesecke; but that is because they are fresh water, and
different. Salt water ought to have tides, and go up and down a great
deal, or else it smells. Look, for instance, at an aquarium.
subQuotationList: ['No, Frau Liesecke; but that is because they are fresh water, and\ndifferent. Salt water ought to have tides, and go up and down a great\ndeal, or else it smells. Look, for instance, at an aquarium.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
An aquarium! Oh, MEESIS Munt, you mean to tell me that fresh aquariums
stink less than salt? Why, then Victor, my brother-in-law, collected
many tadpoles--
subQuotationList: ['An aquarium! Oh, MEESIS Munt, you mean to tell me that fresh aquariums\nstink less than salt? Why, then Victor, my brother-in-law, collected\nmany tadpoles--']
speaker: Frieda

quoteText:
You are not to say  stink, at
least, you may say it, but you must pretend you are being funny while
you say it.
subQuotationList: ['You are not to say  stink,', 'at\nleast, you may say it, but you must pretend you are being funny while\nyou say it.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Then  smell.  And the mud of your Pool down there--does it not smell,
or may I say  stink,  ha, ha?
subQuotationList: ['Then  smell.  And the mud of your Pool down there--does it not smell,\nor may I say  stink,  ha, ha?']
speaker: Frieda

quoteText:
There always has been mud in Poole Harbour, The rivers bring it down, and a most valuable
oyster-fishery depends upon it.
subQuotationList: ['There always has been mud in Poole Harbour,', 'The rivers bring it down, and a most valuable\noyster-fishery depends upon it.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Yes, that is so,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, that is so,']
speaker: Frieda

quoteText:
Bournemouth is, Bournemouth is, Poole was, and Swanage
is to be the most important town of all and biggest of the three.  Now,
Frau Liesecke, I have shown you Bournemouth, and I have shown you Poole,
so let us walk backward a little, and look down again at Swanage.
subQuotationList:
['Bournemouth is,', 'Bournemouth is, Poole was, and Swanage
is to be the most important town of all and biggest of the three.  Now,
Frau Liesecke, I have shown you Bournemouth, and I have shown you Poole,
so let us walk backward a little, and look down again at Swanage.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Aunt Juley, wouldn t that be Meg s train?
subQuotationList: ['Aunt Juley, wouldn t that be Meg s train?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Oh, dearest Margaret, I do hope she won t be overtired.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, dearest Margaret, I do hope she won t be overtired.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Oh, I do wonder--I do wonder whether she s taken the house.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I do wonder--I do wonder whether she s taken the house.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I hope she hasn t been hasty.
subQuotationList: ['I hope she hasn t been hasty.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: So do I--oh, SO do I.
subQuotationList: ['So do I--oh, SO do I.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Will it be as beautiful as Wickham Place?
subQuotationList: ['Will it be as beautiful as Wickham Place?']
speaker: Frieda

quoteText:
I should think it would. Trust Mr. Wilcox for doing himself proud. All
those Ducie Street houses are beautiful in their modern way, and I can t
think why he doesn t keep on with it. But it s really for Evie that he
went there, and now that Evie s going to be married--
subQuotationList:
['I should think it would. Trust Mr. Wilcox for doing himself proud. All
those Ducie Street houses are beautiful in their modern way, and I can t
think why he doesn t keep on with it. But it s really for Evie that he
went there, and now that Evie s going to be married--']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Ah!
speaker: Frieda

quoteText:
You ve never seen Miss Wilcox, Frieda. How absurdly matrimonial you
are!
subQuotationList: ['You ve never seen Miss Wilcox, Frieda. How absurdly matrimonial you\nare!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: But sister to that Paul?
subQuotationList: ['But sister to that Paul?']
speaker: Frieda

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
And to that Charles, Oh, Helen, Helen,
what a time that was!
subQuotationList: ['And to that Charles,', 'Oh, Helen, Helen,\nwhat a time that was!']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Meg and I haven t got such tender hearts. If there s a
chance of a cheap house, we go for it.
subQuotationList: ['Meg and I haven t got such tender hearts. If there s a\nchance of a cheap house, we go for it.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Now look, Frau Liesecke, at my niece s train. You see, it is coming
towards us--coming, coming; and, when it gets to Corfe, it will actually
go THROUGH the downs, on which we are standing, so that, if we walk
over, as I suggested, and look down on Swanage, we shall see it coming
on the other side. Shall we?
subQuotationList:
['Now look, Frau Liesecke, at my niece s train. You see, it is coming
towards us--coming, coming; and, when it gets to Corfe, it will actually
go THROUGH the downs, on which we are standing, so that, if we walk
over, as I suggested, and look down on Swanage, we shall see it coming
on the other side. Shall we?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
You see, the Wilcoxes collect houses
as your Victor collects tadpoles. They have, one, Ducie Street; two,
Howards End, where my great rumpus was; three, a country seat in
Shropshire; four, Charles has a house in Hilton; and five, another near
Epsom; and six, Evie will have a house when she marries, and probably a
pied-a-terre in the country--which makes seven. Oh yes, and Paul a
hut in Africa makes eight. I wish we could get Howards End. That was
something like a dear little house! Didn t you think so, Aunt Juley?
subQuotationList:
['You see,', 'the Wilcoxes collect houses
as your Victor collects tadpoles. They have, one, Ducie Street; two,
Howards End, where my great rumpus was; three, a country seat in
Shropshire; four, Charles has a house in Hilton; and five, another near
Epsom; and six, Evie will have a house when she marries, and probably a
pied-a-terre in the country--which makes seven. Oh yes, and Paul a
hut in Africa makes eight. I wish we could get Howards End. That was
something like a dear little house! Didn t you think so, Aunt Juley?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I had too much to do, dear, to look at it, I had everything to settle and explain, and Charles
Wilcox to keep in his place besides. It isn t likely I should remember
much. I just remember having lunch in your bedroom.
subQuotationList: ['I had too much to do, dear, to look at it,', 'I had everything to settle and explain, and Charles\nWilcox to keep in his place besides. It isn t likely I should remember\nmuch. I just remember having lunch in your bedroom.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Yes, so do I. But, oh dear, dear, how dreadful it all seems! And in the
autumn there began that anti-Pauline movement--you, and Frieda, and
Meg, and Mrs. Wilcox, all obsessed with the idea that I might yet marry
Paul.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, so do I. But, oh dear, dear, how dreadful it all seems! And in the
autumn there began that anti-Pauline movement--you, and Frieda, and
Meg, and Mrs. Wilcox, all obsessed with the idea that I might yet marry
Paul.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: You yet may,
subQuotationList: ['You yet may,']
speaker: Frieda

quoteText:
The Great Wilcox Peril will never return. If I m
certain of anything it s of that.
subQuotationList: ['The Great Wilcox Peril will never return. If I m\ncertain of anything it s of that.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: One is certain of nothing but the truth of one s own emotions.
subQuotationList: ['One is certain of nothing but the truth of one s own emotions.']
speaker: Frieda

quoteText:
Look! Stand where I stand, and you will see the
pony-cart coming. I see the pony-cart coming.
subQuotationList: ['Look!', 'Stand where I stand, and you will see the\npony-cart coming. I see the pony-cart coming.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Have you got the house?
subQuotationList: ['Have you got the house?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Oh, what a nuisance! So we re as we were?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, what a nuisance! So we re as we were?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Not exactly.
subQuotationList: ['Not exactly.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Some mystery, We are to be enlightened presently.
subQuotationList: ['Some mystery,', 'We are to be enlightened presently.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
It s just like a widower, They ve cheek enough for anything, and invariably select one
of their first wife s friends.
subQuotationList: ['It s just like a widower,', 'They ve cheek enough for anything, and invariably select one\nof their first wife s friends.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: That type--
subQuotationList: ['That type--']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Meg, not anything wrong with
you?
subQuotationList: ['Meg, not anything wrong with\nyou?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Wait one minute,
subQuotationList: ['Wait one minute,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But you ve never conceivably--you ve never--
subQuotationList: ['But you ve never conceivably--you ve never--']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Tibby, hurry up through; I can t hold this gate indefinitely.
Aunt Juley! I say, Aunt Juley, make the tea, will you, and Frieda; we ve
got to talk houses, and will come on afterwards.
subQuotationList: ['Tibby, hurry up through; I can t hold this gate indefinitely.\nAunt Juley! I say, Aunt Juley, make the tea, will you, and Frieda; we ve\ngot to talk houses, and will come on afterwards.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Oh, really--
subQuotationList: ['Oh, really--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Don t, don t, don t, Meg, don t!
subQuotationList: ['Don t,', 'don t, don t, Meg, don t!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Don t, don t do such a thing! I tell you not to--don t! I know--don t!
subQuotationList: ['Don t, don t do such a thing! I tell you not to--don t! I know--don t!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: What do you know?
subQuotationList: ['What do you know?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Panic and emptiness, Don t!
subQuotationList: ['Panic and emptiness,', 'Don t!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Helen is a little selfish. I have never behaved
like this when there has seemed a chance of her marrying.
subQuotationList: ['Helen is a little selfish. I have never behaved\nlike this when there has seemed a chance of her marrying.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But we would still see each other very--often, and you--
subQuotationList: ['But we would still see each other very--often, and you--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It s not a thing like that,
subQuotationList: ['It s not a thing like that,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: What s happened to you?
subQuotationList: ['What s happened to you?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
But it s
stupid!
subQuotationList: ['But it s\nstupid!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I don t know what s happened to either of us, We must both have gone mad.
subQuotationList: ['I don t know what s happened to either of us,', 'We must both have gone mad.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Look here, sit down.
subQuotationList: ['Look here, sit down.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: All right; I ll sit down if you ll sit down.
subQuotationList: ['All right; I ll sit down if you ll sit down.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: There.
subQuotationList: ['There.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Now, whatever, whatever is the matter?
subQuotationList: ['Now, whatever, whatever is the matter?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I do mean what I said. Don t; it wouldn t do.
subQuotationList: ['I do mean what I said. Don t; it wouldn t do.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Oh, Helen, stop saying  don t ! It s ignorant. It s as if your head
wasn t out of the slime.  Don t  is probably what Mrs. Bast says all the
day to Mr. Bast.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Helen, stop saying  don t ! It s ignorant. It s as if your head\nwasn t out of the slime.  Don t  is probably what Mrs. Bast says all the\nday to Mr. Bast.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Well?
subQuotationList: ['Well?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Tell me about it first, and meanwhile perhaps I ll have got my head out
of the slime.
subQuotationList: ['Tell me about it first, and meanwhile perhaps I ll have got my head out\nof the slime.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
That s better. Well, where shall I begin? When I arrived at
Waterloo--no, I ll go back before that, because I m anxious you should
know everything from the first. The  first  was about ten days ago. It
was the day Mr. Bast came to tea and lost his temper. I was defending
him, and Mr. Wilcox became jealous about me, however slightly. I thought
it was the involuntary thing, which men can t help any more than we can.
You know--at least, I know in my own case--when a man has said to me,
 So-and-so s a pretty girl,  I am seized with a momentary sourness
against So-and-so, and long to tweak her ear. It s a tiresome feeling,
but not an important one, and one easily manages it. But it wasn t only
this in Mr. Wilcox s case, I gather now.
subQuotationList:
['That s better. Well, where shall I begin? When I arrived at
Waterloo--no, I ll go back before that, because I m anxious you should
know everything from the first. The  first  was about ten days ago. It
was the day Mr. Bast came to tea and lost his temper. I was defending
him, and Mr. Wilcox became jealous about me, however slightly. I thought
it was the involuntary thing, which men can t help any more than we can.
You know--at least, I know in my own case--when a man has said to me,
 So-and-so s a pretty girl,  I am seized with a momentary sourness
against So-and-so, and long to tweak her ear. It s a tiresome feeling,
but not an important one, and one easily manages it. But it wasn t only
this in Mr. Wilcox s case, I gather now.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Then you love him?
subQuotationList: ['Then you love him?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
It is wonderful knowing that a real man cares for
you, The mere fact of that grows more tremendous. Remember,
I ve known and liked him steadily for nearly three years.
subQuotationList: ['It is wonderful knowing that a real man cares for\nyou,', 'The mere fact of that grows more tremendous. Remember,\nI ve known and liked him steadily for nearly three years.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But loved him?
subQuotationList: ['But loved him?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: No.
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But you will?
subQuotationList: ['But you will?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Yes, of that I m pretty sure. Indeed, I began the
moment he spoke to me.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'of that I m pretty sure. Indeed, I began the\nmoment he spoke to me.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: And have settled to marry him?
subQuotationList: ['And have settled to marry him?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I had, but am wanting a long talk about it now. What is it against him,
Helen? You must try and say.
subQuotationList: ['I had, but am wanting a long talk about it now. What is it against him,\nHelen? You must try and say.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It is ever since Paul,
subQuotationList: ['It is ever since Paul,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: But what has Mr. Wilcox to do with Paul?
subQuotationList: ['But what has Mr. Wilcox to do with Paul?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
But he was there, they were all there that morning when I came down
to breakfast, and saw that Paul was frightened--the man who loved me
frightened and all his paraphernalia fallen, so that I knew it was
impossible, because personal relations are the important thing for ever
and ever, and not this outer life of telegrams and anger.
subQuotationList:
['But he was there, they were all there that morning when I came down
to breakfast, and saw that Paul was frightened--the man who loved me
frightened and all his paraphernalia fallen, so that I knew it was
impossible, because personal relations are the important thing for ever
and ever, and not this outer life of telegrams and anger.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
That s foolish. In the first place, I disagree about the outer life.
Well, we ve often argued that. The real point is that there is the
widest gulf between my love-making and yours. Yours was romance; mine
will be prose. I m not running it down--a very good kind of prose, but
well considered, well thought out. For instance, I know all Mr. Wilcox s
faults. He s afraid of emotion. He cares too much about success, too
little about the past. His sympathy lacks poetry, and so isn t sympathy
really. I d even say
subQuotationList:
['That s foolish. In the first place, I disagree about the outer life.
Well, we ve often argued that. The real point is that there is the
widest gulf between my love-making and yours. Yours was romance; mine
will be prose. I m not running it down--a very good kind of prose, but
well considered, well thought out. For instance, I know all Mr. Wilcox s
faults. He s afraid of emotion. He cares too much about success, too
little about the past. His sympathy lacks poetry, and so isn t sympathy
really. I d even say']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
that,
spiritually, he s not as honest as I am. Doesn t that satisfy you?
subQuotationList: ['that,\nspiritually, he s not as honest as I am. Doesn t that satisfy you?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
No, it doesn t, It makes me feel worse and worse. You
must be mad.
subQuotationList: ['No, it doesn t,', 'It makes me feel worse and worse. You\nmust be mad.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I don t intend him, or any man or any woman, to be all my life--good
heavens, no! There are heaps of things in me that he doesn t, and shall
never, understand.
subQuotationList: ['I don t intend him, or any man or any woman, to be all my life--good\nheavens, no! There are heaps of things in me that he doesn t, and shall\nnever, understand.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
So with him, There are heaps of things in him--more
especially things that he does that will always be hidden from me. He
has all those public qualities which you so despise and which enable all
this-- If Wilcoxes hadn t worked and died in England for thousands of years,
you and I couldn t sit here without having our throats cut. There would
be no trains, no ships to carry us literary people about in, no fields
even. Just savagery. No--perhaps not even that. Without their spirit
life might never have moved out of protoplasm. More and more do I refuse
to draw my income and sneer at those who guarantee it. There are times
when it seems to me--
subQuotationList:
['So with him,', 'There are heaps of things in him--more
especially things that he does that will always be hidden from me. He
has all those public qualities which you so despise and which enable all
this--', 'If Wilcoxes hadn t worked and died in England for thousands of years,
you and I couldn t sit here without having our throats cut. There would
be no trains, no ships to carry us literary people about in, no fields
even. Just savagery. No--perhaps not even that. Without their spirit
life might never have moved out of protoplasm. More and more do I refuse
to draw my income and sneer at those who guarantee it. There are times
when it seems to me--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: And to me, and to all women. So one kissed Paul.
subQuotationList: ['And to me, and to all women. So one kissed Paul.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
That s brutal, Mine is an absolutely different case.
I ve thought things out.
subQuotationList: ['That s brutal,', 'Mine is an absolutely different case.\nI ve thought things out.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It makes no difference thinking things out. They come to the same.
subQuotationList: ['It makes no difference thinking things out. They come to the same.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Rubbish!
subQuotationList: ['Rubbish!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: One would lose something,
subQuotationList: ['One would lose something,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Do you remember
the Embankment at Chelsea? It can t be ten days ago.
subQuotationList: ['Do you remember\nthe Embankment at Chelsea? It can t be ten days ago.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Yes, And you and your sister were head and ears
deep in some Quixotic scheme. Ah well!
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'And you and your sister were head and ears\ndeep in some Quixotic scheme. Ah well!']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I little thought then, certainly. Did you?
subQuotationList: ['I little thought then, certainly. Did you?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I don t know about that; I shouldn t like to say.
subQuotationList: ['I don t know about that; I shouldn t like to say.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Why, was it earlier? Did you think of me this way earlier!
How extraordinarily interesting, Henry! Tell me.
subQuotationList: ['Why, was it earlier?', 'Did you think of me this way earlier!\nHow extraordinarily interesting, Henry! Tell me.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I didn t think of it, No; when you spoke to me in the
drawing-room, that was practically the first. It was all so different
from what it s supposed to be. On the stage, or in books, a proposal
is--how shall I put it?--a full-blown affair, a kind of bouquet;
it loses its literal meaning. But in life a proposal really is a
proposal--
subQuotationList:
['I didn t think of it,', 'No; when you spoke to me in the
drawing-room, that was practically the first. It was all so different
from what it s supposed to be. On the stage, or in books, a proposal
is--how shall I put it?--a full-blown affair, a kind of bouquet;
it loses its literal meaning. But in life a proposal really is a
proposal--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: By the way--
subQuotationList: ['By the way--']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: --a suggestion, a seed,
subQuotationList: ['--a suggestion, a seed,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I was thinking, if you didn t mind, that we ought to spend this evening
in a business talk; there will be so much to settle.
subQuotationList: ['I was thinking, if you didn t mind, that we ought to spend this evening\nin a business talk; there will be so much to settle.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I think so too.  Tell me, in the first place, how did you get on with Tibby?
subQuotationList: ['I think so too.  Tell me, in the first place, how did you get on with Tibby?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: With your brother?
subQuotationList: ['With your brother?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Yes, during cigarettes.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, during cigarettes.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, very well.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, very well.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I am so glad, What did you talk
about? Me, presumably.
subQuotationList: ['I am so glad,', 'What did you talk\nabout? Me, presumably.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: About Greece too.
subQuotationList: ['About Greece too.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Greece was a very good card, Henry. Tibby s only a boy still, and one
has to pick and choose subjects a little. Well done.
subQuotationList: ['Greece was a very good card, Henry. Tibby s only a boy still, and one\nhas to pick and choose subjects a little. Well done.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I was telling him I have shares in a currant-farm near Calamata.
subQuotationList: ['I was telling him I have shares in a currant-farm near Calamata.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
What a delightful thing to have shares in! Can t we go there for our
honeymoon?
subQuotationList: ['What a delightful thing to have shares in! Can t we go there for our\nhoneymoon?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What to do?
subQuotationList: ['What to do?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: To eat the currants. And isn t there marvellous scenery?
subQuotationList: ['To eat the currants. And isn t there marvellous scenery?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Moderately, but it s not the kind of place one could possibly go to
with a lady.
subQuotationList: ['Moderately, but it s not the kind of place one could possibly go to\nwith a lady.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Why not?
subQuotationList: ['Why not?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: No hotels.
subQuotationList: ['No hotels.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Some ladies do without hotels. Are you aware that Helen and I have
walked alone over the Apennines, with our luggage on our backs?
subQuotationList: ['Some ladies do without hotels. Are you aware that Helen and I have\nwalked alone over the Apennines, with our luggage on our backs?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I wasn t aware, and, if I can manage it, you will never do such a thing
again.
subQuotationList: ['I wasn t aware, and, if I can manage it, you will never do such a thing\nagain.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
You haven t found time for a talk with Helen
yet, I suppose?
subQuotationList: ['You haven t found time for a talk with Helen\nyet, I suppose?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: No.
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Do, before you go. I am so anxious you two should be friends.
subQuotationList: ['Do, before you go. I am so anxious you two should be friends.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Your sister and I have always hit it off, But
we re drifting away from our business. Let me begin at the beginning.
You know that Evie is going to marry Percy Cahill.
subQuotationList: ['Your sister and I have always hit it off,', 'But\nwe re drifting away from our business. Let me begin at the beginning.\nYou know that Evie is going to marry Percy Cahill.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Dolly s uncle.
subQuotationList: ['Dolly s uncle.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Exactly. The girl s madly in love with him. A very good sort of fellow,
but he demands--and rightly--a suitable provision with her. And in the
second place you will naturally understand, there is Charles. Before
leaving town, I wrote Charles a very careful letter. You see, he has
an increasing family and increasing expenses, and the I. and W. A. is
nothing particular just now, though capable of development.
subQuotationList:
['Exactly. The girl s madly in love with him. A very good sort of fellow,
but he demands--and rightly--a suitable provision with her. And in the
second place you will naturally understand, there is Charles. Before
leaving town, I wrote Charles a very careful letter. You see, he has
an increasing family and increasing expenses, and the I. and W. A. is
nothing particular just now, though capable of development.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Poor fellow!
subQuotationList: ['Poor fellow!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Charles being the elder son, some day Charles will have Howards End;
but I am anxious, in my own happiness, not to be unjust to others.
subQuotationList: ['Charles being the elder son, some day Charles will have Howards End;\nbut I am anxious, in my own happiness, not to be unjust to others.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Of course not, you mean money.
How stupid I am! Of course not!
subQuotationList: ['Of course not,', 'you mean money.\nHow stupid I am! Of course not!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Yes, Money, since you put
it so frankly. I am determined to be just to all--just to you, just to
them. I am determined that my children shall have me.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, Money, since you put\nit so frankly. I am determined to be just to all--just to you, just to\nthem. I am determined that my children shall have me.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Be generous to them, Bother justice!
subQuotationList: ['Be generous to them,', 'Bother justice!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I am determined--and have already written to Charles to that effect--
subQuotationList: ['I am determined--and have already written to Charles to that effect--']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: But how much have you got?
subQuotationList: ['But how much have you got?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What?
subQuotationList: ['What?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: How much have you a year? I ve six hundred.
subQuotationList: ['How much have you a year? I ve six hundred.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: My income?
subQuotationList: ['My income?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Yes. We must begin with how much you have, before we can settle how
much you can give Charles. Justice, and even generosity, depend on
that.
subQuotationList: ['Yes. We must begin with how much you have, before we can settle how\nmuch you can give Charles. Justice, and even generosity, depend on\nthat.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I must say you re a downright young woman, What a question to spring on a fellow!
subQuotationList: ['I must say you re a downright young woman,', 'What a question to spring on a fellow!']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Don t you know your income? Or don t you want to tell it me?
subQuotationList: ['Don t you know your income? Or don t you want to tell it me?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: That s all right
subQuotationList: ['That s all right']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
don t tell me. I don t want to
know. I can do the sum just as well by proportion. Divide your income
into ten parts. How many parts would you give to Evie, how many to
Charles, how many to Paul?
subQuotationList:
['don t tell me. I don t want to
know. I can do the sum just as well by proportion. Divide your income
into ten parts. How many parts would you give to Evie, how many to
Charles, how many to Paul?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
The fact is, my dear, I hadn t any intention of bothering you with
details. I only wanted to let you know that--well, that something must
be done for the others, and you ve understood me perfectly, so let s
pass on to the next point.
subQuotationList:
['The fact is, my dear, I hadn t any intention of bothering you with
details. I only wanted to let you know that--well, that something must
be done for the others, and you ve understood me perfectly, so let s
pass on to the next point.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Yes, we ve settled that, Go ahead; give away all you can, bearing in mind that I ve
a clear six hundred. What a mercy it is to have all this money about
one.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, we ve settled that,', 'Go ahead; give away all you can, bearing in mind that I ve\na clear six hundred. What a mercy it is to have all this money about\none.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: We ve none too much, I assure you; you re marrying a poor man.
subQuotationList: ['We ve none too much, I assure you; you re marrying a poor man.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Helen wouldn t agree with me here, Helen daren t slang
the rich, being rich herself, but she would like to. There s an odd
notion, that I haven t yet got hold of, running about at the back of her
brain, that poverty is somehow  real.  She dislikes all organisation,
and probably confuses wealth with the technique of wealth. Sovereigns in
a stocking wouldn t bother her; cheques do. Helen is too relentless. One
can t deal in her high-handed manner with the world.
subQuotationList:
['Helen wouldn t agree with me here,', 'Helen daren t slang
the rich, being rich herself, but she would like to. There s an odd
notion, that I haven t yet got hold of, running about at the back of her
brain, that poverty is somehow  real.  She dislikes all organisation,
and probably confuses wealth with the technique of wealth. Sovereigns in
a stocking wouldn t bother her; cheques do. Helen is too relentless. One
can t deal in her high-handed manner with the world.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
There s this other point, and then I must go back to my hotel and write
some letters. What s to be done now about the house in Ducie Street?
subQuotationList: ['There s this other point, and then I must go back to my hotel and write\nsome letters. What s to be done now about the house in Ducie Street?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Keep it on--at least, it depends. When do you want to marry me?
subQuotationList: ['Keep it on--at least, it depends. When do you want to marry me?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I say! Take care I don t report you to the police.
subQuotationList: ['I say!', 'Take care I don t report you to the police.']
speaker: Henry
referringExpression: Mr Wilcox turned on them and said

quoteText:
Evie will probably be married in September. We could scarcely think of
anything before then.
subQuotationList: ['Evie will probably be married in September. We could scarcely think of\nanything before then.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
The earlier the nicer, Henry. Females are not supposed to say such
things, but the earlier the nicer.
subQuotationList: ['The earlier the nicer, Henry. Females are not supposed to say such\nthings, but the earlier the nicer.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: How about September for us too?
subQuotationList: ['How about September for us too?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Right. Shall we go into Ducie Street ourselves in September? Or shall
we try to bounce Helen and Tibby into it? That s rather an idea. They
are so unbusinesslike, we could make them do anything by judicious
management. Look here--yes. We ll do that. And we ourselves could live
at Howards End or Shropshire.
subQuotationList:
['Right. Shall we go into Ducie Street ourselves in September? Or shall
we try to bounce Helen and Tibby into it? That s rather an idea. They
are so unbusinesslike, we could make them do anything by judicious
management. Look here--yes. We ll do that. And we ourselves could live
at Howards End or Shropshire.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Heavens! how you women do fly round! My head s
in a whirl. Point by point, Margaret. Howards End s impossible. I let
it to Hamar Bryce on a three years  agreement last March. Don t you
remember? Oniton. Well, that is much, much too far away to rely on
entirely. You will be able to be down there entertaining a certain
amount, but we must have a house within easy reach of Town. Only Ducie
Street has huge drawbacks. There s a mews behind.
subQuotationList:
['Heavens! how you women do fly round! My head s
