in a whirl. Point by point, Margaret. Howards End s impossible. I let
it to Hamar Bryce on a three years  agreement last March. Don t you
remember? Oniton. Well, that is much, much too far away to rely on
entirely. You will be able to be down there entertaining a certain
amount, but we must have a house within easy reach of Town. Only Ducie
Street has huge drawbacks. There s a mews behind.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Yes, in summer especially, the mews is a serious nuisance. The
smoking-room, too, is an abominable little den. The house opposite
has been taken by operatic people. Ducie Street s going down, it s my
private opinion.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, in summer especially, the mews is a serious nuisance. The
smoking-room, too, is an abominable little den. The house opposite
has been taken by operatic people. Ducie Street s going down, it s my
private opinion.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: How sad! It s only a few years since they built those pretty houses.
subQuotationList: ['How sad! It s only a few years since they built those pretty houses.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Shows things are moving. Good for trade.
subQuotationList: ['Shows things are moving. Good for trade.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I hate this continual flux of London. It is an epitome of us at
our worst--eternal formlessness; all the qualities, good, bad, and
indifferent, streaming away--streaming, streaming for ever. That s why I
dread it so. I mistrust rivers, even in scenery. Now, the sea--
subQuotationList:
['I hate this continual flux of London. It is an epitome of us at
our worst--eternal formlessness; all the qualities, good, bad, and
indifferent, streaming away--streaming, streaming for ever. That s why I
dread it so. I mistrust rivers, even in scenery. Now, the sea--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: High tide, yes.
subQuotationList: ['High tide, yes.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: And these are the men to whom we give the vote, However, they have their own lives and interests. Let s get on.
subQuotationList: ['And these are the men to whom we give the vote,', 'However, they have their own lives and interests. Let s get on.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: A nice beginning, if your aunt saw you slip in alone!
subQuotationList: ['A nice beginning, if your aunt saw you slip in alone!']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
But I always do go about alone. Considering I ve walked over the
Apennines, it s common sense. You will make me so angry. I don t the
least take it as a compliment.
subQuotationList: ['But I always do go about alone. Considering I ve walked over the\nApennines, it s common sense. You will make me so angry. I don t the\nleast take it as a compliment.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
It isn t meant as a compliment, my dear. I
just won t have you going about in the dark. Such people about too! It s
dangerous.
subQuotationList: ['It isn t meant as a compliment, my dear. I\njust won t have you going about in the dark. Such people about too! It s\ndangerous.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Can t I look after myself? I do wish--
subQuotationList: ['Can t I look after myself? I do wish--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Come along, Margaret; no wheedling.
subQuotationList: ['Come along, Margaret; no wheedling.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Margaret
subQuotationList: ['Margaret']
speaker: Henry
referringExpression: Mr Wilcox who was in front said

quoteText:
You ve waked the baby. I knew you would. (Rum-ti-foo,
Rackety-tackety-Tompkin!) I m not responsible for what Uncle Percy does,
nor for anybody else or anything, so there!
subQuotationList: ['You ve waked the baby. I knew you would. (Rum-ti-foo,\nRackety-tackety-Tompkin!) I m not responsible for what Uncle Percy does,\nnor for anybody else or anything, so there!']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
Who asked him while I was away? Who asked my sister down to meet him?
Who sent them out in the motor day after day?
subQuotationList: ['Who asked him while I was away? Who asked my sister down to meet him?\nWho sent them out in the motor day after day?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Charles, that reminds me of some poem.
subQuotationList: ['Charles, that reminds me of some poem.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
Does it indeed? We shall all be dancing to a very different music
presently. Miss Schlegel has fairly got us on toast.
subQuotationList: ['Does it indeed? We shall all be dancing to a very different music\npresently. Miss Schlegel has fairly got us on toast.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
I could simply scratch that woman s eyes out, and to say it s my fault
is most unfair.
subQuotationList: ['I could simply scratch that woman s eyes out, and to say it s my fault\nis most unfair.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: It s your fault, and five months ago you admitted it.
subQuotationList: ['It s your fault, and five months ago you admitted it.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: I didn t.
subQuotationList: ['I didn t.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: You did.
subQuotationList: ['You did.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Tootle, tootle, playing on the pootle!
subQuotationList: ['Tootle, tootle, playing on the pootle!']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
It s all very well to turn the conversation, but father would
never have dreamt of marrying as long as Evie was there to make him
comfortable. But you must needs start match-making. Besides, Cahill s
too old.
subQuotationList:
['It s all very well to turn the conversation, but father would
never have dreamt of marrying as long as Evie was there to make him
comfortable. But you must needs start match-making. Besides, Cahill s
too old.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Of course, if you re going to be rude to Uncle Percy.
subQuotationList: ['Of course, if you re going to be rude to Uncle Percy.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
Miss Schlegel always meant to get hold of Howards End, and, thanks to
you, she s got it.
subQuotationList: ['Miss Schlegel always meant to get hold of Howards End, and, thanks to\nyou, she s got it.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
I call the way you twist things round and make them hang together most
unfair. You couldn t have been nastier if you d caught me flirting.
Could he, diddums?
subQuotationList: ['I call the way you twist things round and make them hang together most\nunfair. You couldn t have been nastier if you d caught me flirting.\nCould he, diddums?']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
We re in a bad hole, and must make the best of it. I shall answer the
pater s letter civilly. He s evidently anxious to do the decent thing.
But I do not intend to forget these Schlegels in a hurry. As long
as they re on their best behaviour--Dolly, are you listening?--we ll
behave, too. But if I find them giving themselves airs or monopolising
my father, or at all ill-treating him, or worrying him with their
artistic beastliness, I intend to put my foot down, yes, firmly. Taking
my mother s place! Heaven knows what poor old Paul will say when the
news reaches him.
subQuotationList:
['We re in a bad hole, and must make the best of it. I shall answer the
pater s letter civilly. He s evidently anxious to do the decent thing.
But I do not intend to forget these Schlegels in a hurry. As long
as they re on their best behaviour--Dolly, are you listening?--we ll
behave, too. But if I find them giving themselves airs or monopolising
my father, or at all ill-treating him, or worrying him with their
artistic beastliness, I intend to put my foot down, yes, firmly. Taking
my mother s place! Heaven knows what poor old Paul will say when the
news reaches him.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
My motto is Concentrate. I ve no intention of frittering away
my strength on that sort of thing.
subQuotationList: ['My motto is Concentrate. I ve no intention of frittering away\nmy strength on that sort of thing.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
It isn t frittering away the
strength, It s enlarging the space in which you may
be strong.
subQuotationList: ['It isn t frittering away the\nstrength,', 'It s enlarging the space in which you may\nbe strong.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
You re a clever little woman, but my motto s
Concentrate.
subQuotationList: ['You re a clever little woman, but my motto s\nConcentrate.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Here we all are!
subQuotationList: ['Here we all are!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Here we are. Good-morning, Helen.
subQuotationList: ['Here we are. Good-morning, Helen.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Good-morning, Mr. Wilcox.
subQuotationList: ['Good-morning, Mr. Wilcox.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Henry, she has had such a nice letter from the queer, cross boy. Do
you remember him? He had a sad moustache, but the back of his head was
young.
subQuotationList: ['Henry, she has had such a nice letter from the queer, cross boy. Do\nyou remember him? He had a sad moustache, but the back of his head was\nyoung.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I have had a letter too. Not a nice one--I want to talk it over with
you
subQuotationList: ['I have had a letter too. Not a nice one--I want to talk it over with\nyou']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Thanks to your hint, he s clearing out of the Porphyrion.
subQuotationList: ['Thanks to your hint, he s clearing out of the Porphyrion.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Not a bad business that Porphyrion,
subQuotationList: ['Not a bad business that Porphyrion,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Not a BAD-- Surely, on Chelsea
Embankment--
subQuotationList: ['Not a BAD--', 'Surely, on Chelsea\nEmbankment--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Here s our hostess. Good-morning, Mrs. Munt. Fine rhododendrons.
Good-morning, Frau Liesecke; we manage to grow flowers in England, don t
we?
subQuotationList: ['Here s our hostess. Good-morning, Mrs. Munt. Fine rhododendrons.\nGood-morning, Frau Liesecke; we manage to grow flowers in England, don t\nwe?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Not a BAD business?
subQuotationList: ['Not a BAD business?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
No. My letter s about Howards End. Bryce has been ordered abroad, and
wants to sublet it--I am far from sure that I shall give him permission.
There was no clause in the agreement. In my opinion, subletting is a
mistake. If he can find me another tenant, whom I consider suitable,
I may cancel the agreement. Morning, Schlegel. Don t you think that s
better than subletting?
subQuotationList:
['No. My letter s about Howards End. Bryce has been ordered abroad, and
wants to sublet it--I am far from sure that I shall give him permission.
There was no clause in the agreement. In my opinion, subletting is a
mistake. If he can find me another tenant, whom I consider suitable,
I may cancel the agreement. Morning, Schlegel. Don t you think that s
better than subletting?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: When there is a sublet I find that damage--
subQuotationList: ['When there is a sublet I find that damage--']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Do excuse me, but about the Porphyrion. I don t feel easy--might I just
bother you, Henry?
subQuotationList: ['Do excuse me, but about the Porphyrion. I don t feel easy--might I just\nbother you, Henry?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
You said on Chelsea Embankment, surely, that it was a bad concern, so
we advised this clerk to clear out. He writes this morning that he s
taken our advice, and now you say it s not a bad concern.
subQuotationList: ['You said on Chelsea Embankment, surely, that it was a bad concern, so\nwe advised this clerk to clear out. He writes this morning that he s\ntaken our advice, and now you say it s not a bad concern.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
A clerk who clears out of any concern, good or bad, without securing a
berth somewhere else first, is a fool, and I ve no pity for him.
subQuotationList: ['A clerk who clears out of any concern, good or bad, without securing a\nberth somewhere else first, is a fool, and I ve no pity for him.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
He has not done that. He s going into a bank in Camden Town, he says.
The salary s much lower, but he hopes to manage--a branch of Dempster s
Bank. Is that all right?
subQuotationList: ['He has not done that. He s going into a bank in Camden Town, he says.\nThe salary s much lower, but he hopes to manage--a branch of Dempster s\nBank. Is that all right?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Dempster! Why goodness me, yes.
subQuotationList: ['Dempster! Why goodness me, yes.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: More right than the Porphyrion?
subQuotationList: ['More right than the Porphyrion?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes, yes, yes; safe as houses--safer.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, yes, yes; safe as houses--safer.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Very many thanks. I m sorry--if you sublet--?
subQuotationList: ['Very many thanks. I m sorry--if you sublet--?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
If he sublets, I shan t have the same control. In theory there should
be no more damage done at Howards End; in practice there will be. Things
may be done for which no money can compensate. For instance, I shouldn t
want that fine wych-elm spoilt. It hangs--Margaret, we must go and see
the old place some time. It s pretty in its way. We ll motor down and
have lunch with Charles.
subQuotationList:
['If he sublets, I shan t have the same control. In theory there should
be no more damage done at Howards End; in practice there will be. Things
may be done for which no money can compensate. For instance, I shouldn t
want that fine wych-elm spoilt. It hangs--Margaret, we must go and see
the old place some time. It s pretty in its way. We ll motor down and
have lunch with Charles.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I should enjoy that,
subQuotationList: ['I should enjoy that,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What about next Wednesday?
subQuotationList: ['What about next Wednesday?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Wednesday? No, I couldn t well do that. Aunt Juley expects us to stop
here another week at least.
subQuotationList: ['Wednesday? No, I couldn t well do that. Aunt Juley expects us to stop\nhere another week at least.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But you can give that up now.
subQuotationList: ['But you can give that up now.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Er--no,
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, that ll be all right. I ll speak to her.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, that ll be all right. I ll speak to her.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
This visit is a high solemnity. My aunt counts on it year after
year. She turns the house upside down for us; she invites our special
friends--she scarcely knows Frieda, and we can t leave her on her hands.
I missed one day, and she would be so hurt if I didn t stay the full
ten.
subQuotationList:
['This visit is a high solemnity. My aunt counts on it year after
year. She turns the house upside down for us; she invites our special
friends--she scarcely knows Frieda, and we can t leave her on her hands.
I missed one day, and she would be so hurt if I didn t stay the full
ten.']
speaker: Margaret
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Aunt Juley'], ['Aunt Juley'], ['Margaret', 'Tibby', 'Helen'], ['Aunt Juley'], ['Aunt Juley'], ['Frieda'], ['Margaret', 'Henry'], ['Frieda'], ['Aunt Juley'], ['Aunt Juley']]]

quoteText: But I ll say a word to her. Don t you bother.
subQuotationList: ['But I ll say a word to her. Don t you bother.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Henry, I won t go. Don t bully me.
subQuotationList: ['Henry, I won t go. Don t bully me.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: You want to see the house, though?
subQuotationList: ['You want to see the house, though?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Very much--I ve heard so much about it, one way or the other. Aren t
there pigs  teeth in the wych-elm?
subQuotationList: ['Very much--I ve heard so much about it, one way or the other. Aren t\nthere pigs  teeth in the wych-elm?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: PIGS TEETH?
subQuotationList: ['PIGS TEETH?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: And you chew the bark for toothache.
subQuotationList: ['And you chew the bark for toothache.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What a rum notion! Of course not!
subQuotationList: ['What a rum notion! Of course not!']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Perhaps I have confused it with some other tree. There are still a
great number of sacred trees in England, it seems.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps I have confused it with some other tree. There are still a\ngreat number of sacred trees in England, it seems.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh. Mr. Wilcox, about the Porphyrion--
subQuotationList: ['Oh. Mr. Wilcox, about the Porphyrion--']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
It s all right, Dempster s Bank s
better.
subQuotationList: ['It s all right,', 'Dempster s Bank s\nbetter.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
But I think you told us the Porphyrion was bad, and would smash before
Christmas.
subQuotationList: ['But I think you told us the Porphyrion was bad, and would smash before\nChristmas.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Did I? It was still outside the Tariff Ring, and had to take rotten
policies. Lately it came in--safe as houses now.
subQuotationList: ['Did I? It was still outside the Tariff Ring, and had to take rotten\npolicies. Lately it came in--safe as houses now.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: In other words, Mr. Bast need never have left it.
subQuotationList: ['In other words, Mr. Bast need never have left it.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: No, the fellow needn t.
subQuotationList: ['No, the fellow needn t.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: --and needn t have started life elsewhere at a greatly reduced salary.
subQuotationList: ['--and needn t have started life elsewhere at a greatly reduced salary.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: He only says  reduced,
subQuotationList: ['He only says  reduced,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
With a man so poor, every reduction must be great. I consider it a
deplorable misfortune.
subQuotationList: ['With a man so poor, every reduction must be great. I consider it a\ndeplorable misfortune.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
What? What s that? Do you mean
that I m responsible?
subQuotationList: ['What? What s that? Do you mean\nthat I m responsible?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: You re ridiculous, Helen.
subQuotationList: ['You re ridiculous, Helen.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: You seem to think--
subQuotationList: ['You seem to think--']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Let me explain the point
to you. It is like this. You seem to assume, when a business concern is
conducting a delicate negotiation, it ought to keep the public informed
stage by stage. The Porphyrion, according to you, was bound to say,  I
am trying all I can to get into the Tariff Ring. I am not sure that
I shall succeed, but it is the only thing that will save me from
insolvency, and I am trying.  My dear Helen--
subQuotationList:
['Let me explain the point
to you. It is like this. You seem to assume, when a business concern is
conducting a delicate negotiation, it ought to keep the public informed
stage by stage. The Porphyrion, according to you, was bound to say,  I
am trying all I can to get into the Tariff Ring. I am not sure that
I shall succeed, but it is the only thing that will save me from
insolvency, and I am trying.  My dear Helen--']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Is that your point? A man who had little money has less--that s mine.
subQuotationList: ['Is that your point? A man who had little money has less--that s mine.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I am grieved for your clerk. But it is all in the day s work. It s part
of the battle of life.
subQuotationList: ['I am grieved for your clerk. But it is all in the day s work. It s part\nof the battle of life.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
A man who had little money-- has less, owing to
us. Under these circumstances I consider  the battle of life  a happy
expression.
subQuotationList: ['A man who had little money--', 'has less, owing to\nus. Under these circumstances I consider  the battle of life  a happy\nexpression.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Oh come, come! you re not to blame. No one s
to blame.
subQuotationList: ['Oh come, come!', 'you re not to blame. No one s\nto blame.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Is no one to blame for anything?
subQuotationList: ['Is no one to blame for anything?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I wouldn t say that, but you re taking it far too seriously. Who is
this fellow?
subQuotationList: ['I wouldn t say that, but you re taking it far too seriously. Who is\nthis fellow?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
We have told you about the fellow twice already, You
have even met the fellow. He is very poor and his wife is an
extravagant imbecile. He is capable of better things. We--we, the upper
classes--thought we would help him from the height of our superior
knowledge--and here s the result!
subQuotationList:
['We have told you about the fellow twice already,', 'You
have even met the fellow. He is very poor and his wife is an
extravagant imbecile. He is capable of better things. We--we, the upper
classes--thought we would help him from the height of our superior
knowledge--and here s the result!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Now, a word of advice.
subQuotationList: ['Now, a word of advice.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I require no more advice.
subQuotationList: ['I require no more advice.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
A word of advice. Don t take up that sentimental attitude over the
poor. See that she doesn t, Margaret. The poor are poor, and one s sorry
for them, but there it is. As civilisation moves forward, the shoe is
bound to pinch in places, and it s absurd to pretend that any one is
responsible personally. Neither you, nor I, nor my informant, nor the
man who informed him, nor the directors of the Porphyrion, are to blame
for this clerk s loss of salary. It s just the shoe pinching--no one can
help it; and it might easily have been worse.
subQuotationList:
['A word of advice. Don t take up that sentimental attitude over the
poor. See that she doesn t, Margaret. The poor are poor, and one s sorry
for them, but there it is. As civilisation moves forward, the shoe is
bound to pinch in places, and it s absurd to pretend that any one is
responsible personally. Neither you, nor I, nor my informant, nor the
man who informed him, nor the directors of the Porphyrion, are to blame
for this clerk s loss of salary. It s just the shoe pinching--no one can
help it; and it might easily have been worse.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
By all means subscribe to charities--subscribe to them largely--but
don t get carried away by absurd schemes of Social Reform. I see a good
deal behind the scenes, and you can take it from me that there is no
Social Question--except for a few journalists who try to get a living
out of the phrase. There are just rich and poor, as there always have
been and always will be. Point me out a time when men have been equal--
subQuotationList:
['By all means subscribe to charities--subscribe to them largely--but
don t get carried away by absurd schemes of Social Reform. I see a good
deal behind the scenes, and you can take it from me that there is no
Social Question--except for a few journalists who try to get a living
out of the phrase. There are just rich and poor, as there always have
been and always will be. Point me out a time when men have been equal--']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I didn t say--
subQuotationList: ['I didn t say--']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Point me out a time when desire for equality has made them happier. No,
no. You can t. There always have been rich and poor. I m no fatalist.
Heaven forbid! But our civilisation is moulded by great impersonal
forces
subQuotationList:
['Point me out a time when desire for equality has made them happier. No,
no. You can t. There always have been rich and poor. I m no fatalist.
Heaven forbid! But our civilisation is moulded by great impersonal
forces']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: and there always will be rich and poor. You can t deny it
subQuotationList: ['and there always will be rich and poor. You can t deny it']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
and you can t deny that, in spite
of all, the tendency of civilisation has on the whole been upward.
subQuotationList: ['and you can t deny that, in spite\nof all, the tendency of civilisation has on the whole been upward.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Owing to God, I suppose,
subQuotationList: ['Owing to God, I suppose,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: You grab the dollars. God does the rest.
subQuotationList: ['You grab the dollars. God does the rest.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
She rather reminds me of
Dolly.
subQuotationList: ['She rather reminds me of\nDolly.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Don t ever discuss political economy with Henry, It ll only end in a cry.
subQuotationList: ['Don t ever discuss political economy with Henry,', 'It ll only end in a cry.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
But he must be one of those men who have reconciled science with
religion, I don t like those men. They are
scientific themselves, and talk of the survival of the fittest, and cut
down the salaries of their clerks, and stunt the independence of all who
may menace their comfort, but yet they believe that somehow good--it
is always that sloppy  somehow  will be the outcome, and that in some
mystical way the Mr. Basts of the future will benefit because the Mr.
Brits of today are in pain.
subQuotationList:
['But he must be one of those men who have reconciled science with
religion,', 'I don t like those men. They are
scientific themselves, and talk of the survival of the fittest, and cut
down the salaries of their clerks, and stunt the independence of all who
may menace their comfort, but yet they believe that somehow good--it
is always that sloppy  somehow  will be the outcome, and that in some
mystical way the Mr. Basts of the future will benefit because the Mr.
Brits of today are in pain.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: He is such a man in theory. But oh, Helen, in theory!
subQuotationList: ['He is such a man in theory. But oh, Helen, in theory!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But oh, Meg, what a theory!
subQuotationList: ['But oh, Meg, what a theory!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Why should you put things so bitterly, dearie?
subQuotationList: ['Why should you put things so bitterly, dearie?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Because I m an old maid, I can t think
why I go on like this myself.
subQuotationList: ['Because I m an old maid,', 'I can t think\nwhy I go on like this myself.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Margaret! Magsy! It isn t true, surely, what Mr.
Wilcox says, that you want to go away early next week?
subQuotationList: ['Margaret!', 'Magsy! It isn t true, surely, what Mr.\nWilcox says, that you want to go away early next week?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Not  want, but there is so much to be
settled, and I do want to see the Charles s.
subQuotationList: ['Not  want,', 'but there is so much to be\nsettled, and I do want to see the Charles s.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
But going away without taking the Weymouth trip, or even the Lulworth? Without going once more up Nine Barrows
Down?
subQuotationList: ['But going away without taking the Weymouth trip, or even the Lulworth?', 'Without going once more up Nine Barrows\nDown?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: I m afraid so.
subQuotationList: ['I m afraid so.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Good! I did the breaking of the ice.
subQuotationList: ['Good! I did the breaking of the ice.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Yes, there is a mystery.
I can t help it. It s not my fault. It s the way life has been made.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'there is a mystery.\nI can t help it. It s not my fault. It s the way life has been made.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Go on and marry him. I think you re
splendid; and if any one can pull it off, you will.
subQuotationList: ['Go on and marry him. I think you re\nsplendid; and if any one can pull it off, you will.']
speaker: Helen
referringExpression: Helen was silent for a minute and then burst into a queer speech

quoteText:
Yes, there
is, and I wasn t up to it with Paul. I can do only what s easy. I
can only entice and be enticed. I can t, and won t, attempt difficult
relations. If I marry, it will either be a man who s strong enough to
boss me or whom I m strong enough to boss. So I shan t ever marry, for
there aren t such men. And Heaven help any one whom I do marry, for I
shall certainly run away from him before you can say  Jack Robinson. 
There! Because I m uneducated. But you, you re different; you re a
heroine.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, there
is, and I wasn t up to it with Paul. I can do only what s easy. I
can only entice and be enticed. I can t, and won t, attempt difficult
relations. If I marry, it will either be a man who s strong enough to
boss me or whom I m strong enough to boss. So I shan t ever marry, for
there aren t such men. And Heaven help any one whom I do marry, for I
shall certainly run away from him before you can say  Jack Robinson. 
There! Because I m uneducated. But you, you re different; you re a
heroine.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Oh, Helen! Am I? Will it be as dreadful for poor Henry as all that?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Helen! Am I? Will it be as dreadful for poor Henry as all that?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
You mean to keep proportion, and that s heroic, it s Greek, and I don t
see why it shouldn t succeed with you. Go on and fight with him and help
him. Don t ask me for help, or even for sympathy. Henceforward I m going
my own way. I mean to be thorough, because thoroughness is easy. I
mean to dislike your husband, and to tell him so. I mean to make no
concessions to Tibby. If Tibby wants to live with me, he must lump me.
I mean to love you more than ever. Yes, I do. You and I have built
up something real, because it is purely spiritual. There s no veil of
mystery over us. Unreality and mystery begin as soon as one touches the
body. The popular view is, as usual, exactly the wrong one. Our bothers
are over tangible things--money, husbands, house-hunting. But Heaven
will work of itself.
subQuotationList:
['You mean to keep proportion, and that s heroic, it s Greek, and I don t
see why it shouldn t succeed with you. Go on and fight with him and help

will work of itself.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Perhaps.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps.']
speaker: Margaret
referringExpression: Margaret was grateful for this expression of affection and answered

quoteText:
Yes, I see, dear; it s
about half-way between,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I see, dear; it s\nabout half-way between,']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
I definitely dislike
him, but I ll do what I can, Do what you can with my
friends in return.
subQuotationList: ['I definitely dislike\nhim, but I ll do what I can,', 'Do what you can with my\nfriends in return.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: One minute!
subQuotationList: ['One minute!']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I hope that my wife--how do you do?--will give you a decent lunch, I left instructions, but we live in a rough-and-ready way.
She expects you back to tea, too, after you have had a look at Howards
End. I wonder what you ll think of the place. I wouldn t touch it with
tongs myself. Do sit down! It s a measly little place.

['I hope that my wife--how do you do?--will give you a decent lunch,', 'I left instructions, but we live in a rough-and-ready way.

quoteText: I shall enjoy seeing it,
subQuotationList: ['I shall enjoy seeing it,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
You ll see it at its worst, for Bryce decamped abroad last Monday
without even arranging for a charwoman to clear up after him. I never
saw such a disgraceful mess. It s unbelievable. He wasn t in the house a
month.
subQuotationList:
['You ll see it at its worst, for Bryce decamped abroad last Monday

subQuotationList: ['I ve more than a little bone to pick with Bryce,']

quoteText: Why did he go so suddenly?
subQuotationList: ['Why did he go so suddenly?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Invalid type; couldn t sleep.
subQuotationList: ['Invalid type; couldn t sleep.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Poor fellow!
subQuotationList: ['Poor fellow!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Poor fiddlesticks! He had the
impudence to put up notice-boards without as much as saying with your
leave or by your leave. Charles flung them down.
subQuotationList: ['Poor fiddlesticks!', 'He had the\nimpudence to put up notice-boards without as much as saying with your\nleave or by your leave. Charles flung them down.']

quoteText: Yes, I flung them down,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I flung them down,']

quoteText:
I ve sent a telegram after him, and a pretty sharp one, too. He, and
he in person, is responsible for the upkeep of that house for the next
three years.
subQuotationList: ['I ve sent a telegram after him, and a pretty sharp one, too. He, and\nhe in person, is responsible for the upkeep of that house for the next\nthree years.']

quoteText: Quite right.

quoteText: Dolly would have taken them, but I was in, fortunately.

quoteText: What s Mr. Bryce like?

Now we ll be
off,

speaker: Henry

quoteText:
They re all right, They ll learn--like the swallows
and the telegraph-wires.
subQuotationList: ['They re all right,', 'They ll learn--like the swallows\nand the telegraph-wires.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Yes, but, while they re learning--
subQuotationList: ['Yes, but, while they re learning--']

The motor s come to stay, One must get about. There s a

worries you--right outward at the scenery.

Kiss them now, and
come away,

subQuotationList: ['What do you suppose?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Are we there already?
subQuotationList: ['Are we there already?']

subQuotationList: ['We are.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Well, I never! In years ago it seemed so far away.
subQuotationList: ['Well, I never! In years ago it seemed so far away.']

subQuotationList: ['That s no good; it s locked. Who s got the key?']

Margaret, you wait in the dry. I ll go
down for the key. It isn t a hundred yards.

speaker: Henry

subQuotationList: ['Mayn t I come too?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: No; I shall be back before I m gone.
subQuotationList: ['No; I shall be back before I m gone.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Is that you, Henry?
subQuotationList: ['Is that you, Henry?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Henry, have you got in?
subQuotationList: ['Henry, have you got in?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh! Well, I took you for Ruth Wilcox.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! Well, I took you for Ruth Wilcox.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: I--Mrs. Wilcox--I?
subQuotationList: ['I--Mrs. Wilcox--I?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: In fancy, of course--in fancy. You had her way of walking. Good-day.
subQuotationList: ['In fancy, of course--in fancy. You had her way of walking. Good-day.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText:
It gave her quite a turn, None of you girls have any nerves, really. Of
course, a word from me put it all right, but silly old Miss Avery--she
frightened you, didn t she, Margaret? There you stood clutching a bunch
of weeds. She might have said something, instead of coming down the
stairs with that alarming bonnet on. I passed her as I came in. Enough
to make the car shy. I believe Miss Avery goes in for being a character;
some old maids do. It is their last resource.
Heaven knows what she was doing in the place; but that s Bryce s
business, not mine.

some old maids do.', 'It is their last resource.
Heaven knows what she was doing in the place; but that s Bryce s
business, not mine.']

quoteText:
I wasn t as foolish as you suggest, She only startled
me, for the house had been silent so long.
subQuotationList: ['I wasn t as foolish as you suggest,', 'She only startled\nme, for the house had been silent so long.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Did you take her for a spook?
subQuotationList: ['Did you take her for a spook?']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: Not exactly.
subQuotationList: ['Not exactly.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
She really did frighten you, Poor Margaret! And very naturally. Uneducated
classes are so stupid.
subQuotationList: ['She really did frighten you,', 'Poor Margaret! And very naturally. Uneducated\nclasses are so stupid.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Is Miss Avery uneducated classes?
subQuotationList: ['Is Miss Avery uneducated classes?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
She s just one of the crew at the farm. People like that always assume
things. She assumed you d know who she was. She left all the Howards End
keys in the front lobby, and assumed that you d seen them as you came
in, that you d lock up the house when you d done, and would bring them
on down to her. And there was her niece hunting for them down at the
farm. Lack of education makes people very casual. Hilton was full of
women like Miss Avery once.
subQuotationList:
['She s just one of the crew at the farm. People like that always assume
things. She assumed you d know who she was. She left all the Howards End
keys in the front lobby, and assumed that you d seen them as you came
in, that you d lock up the house when you d done, and would bring them
on down to her. And there was her niece hunting for them down at the
farm. Lack of education makes people very casual. Hilton was full of

quoteText: I shouldn t have disliked it, perhaps.
subQuotationList: ['I shouldn t have disliked it, perhaps.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Or Miss Avery giving me a wedding present,
subQuotationList: ['Or Miss Avery giving me a wedding present,']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
But Charles said I must try not to mind, because she had known his
grandmother.
subQuotationList: ['But Charles said I must try not to mind, because she had known his\ngrandmother.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: As usual, you ve got the story wrong, my good Dorothea.
subQuotationList: ['As usual, you ve got the story wrong, my good Dorothea.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I meant great-grandmother--the one who left Mrs. Wilcox the house.
Weren t both of them and Miss Avery friends when Howards End, too, was a
farm?
subQuotationList: ['I meant great-grandmother--the one who left Mrs. Wilcox the house.\nWeren t both of them and Miss Avery friends when Howards End, too, was a\nfarm?']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
Then hadn t Mrs. Wilcox a brother--or was it an uncle? Anyhow, he
popped the question, and Miss Avery, she said  No.  Just imagine, if
she d said  Yes,  she would have been Charles s aunt. (Oh, I say,
that s rather good!  Charlie s Aunt ! I must chaff him about that this
evening.) And the man went out and was killed. Yes, I m certain I ve
got it right now. Tom Howard--he was the last of them.
subQuotationList:
['Then hadn t Mrs. Wilcox a brother--or was it an uncle? Anyhow, he
popped the question, and Miss Avery, she said  No.  Just imagine, if

quoteText: I believe so,
subQuotationList: ['I believe so,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I say! Howards End--Howards Ended! I m rather on the
spot this evening, eh?
subQuotationList: ['I say! Howards End--Howards Ended!', 'I m rather on the\nspot this evening, eh?']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: I wish you d ask whether Crane s ended.
subQuotationList: ['I wish you d ask whether Crane s ended.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Oh, Mr. Wilcox, how can you?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Mr. Wilcox, how can you?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Because, if he has had enough tea, we ought to go--Dolly s a good
little woman, but a little of her goes a long way. I
couldn t live near her if you paid me.
subQuotationList: ['Because, if he has had enough tea, we ought to go--Dolly s a good\nlittle woman,', 'but a little of her goes a long way. I\ncouldn t live near her if you paid me.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Curious mounds, but in with you now;
another time.
subQuotationList: ['Curious mounds,', 'but in with you now;\nanother time.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
It is so unlucky, that money wasn t put into it about fifty years ago.
Then it had four--five--times the land--thirty acres at least. One
could have made something out of it then--a small park, or at all events
shrubberies, and rebuilt the house farther away from the road. What s
the good of taking it in hand now? Nothing but the meadow left, and even
that was heavily mortgaged when I first had to do with things--yes, and
the house too. Oh, it was no joke. Mismanagement did it--besides, the days for
small farms are over. It doesn t pay--except with intensive cultivation.
Small holdings, back to the land--ah! philanthropic bunkum. Take it as a
rule that nothing pays on a small scale. Most of the land you see belongs
to the people at the Park--they made their pile over copper--good chaps.
Avery s Farm, Sishe s--what they call the Common, where you see that
ruined oak--one after the other fell in, and so did this, as near as
is no matter. When I had more control I did what I could--sold off the two and a half
animals, and the mangy pony, and the superannuated tools; pulled down
the outhouses; drained; thinned out I don t know how many guelder-roses
and elder-trees; and inside the house I turned the old kitchen into a
hall, and made a kitchen behind where the dairy was. Garage and so on
came later. But one could still tell it s been an old farm. And yet
it isn t the place that would fetch one of your artistic crew.
subQuotationList:
['It is so unlucky,', 'that money wasn t put into it about fifty years ago.

subQuotationList: ['Extraordinary!', 'Who told you?']

speaker: Margaret

But I never dreamt of such a thing, Dad took
me to call now and then, and made me ask her to Simpson s. Well, I m
altogether off dad.

For God s sake, hurry the women up;
we shall never be off,

Not I; I ve done
my share,

They threaten to
cut the painter, and where shall we be then? Miss Schlegel,

will be

quoteText: There! It s only a rotten cat.
subQuotationList: ['There!', 'It s only a rotten cat.']

quoteText:
Got room in your car for a little un? I cut as soon as I saw it wasn t
a dog; the chauffeurs are tackling the girl.
subQuotationList: ['Got room in your car for a little un? I cut as soon as I saw it wasn t\na dog; the chauffeurs are tackling the girl.']
speaker: Albert Fussell

quoteText: Miss Schlegel!  Pon my word, you ve hurt your hand.
subQuotationList: ['Miss Schlegel!  Pon my word, you ve hurt your hand.']
speaker: Albert Fussell

quoteText: I m just going to see, Don t you wait, Mr. Fussell.
subQuotationList: ['I m just going to see,', 'Don t you wait, Mr. Fussell.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It is all right, madam,
subQuotationList: ['It is all right, madam,']

quoteText: What s all right? The cat?
subQuotationList: ['What s all right? The cat?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes, madam. The girl will receive compensation for it.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, madam. The girl will receive compensation for it.']
speaker: Crane

quoteText: She was a very ruda girla,
subQuotationList: ['She was a very ruda girla,']
speaker: Angelo

quoteText: Wouldn t you have been rude?
subQuotationList: ['Wouldn t you have been rude?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Oh, Henry, I have been so naughty, We ran over a cat. Charles told me not to
jump out, but I would, and look! Your
poor Meg went such a flop.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Henry,', 'I have been so naughty,', 'We ran over a cat. Charles told me not to\njump out, but I would, and look!', 'Your\npoor Meg went such a flop.']

quoteText: Thinking it was a dog,
subQuotationList: ['Thinking it was a dog,']
speaker: Mrs. Warrington

quoteText: Ah, a dog s a companion! A dog ll remember you.
subQuotationList: ['Ah, a dog s a companion!', 'A dog ll remember you.']
speaker: Colonel Fussell

quoteText: Have you hurt yourself, Margaret?
subQuotationList: ['Have you hurt yourself, Margaret?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Not to speak about; and it s my left hand.
subQuotationList: ['Not to speak about; and it s my left hand.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Well, hurry up and change.
subQuotationList: ['Well, hurry up and change.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Now, Charles, what s happened?
subQuotationList: ['Now, Charles, what s happened?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
It is all very well, the pater s saying that he will be just to all, but one
can t be just indefinitely. Money isn t elastic. What s to happen if
Evie has a family? And, come to that, so may the pater. There ll not be
enough to go round, for there s none coming in, either through Dolly or
Percy. It s damnable!
subQuotationList:
['It is all very well,', 'the pater s saying that he will be just to all, but one
can t be just indefinitely. Money isn t elastic. What s to happen if

speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Hullo! Who s that?
subQuotationList: ['Hullo! Who s that?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Saxon or Celt? But it
doesn t matter. Whichever you are, you will have to listen to me. I love
this place. I love Shropshire. I hate London. I am glad that this will
be my home. Ah, dear what
a comfort to have arrived!
subQuotationList:
['Saxon or Celt?', 'But it
doesn t matter. Whichever you are, you will have to listen to me. I love
this place. I love Shropshire. I hate London. I am glad that this will

a comfort to have arrived!']

quoteText: That woman means mischief,
subQuotationList: ['That woman means mischief,']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
Good-morning,
dear,
subQuotationList: ['Good-morning,\ndear,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Miss Wilcox is up--
subQuotationList: ['Miss Wilcox is up--']
speaker: The Child

quoteText: What is that?
subQuotationList: ['What is that?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I can t hear.
subQuotationList: ['I can t hear.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: --On the bed--tissue-paper--
subQuotationList: ['--On the bed--tissue-paper--']
speaker: The Child

quoteText:
Dolly is a rotter not to be here! Oh, we would rag just
then!
subQuotationList: ['Dolly is a rotter not to be here! Oh, we would rag just\nthen!']
speaker: Evie

quoteText:
Burton, serve tea and coffee from the
sideboard!
subQuotationList: ['Burton,', 'serve tea and coffee from the\nsideboard!']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Certainly, dear, Of course, I have the time. What do you
want?
subQuotationList: ['Certainly, dear,', 'Of course, I have the time. What do you\nwant?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Nothing.
subQuotationList: ['Nothing.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I was afraid something had gone wrong.
subQuotationList: ['I was afraid something had gone wrong.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: No; I have nothing to say, but you may talk.
subQuotationList: ['No; I have nothing to say, but you may talk.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
If there is this nasty curve, couldn t we walk to the
church? Not, of course, you and Evie; but the rest of us might very well
go on first, and that would mean fewer carriages.
subQuotationList: ['If there is this nasty curve,', 'couldn t we walk to the\nchurch? Not, of course, you and Evie; but the rest of us might very well\ngo on first, and that would mean fewer carriages.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
One can t have ladies walking through the Market Square. The Fussells
wouldn t like it; they were awfully particular at Charles s wedding.
My--she--our party was anxious to walk, and certainly the church was
just round the corner, and I shouldn t have minded; but the Colonel made
a great point of it.
subQuotationList:
['One can t have ladies walking through the Market Square. The Fussells
wouldn t like it; they were awfully particular at Charles s wedding.

speaker: Henry

quoteText: You men shouldn t be so chivalrous,
subQuotationList: ['You men shouldn t be so chivalrous,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Why not?
subQuotationList: ['Why not?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: By your leave; let me pass, please.
subQuotationList: ['By your leave; let me pass, please.']
speaker: A Little Boy

quoteText:
We shall
never get through it!
subQuotationList: ['We shall\nnever get through it!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I think it did go off
well, Since I had to jump out of the motor, I m thankful I
lighted on my left hand. I am so very glad about it, Henry dear; I only
hope that the guests at ours may be half as comfortable. You must all
remember that we have no practical person among us, except my aunt, and
she is not used to entertainments on a large scale.
subQuotationList:
['I think it did go off
well,', 'Since I had to jump out of the motor, I m thankful I
lighted on my left hand. I am so very glad about it, Henry dear; I only
hope that the guests at ours may be half as comfortable. You must all
remember that we have no practical person among us, except my aunt, and
she is not used to entertainments on a large scale.']

quoteText:
I know, Under the circumstances, it would be better
to put everything into the hands of Harrods or Whiteley s, or even to go
to some hotel.
subQuotationList: ['I know,', 'Under the circumstances, it would be better\nto put everything into the hands of Harrods or Whiteley s, or even to go\nto some hotel.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: You desire a hotel?
subQuotationList: ['You desire a hotel?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Yes, because--well, I mustn t interfere with you. No doubt you want to
be married from your old home.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, because--well, I mustn t interfere with you. No doubt you want to\nbe married from your old home.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
My old home s falling into pieces, Henry. I only want my new. Isn t it
a perfect evening--
subQuotationList: ['My old home s falling into pieces, Henry. I only want my new. Isn t it\na perfect evening--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: The Alexandrina isn t bad--
subQuotationList: ['The Alexandrina isn t bad--']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: The Alexandrina,
subQuotationList: ['The Alexandrina,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It s off Curzon Street.
subQuotationList: ['It s off Curzon Street.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Is it? Let s be married from off Curzon Street.
subQuotationList: ['Is it? Let s be married from off Curzon Street.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Who are those people?
subQuotationList: ['Who are those people?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: They re callers! It s too late for callers.
subQuotationList: ['They re callers!', 'It s too late for callers.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Perhaps they re town people who want to see the wedding presents.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps they re town people who want to see the wedding presents.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I m not at home yet to townees.
subQuotationList: ['I m not at home yet to townees.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Well, hide among the ruins, and if I can stop them, I will.
subQuotationList: ['Well, hide among the ruins, and if I can stop them, I will.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What is it? Oh, what s wrong? Is Tibby ill?
subQuotationList: ['What is it?', 'Oh, what s wrong? Is Tibby ill?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: They re starving! I found them starving!
subQuotationList: ['They re starving!', 'I found them starving!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Who? Why have you come?
subQuotationList: ['Who? Why have you come?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: The Basts.
subQuotationList: ['The Basts.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Oh, Helen! Whatever have you done now?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Helen!', 'Whatever have you done now?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
He has lost his place. He has been turned out of his bank. Yes, he s
done for. We upper classes have ruined him, and I suppose you ll tell
me it s the battle of life. Starving. His wife is ill. Starving. She
fainted in the train.
subQuotationList:
['He has lost his place. He has been turned out of his bank. Yes, he s
done for. We upper classes have ruined him, and I suppose you ll tell
me it s the battle of life. Starving. His wife is ill. Starving. She
fainted in the train.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Helen, are you mad?
subQuotationList: ['Helen, are you mad?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Perhaps. Yes. If you like, I m mad. But I ve brought them. I ll stand
injustice no longer. I ll show up the wretchedness that lies under this
luxury, this talk of impersonal forces, this cant about God doing what
we re too slack to do ourselves.
subQuotationList:
['Perhaps. Yes. If you like, I m mad. But I ve brought them. I ll stand
injustice no longer. I ll show up the wretchedness that lies under this
luxury, this talk of impersonal forces, this cant about God doing what
we re too slack to do ourselves.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Have you actually brought two starving people from London to
Shropshire, Helen?
subQuotationList: ['Have you actually brought two starving people from London to\nShropshire, Helen?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: There was a restaurant car on the train,
subQuotationList: ['There was a restaurant car on the train,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Don t be absurd. They aren t starving, and you know it. Now, begin from
the beginning. I won t have such theatrical nonsense. How dare you! Yes,
how dare you! bursting in to Evie s
wedding in this heartless way. My goodness! but you ve a perverted
notion of philanthropy. Look servants,
people out of the windows. They think it s some vulgar scandal, and
I must explain,  Oh no, it s only my sister screaming, and only two
hangers-on of ours, whom she has brought here for no conceivable
reason.
subQuotationList:
['Don t be absurd. They aren t starving, and you know it. Now, begin from
the beginning. I won t have such theatrical nonsense. How dare you! Yes,
how dare you!', 'bursting in to Evie s
wedding in this heartless way. My goodness! but you ve a perverted
notion of philanthropy. Look', 'servants,
people out of the windows. They think it s some vulgar scandal, and
I must explain,  Oh no, it s only my sister screaming, and only two
hangers-on of ours, whom she has brought here for no conceivable
reason.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Kindly take back that word  hangers-on,
subQuotationList: ['Kindly take back that word  hangers-on,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Very well, I, too, am sorry about them, but it beats me why
you ve brought them here, or why you re here yourself.
subQuotationList: ['Very well,', 'I, too, am sorry about them, but it beats me why\nyou ve brought them here, or why you re here yourself.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It s our last chance of seeing Mr. Wilcox.
subQuotationList: ['It s our last chance of seeing Mr. Wilcox.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: He s going to Scotland. I know he is. I insist on seeing him.
subQuotationList: ['He s going to Scotland. I know he is. I insist on seeing him.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Yes, to-morrow.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, to-morrow.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I knew it was our last chance.
subQuotationList: ['I knew it was our last chance.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: How do you do, Mr. Bast? This is an odd business. What view do you take of it?
subQuotationList: ['How do you do, Mr. Bast?', 'This is an odd business. What view do you take of it?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: There is Mrs. Bast, too,
subQuotationList: ['There is Mrs. Bast, too,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: You have fainted, Perhaps the air will do you good.
subQuotationList: ['You have fainted,', 'Perhaps the air will do you good.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I m sure I don t want to intrude, But you have been so kind to me in the past
in warning me about the Porphyrion that I wondered--why, I wondered
whether--
subQuotationList: ['I m sure I don t want to intrude,', 'But you have been so kind to me in the past\nin warning me about the Porphyrion that I wondered--why, I wondered\nwhether--']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Whether we could get him back into the Porphyrion again, Meg, this has been a cheerful business. A bright evening s work
that was on Chelsea Embankment.
subQuotationList: ['Whether we could get him back into the Porphyrion again,', 'Meg, this has been a cheerful business. A bright evening s work\nthat was on Chelsea Embankment.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I don t understand. You left the Porphyrion because we suggested it was
a bad concern, didn t you?
subQuotationList: ['I don t understand. You left the Porphyrion because we suggested it was\na bad concern, didn t you?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: That s right.
subQuotationList: ['That s right.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: And went into a bank instead?
subQuotationList: ['And went into a bank instead?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I told you all that, and they reduced their staff after
he had been in a month, and now he s penniless, and I consider that we
and our informant are directly to blame.
subQuotationList: ['I told you all that,', 'and they reduced their staff after\nhe had been in a month, and now he s penniless, and I consider that we\nand our informant are directly to blame.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I hate all this,
subQuotationList: ['I hate all this,']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
I hope you do, Mr. Bast. But it s no good mincing matters. You have
done yourself no good by coming here. If you intend to confront Mr.
Wilcox, and to call him to account for a chance remark, you will make a
very great mistake.
subQuotationList:
['I hope you do, Mr. Bast. But it s no good mincing matters. You have
done yourself no good by coming here. If you intend to confront Mr.
Wilcox, and to call him to account for a chance remark, you will make a
very great mistake.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I brought them. I did it all,
subQuotationList: ['I brought them. I did it all,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I can only advise you to go at once. My sister has put you in a false
position, and it is kindest to tell you so. It s too late to get to
town, but you ll find a comfortable hotel in Oniton, where Mrs. Bast can
rest, and I hope you ll be my guests there.
subQuotationList:
['I can only advise you to go at once. My sister has put you in a false
position, and it is kindest to tell you so. It s too late to get to
town, but you ll find a comfortable hotel in Oniton, where Mrs. Bast can
rest, and I hope you ll be my guests there.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
That isn t what I want, Miss Schlegel, You re very
kind, and no doubt it s a false position, but you make me miserable. I
seem no good at all.
subQuotationList: ['That isn t what I want, Miss Schlegel,', 'You re very\nkind, and no doubt it s a false position, but you make me miserable. I\nseem no good at all.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: It s work he wants, Can t you see?
subQuotationList: ['It s work he wants,', 'Can t you see?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Jacky, let s go. We re more bother than we re worth.
We re costing these ladies pounds and pounds already to get work for us,
and they never will. There s nothing we re good enough to do.
subQuotationList: ['Jacky, let s go. We re more bother than we re worth.\nWe re costing these ladies pounds and pounds already to get work for us,\nand they never will. There s nothing we re good enough to do.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
We would like to find you work, We want to--I, like my sister. You re only down in your luck. Go to the
hotel, have a good night s rest, and some day you shall pay me back the
bill, if you prefer it.
subQuotationList: ['We would like to find you work,', 'We want to--I, like my sister. You re only down in your luck. Go to the\nhotel, have a good night s rest, and some day you shall pay me back the\nbill, if you prefer it.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
You don t know what you re talking about, I shall never get
work now. If rich people fail at one profession, they can try another.
Not I. I had my groove, and I ve got out of it. I could do one
particular branch of insurance in one particular office well enough to
command a salary, but that s all. Poetry s nothing, Miss Schlegel. One s
thoughts about this and that are nothing. Your money, too, is nothing,
if you ll understand me. I mean if a man over twenty once loses his own
particular job, it s all over with him. I have seen it happen to others.
Their friends gave them money for a little, but in the end they fall
over the edge. It s no good. It s the whole world pulling. There always
will be rich and poor.
subQuotationList:
['You don t know what you re talking about,', 'I shall never get
work now. If rich people fail at one profession, they can try another.
Not I. I had my groove, and I ve got out of it. I could do one
particular branch of insurance in one particular office well enough to
command a salary, but that s all. Poetry s nothing, Miss Schlegel. One s
thoughts about this and that are nothing. Your money, too, is nothing,
if you ll understand me. I mean if a man over twenty once loses his own
particular job, it s all over with him. I have seen it happen to others.
Their friends gave them money for a little, but in the end they fall
over the edge. It s no good. It s the whole world pulling. There always
will be rich and poor.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Won t you have something to eat? I don t
know what to do. It isn t my house, and though Mr. Wilcox would have
been glad to see you at any other time--as I say, I don t know what
to do, but I undertake to do what I can for you. Helen, offer them
something. Do try a sandwich, Mrs. Bast.
subQuotationList:
['Won t you have something to eat?', 'I don t
know what to do. It isn t my house, and though Mr. Wilcox would have
been glad to see you at any other time--as I say, I don t know what
to do, but I undertake to do what I can for you. Helen, offer them
something. Do try a sandwich, Mrs. Bast.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Helen, I like Mr. Bast. I agree that he s worth helping. I
agree that we are directly responsible.
subQuotationList: ['Helen, I like Mr. Bast. I agree that he s worth helping. I\nagree that we are directly responsible.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: No, indirectly. Via Mr. Wilcox.
subQuotationList: ['No, indirectly. Via Mr. Wilcox.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Let me tell you once for all that if you take up that attitude, I ll
do nothing. No doubt you re right logically, and are entitled to say
a great many scathing things about Henry. Only, I won t have it. So
choose.
subQuotationList:
['Let me tell you once for all that if you take up that attitude, I ll
do nothing. No doubt you re right logically, and are entitled to say
a great many scathing things about Henry. Only, I won t have it. So
choose.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
If you promise to take them quietly to the George I will speak to Henry
about them--in my own way, mind; there is to be none of this absurd
screaming about justice. I have no use for justice. If it was only a
question of money, we could do it ourselves. But he wants work, and that
we can t give him, but possibly Henry can.
subQuotationList:
['If you promise to take them quietly to the George I will speak to Henry
about them--in my own way, mind; there is to be none of this absurd
screaming about justice. I have no use for justice. If it was only a
question of money, we could do it ourselves. But he wants work, and that
we can t give him, but possibly Henry can.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It s his duty to,
subQuotationList: ['It s his duty to,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Nor am I concerned with duty. I m concerned with the characters of
various people whom we know, and how, things being as they are, things
may be made a little better. Mr. Wilcox hates being asked favours; all
business men do. But I am going to ask him, at the risk of a rebuff,
because I want to make things a little better.
subQuotationList:
['Nor am I concerned with duty. I m concerned with the characters of
various people whom we know, and how, things being as they are, things
may be made a little better. Mr. Wilcox hates being asked favours; all
business men do. But I am going to ask him, at the risk of a rebuff,
because I want to make things a little better.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Very well. I promise. You take it very calmly.
subQuotationList: ['Very well. I promise. You take it very calmly.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Take them off to the George, then, and I ll try. Poor creatures! but
they look tired. I haven t nearly done with
you, though, Helen. You have been most self-indulgent. I can t get over
it. You have less restraint rather than more as you grow older. Think it
over and alter yourself, or we shan t have happy lives.
subQuotationList:
['Take them off to the George, then, and I ll try. Poor creatures! but
they look tired.', 'I haven t nearly done with
you, though, Helen. You have been most self-indulgent. I can t get over
it. You have less restraint rather than more as you grow older. Think it
over and alter yourself, or we shan t have happy lives.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Was it townees?
subQuotationList: ['Was it townees?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
You ll never believe me, It s
all right now, but it was my sister.
subQuotationList: ['You ll never believe me,', 'It s\nall right now, but it was my sister.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Helen here? But she refused the
invitation. I thought hated weddings.
subQuotationList: ['Helen here?', 'But she refused the\ninvitation. I thought hated weddings.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Don t get up. She has not come to the wedding. I ve bundled her off to
the George.
subQuotationList: ['Don t get up. She has not come to the wedding. I ve bundled her off to\nthe George.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: No; she has two of her proteges with her and must keep with them.
subQuotationList: ['No; she has two of her proteges with her and must keep with them.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Let  em all come.
subQuotationList: ['Let  em all come.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: My dear Henry, did you see them?
subQuotationList: ['My dear Henry, did you see them?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I did catch sight of a brown bunch of a woman, certainly.
subQuotationList: ['I did catch sight of a brown bunch of a woman, certainly.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
The brown bunch was Helen, but did you catch sight of a sea-green and
salmon bunch?
subQuotationList: ['The brown bunch was Helen, but did you catch sight of a sea-green and\nsalmon bunch?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What! are they out bean-feasting?
subQuotationList: ['What! are they out bean-feasting?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
No; business. They wanted to see me, and later on I want to talk to you
about them.
subQuotationList: ['No; business. They wanted to see me, and later on I want to talk to you\nabout them.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Why later
on? Tell me now. No time like the present.
subQuotationList: ['Why later\non? Tell me now. No time like the present.']
speaker: Henry
referringExpression: Henry took the hint at once and said

quoteText: Shall I?
subQuotationList: ['Shall I?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: If it isn t a long story.
subQuotationList: ['If it isn t a long story.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Oh, not five minutes; but there s a sting at the end of it, for I want
you to find the man some work in your office.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, not five minutes; but there s a sting at the end of it, for I want\nyou to find the man some work in your office.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What are his qualifications?
subQuotationList: ['What are his qualifications?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I don t know. He s a clerk.
subQuotationList: ['I don t know. He s a clerk.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: How old?
subQuotationList: ['How old?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Twenty-five, perhaps.
subQuotationList: ['Twenty-five, perhaps.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What s his name?
subQuotationList: ['What s his name?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Bast,
subQuotationList: ['Bast,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Where was he before?
subQuotationList: ['Where was he before?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Dempster s Bank.
subQuotationList: ['Dempster s Bank.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Why did he leave?
subQuotationList: ['Why did he leave?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: They reduced their staff.
subQuotationList: ['They reduced their staff.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: All right; I ll see him.
subQuotationList: ['All right; I ll see him.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
The woman who can t influence
her husband to vote the way she wants ought to be ashamed of herself.
subQuotationList: ['The woman who can t influence\nher husband to vote the way she wants ought to be ashamed of herself.']
speaker: Mrs. Plynlimmon
referringExpression: Mrs Plynlimmon when condemning suffragettes had said

quoteText:
I should be glad if you took him, but I don t know whether
he s qualified.
subQuotationList: ['I should be glad if you took him,', 'but I don t know whether\nhe s qualified.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I ll do what I can. But, Margaret, this mustn t be taken as a
precedent.
subQuotationList: ['I ll do what I can. But, Margaret, this mustn t be taken as a\nprecedent.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: No, of course--of course--
subQuotationList: ['No, of course--of course--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I can t fit in your proteges every day. Business would suffer.
subQuotationList: ['I can t fit in your proteges every day. Business would suffer.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I can promise you he s the last. He--he s rather a special case.
subQuotationList: ['I can promise you he s the last. He--he s rather a special case.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Proteges always are.
subQuotationList: ['Proteges always are.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Your protege has made us late, The Fussells--will just be
starting.
subQuotationList: ['Your protege has made us late,', 'The Fussells--will just be\nstarting.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: She s overtired,
subQuotationList: ['She s overtired,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
She s something else, This won t do. I can t have her in
my garden in this state.
subQuotationList: ['She s something else,', 'This won t do. I can t have her in\nmy garden in this state.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Is she--
subQuotationList: ['Is she--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Madam, you will be more comfortable at the hotel,
subQuotationList: ['Madam, you will be more comfortable at the hotel,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: If it isn t Hen!
subQuotationList: ['If it isn t Hen!']
speaker: Jacky

quoteText:
Ne crois pas que le mari lui ressemble, Il est
tout   fait diff rent.
subQuotationList: ['Ne crois pas que le mari lui ressemble,', 'Il est\ntout   fait diff rent.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Henry!
subQuotationList: ['Henry!']
speaker: Jacky

quoteText: I congratulate you on your proteges,
subQuotationList: ['I congratulate you on your proteges,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Hen, don t go. You do love me, dear, don t you?
subQuotationList: ['Hen, don t go. You do love me, dear, don t you?']
speaker: Jacky

quoteText: Bless us, what a person!
subQuotationList: ['Bless us, what a person!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: You re a nice boy, you are.
subQuotationList: ['You re a nice boy, you are.']
speaker: Jacky

quoteText: There now, I love you.
subQuotationList: ['There now, I love you.']
speaker: Jacky

quoteText: Henry, I am awfully sorry.
subQuotationList: ['Henry, I am awfully sorry.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: And pray why?
subQuotationList: ['And pray why?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: To have brought this down on you.
subQuotationList: ['To have brought this down on you.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Pray don t apologise.
subQuotationList: ['Pray don t apologise.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Why does she call you  Hen ? Has she ever
seen you before?
subQuotationList: ['Why does she call you  Hen ?', 'Has she ever\nseen you before?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Seen Hen before! Who hasn t seen Hen? He s serving you
like me, my boys! You wait--Still we love  em.
subQuotationList: ['Seen Hen before!', 'Who hasn t seen Hen? He s serving you\nlike me, my boys! You wait--Still we love  em.']
speaker: Jacky

quoteText: Are you now satisfied?
subQuotationList: ['Are you now satisfied?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I don t know what it is all about, Let s come in.
subQuotationList: ['I don t know what it is all about,', 'Let s come in.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Don t you indeed? I do. Allow
me to congratulate you on the success of your plan.
subQuotationList: ['Don t you indeed?', 'I do. Allow\nme to congratulate you on the success of your plan.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: This is Helen s plan, not mine.
subQuotationList: ['This is Helen s plan, not mine.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I now understand your interest in the Basts. Very well thought out.
I am amused at your caution, Margaret. You are quite right--it was
necessary. I am a man, and have lived a man s past. I have the honour to
release you from your engagement.
subQuotationList:
['I now understand your interest in the Basts. Very well thought out.
I am amused at your caution, Margaret. You are quite right--it was
necessary. I am a man, and have lived a man s past. I have the honour to
release you from your engagement.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: So that--
subQuotationList: ['So that--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: So what?
subQuotationList: ['So what?']
speaker: Colonel Fussell

quoteText:
We were saying--Henry and I were just having the fiercest argument, my
point being--
subQuotationList: ['We were saying--Henry and I were just having the fiercest argument, my\npoint being--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: No, let me do that,
subQuotationList: ['No, let me do that,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Thanks so much! You see--he has forgiven me!
subQuotationList: ['Thanks so much! You see--he has forgiven me!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I don t expect there s much to forgive.
subQuotationList: ['I don t expect there s much to forgive.']
speaker: Colonel Fussell

quoteText: So that woman has been your mistress?
subQuotationList: ['So that woman has been your mistress?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: You put it with your usual delicacy,
subQuotationList: ['You put it with your usual delicacy,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: When, please?
subQuotationList: ['When, please?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Why?
speaker: Henry

quoteText: When, please?
subQuotationList: ['When, please?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Ten years ago.
subQuotationList: ['Ten years ago.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Mr. Wilcox is so illogical, If we
told him it was his duty to take you on, he might refuse to do it. The
fact is, he isn t properly educated. I don t want to set you against
him, but you ll find him a trial.
subQuotationList:
['Mr. Wilcox is so illogical,', 'If we
told him it was his duty to take you on, he might refuse to do it. The
fact is, he isn t properly educated. I don t want to set you against
him, but you ll find him a trial.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I can never thank you sufficiently, Miss Schlegel,
subQuotationList: ['I can never thank you sufficiently, Miss Schlegel,']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
I believe in personal responsibility. Don t you? And in personal
everything. I hate--I suppose I oughtn t to say that--but the Wilcoxes
are on the wrong tack surely. Or perhaps it isn t their fault. Perhaps
the little thing that says  I  is missing out of the middle of their
heads, and then it s a waste of time to blame them. There s a nightmare
of a theory that says a special race is being born which will rule the
rest of us in the future just because it lacks the little thing that
says  I.  Had you heard that?
subQuotationList:
['I believe in personal responsibility. Don t you? And in personal
everything. I hate--I suppose I oughtn t to say that--but the Wilcoxes
are on the wrong tack surely. Or perhaps it isn t their fault. Perhaps
the little thing that says  I  is missing out of the middle of their
heads, and then it s a waste of time to blame them. There s a nightmare
of a theory that says a special race is being born which will rule the
rest of us in the future just because it lacks the little thing that
says  I.  Had you heard that?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I get no time for reading.
subQuotationList: ['I get no time for reading.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Had you thought it, then? That there are two kinds of people--our kind,
who live straight from the middle of their heads, and the other kind
who can t, because their heads have no middle? They can t say  I.  They
AREN T in fact, and so they re supermen. Pierpont Morgan has never said
 I  in his life.
subQuotationList:
['Had you thought it, then? That there are two kinds of people--our kind,
who live straight from the middle of their heads, and the other kind
who can t, because their heads have no middle? They can t say  I.  They
AREN T in fact, and so they re supermen. Pierpont Morgan has never said
 I  in his life.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I never got on to Nietzsche, But I always understood
that those supermen were rather what you may call egoists.
subQuotationList: ['I never got on to Nietzsche,', 'But I always understood\nthat those supermen were rather what you may call egoists.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Oh no, that s wrong, No superman ever said  I want, 
because  I want  must lead to the question,  Who am I?  and so to Pity
and to Justice. He only says  want.   Want Europe,  if he s Napoleon;
 want wives,  if he s Bluebeard;  want Botticelli,  if he s Pierpont
Morgan. Never the  I ; and if you could pierce through the superman,
you d find panic and emptiness in the middle."
subQuotationList:
['Oh no, that s wrong,', 'No superman ever said  I want, 
because  I want  must lead to the question,  Who am I?  and so to Pity
and to Justice. He only says  want.   Want Europe,  if he s Napoleon;
 want wives,  if he s Bluebeard;  want Botticelli,  if he s Pierpont
Morgan. Never the  I ; and if you could pierce through the superman,
you d find panic and emptiness in the middle."']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
May I take it, Miss
Schlegel, that you and I are both the sort that say  I ?
subQuotationList: ['May I take it, Miss\nSchlegel, that you and I are both the sort that say  I ?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Of course.
subQuotationList: ['Of course.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: And your sister, too?
subQuotationList: ['And your sister, too?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Of course, All presentable people say
 I.
subQuotationList: ['Of course,', 'All presentable people say\n I.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: But Mr. Wilcox--he is not perhaps--
subQuotationList: ['But Mr. Wilcox--he is not perhaps--']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: I don t know that it s any good discussing Mr. Wilcox either.
subQuotationList: ['I don t know that it s any good discussing Mr. Wilcox either.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Quite so, quite so,
subQuotationList: ['Quite so, quite so,']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Mrs.
Bast--does she ever say  I ? Is she very tired?
subQuotationList: ['Mrs.\nBast--does she ever say  I ?', 'Is she very tired?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: It s better she stops in her room,
subQuotationList: ['It s better she stops in her room,']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Shall I sit up with her?
subQuotationList: ['Shall I sit up with her?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: No, thank you; she does not need company.
subQuotationList: ['No, thank you; she does not need company.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Mr. Bast, what kind of woman is your wife?
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Bast, what kind of woman is your wife?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: You ought to know my ways by now. Does that question offend you?
subQuotationList: ['You ought to know my ways by now. Does that question offend you?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: No, oh no, Miss Schlegel, no.
subQuotationList: ['No, oh no, Miss Schlegel, no.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Because I love honesty. Don t pretend your marriage has been a happy
one. You and she can have nothing in common.
subQuotationList: ['Because I love honesty. Don t pretend your marriage has been a happy\none. You and she can have nothing in common.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I suppose that s pretty obvious;
but Jacky never meant to do anybody any harm. When things went wrong,
or I heard things, I used to think it was her fault, but, looking back,
it s more mine. I needn t have married her, but as I have I must stick
to her and keep her.
subQuotationList:
