['I suppose that s pretty obvious;
but Jacky never meant to do anybody any harm. When things went wrong,
or I heard things, I used to think it was her fault, but, looking back,
it s more mine. I needn t have married her, but as I have I must stick
to her and keep her.']
speaker: Leonard
referringExpression: He did not deny it but said

quoteText: How long have you been married?
subQuotationList: ['How long have you been married?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Nearly three years.
subQuotationList: ['Nearly three years.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: What did your people say?
subQuotationList: ['What did your people say?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
They will not have anything to do with us. They had a sort of family
council when they heard I was married, and cut us off altogether.
subQuotationList: ['They will not have anything to do with us. They had a sort of family\ncouncil when they heard I was married, and cut us off altogether.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: My good boy, what a mess! Who are your people?
subQuotationList: ['My good boy, what a mess!', 'Who are your people?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: And your grandparents?
subQuotationList: ['And your grandparents?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
They
were just nothing at all, agricultural labourers and that
sort.
subQuotationList: ['They\nwere just nothing at all,', 'agricultural labourers and that\nsort.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: So! From which part?
subQuotationList: ['So! From which part?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Lincolnshire mostly, but my mother s father--he, oddly enough, came
from these parts round here.
subQuotationList: ['Lincolnshire mostly, but my mother s father--he, oddly enough, came\nfrom these parts round here.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
From this very Shropshire. Yes, that is odd. My mother s people were
Lancashire. But why do your brother and your sisters object to Mrs.
Bast?
subQuotationList: ['From this very Shropshire. Yes, that is odd. My mother s people were\nLancashire. But why do your brother and your sisters object to Mrs.\nBast?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Oh, I don t know.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I don t know.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Excuse me, you do know. I am not a baby. I can bear anything you tell
me, and the more you tell the more I shall be able to help. Have they
heard anything against her?
subQuotationList: ['Excuse me, you do know. I am not a baby. I can bear anything you tell\nme, and the more you tell the more I shall be able to help. Have they\nheard anything against her?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I think I have guessed now,
subQuotationList: ['I think I have guessed now,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I don t think so, Miss Schlegel; I hope not.
subQuotationList: ['I don t think so, Miss Schlegel; I hope not.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
We must be honest, even over these things. I have guessed. I am
frightfully, dreadfully sorry, but it does not make the least difference
to me. I shall feel just the same to both of you. I blame, not your wife
for these things, but men.
subQuotationList:
['We must be honest, even over these things. I have guessed. I am
frightfully, dreadfully sorry, but it does not make the least difference
to me. I shall feel just the same to both of you. I blame, not your wife
for these things, but men.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Don t you worry, I can t bear that. We
shall be all right if I get work. If I could only get work--something
regular to do. Then it wouldn t be so bad again. I don t trouble after
books as I used. I can imagine that with regular work we should settle
down again. It stops one thinking.
subQuotationList:
['Don t you worry,', 'I can t bear that. We
shall be all right if I get work. If I could only get work--something
regular to do. Then it wouldn t be so bad again. I don t trouble after
books as I used. I can imagine that with regular work we should settle
down again. It stops one thinking.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Settle down to what?
subQuotationList: ['Settle down to what?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Oh, just settle down.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, just settle down.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
And that s to be life! How
can you, with all the beautiful things to see and do--with music--with
walking at night--
subQuotationList: ['And that s to be life!', 'How\ncan you, with all the beautiful things to see and do--with music--with\nwalking at night--']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Walking is well enough when a man s in work, Oh, I did
talk a lot of nonsense once, but there s nothing like a bailiff in the
house to drive it out of you. When I saw him fingering my Ruskins and
Stevensons, I seemed to see life straight and real, and it isn t a
pretty sight. My books are back again, thanks to you, but they ll never
be the same to me again, and I shan t ever again think night in the
woods is wonderful.
subQuotationList:
['Walking is well enough when a man s in work,', 'Oh, I did
talk a lot of nonsense once, but there s nothing like a bailiff in the
house to drive it out of you. When I saw him fingering my Ruskins and
Stevensons, I seemed to see life straight and real, and it isn t a
pretty sight. My books are back again, thanks to you, but they ll never
be the same to me again, and I shan t ever again think night in the
woods is wonderful.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Why not?
subQuotationList: ['Why not?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Because I see one must have money.
subQuotationList: ['Because I see one must have money.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Well, you re wrong.
subQuotationList: ['Well, you re wrong.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I wish I was wrong, but--the clergyman--he has money of his own, or
else he s paid; the poet or the musician--just the same; the tramp--he s
no different. The tramp goes to the workhouse in the end, and is paid
for with other people s money. Miss Schlegel, the real thing s money, and
all the rest is a dream.
subQuotationList:
['I wish I was wrong, but--the clergyman--he has money of his own, or
else he s paid; the poet or the musician--just the same; the tramp--he s
no different. The tramp goes to the workhouse in the end, and is paid
for with other people s money. Miss Schlegel, the real thing s money, and
all the rest is a dream.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: You re still wrong. You ve forgotten Death.
subQuotationList: ['You re still wrong. You ve forgotten Death.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
If we lived forever, what you say would be true. But we have to die,
we have to leave life presently. Injustice and greed would be the real
thing if we lived for ever. As it is, we must hold to other things,
because Death is coming. I love Death--not morbidly, but because He
explains. He shows me the emptiness of Money. Death and Money are the
eternal foes. Not Death and Life. Never mind what lies behind Death, Mr.
Bast, but be sure that the poet and the musician and the tramp will be
happier in it than the man who has never learnt to say,  I am I.
subQuotationList:
['If we lived forever, what you say would be true. But we have to die,
we have to leave life presently. Injustice and greed would be the real
thing if we lived for ever. As it is, we must hold to other things,
because Death is coming. I love Death--not morbidly, but because He
explains. He shows me the emptiness of Money. Death and Money are the
eternal foes. Not Death and Life. Never mind what lies behind Death, Mr.
Bast, but be sure that the poet and the musician and the tramp will be
happier in it than the man who has never learnt to say,  I am I.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I wonder.
subQuotationList: ['I wonder.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
We are all in a mist--I know, but I can help you this far--men like
the Wilcoxes are deeper in the mist than any. Sane, sound Englishmen!
building up empires, levelling all the world into what they call common
sense. But mention Death to them and they re offended, because Death s
really Imperial, and He cries out against them for ever.
subQuotationList:
['We are all in a mist--I know, but I can help you this far--men like
the Wilcoxes are deeper in the mist than any. Sane, sound Englishmen!
building up empires, levelling all the world into what they call common
sense. But mention Death to them and they re offended, because Death s
really Imperial, and He cries out against them for ever.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I am as afraid of Death as any one.
subQuotationList: ['I am as afraid of Death as any one.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: But not of the idea of Death.
subQuotationList: ['But not of the idea of Death.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: But what is the difference?
subQuotationList: ['But what is the difference?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Infinite difference,
subQuotationList: ['Infinite difference,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I must be stupid,
subQuotationList: ['I must be stupid,']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Death destroys a
man: the idea of Death saves him.
subQuotationList: ['Death destroys a\nman: the idea of Death saves him.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: So never give in,
subQuotationList: ['So never give in,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I think that ll about do,
subQuotationList: ['I think that ll about do,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Who s there?
subQuotationList: ['Who s there?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I have asked Helen to sleep, She is best here; so don t
lock the front-door.
subQuotationList: ['I have asked Helen to sleep,', 'She is best here; so don t\nlock the front-door.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I thought some one had got in,
subQuotationList: ['I thought some one had got in,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
At the same time I told the man that we could do nothing for him. I
don t know about later, but now the Basts must clearly go.
subQuotationList: ['At the same time I told the man that we could do nothing for him. I\ndon t know about later, but now the Basts must clearly go.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Did you say that your sister is sleeping here, after all?
subQuotationList: ['Did you say that your sister is sleeping here, after all?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Probably.
subQuotationList: ['Probably.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Is she to be shown up to your room?
subQuotationList: ['Is she to be shown up to your room?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I have naturally nothing to say to her; I am going to bed. Will you
tell the servants about Helen? Could some one go to carry her bag?
subQuotationList: ['I have naturally nothing to say to her; I am going to bed. Will you\ntell the servants about Helen? Could some one go to carry her bag?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: You must make more noise than that if you want them to hear.
subQuotationList: ['You must make more noise than that if you want them to hear.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Far
too much screaming there,
subQuotationList: ['Far\ntoo much screaming there,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Henry dear--
subQuotationList: ['Henry dear--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Henry dear, look at me. No, I won t have you shirking. Look at me.
There. That s all.
subQuotationList: ['Henry dear, look at me. No, I won t have you shirking. Look at me.\nThere. That s all.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
You re referring to last evening, I have released
you from your engagement. I could find excuses, but I won t. No, I
won t. A thousand times no. I m a bad lot, and must be left at that.
subQuotationList: ['You re referring to last evening,', 'I have released\nyou from your engagement. I could find excuses, but I won t. No, I\nwon t. A thousand times no. I m a bad lot, and must be left at that.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Leave it where you will, boy. It s not going to trouble us; I know what
I m talking about, and it will make no difference.
subQuotationList: ['Leave it where you will, boy. It s not going to trouble us; I know what\nI m talking about, and it will make no difference.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
No difference? No difference, when you find that I am
not the fellow you thought?
subQuotationList: ['No difference?', 'No difference, when you find that I am\nnot the fellow you thought?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I am unworthy of you, Had I been worthy, I should not have
released you from your engagement. I know what I am talking about. I
can t bear to talk of such things. We had better leave it.
subQuotationList: ['I am unworthy of you,', 'Had I been worthy, I should not have\nreleased you from your engagement. I know what I am talking about. I\ncan t bear to talk of such things. We had better leave it.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
You, with your sheltered life, and refined pursuits, and
friends, and books, you and your sister, and women like you--I say, how
can you guess the temptations that lie round a man?
subQuotationList: ['You, with your sheltered life, and refined pursuits, and\nfriends, and books, you and your sister, and women like you--I say, how\ncan you guess the temptations that lie round a man?']
speaker: Henry
referringExpression: He jerked it from her and rising to his feet went on

quoteText:
It is difficult for us, but if we are worth marrying,
we do guess.
subQuotationList: ['It is difficult for us,', 'but if we are worth marrying,\nwe do guess.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Cut off from decent society and family ties, what do you suppose
happens to thousands of young fellows overseas? Isolated. No one near. I
know by bitter experience, and yet you say it makes  no difference.
subQuotationList: ['Cut off from decent society and family ties, what do you suppose\nhappens to thousands of young fellows overseas? Isolated. No one near. I\nknow by bitter experience, and yet you say it makes  no difference.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Not to me.
subQuotationList: ['Not to me.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Did Helen come?
subQuotationList: ['Did Helen come?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
But that won t do at all, at all! We don t want her gossiping with Mrs.
Bast.
subQuotationList: ['But that won t do at all, at all! We don t want her gossiping with Mrs.\nBast.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Good God! no! Let them gossip, my game s up, though I thank you for your
unselfishness--little as my thanks are worth.
subQuotationList: ['Good God! no!', 'Let them gossip, my game s up, though I thank you for your\nunselfishness--little as my thanks are worth.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Didn t she send me a message or anything?
subQuotationList: ['Didn t she send me a message or anything?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I heard of none.
subQuotationList: ['I heard of none.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Would you ring the bell, please?
subQuotationList: ['Would you ring the bell, please?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What to do?
subQuotationList: ['What to do?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Why, to inquire.
subQuotationList: ['Why, to inquire.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I ll go, thank you,
subQuotationList: ['I ll go, thank you,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
It is no good, Those things leak out; you cannot stop a
story once it has started. I have known cases of other men--I despised
them once, I thought that I m different, I shall never be tempted. Oh,
Margaret-- We fellows all come to grief once in
our time. Will you believe that? There are moments when the strongest
man-- That s true,
isn t it? If you knew all, you would excuse me. I was far from good
influences--far even from England. I was very, very lonely, and longed
for a woman s voice. That s enough. I have told you too much already for
you to forgive me now.
subQuotationList:
['It is no good,', 'Those things leak out; you cannot stop a
story once it has started. I have known cases of other men--I despised
them once, I thought that I m different, I shall never be tempted. Oh,
Margaret--', 'We fellows all come to grief once in
our time. Will you believe that? There are moments when the strongest
man--', 'That s true,
isn t it? If you knew all, you would excuse me. I was far from good
influences--far even from England. I was very, very lonely, and longed
for a woman s voice. That s enough. I have told you too much already for
you to forgive me now.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Yes, that s enough, dear.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, that s enough, dear.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I have
subQuotationList: ['I have']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I have been through hell.
subQuotationList: ['I have been through hell.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I have already forgiven you, Henry.
subQuotationList: ['I have already forgiven you, Henry.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Well, let them go--the man and his wife, I mean, for the more we see of
your sister the better.
subQuotationList: ['Well, let them go--the man and his wife, I mean, for the more we see of\nyour sister the better.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
But they have gone separately--Helen very early, the Basts just before
I arrived. They have left no message. They have answered neither of my
notes. I don t like to think what it all means.
subQuotationList: ['But they have gone separately--Helen very early, the Basts just before\nI arrived. They have left no message. They have answered neither of my\nnotes. I don t like to think what it all means.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What did you say in the notes?
subQuotationList: ['What did you say in the notes?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I told you last night.
subQuotationList: ['I told you last night.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh--ah--yes! Dear, would you like one turn in the garden?
subQuotationList: ['Oh--ah--yes! Dear, would you like one turn in the garden?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I am afraid there has been gossiping of some kind at the George. Helen
would not have left unless she had heard something. I mismanaged that.
It is wretched. I ought to have parted her from that woman at once.
subQuotationList: ['I am afraid there has been gossiping of some kind at the George. Helen\nwould not have left unless she had heard something. I mismanaged that.\nIt is wretched. I ought to have parted her from that woman at once.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Margaret!
subQuotationList: ['Margaret!']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Yes--yes, Henry?
subQuotationList: ['Yes--yes, Henry?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I am far from a saint--in fact, the reverse--but you have taken me, for
better or worse. Bygones must be bygones. You have promised to forgive
me. Margaret, a promise is a promise. Never mention that woman again.
subQuotationList: ['I am far from a saint--in fact, the reverse--but you have taken me, for\nbetter or worse. Bygones must be bygones. You have promised to forgive\nme. Margaret, a promise is a promise. Never mention that woman again.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Except for some practical reason--never.
subQuotationList: ['Except for some practical reason--never.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Practical! You practical!
subQuotationList: ['Practical! You practical!']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Yes, I m practical,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I m practical,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: At all events, you mustn t worry, This is a man s business. On no account mention it to anybody.
subQuotationList: ['At all events, you mustn t worry,', 'This is a man s business.', 'On no account mention it to anybody.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I have come from Oniton, There has been a great deal of
trouble there.
subQuotationList: ['I have come from Oniton,', 'There has been a great deal of\ntrouble there.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Who s for lunch?
subQuotationList: ['Who s for lunch?']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
Why such an
early start?
subQuotationList: ['Why such an\nearly start?']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: Sunrise or something--when I could get away.
subQuotationList: ['Sunrise or something--when I could get away.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: So I surmise. Why?
subQuotationList: ['So I surmise. Why?']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
I don t know what s to be done, Tibby. I am very much upset at a piece
of news that concerns Meg, and do not want to face her, and I am not
going back to Wickham Place. I stopped here to tell you this.
subQuotationList: ['I don t know what s to be done, Tibby. I am very much upset at a piece\nof news that concerns Meg, and do not want to face her, and I am not\ngoing back to Wickham Place. I stopped here to tell you this.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Give Meg my love and say that I want to be alone. I mean to go to
Munich or else Bonn.
subQuotationList: ['Give Meg my love and say that I want to be alone. I mean to go to\nMunich or else Bonn.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Such a message is easily given,
subQuotationList: ['Such a message is easily given,']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
As regards Wickham Place and my share of the furniture, you and she are
to do exactly as you like. My own feeling is that everything may just as
well be sold. What does one want with dusty economic books, which have
made the world no better, or with mother s hideous chiffoniers? I have
also another commission for you. I want you to deliver a letter.
subQuotationList:
['As regards Wickham Place and my share of the furniture, you and she are
to do exactly as you like. My own feeling is that everything may just as
well be sold. What does one want with dusty economic books, which have
made the world no better, or with mother s hideous chiffoniers? I have
also another commission for you. I want you to deliver a letter.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I haven t written it yet. Why shouldn t I post it, though?
subQuotationList: ['I haven t written it yet. Why shouldn t I post it, though?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
My head is rather wretched. I hope that none of your
friends are likely to come in.
subQuotationList: ['My head is rather wretched. I hope that none of your\nfriends are likely to come in.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Not there,
subQuotationList: ['Not there,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Do you mind Mrs.
Martlett coming in? or shall I take it from her at the
door?
subQuotationList: ['Do you mind Mrs.\nMartlett coming in?', 'or shall I take it from her at the\ndoor?']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: Could I bathe my eyes, Tibby?
subQuotationList: ['Could I bathe my eyes, Tibby?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Now for the explanation, Why didn t I begin with it? I
have found out something about Mr. Wilcox. He has behaved very wrongly
indeed, and ruined two people s lives. It all came on me very suddenly
last night; I am very much upset, and I do not know what to do. Mrs.
Bast--
subQuotationList:
['Now for the explanation,', 'Why didn t I begin with it? I
have found out something about Mr. Wilcox. He has behaved very wrongly
indeed, and ruined two people s lives. It all came on me very suddenly
last night; I am very much upset, and I do not know what to do. Mrs.
Bast--']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Oh, those people!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, those people!']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: Shall I lock the door again?
subQuotationList: ['Shall I lock the door again?']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
No thanks, Tibbikins. You re being very good to me. I want to tell you
the story before I go abroad, you must do exactly what you like--treat
it as part of the furniture. Meg cannot have heard it yet, I think. But
I cannot face her and tell her that the man she is going to marry has
misconducted himself. I don t even know whether she ought to be told.
Knowing as she does that I dislike him, she will suspect me, and think
that I want to ruin her match. I simply don t know what to make of such
a thing. I trust your judgment. What would you do?
subQuotationList:
['No thanks, Tibbikins. You re being very good to me. I want to tell you
the story before I go abroad, you must do exactly what you like--treat
it as part of the furniture. Meg cannot have heard it yet, I think. But
I cannot face her and tell her that the man she is going to marry has
misconducted himself. I don t even know whether she ought to be told.
Knowing as she does that I dislike him, she will suspect me, and think
that I want to ruin her match. I simply don t know what to make of such
a thing. I trust your judgment. What would you do?']
speaker: Helen
mentionTextsList: [['Tibbikins', 'You', 'you', 'you', 'you', 'Meg', 'her', 'her', 'the man she is going to marry', 'she', 'she', 'she', 'him', 'she', 'her', 'you']]

quoteText: I gather he has had a mistress,
subQuotationList: ['I gather he has had a mistress,']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
And ruined two people s lives. And
goes about saying that personal actions count for nothing, and there
always will be rich and poor. He met her when he was trying to get rich
out in Cyprus--I don t wish to make him worse than he is, and no doubt
she was ready enough to meet him. But there it is. They met. He goes his
way and she goes hers. What do you suppose is the end of such women?
subQuotationList:
['And ruined two people s lives. And
goes about saying that personal actions count for nothing, and there
always will be rich and poor. He met her when he was trying to get rich
out in Cyprus--I don t wish to make him worse than he is, and no doubt
she was ready enough to meet him. But there it is. They met. He goes his
way and she goes hers. What do you suppose is the end of such women?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
They end in two ways: Either they sink till the lunatic asylums and the
workhouses are full of them, and cause Mr. Wilcox to write letters to
the papers complaining of our national degeneracy, or else they entrap a
boy into marriage before it is too late. She--I can t blame her.
subQuotationList:
['They end in two ways: Either they sink till the lunatic asylums and the
workhouses are full of them, and cause Mr. Wilcox to write letters to
the papers complaining of our national degeneracy, or else they entrap a
boy into marriage before it is too late. She--I can t blame her.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
But this isn t all, I come now to the business that took
us to Oniton. We went all three. Acting on Mr. Wilcox s advice, the man
throws up a secure situation and takes an insecure one, from which he is
dismissed. There are certain excuses, but in the main Mr. Wilcox is to
blame, as Meg herself admitted. It is only common justice that he should
employ the man himself. But he meets the woman, and, like the cur that
he is, he refuses, and tries to get rid of them. He makes Meg write.
Two notes came from her late that evening--one for me, one for Leonard,
dismissing him with barely a reason. I couldn t understand. Then it
comes out that Mrs. Bast had spoken to Mr. Wilcox on the lawn while we
left her to get rooms, and was still speaking about him when Leonard
came back to her. This Leonard knew all along. He thought it natural he
should be ruined twice. Natural! Could you have contained yourself?
subQuotationList:
['But this isn t all,', 'I come now to the business that took
us to Oniton. We went all three. Acting on Mr. Wilcox s advice, the man
throws up a secure situation and takes an insecure one, from which he is
dismissed. There are certain excuses, but in the main Mr. Wilcox is to
blame, as Meg herself admitted. It is only common justice that he should
employ the man himself. But he meets the woman, and, like the cur that
he is, he refuses, and tries to get rid of them. He makes Meg write.
Two notes came from her late that evening--one for me, one for Leonard,
dismissing him with barely a reason. I couldn t understand. Then it
comes out that Mrs. Bast had spoken to Mr. Wilcox on the lawn while we
left her to get rooms, and was still speaking about him when Leonard
came back to her. This Leonard knew all along. He thought it natural he
should be ruined twice. Natural! Could you have contained yourself?']
speaker: Helen
mentionTextsList: [[], ['We', 'Mr. Wilcox', 'the man', 'he', 'Mr. Wilcox', 'Meg', 'he', 'the man', 'he', 'the woman', 'he', 'he', 'them', 'He', 'Meg', 'Leonard', 'him', 'Mrs. Bast', 'Mr. Wilcox', 'we', 'her', 'him', 'Leonard', 'her', 'Leonard', 'He', 'he', 'you']]

quoteText: It is certainly a very bad business,
subQuotationList: ['It is certainly a very bad business,']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
I was afraid that I saw it out of
proportion. But you are right outside it, and you must know. In a day or
two--or perhaps a week--take whatever steps you think fit. I leave it in
your hands.
subQuotationList:
['I was afraid that I saw it out of
proportion. But you are right outside it, and you must know. In a day or
two--or perhaps a week--take whatever steps you think fit. I leave it in
your hands.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: The facts as they touch Meg are all before you,
subQuotationList: ['The facts as they touch Meg are all before you,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: You see, Helen--have a cigarette--I don t see what I m to do.
subQuotationList: ['You see, Helen--have a cigarette--I don t see what I m to do.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
Then there s nothing to be done. I dare say you are right. Let them
marry. There remains the question of compensation.
subQuotationList: ['Then there s nothing to be done. I dare say you are right. Let them\nmarry. There remains the question of compensation.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Do you want me to adjudicate that too? Had you not better consult an
expert?
subQuotationList: ['Do you want me to adjudicate that too? Had you not better consult an\nexpert?']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
This part is in confidence, It has nothing to do with
Meg, and do not mention it to her. The compensation--I do not see who is
to pay it if I don t, and I have already decided on the minimum sum.
As soon as possible I am placing it to your account, and when I am in
Germany you will pay it over for me. I shall never forget your kindness,
Tibbikins, if you do this.
subQuotationList:
['This part is in confidence,', 'It has nothing to do with
Meg, and do not mention it to her. The compensation--I do not see who is
to pay it if I don t, and I have already decided on the minimum sum.
As soon as possible I am placing it to your account, and when I am in
Germany you will pay it over for me. I shall never forget your kindness,
Tibbikins, if you do this.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: What is the sum?
subQuotationList: ['What is the sum?']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: Five thousand.
subQuotationList: ['Five thousand.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Good God alive!
subQuotationList: ['Good God alive!']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
Now, what is the good of driblets? To go through life having done one
thing--to have raised one person from the abyss; not these puny gifts of
shillings and blankets--making the grey more grey. No doubt people will
think me extraordinary.
subQuotationList:
['Now, what is the good of driblets? To go through life having done one
thing--to have raised one person from the abyss; not these puny gifts of
shillings and blankets--making the grey more grey. No doubt people will
think me extraordinary.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I don t care an iota what people think! But it s half what you have.
subQuotationList: ['I don t care an iota what people think!', 'But it s half what you have.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: Not nearly half.
subQuotationList: ['Not nearly half.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I
have far too much, and we settled at Chelsea last spring that three
hundred a year is necessary to set a man on his feet. What I give will
bring in a hundred and fifty between two. It isn t enough.
subQuotationList:
['I
have far too much, and we settled at Chelsea last spring that three
hundred a year is necessary to set a man on his feet. What I give will
bring in a hundred and fifty between two. It isn t enough.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I didn t expect you to understand me.
subQuotationList: ['I didn t expect you to understand me.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I? I understand nobody.
subQuotationList: ['I? I understand nobody.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: But you ll do it?
subQuotationList: ['But you ll do it?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Apparently.
subQuotationList: ['Apparently.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
I leave you two commissions, then. The first concerns Mr. Wilcox, and
you are to use your discretion. The second concerns the money, and is
to be mentioned to no one, and carried out literally. You will send a
hundred pounds on account to-morrow.
subQuotationList:
['I leave you two commissions, then. The first concerns Mr. Wilcox, and
you are to use your discretion. The second concerns the money, and is
to be mentioned to no one, and carried out literally. You will send a
hundred pounds on account to-morrow.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Does that seem to you so odd?
subQuotationList: ['Does that seem to you so odd?']
speaker: Helen
referringExpression: She stopped like a frightened animal and said

quoteText:
Did she
seem worried at any rumour about Henry?
subQuotationList: ['Did she\nseem worried at any rumour about Henry?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
I knew it
was that! I ll write to her.
subQuotationList: ['I knew it\nwas that!', 'I ll write to her.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I didn t want to bother you, Besides, I have only heard
for certain this morning.
subQuotationList: ['I didn t want to bother you,', 'Besides, I have only heard\nfor certain this morning.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Where are we to live? I loved the
place extraordinarily. Don t you believe in having a permanent home,
Henry?
subQuotationList: ['Where are we to live?', 'I loved the\nplace extraordinarily. Don t you believe in having a permanent home,\nHenry?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: This is news. I never heard till this minute that Oniton was damp.
subQuotationList: ['This is news. I never heard till this minute that Oniton was damp.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: My dear girl!
subQuotationList: ['My dear girl!']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
have you eyes? have you a skin?
How could it be anything but damp in such a situation? In the first
place, the Grange is on clay, and built where the castle moat must have
been; then there s that detestable little river, steaming all night like
a kettle. Feel the cellar walls; look up under the eaves. Ask Sir James
or any one. Those Shropshire valleys are notorious. The only possible
place for a house in Shropshire is on a hill; but, for my part, I think
the country is too far from London, and the scenery nothing special.
subQuotationList:
['have you eyes? have you a skin?
How could it be anything but damp in such a situation? In the first
place, the Grange is on clay, and built where the castle moat must have
been; then there s that detestable little river, steaming all night like
a kettle. Feel the cellar walls; look up under the eaves. Ask Sir James
or any one. Those Shropshire valleys are notorious. The only possible
place for a house in Shropshire is on a hill; but, for my part, I think
the country is too far from London, and the scenery nothing special.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Why did you go there, then?
subQuotationList: ['Why did you go there, then?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I--because--
subQuotationList: ['I--because--']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Why have
we come to the Tyrol, if it comes to that? One might go on asking such
questions indefinitely.
subQuotationList: ['Why have\nwe come to the Tyrol, if it comes to that? One might go on asking such\nquestions indefinitely.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
The truth is, I took Oniton on account of Evie. Don t let this go any
further.
subQuotationList: ['The truth is, I took Oniton on account of Evie. Don t let this go any\nfurther.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Certainly not.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly not.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I shouldn t like her to know that she nearly let me in for a very bad
bargain. No sooner did I sign the agreement than she got engaged. Poor
little girl! She was so keen on it all, and wouldn t even wait to
make proper inquiries about the shooting. Afraid it would get snapped
up--just like all of your sex. Well, no harm s done. She has had her
country wedding, and I ve got rid of my goose to some fellows who are
starting a preparatory school.
subQuotationList:
['I shouldn t like her to know that she nearly let me in for a very bad
bargain. No sooner did I sign the agreement than she got engaged. Poor
little girl! She was so keen on it all, and wouldn t even wait to
make proper inquiries about the shooting. Afraid it would get snapped
up--just like all of your sex. Well, no harm s done. She has had her
country wedding, and I ve got rid of my goose to some fellows who are
starting a preparatory school.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Where shall we live, then, Henry? I should enjoy living somewhere.
subQuotationList: ['Where shall we live, then, Henry? I should enjoy living somewhere.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I have not yet decided. What about Norfolk?
subQuotationList: ['I have not yet decided. What about Norfolk?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
It is now what? Nearly October. Let us camp for the
winter at Ducie Street, and look out for something in the spring.
subQuotationList: ['It is now what?', 'Nearly October. Let us camp for the\nwinter at Ducie Street, and look out for something in the spring.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
If possible, something permanent. I can t be as young as I was, for
these alterations don t suit me.
subQuotationList: ['If possible, something permanent. I can t be as young as I was, for\nthese alterations don t suit me.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But, my dear, which would you rather have--alterations or rheumatism?
subQuotationList: ['But, my dear, which would you rather have--alterations or rheumatism?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I see your point, If Oniton is really
damp, it is impossible, and must be inhabited by little boys. Only, in
the spring, let us look before we leap. I will take warning by Evie,
and not hurry you. Remember that you have a free hand this time.
These endless moves must be bad for the furniture, and are certainly
expensive.
subQuotationList:
['I see your point,', 'If Oniton is really
damp, it is impossible, and must be inhabited by little boys. Only, in
the spring, let us look before we leap. I will take warning by Evie,
and not hurry you. Remember that you have a free hand this time.
These endless moves must be bad for the furniture, and are certainly
expensive.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
What a practical little woman it is! What s it been reading?
Theo--theo--how much?
subQuotationList: ['What a practical little woman it is! What s it been reading?\nTheo--theo--how much?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Theosophy.
subQuotationList: ['Theosophy.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Have you heard the news? Charles is so ang--I mean he is sure you know about it, or, rather, that
you don t know.
subQuotationList: ['Have you heard the news?', 'Charles is so ang--I mean he is sure you know about it, or, rather, that\nyou don t know.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
Why, Dolly! Here s a surprise!
How are the boys and the baby?
subQuotationList: ['Why, Dolly!', 'Here s a surprise!\nHow are the boys and the baby?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But lucky you, with four courts of your own at Midhurst.
subQuotationList: ['But lucky you, with four courts of your own at Midhurst.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: It will be very jolly,
subQuotationList: ['It will be very jolly,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Are those the plans? Does it matter my seeing them?
subQuotationList: ['Are those the plans? Does it matter my seeing them?']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: Of course not.
subQuotationList: ['Of course not.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Charles has never seen the plans.
subQuotationList: ['Charles has never seen the plans.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
They have only just arrived. Here is the ground floor--no, that s
rather difficult. Try the elevation. We are to have a good many gables
and a picturesque sky-line.
subQuotationList: ['They have only just arrived. Here is the ground floor--no, that s\nrather difficult. Try the elevation. We are to have a good many gables\nand a picturesque sky-line.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What makes it smell so funny?
subQuotationList: ['What makes it smell so funny?']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: I suppose the paper.
subQuotationList: ['I suppose the paper.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: And WHICH way up is it?
subQuotationList: ['And WHICH way up is it?']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
Just the ordinary way up. That s the sky-line and the part that smells
strongest is the sky.
subQuotationList: ['Just the ordinary way up. That s the sky-line and the part that smells\nstrongest is the sky.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Well, ask me another. Margaret--oh--what was I going to say? How s
Helen?
subQuotationList: ['Well, ask me another. Margaret--oh--what was I going to say? How s\nHelen?']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: Quite well.
subQuotationList: ['Quite well.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Is she never coming back to England? Every one thinks it s awfully odd
she doesn t.
subQuotationList: ['Is she never coming back to England? Every one thinks it s awfully odd\nshe doesn t.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
So it is, Helen is odd, awfully. She has now
been away eight months.
subQuotationList: ['So it is,', 'Helen is odd, awfully. She has now\nbeen away eight months.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But hasn t she any address?
subQuotationList: ['But hasn t she any address?']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
A poste restante somewhere in Bavaria is her address. Do write her a
line. I will look it up for you.
subQuotationList: ['A poste restante somewhere in Bavaria is her address. Do write her a\nline. I will look it up for you.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: No, don t bother. That s eight months she has been away, surely?
subQuotationList: ['No, don t bother. That s eight months she has been away, surely?']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: Exactly. She left just after Evie s wedding. It would be eight months.
subQuotationList: ['Exactly. She left just after Evie s wedding. It would be eight months.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Just when baby was born, then?
subQuotationList: ['Just when baby was born, then?']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: Just so.
subQuotationList: ['Just so.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Oh, yes, that is it: Miss Avery has been unpacking your
packing-cases.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes,', 'that is it: Miss Avery has been unpacking your\npacking-cases.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: Why has she done that? How unnecessary!
subQuotationList: ['Why has she done that? How unnecessary!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Ask another. I suppose you ordered her to.
subQuotationList: ['Ask another. I suppose you ordered her to.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
I gave no such orders. Perhaps she was airing the things. She did
undertake to light an occasional fire.
subQuotationList: ['I gave no such orders. Perhaps she was airing the things. She did\nundertake to light an occasional fire.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
It was far more than an air, The floor sounds
covered with books. Charles sent me to know what is to be done, for he
feels certain you don t know.
subQuotationList: ['It was far more than an air,', 'The floor sounds\ncovered with books. Charles sent me to know what is to be done, for he\nfeels certain you don t know.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
Books! Dolly, are you
serious? Has she been touching our books?
subQuotationList: ['Books!', 'Dolly, are you\nserious? Has she been touching our books?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Hasn t she, though! What used to be the hall s full of them. Charles
thought for certain you knew of it.
subQuotationList: ['Hasn t she, though! What used to be the hall s full of them. Charles\nthought for certain you knew of it.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
I am very much obliged to you, Dolly. What can have come over Miss
Avery? I must go down about it at once. Some of the books are my
brother s, and are quite valuable. She had no right to open any of the
cases.
subQuotationList:
['I am very much obliged to you, Dolly. What can have come over Miss
Avery? I must go down about it at once. Some of the books are my
brother s, and are quite valuable. She had no right to open any of the
cases.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I say she s dotty. She was the one that never got married, you know.
Oh, I say, perhaps, she thinks your books are wedding-presents to
herself. Old maids are taken that way sometimes. Miss Avery hates us all
like poison ever since her frightful dust-up with Evie.
subQuotationList:
['I say she s dotty. She was the one that never got married, you know.
Oh, I say, perhaps, she thinks your books are wedding-presents to
herself. Old maids are taken that way sometimes. Miss Avery hates us all
like poison ever since her frightful dust-up with Evie.']
speaker: Dolly
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Miss Avery'], ['Miss Avery'], ['Margaret'], ['Miss Avery'], ['Margaret'], ['Miss Avery'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Henry', 'Evie', 'Dolly'], ['Miss Avery'], ['Evie']]]

quoteText: I hadn t heard of that,
subQuotationList: ['I hadn t heard of that,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Didn t you know she gave Evie a present last August, and Evie returned
it, and then--oh, goloshes! You never read such a letter as Miss Avery
wrote.
subQuotationList: ['Didn t you know she gave Evie a present last August, and Evie returned\nit, and then--oh, goloshes! You never read such a letter as Miss Avery\nwrote.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
But it was wrong of Evie to return it. It wasn t like her to do such a
heartless thing.
subQuotationList: ['But it was wrong of Evie to return it. It wasn t like her to do such a\nheartless thing.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But the present was so expensive.
subQuotationList: ['But the present was so expensive.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: Why does that make any difference, Dolly?
subQuotationList: ['Why does that make any difference, Dolly?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Still, when it costs over five pounds--I didn t see it, but it was
a lovely enamel pendant from a Bond Street shop. You can t very well
accept that kind of thing from a farm woman. Now, can you?
subQuotationList: ['Still, when it costs over five pounds--I didn t see it, but it was\na lovely enamel pendant from a Bond Street shop. You can t very well\naccept that kind of thing from a farm woman. Now, can you?']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: You accepted a present from Miss Avery when you were married.
subQuotationList: ['You accepted a present from Miss Avery when you were married.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Oh, mine was old earthenware stuff--not worth a halfpenny. Evie s was
quite different. You d have to ask any one to the wedding who gave you
a pendant like that. Uncle Percy and Albert and father and Charles all
said it was quite impossible, and when four men agree, what is a girl to
do? Evie didn t want to upset the old thing, so thought a sort of joking
letter best, and returned the pendant straight to the shop to save Miss
Avery trouble.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, mine was old earthenware stuff--not worth a halfpenny. Evie s was
quite different. You d have to ask any one to the wedding who gave you
a pendant like that. Uncle Percy and Albert and father and Charles all
said it was quite impossible, and when four men agree, what is a girl to
do? Evie didn t want to upset the old thing, so thought a sort of joking
letter best, and returned the pendant straight to the shop to save Miss
Avery trouble.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: But Miss Avery said--
subQuotationList: ['But Miss Avery said--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
It was a perfectly awful letter. Charles said
it was the letter of a madman. In the end she had the pendant back again
from the shop and threw it into the duck-pond.
subQuotationList: ['It was a perfectly awful letter. Charles said\nit was the letter of a madman. In the end she had the pendant back again\nfrom the shop and threw it into the duck-pond.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: Did she give any reasons?
subQuotationList: ['Did she give any reasons?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: We think she meant to be invited to Oniton, and so climb into society.
subQuotationList: ['We think she meant to be invited to Oniton, and so climb into society.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
She s rather old for that, May she not have
given the present to Evie in remembrance of her mother?
subQuotationList: ['She s rather old for that,', 'May she not have\ngiven the present to Evie in remembrance of her mother?']
speaker: Margaret

subQuotationList: ['That s a notion. Give every one their due, eh? Well, I suppose I ought\nto be toddling. Come along, Mr. Muff--you want a new coat, but I don t\nknow who ll give it you, I m sure;']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: Oh yes.
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: I wonder, then, why he let me ask her to look after the house.
subQuotationList: ['I wonder, then, why he let me ask her to look after the house.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But she s only a farm woman,
subQuotationList: ['But she s only a farm woman,']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: I have patience with a man who knows his job,
subQuotationList: ['I have patience with a man who knows his job,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Left to itself, this county would vote
Liberal.
subQuotationList: ['Left to itself,', 'this county would vote\nLiberal.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Yes, Mrs. Wilcox; no, Mrs. Wilcox; oh yes, Mrs.
Wilcox, auntie received your letter quite duly. Auntie has gone up to
your little place at the present moment. Shall I send the servant to
direct you?
subQuotationList:
['Yes, Mrs. Wilcox; no, Mrs. Wilcox; oh yes, Mrs.
Wilcox, auntie received your letter quite duly. Auntie has gone up to
your little place at the present moment. Shall I send the servant to
direct you?']
speaker: Madge

quoteText:
Of course, auntie does not generally look
after your place; she only does it to oblige a neighbour as something
exceptional. It gives her something to do. She spends quite a lot of her
time there. My husband says to me sometimes,
subQuotationList:
['Of course, auntie does not generally look
after your place; she only does it to oblige a neighbour as something
exceptional. It gives her something to do. She spends quite a lot of her
time there. My husband says to me sometimes,']
speaker: Madge

quoteText: I say,
subQuotationList: ['I say,']
speaker: Madge

quoteText:
Yes, Mrs. Wilcox. Mrs. Wilcox,
could I prevail upon you to accept a piece of cake? Not if I cut it for
you?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, Mrs. Wilcox. Mrs. Wilcox,\ncould I prevail upon you to accept a piece of cake? Not if I cut it for\nyou?']
speaker: Madge

quoteText:
I cannot let you go on alone. Now don t. You really mustn t. I
will direct you myself if it comes to that. I must get my hat.
Now
subQuotationList: ['I cannot let you go on alone. Now don t. You really mustn t. I\nwill direct you myself if it comes to that. I must get my hat.\nNow']
speaker: Madge

quoteText: Mrs. Wilcox, don t you move while I m gone.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Wilcox, don t you move while I m gone.']
speaker: Madge

quoteText: Auntie!
subQuotationList: ['Auntie!']
speaker: Madge

quoteText: Are you sure that Miss Avery is up here?
subQuotationList: ['Are you sure that Miss Avery is up here?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, yes, Mrs. Wilcox, quite sure. She is here daily.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, yes, Mrs. Wilcox, quite sure. She is here daily.']
speaker: Madge

quoteText:
Well, well! If it isn t Mrs.
Wilcox come at last!
subQuotationList: ['Well, well!', 'If it isn t Mrs.\nWilcox come at last!']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: Have you got the key, auntie?
subQuotationList: ['Have you got the key, auntie?']
speaker: Madge

quoteText: Madge, go away,
subQuotationList: ['Madge, go away,']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: Auntie, it s Mrs. Wilcox--
subQuotationList: ['Auntie, it s Mrs. Wilcox--']
speaker: Madge

quoteText: Your niece and I have come together.
subQuotationList: ['Your niece and I have come together.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Madge, go away. This is no moment for your hat.
subQuotationList: ['Madge, go away. This is no moment for your hat.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: Auntie gets more eccentric lately,
subQuotationList: ['Auntie gets more eccentric lately,']
speaker: Madge

quoteText:
Miss Avery! I have come about the furniture. Could
you kindly let me in?
subQuotationList: ['Miss Avery!', 'I have come about the furniture. Could\nyou kindly let me in?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes, Mrs. Wilcox, of course.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, Mrs. Wilcox,', 'of course.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: I hope Miss Avery is not ill,
subQuotationList: ['I hope Miss Avery is not ill,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Well, if you ll excuse me, perhaps I ought to be leaving
you now. The servants need seeing to at the farm. Auntie is so odd at
times.
subQuotationList: ['Well, if you ll excuse me,', 'perhaps I ought to be leaving\nyou now. The servants need seeing to at the farm. Auntie is so odd at\ntimes.']
speaker: Madge

quoteText: Well, come right in, Mrs. Wilcox!
subQuotationList: ['Well, come right in, Mrs. Wilcox!']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: Thank you so much,
subQuotationList: ['Thank you so much,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Come right into the hall first,
subQuotationList: ['Come right into the hall first,']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText:
I m afraid this isn t what we meant, Mr. Wilcox and I
never intended the cases to be touched. For instance, these books are my
brother s. We are storing them for him and for my sister, who is abroad.
When you kindly undertook to look after things, we never expected you to
do so much.
subQuotationList:
['I m afraid this isn t what we meant,', 'Mr. Wilcox and I
never intended the cases to be touched. For instance, these books are my
brother s. We are storing them for him and for my sister, who is abroad.
When you kindly undertook to look after things, we never expected you to
do so much.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: The house has been empty long enough,
subQuotationList: ['The house has been empty long enough,']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: I dare say we didn t explain, It has been a mistake, and very likely our mistake.
subQuotationList: ['I dare say we didn t explain,', 'It has been a mistake, and very likely our mistake.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Mrs. Wilcox, it has been mistake upon mistake for fifty years. The
house is Mrs. Wilcox s, and she would not desire it to stand empty any
longer.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Wilcox, it has been mistake upon mistake for fifty years. The\nhouse is Mrs. Wilcox s, and she would not desire it to stand empty any\nlonger.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: Yes, Mrs. Wilcox s house, the mother of Mr. Charles.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, Mrs. Wilcox s house, the mother of Mr. Charles.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Mistake upon mistake, Mistake upon mistake.
subQuotationList: ['Mistake upon mistake,', 'Mistake upon mistake.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: Well, I don t know, I really don t know what s to be done.
subQuotationList: ['Well, I don t know,', 'I really don t know what s to be done.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes, it should be a merry house enough.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, it should be a merry house enough.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText:
I don t know--I dare say. Well, thank you very much, Miss Avery. Yes,
that s all right. Delightful.
subQuotationList: ['I don t know--I dare say. Well, thank you very much, Miss Avery. Yes,\nthat s all right. Delightful.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: There is still the parlour.
subQuotationList: ['There is still the parlour.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: And the dining-room.
subQuotationList: ['And the dining-room.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: Then through here--
subQuotationList: ['Then through here--']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText:
I ve not finished
here yet, There s still a deal to do. The
farm lads will carry your great wardrobes upstairs, for there is no need
to go into expense at Hilton.
subQuotationList:
['I ve not finished
here yet,', 'There s still a deal to do. The
farm lads will carry your great wardrobes upstairs, for there is no need
to go into expense at Hilton.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText:
It is all a mistake, A misunderstanding. Mr. Wilcox and I are not going to live
at Howards End.
subQuotationList: ['It is all a mistake,', 'A misunderstanding. Mr. Wilcox and I are not going to live\nat Howards End.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, indeed! On account of his hay fever?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, indeed! On account of his hay fever?']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText:
We have settled to build a new home for ourselves in Sussex, and part
of this furniture--my part--will go down there presently.
subQuotationList: ['We have settled to build a new home for ourselves in Sussex, and part\nof this furniture--my part--will go down there presently.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
You think that you won t come back to live here, Mrs. Wilcox,
but you will.
subQuotationList: ['You think that you won t come back to live here, Mrs. Wilcox,\nbut you will.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText:
That remains to be seen, We have no intention
of doing so for the present. We happen to need a much larger house.
Circumstances oblige us to give big parties. Of course, some day--one
never knows, does one?
subQuotationList:
['That remains to be seen,', 'We have no intention
of doing so for the present. We happen to need a much larger house.
Circumstances oblige us to give big parties. Of course, some day--one
never knows, does one?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Some day! Tcha! tcha! Don t talk about some day.
You are living here now.
subQuotationList: ['Some day! Tcha! tcha! Don t talk about some day.\nYou are living here now.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: Am I?
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
You are living here, and have been for the last ten minutes, if you ask
me.
subQuotationList: ['You are living here, and have been for the last ten minutes, if you ask\nme.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: The nursery,
subQuotationList: ['The nursery,']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: It s a beautiful meadow,
subQuotationList: ['It s a beautiful meadow,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Yes, the maidy s well enough, for those, that is,
who don t suffer from sneezing. I ve
seen Charlie Wilcox go out to my lads in hay time--oh, they ought to do
this--they mustn t do that--he d learn them to be lads. And just then
the tickling took him. He has it from his father, with other things.
There s not one Wilcox that can stand up against a field in June--I
laughed fit to burst while he was courting Ruth.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, the maidy s well enough,', 'for those, that is,
who don t suffer from sneezing.', 'I ve
seen Charlie Wilcox go out to my lads in hay time--oh, they ought to do
this--they mustn t do that--he d learn them to be lads. And just then
the tickling took him. He has it from his father, with other things.
There s not one Wilcox that can stand up against a field in June--I
laughed fit to burst while he was courting Ruth.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: My brother gets hay fever too,
subQuotationList: ['My brother gets hay fever too,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
This house lies too much on the land for them. Naturally, they were
glad enough to slip in at first. But Wilcoxes are better than nothing,
as I see you ve found.
subQuotationList: ['This house lies too much on the land for them. Naturally, they were\nglad enough to slip in at first. But Wilcoxes are better than nothing,\nas I see you ve found.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: They keep a place going, don t they? Yes, it is just that.
subQuotationList: ['They keep a place going, don t they? Yes, it is just that.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: They keep England going, it is my opinion.
subQuotationList: ['They keep England going, it is my opinion.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Ay, they breed like rabbits.
Well, well, it s a funny world. But He who made it knows what He wants
in it, I suppose. If Mrs. Charlie is expecting her fourth, it isn t for
us to repine.
subQuotationList:
['Ay, they breed like rabbits.
Well, well, it s a funny world. But He who made it knows what He wants
in it, I suppose. If Mrs. Charlie is expecting her fourth, it isn t for
us to repine.']
speaker: Miss Avery
referringExpression: Miss Avery upset her by replying

quoteText:
They breed and they also work, It certainly is a funny world, but so long as men
like my husband and his sons govern it, I think it ll never be a bad
one--never really bad.
subQuotationList: ['They breed and they also work,', 'It certainly is a funny world, but so long as men\nlike my husband and his sons govern it, I think it ll never be a bad\none--never really bad.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: No, better n nothing,
subQuotationList: ['No, better n nothing,']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText:
I
never saw much of Ruth after her grandmother died, but we stayed civil.
It was a very civil family. Old Mrs. Howard never spoke against
anybody, nor let any one be turned away without food. Then it was never
 Trespassers will be prosecuted  in their land, but would people please
not come in? Mrs. Howard was never created to run a farm.
subQuotationList:
['I
never saw much of Ruth after her grandmother died, but we stayed civil.
It was a very civil family. Old Mrs. Howard never spoke against
anybody, nor let any one be turned away without food. Then it was never
 Trespassers will be prosecuted  in their land, but would people please
not come in? Mrs. Howard was never created to run a farm.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: Had they no men to help them?
subQuotationList: ['Had they no men to help them?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Things went on until there were no men.
subQuotationList: ['Things went on until there were no men.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: Until Mr. Wilcox came along,
subQuotationList: ['Until Mr. Wilcox came along,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I suppose so; but Ruth should have married a--no disrespect to you to
say this, for I take it you were intended to get Wilcox any way, whether
she got him first or no.
subQuotationList: ['I suppose so; but Ruth should have married a--no disrespect to you to\nsay this, for I take it you were intended to get Wilcox any way, whether\nshe got him first or no.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: Whom should she have married?
subQuotationList: ['Whom should she have married?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: A soldier! Some real soldier.
subQuotationList: ['A soldier!', 'Some real soldier.']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText:
But that s all over, A better time is coming now, though
you ve kept me long enough waiting. In a couple of weeks I ll see your
light shining through the hedge of an evening. Have you ordered in
coals?
subQuotationList:
['But that s all over,', 'A better time is coming now, though
you ve kept me long enough waiting. In a couple of weeks I ll see your
light shining through the hedge of an evening. Have you ordered in
coals?']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText:
We are not coming, No. Not coming. Never coming. It has all been a
mistake. The furniture must be repacked at once, and I am very sorry,
but I am making other arrangements, and must ask you to give me the
keys.
subQuotationList:
['We are not coming,', 'No. Not coming. Never coming. It has all been a
mistake. The furniture must be repacked at once, and I am very sorry,
but I am making other arrangements, and must ask you to give me the
keys.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Certainly, Mrs. Wilcox,
subQuotationList: ['Certainly, Mrs. Wilcox,']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText:
to really
take my tiresome chest in hand,
subQuotationList: ['to really\ntake my tiresome chest in hand,']
speaker: Aunt Juley
referringExpression: She had scarcely promised her niece

quoteText: Important--Margaret dear, take the Lulworth when Helen comes.
subQuotationList: ['Important--Margaret dear, take the Lulworth when Helen comes.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Helen won t be able to stop, Aunt Juley. She has telegraphed that she
can only get away just to see you. She must go back to Germany as soon
as you are well.
subQuotationList: ['Helen won t be able to stop, Aunt Juley. She has telegraphed that she\ncan only get away just to see you. She must go back to Germany as soon\nas you are well.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: How very odd of Helen! Mr. Wilcox--
subQuotationList: ['How very odd of Helen! Mr. Wilcox--']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Yes, dear?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, dear?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Can he spare you?
subQuotationList: ['Can he spare you?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
Margaret--important, I should like you to have some
companion to take walks with. Do try Miss Conder.
subQuotationList: ['Margaret--important,', 'I should like you to have some\ncompanion to take walks with. Do try Miss Conder.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: I have been for a little walk with Miss Conder.
subQuotationList: ['I have been for a little walk with Miss Conder.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But she is not really interesting. If only you had Helen.
subQuotationList: ['But she is not really interesting. If only you had Helen.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: I have Tibby, Aunt Juley.
subQuotationList: ['I have Tibby, Aunt Juley.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
No, but he has to do his Chinese. Some real companion is what you need.
Really, Helen is odd.
subQuotationList: ['No, but he has to do his Chinese. Some real companion is what you need.\nReally, Helen is odd.']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText: Helen is odd, very,
subQuotationList: ['Helen is odd, very,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Not content with going abroad, why does she want to go back there at
once?
subQuotationList: ['Not content with going abroad, why does she want to go back there at\nonce?']
speaker: Aunt Juley

quoteText:
No doubt she will change her mind when she sees us. She has not the
least balance.
subQuotationList: ['No doubt she will change her mind when she sees us. She has not the\nleast balance.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Why don t you tell Mr. Wilcox?
subQuotationList: ['Why don t you tell Mr. Wilcox?']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: About Helen?
subQuotationList: ['About Helen?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Perhaps he has come across that sort of thing.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps he has come across that sort of thing.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: He would do all he could, but--
subQuotationList: ['He would do all he could, but--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, you know best. But he is practical.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, you know best. But he is practical.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: Tibby love, what next?
subQuotationList: ['Tibby love, what next?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It is extraordinary.
subQuotationList: ['It is extraordinary.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
Dear, your judgment s often clearer than mine. Have you any notion
what s at the back?
subQuotationList: ['Dear, your judgment s often clearer than mine. Have you any notion\nwhat s at the back?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: None, unless it s something mental.
subQuotationList: ['None, unless it s something mental.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: Oh--that! Quite impossible.
subQuotationList: ['Oh--that!', 'Quite impossible.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: just like Helen
subQuotationList: ['just like Helen']
speaker: Henry
referringExpression: he only chaffed Tibby and the Schlegels generally and declared

quoteText:
That is what we all say, But why should it be
just like Helen? Why should she be allowed to be so queer, and to grow
queerer?
subQuotationList: ['That is what we all say,', 'But why should it be\njust like Helen? Why should she be allowed to be so queer, and to grow\nqueerer?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Don t ask me. I m a plain man of business. I live and let live. My
advice to you both is, don t worry. Margaret, you ve got black marks
again under your eyes. You know that s strictly forbidden. First
your aunt--then your sister. No, we aren t going to have it. Are we,
Theobald?
subQuotationList:
['Don t ask me. I m a plain man of business. I live and let live. My
advice to you both is, don t worry. Margaret, you ve got black marks
again under your eyes. You know that s strictly forbidden. First
your aunt--then your sister. No, we aren t going to have it. Are we,
Theobald?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I ll give you some tea, and then you go
straight to Ducie Street. I can t have my girl looking as old as her
husband.
subQuotationList: ['I ll give you some tea, and then you go\nstraight to Ducie Street. I can t have my girl looking as old as her\nhusband.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: All the same, you have not quite seen our point,
subQuotationList: ['All the same, you have not quite seen our point,']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
I don t suppose I ever
shall.
subQuotationList: ['I don t suppose I ever\nshall.']
speaker: Henry
referringExpression: Mr Wilcox who was in good spirits retorted

quoteText: Margaret s point is this, Our sister may be mad.
subQuotationList: ['Margaret s point is this,', 'Our sister may be mad.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
Come in, Charles, Could you help us at all? We
are again in trouble.
subQuotationList: ['Come in, Charles,', 'Could you help us at all? We\nare again in trouble.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I m afraid I cannot. What are the facts? We are all mad more or less,
you know, in these days.
subQuotationList: ['I m afraid I cannot. What are the facts? We are all mad more or less,\nyou know, in these days.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
The facts are as follows, The facts are that she has been in England for three days and
will not see us. She has forbidden the bankers to give us her address.
She refuses to answer questions. Margaret finds her letters colourless.
There are other facts, but these are the most striking.
subQuotationList:
['The facts are as follows,', 'The facts are that she has been in England for three days and
will not see us. She has forbidden the bankers to give us her address.
She refuses to answer questions. Margaret finds her letters colourless.
There are other facts, but these are the most striking.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: She has never behaved like this before, then?
subQuotationList: ['She has never behaved like this before, then?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Of course not!
subQuotationList: ['Of course not!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Well, my dear, how am I to know?
subQuotationList: ['Well, my dear, how am I to know?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
You know quite well that
Helen never sins against affection, You must have noticed
that much in her, surely.
subQuotationList: ['You know quite well that\nHelen never sins against affection,', 'You must have noticed\nthat much in her, surely.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh yes; she and I have always hit it off together.
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes; she and I have always hit it off together.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: No, Henry--can t you see?--I don t mean that.
subQuotationList: ['No, Henry--can t you see?--I don t mean that.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I was meaning that when she was eccentric in the past, one could trace
it back to the heart in the long-run. She behaved oddly because she
cared for some one, or wanted to help them. There s no possible excuse
for her now. She is grieving us deeply, and that is why I am sure that
she is not well.  Mad  is too terrible a word, but she is not well.
I shall never believe it. I shouldn t discuss my sister with you if I
thought she was well--trouble you about her, I mean.
subQuotationList:
['I was meaning that when she was eccentric in the past, one could trace
it back to the heart in the long-run. She behaved oddly because she
cared for some one, or wanted to help them. There s no possible excuse
for her now. She is grieving us deeply, and that is why I am sure that
she is not well.  Mad  is too terrible a word, but she is not well.
I shall never believe it. I shouldn t discuss my sister with you if I
thought she was well--trouble you about her, I mean.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
You want to get hold of her? That s the problem, isn t it?
She has got to see a doctor.
subQuotationList: ['You want to get hold of her?', 'That s the problem, isn t it?\nShe has got to see a doctor.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: For all I know she has seen one already.
subQuotationList: ['For all I know she has seen one already.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes, yes; don t interrupt.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, yes; don t interrupt.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I ve got it, It s
perfectly easy. Leave it to me. We ll send her down to Howards End.
subQuotationList: ['I ve got it,', 'It s\nperfectly easy. Leave it to me. We ll send her down to Howards End.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: How will you do that?
subQuotationList: ['How will you do that?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
After her books. Tell her that she must unpack them herself. Then you
can meet her there.
subQuotationList: ['After her books. Tell her that she must unpack them herself. Then you\ncan meet her there.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
But, Henry, that s just what she won t let me do. It s part of
her--whatever it is--never to see me.
subQuotationList: ['But, Henry, that s just what she won t let me do. It s part of\nher--whatever it is--never to see me.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Of course you won t tell her you re going. When she is there, looking
at the cases, you ll just stroll in. If nothing is wrong with her, so
much the better. But there ll be the motor round the corner, and we can
run her to a specialist in no time.
subQuotationList:
['Of course you won t tell her you re going. When she is there, looking
at the cases, you ll just stroll in. If nothing is wrong with her, so
much the better. But there ll be the motor round the corner, and we can
run her to a specialist in no time.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: It s quite impossible.
subQuotationList: ['It s quite impossible.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Why?
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
It doesn t seem impossible to me, it is surely a very
tippy plan.
subQuotationList: ['It doesn t seem impossible to me,', 'it is surely a very\ntippy plan.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: It is impossible, because--
subQuotationList: ['It is impossible, because--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
It s not
the particular language that Helen and I talk, if you see my meaning. It
would do splendidly for other people, whom I don t blame.
subQuotationList: ['It s not\nthe particular language that Helen and I talk, if you see my meaning. It\nwould do splendidly for other people, whom I don t blame.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
But Helen doesn t talk, That s our whole difficulty. She
won t talk your particular language, and on that account you think she s
ill.
subQuotationList: ['But Helen doesn t talk,', 'That s our whole difficulty. She\nwon t talk your particular language, and on that account you think she s\nill.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: No, Henry; it s sweet of you, but I couldn t.
subQuotationList: ['No, Henry; it s sweet of you, but I couldn t.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I see, you have scruples.
subQuotationList: ['I see,', 'you have scruples.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I suppose so.
subQuotationList: ['I suppose so.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
And sooner than go against them you would have your sister suffer. You
could have got her down to Swanage by a word, but you had scruples. And
scruples are all very well. I am as scrupulous as any man alive, I hope;
but when it is a case like this, when there is a question of madness--
subQuotationList:
['And sooner than go against them you would have your sister suffer. You
could have got her down to Swanage by a word, but you had scruples. And
scruples are all very well. I am as scrupulous as any man alive, I hope;
but when it is a case like this, when there is a question of madness--']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I deny it s madness.
subQuotationList: ['I deny it s madness.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: You said just now--
subQuotationList: ['You said just now--']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: It s madness when I say it, but not when you say it.
subQuotationList: ['It s madness when I say it, but not when you say it.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Margaret! Margaret! No
education can teach a woman logic. Now, my dear, my time is valuable. Do
you want me to help you or not?
subQuotationList: ['Margaret! Margaret!', 'No\neducation can teach a woman logic. Now, my dear, my time is valuable. Do\nyou want me to help you or not?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Not in that way.
subQuotationList: ['Not in that way.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Answer my question. Plain question, plain answer. Do--
subQuotationList: ['Answer my question. Plain question, plain answer. Do--']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Pater, we may as well keep
Howards End out of it,
subQuotationList: ['Pater, we may as well keep\nHowards End out of it,']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Why, Charles?
subQuotationList: ['Why, Charles?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
The whole house is at sixes and sevens, We don t
want any more mess.
subQuotationList: ['The whole house is at sixes and sevens,', 'We don t\nwant any more mess.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Who s  we ? My boy, pray who s  we ?
subQuotationList: ['Who s  we ?', 'My boy, pray who s  we ?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I am sure I beg your pardon, I appear always to be
intruding.
subQuotationList: ['I am sure I beg your pardon,', 'I appear always to be\nintruding.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
I can t have this sort
of behaviour, my boy. Margaret s too sweet-natured to mind, but I mind
for her.
subQuotationList: ['I can t have this sort\nof behaviour, my boy. Margaret s too sweet-natured to mind, but I mind\nfor her.']
speaker: Henry
referringExpression: Mr Wilcox said to his son

quoteText: Is anything wrong with you, Charles, this afternoon?
subQuotationList: ['Is anything wrong with you, Charles, this afternoon?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: No, pater; but you may be taking on a bigger business than you reckon.
subQuotationList: ['No, pater; but you may be taking on a bigger business than you reckon.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: How?
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Don t ask me.
subQuotationList: ['Don t ask me.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: She was bound to drive, There will be her books.
subQuotationList: ['She was bound to drive,', 'There will be her books.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I cannot make it out,
subQuotationList: ['I cannot make it out,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Finish your coffee, dear. We must be off.
subQuotationList: ['Finish your coffee, dear. We must be off.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Yes, Margaret, you know you must take plenty,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, Margaret, you know you must take plenty,']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText:
You re not fit for it, Let me go alone. I know
exactly what to do.
subQuotationList: ['You re not fit for it,', 'Let me go alone. I know\nexactly what to do.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Oh yes, I am fit, Only most
frightfully worried. I cannot feel that Helen is really alive. Her
letters and telegrams seem to have come from some one else. Her voice
isn t in them. I don t believe your driver really saw her at the
station. I wish I d never mentioned it. I know that Charles is vexed.
Yes, he is-- There, Dolly will
forgive me. There. Now we ll be off.
subQuotationList:
['Oh yes, I am fit,', 'Only most
frightfully worried. I cannot feel that Helen is really alive. Her
letters and telegrams seem to have come from some one else. Her voice
isn t in them. I don t believe your driver really saw her at the
station. I wish I d never mentioned it. I know that Charles is vexed.
Yes, he is--', 'There, Dolly will
forgive me. There. Now we ll be off.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Don t you want to tidy yourself?
