subQuotationList: ['Don t you want to tidy yourself?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Have I time?
subQuotationList: ['Have I time?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes, plenty.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, plenty.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Dolly, I m going without her.
subQuotationList: ['Dolly, I m going without her.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Tell her I thought it best.
subQuotationList: ['Tell her I thought it best.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Yes, Mr. Wilcox, I see.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, Mr. Wilcox, I see.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: Say anything you like. All right.
subQuotationList: ['Say anything you like. All right.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I deserve it; I am punished for
lowering my colours.
subQuotationList: ['I deserve it; I am punished for\nlowering my colours.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I still consider you are not fit for it,
subQuotationList: ['I still consider you are not fit for it,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Perhaps I was not at lunch. But the whole thing is spread clearly
before me now.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps I was not at lunch. But the whole thing is spread clearly\nbefore me now.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I was meaning to act for the best.
subQuotationList: ['I was meaning to act for the best.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Just lend me your scarf, will you. This wind takes one s hair so.
subQuotationList: ['Just lend me your scarf, will you. This wind takes one s hair so.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Certainly, dear girl. Are you all right now?
subQuotationList: ['Certainly, dear girl. Are you all right now?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Look! My hands have stopped trembling.
subQuotationList: ['Look! My hands have stopped trembling.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
And have quite forgiven me? Then listen. Her cab should already have
arrived at Howards End. (We re a little late, but no matter.) Our first
move will be to send it down to wait at the farm, as, if possible, one
doesn t want a scene before servants. A certain gentleman
subQuotationList:
['And have quite forgiven me? Then listen. Her cab should already have
arrived at Howards End. (We re a little late, but no matter.) Our first
move will be to send it down to wait at the farm, as, if possible, one
doesn t want a scene before servants. A certain gentleman']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
won t drive in, but will wait a little short of the
front gate, behind the laurels. Have you still the keys of the house?
subQuotationList: ['won t drive in, but will wait a little short of the\nfront gate, behind the laurels. Have you still the keys of the house?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Well, they aren t wanted. Do you remember how the house stands?
subQuotationList: ['Well, they aren t wanted. Do you remember how the house stands?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
If we don t find her in the porch, we can stroll round into the garden.
Our object--
subQuotationList: ['If we don t find her in the porch, we can stroll round into the garden.\nOur object--']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I was just saying to my wife, Mansbridge, that our main object is not
to frighten Miss Schlegel. The house, as you know, is my property, so it
should seem quite natural for us to be there. The trouble is evidently
nervous--wouldn t you say so, Margaret?
subQuotationList:
['I was just saying to my wife, Mansbridge, that our main object is not
to frighten Miss Schlegel. The house, as you know, is my property, so it
should seem quite natural for us to be there. The trouble is evidently
nervous--wouldn t you say so, Margaret?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Nothing,
subQuotationList: ['Nothing,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Though she did resent my husband s immorality.
subQuotationList: ['Though she did resent my husband s immorality.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
She always was highly strung, A tendency to spiritualism and those
things, though nothing serious. Musical, literary, artistic, but I
should say normal--a very charming girl.
subQuotationList: ['She always was highly strung,', 'A tendency to spiritualism and those\nthings, though nothing serious. Musical, literary, artistic, but I\nshould say normal--a very charming girl.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Is the truant all right?
subQuotationList: ['Is the truant all right?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Oh, my darling--
subQuotationList: ['Oh, my darling--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Yes,
all right,
subQuotationList: ['Yes,\nall right,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Margaret, you look upset!
subQuotationList: ['Margaret, you look upset!']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
You
might have given me a knock with the gate,
subQuotationList: ['You\nmight have given me a knock with the gate,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Go
away.
subQuotationList: ['Go\naway.']
speaker: Margaret
referringExpression: She or someone for her said

quoteText:
Margaret, you look upset again.
My dear, give me the keys. What are you doing with Helen?
subQuotationList: ['Margaret, you look upset again.\nMy dear, give me the keys. What are you doing with Helen?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Oh, dearest, do go away, and I will manage it all.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, dearest, do go away, and I will manage it all.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Manage what?
subQuotationList: ['Manage what?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Stop that at least,
subQuotationList: ['Stop that at least,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Come, this is an odd beginning,
subQuotationList: ['Come, this is an odd beginning,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I cannot help it, Do wait. It s not my fault. Please
all four of you go away now.
subQuotationList: ['I cannot help it,', 'Do wait. It s not my fault. Please\nall four of you go away now.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: We are relying on you to help us, Mrs. Wilcox, Could you go in and persuade your sister to come out?
subQuotationList: ['We are relying on you to help us, Mrs. Wilcox,', 'Could you go in and persuade your sister to come out?']
speaker: Mansbridge

quoteText: On what grounds?
subQuotationList: ['On what grounds?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I beg your pardon, but it is nothing of the sort. You are not qualified
to attend my sister, Mr. Mansbridge. If we require your services, we
will let you know.
subQuotationList: ['I beg your pardon, but it is nothing of the sort. You are not qualified\nto attend my sister, Mr. Mansbridge. If we require your services, we\nwill let you know.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I can diagnose the case more bluntly if you wish,
subQuotationList: ['I can diagnose the case more bluntly if you wish,']
speaker: Mansbridge

quoteText:
You could, but you have not. You are, therefore, not qualified to
attend my sister.
subQuotationList: ['You could, but you have not. You are, therefore, not qualified to\nattend my sister.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Come, come, Margaret! This is a
terrible business, an appalling business. It s doctor s orders. Open the
door.
subQuotationList: ['Come, come, Margaret!', 'This is a\nterrible business, an appalling business. It s doctor s orders. Open the\ndoor.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Forgive me, but I will not.
subQuotationList: ['Forgive me, but I will not.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I don t agree.
subQuotationList: ['I don t agree.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
This business is as broad as it s long, We
had better all work together. You need us, Mrs. Wilcox, and we need
you.
subQuotationList: ['This business is as broad as it s long,', 'We\nhad better all work together. You need us, Mrs. Wilcox, and we need\nyou.']
speaker: Mansbridge

quoteText: Quite so,
subQuotationList: ['Quite so,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I do not need you in the least,
subQuotationList: ['I do not need you in the least,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: No more does my sister, who is still many weeks from her confinement.
subQuotationList: ['No more does my sister, who is still many weeks from her confinement.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Margaret, Margaret!
subQuotationList: ['Margaret, Margaret!']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Well, Henry, send your doctor away. What possible use is he now?
subQuotationList: ['Well, Henry, send your doctor away. What possible use is he now?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
It all turns on affection now, Affection. Don t you
see? Surely you see. I like Helen very much, you not so much.
Mr. Mansbridge doesn t know her. That s all. And affection, when
reciprocated, gives rights. Put that down in your note-book, Mr.
Mansbridge. It s a useful formula. You don t know what you want yourselves, For one sensible remark I will let you in. But you cannot make
it. You would trouble my sister for no reason. I will not permit it.
I ll stand here all the day sooner.
subQuotationList:
['It all turns on affection now,', 'Affection. Don t you
see?', 'Surely you see. I like Helen very much, you not so much.
Mr. Mansbridge doesn t know her. That s all. And affection, when
reciprocated, gives rights. Put that down in your note-book, Mr.
Mansbridge. It s a useful formula.', 'You don t know what you want yourselves,', 'For one sensible remark I will let you in. But you cannot make
it. You would trouble my sister for no reason. I will not permit it.
I ll stand here all the day sooner.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Mansbridge, perhaps not now.
subQuotationList: ['Mansbridge,', 'perhaps not now.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Now, Henry, you, Go away now, dear. I shall want your advice later, no
doubt. Forgive me if I have been cross. But, seriously, you must go.
subQuotationList: ['Now, Henry, you,', 'Go away now, dear. I shall want your advice later, no\ndoubt. Forgive me if I have been cross. But, seriously, you must go.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I shall soon find you down at Dolly s,
subQuotationList: ['I shall soon find you down at Dolly s,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, my darling! My darling, forgive me.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, my darling!', 'My darling, forgive me.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Convenient! You did not tell me that the books were unpacked. I have
found nearly everything that I want.
subQuotationList: ['Convenient! You did not tell me that the books were unpacked. I have\nfound nearly everything that I want.']
speaker: Helen
referringExpression: Helen in a dignified voice that came strangely from her said

quoteText: I told you nothing that was true.
subQuotationList: ['I told you nothing that was true.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: It has been a great surprise, certainly. Has Aunt Juley been ill?
subQuotationList: ['It has been a great surprise, certainly. Has Aunt Juley been ill?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Helen, you wouldn t think I d invent that?
subQuotationList: ['Helen, you wouldn t think I d invent that?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I suppose not, But one loses faith in everything after this.
subQuotationList: ['I suppose not,', 'But one loses faith in everything after this.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: We thought it was illness, but even then--I haven t behaved worthily.
subQuotationList: ['We thought it was illness, but even then--I haven t behaved worthily.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I ought not to have consulted any one. What would our father have
thought of me?
subQuotationList: ['I ought not to have consulted any one. What would our father have\nthought of me?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Yes, I am annoyed, My wishes should have been
respected. I would have gone through this meeting if it was necessary,
but after Aunt Juley recovered, it was not necessary. Planning my life,
as I now have to do.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, I am annoyed,', 'My wishes should have been
respected. I would have gone through this meeting if it was necessary,
but after Aunt Juley recovered, it was not necessary. Planning my life,
as I now have to do.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Come away from those books, Helen, do talk to me.
subQuotationList: ['Come away from those books,', 'Helen, do talk to me.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I was just saying that I have stopped living haphazard. One can t go
through a great deal of --
subQuotationList: ['I was just saying that I have stopped living haphazard. One can t go\nthrough a great deal of --']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
without planning one s
actions in advance. I am going to have a child in June, and in the first
place conversations, discussions, excitement, are not good for me. I
will go through them if necessary, but only then. In the second place I
have no right to trouble people. I cannot fit in with England as I know
it. I have done something that the English never pardon. It would not be
right for them to pardon it. So I must live where I am not known.
subQuotationList:
['without planning one s
actions in advance. I am going to have a child in June, and in the first
place conversations, discussions, excitement, are not good for me. I
will go through them if necessary, but only then. In the second place I
have no right to trouble people. I cannot fit in with England as I know
it. I have done something that the English never pardon. It would not be
right for them to pardon it. So I must live where I am not known.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: But why didn t you tell me, dearest?
subQuotationList: ['But why didn t you tell me, dearest?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes, I might have, but decided to wait.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'I might have, but decided to wait.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I believe you would never have told me.
subQuotationList: ['I believe you would never have told me.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh yes, I should. We have taken a flat in Munich.
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes, I should. We have taken a flat in Munich.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
By  we  I mean myself and Monica. But for her, I am and have been and
always wish to be alone.
subQuotationList: ['By  we  I mean myself and Monica. But for her, I am and have been and\nalways wish to be alone.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I have not heard of Monica.
subQuotationList: ['I have not heard of Monica.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
You wouldn t have. She s an Italian--by birth at least. She makes her
living by journalism. I met her originally on Garda. Monica is much the
best person to see me through.
subQuotationList: ['You wouldn t have. She s an Italian--by birth at least. She makes her\nliving by journalism. I met her originally on Garda. Monica is much the\nbest person to see me through.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: You are very fond of her, then.
subQuotationList: ['You are very fond of her, then.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: She has been extraordinarily sensible with me.
subQuotationList: ['She has been extraordinarily sensible with me.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
You must not think that we shall never meet, I shall always have a room for you when you can be
spared, and the longer you can be with me the better. But you haven t
understood yet, Meg, and of course it is very difficult for you. This is
a shock to you. It isn t to me, who have been thinking over our futures
for many months, and they won t be changed by a slight contretemps, such
as this. I cannot live in England.
subQuotationList:
['You must not think that we shall never meet,', 'I shall always have a room for you when you can be
spared, and the longer you can be with me the better. But you haven t
understood yet, Meg, and of course it is very difficult for you. This is
a shock to you. It isn t to me, who have been thinking over our futures
for many months, and they won t be changed by a slight contretemps, such
as this. I cannot live in England.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Helen, you ve not forgiven me for my treachery. You COULDN T talk like
this to me if you had.
subQuotationList: ['Helen, you ve not forgiven me for my treachery. You COULDN T talk like\nthis to me if you had.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, Meg dear, why do we talk at all?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Meg dear, why do we talk at all?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Tell me, how is it that
all the books are down here?
subQuotationList: ['Tell me, how is it that\nall the books are down here?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Series of mistakes.
subQuotationList: ['Series of mistakes.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: And a great deal of furniture has been unpacked.
subQuotationList: ['And a great deal of furniture has been unpacked.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: All.
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Who lives here, then?
subQuotationList: ['Who lives here, then?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: No one.
subQuotationList: ['No one.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I suppose you are letting it, though.
subQuotationList: ['I suppose you are letting it, though.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
The house is dead, Why worry on about
it?
subQuotationList: ['The house is dead,', 'Why worry on about\nit?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
But I am interested. You talk as if I had lost all my interest in life.
I am still Helen, I hope. Now this hasn t the feel of a dead house.
The hall seems more alive even than in the old days, when it held the
Wilcoxes  own things.
subQuotationList:
['But I am interested. You talk as if I had lost all my interest in life.
I am still Helen, I hope. Now this hasn t the feel of a dead house.
The hall seems more alive even than in the old days, when it held the
Wilcoxes  own things.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Interested, are you? Very well, I must tell you, I suppose. My husband
lent it on condition we--but by a mistake all our things were unpacked,
and Miss Avery, instead of--
subQuotationList: ['Interested, are you? Very well, I must tell you, I suppose. My husband\nlent it on condition we--but by a mistake all our things were unpacked,\nand Miss Avery, instead of--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Look here, I can t go on
like this. I warn you I won t. Helen, why should you be so miserably
unkind to me, simply because you hate Henry?
subQuotationList: ['Look here, I can t go on\nlike this. I warn you I won t. Helen, why should you be so miserably\nunkind to me, simply because you hate Henry?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I don t hate him now, I have stopped being a schoolgirl,
and, Meg, once again, I m not being unkind. But as for fitting in with
your English life--no, put it out of your head at once. Imagine a visit
from me at Ducie Street! It s unthinkable. Tell me about yourself,
subQuotationList:
['I don t hate him now,', 'I have stopped being a schoolgirl,
and, Meg, once again, I m not being unkind. But as for fitting in with
your English life--no, put it out of your head at once. Imagine a visit
from me at Ducie Street! It s unthinkable.', 'Tell me about yourself,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: There s nothing to tell.
subQuotationList: ['There s nothing to tell.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But your marriage has been happy, Meg?
subQuotationList: ['But your marriage has been happy, Meg?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Yes, but I don t feel inclined to talk.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, but I don t feel inclined to talk.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: You feel as I do.
subQuotationList: ['You feel as I do.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Not that, but I can t.
subQuotationList: ['Not that, but I can t.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: No more can I. It is a nuisance, but no good trying.
subQuotationList: ['No more can I. It is a nuisance, but no good trying.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Look here, Meg, is the coast clear?
subQuotationList: ['Look here, Meg, is the coast clear?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: You mean that you want to go away from me?
subQuotationList: ['You mean that you want to go away from me?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I suppose so--dear old lady! it isn t any use. I knew we should have
nothing to say. Give my love to Aunt Juley and Tibby, and take more
yourself than I can say. Promise to come and see me in Munich later.
subQuotationList: ['I suppose so--dear old lady! it isn t any use. I knew we should have\nnothing to say. Give my love to Aunt Juley and Tibby, and take more\nyourself than I can say. Promise to come and see me in Munich later.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Certainly, dearest.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly, dearest.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: For that is all we can do.
subQuotationList: ['For that is all we can do.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I am glad to have seen you and the things.
subQuotationList: ['I am glad to have seen you and the things.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
The car has gone, and here s
your cab.
subQuotationList: ['The car has gone, and here s\nyour cab.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Please, lady, a message,
subQuotationList: ['Please, lady, a message,']
speaker: The Driver
referringExpression: The driver who was leaning on the gate called out

quoteText: How did this come?
subQuotationList: ['How did this come?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Henry would have done what he could,
subQuotationList: ['Henry would have done what he could,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: This IS Mr. Wilcox s house?
subQuotationList: ['This IS Mr. Wilcox s house?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Surely you remember Howards End?
subQuotationList: ['Surely you remember Howards End?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Remember? I who remember everything! But it looks to be ours now.
subQuotationList: ['Remember? I who remember everything! But it looks to be ours now.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Miss Avery was extraordinary, She loved
Mrs. Wilcox, and would rather furnish her home with our things than
think of it empty. In consequence here are all the library books.
subQuotationList: ['Miss Avery was extraordinary,', 'She loved\nMrs. Wilcox, and would rather furnish her home with our things than\nthink of it empty. In consequence here are all the library books.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Not all the books. She hasn t unpacked the Art books, in which she may
show her sense. And we never used to have the sword here.
subQuotationList: ['Not all the books. She hasn t unpacked the Art books, in which she may\nshow her sense. And we never used to have the sword here.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: The sword looks well, though.
subQuotationList: ['The sword looks well, though.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Magnificent.
subQuotationList: ['Magnificent.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Yes, doesn t it?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, doesn t it?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Where s the piano, Meg?
subQuotationList: ['Where s the piano, Meg?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I warehoused that in London. Why?
subQuotationList: ['I warehoused that in London. Why?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Nothing.
subQuotationList: ['Nothing.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Curious, too, that the carpet fits.
subQuotationList: ['Curious, too, that the carpet fits.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
The carpet s a mistake, I know that we had it in
London, but this floor ought to be bare. It is far too beautiful.
subQuotationList: ['The carpet s a mistake,', 'I know that we had it in\nLondon, but this floor ought to be bare. It is far too beautiful.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
You still have a mania for under-furnishing. Would you care to come
into the dining-room before you start? There s no carpet there.
subQuotationList: ['You still have a mania for under-furnishing. Would you care to come\ninto the dining-room before you start? There s no carpet there.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, WHAT a place for mother s chiffonier!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, WHAT a place for mother s chiffonier!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Look at the chairs, though.
subQuotationList: ['Look at the chairs, though.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, look at them! Wickham Place faced north, didn t it?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, look at them! Wickham Place faced north, didn t it?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: North-west.
subQuotationList: ['North-west.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Anyhow, it is thirty years since any of those chairs have felt the sun.
Feel. Their dear little backs are quite warm.
subQuotationList: ['Anyhow, it is thirty years since any of those chairs have felt the sun.\nFeel. Their dear little backs are quite warm.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: But why has Miss Avery made them set to partners? I shall just--
subQuotationList: ['But why has Miss Avery made them set to partners? I shall just--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Over here, Meg. Put it so that any one sitting will see the lawn.
subQuotationList: ['Over here, Meg. Put it so that any one sitting will see the lawn.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Ye--es. The window s too high.
subQuotationList: ['Ye--es. The window s too high.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Try a drawing-room chair.
subQuotationList: ['Try a drawing-room chair.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
No, I don t like the drawing-room so much. The beam has been
match-boarded. It would have been so beautiful otherwise.
subQuotationList: ['No, I don t like the drawing-room so much. The beam has been\nmatch-boarded. It would have been so beautiful otherwise.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Helen, what a memory you have for some things! You re perfectly right.
It s a room that men have spoilt through trying to make it nice for
women. Men don t know what we want--
subQuotationList: ['Helen, what a memory you have for some things! You re perfectly right.\nIt s a room that men have spoilt through trying to make it nice for\nwomen. Men don t know what we want--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: And never will.
subQuotationList: ['And never will.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I don t agree. In two thousand years they ll know. Look where Tibby
spilt the soup.
subQuotationList: ['I don t agree. In two thousand years they ll know. Look where Tibby\nspilt the soup.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Coffee. It was coffee surely.
subQuotationList: ['Coffee. It was coffee surely.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Impossible. Tibby was far too young to be given
coffee at that time.
subQuotationList: ['Impossible. Tibby was far too young to be given\ncoffee at that time.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Was father alive?
subQuotationList: ['Was father alive?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Then you re right and it must have been soup. I was thinking of much
later--that unsuccessful visit of Aunt Juley s, when she didn t realise
that Tibby had grown up. It was coffee then, for he threw it down on
purpose. There was some rhyme,  Tea, coffee--coffee tea,  that she said
to him every morning at breakfast. Wait a minute--how did it go?
subQuotationList:
['Then you re right and it must have been soup. I was thinking of much
later--that unsuccessful visit of Aunt Juley s, when she didn t realise
that Tibby had grown up. It was coffee then, for he threw it down on
purpose. There was some rhyme,  Tea, coffee--coffee tea,  that she said
to him every morning at breakfast. Wait a minute--how did it go?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I know--no, I don t. What a detestable boy Tibby was!
subQuotationList: ['I know--no, I don t. What a detestable boy Tibby was!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: But the rhyme was simply awful. No decent person could put up with it.
subQuotationList: ['But the rhyme was simply awful. No decent person could put up with it.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Ah, that greengage-tree, Why do I connect it with dumb-bells? And there come
the chickens. The grass wants cutting. I love yellow-hammers.
subQuotationList: ['Ah, that greengage-tree,', 'Why do I connect it with dumb-bells? And there come\nthe chickens. The grass wants cutting. I love yellow-hammers.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I have got it, That every morning for three weeks. No wonder Tibby was wild.
subQuotationList: ['I have got it,', 'That every morning for three weeks. No wonder Tibby was wild.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Tibby is moderately a dear now,
subQuotationList: ['Tibby is moderately a dear now,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: There! I knew you d say that in the end. Of course he s a dear.
subQuotationList: ['There! I knew you d say that in the end. Of course he s a dear.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Listen! what s that?
subQuotationList: ['Listen! what s that?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Perhaps the Wilcoxes are beginning the siege.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps the Wilcoxes are beginning the siege.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: What nonsense--listen!
subQuotationList: ['What nonsense--listen!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
It
is always Meg.
subQuotationList: ['It\nis always Meg.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Little boy, what do you want?
subQuotationList: ['Little boy, what do you want?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Please, I am the milk.
subQuotationList: ['Please, I am the milk.']
speaker: Tom

quoteText: Did Miss Avery send you?
subQuotationList: ['Did Miss Avery send you?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes, please.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, please.']
speaker: Tom

quoteText: Then take it back and say we require no milk.
subQuotationList: ['Then take it back and say we require no milk.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
No, it s not the siege, but possibly an attempt to provision us
against one.
subQuotationList: ['No, it s not the siege, but possibly an attempt to provision us\nagainst one.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But I like milk, Why send it away?
subQuotationList: ['But I like milk,', 'Why send it away?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Do you? Oh, very well. But we ve nothing to put it in, and he wants the
can.
subQuotationList: ['Do you? Oh, very well. But we ve nothing to put it in, and he wants the\ncan.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Please, I m to call in the morning for the can,
subQuotationList: ['Please, I m to call in the morning for the can,']
speaker: Tom

quoteText: The house will be locked up then.
subQuotationList: ['The house will be locked up then.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: In the morning would I bring eggs too?
subQuotationList: ['In the morning would I bring eggs too?']
speaker: Tom

quoteText: Are you the boy whom I saw playing in the stacks last week?
subQuotationList: ['Are you the boy whom I saw playing in the stacks last week?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Well, run away and do it again.
subQuotationList: ['Well, run away and do it again.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Nice little boy, I say, what s your name? Mine s
Helen.
subQuotationList: ['Nice little boy,', 'I say, what s your name? Mine s\nHelen.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Tom.
speaker: Tom

quoteText: Tom, this one here is Margaret. And at home we ve another called Tibby.
subQuotationList: ['Tom, this one here is Margaret. And at home we ve another called Tibby.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Mine are lop-eareds,
subQuotationList: ['Mine are lop-eareds,']
speaker: Tom

quoteText:
You re a very good and rather a clever little boy. Mind you come
again.--Isn t he charming?
subQuotationList: ['You re a very good and rather a clever little boy. Mind you come\nagain.--Isn t he charming?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Undoubtedly, He is probably the son of Madge, and
Madge is dreadful. But this place has wonderful powers.
subQuotationList: ['Undoubtedly,', 'He is probably the son of Madge, and\nMadge is dreadful. But this place has wonderful powers.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What do you mean?
subQuotationList: ['What do you mean?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I don t know.
subQuotationList: ['I don t know.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Because I probably agree with you.
subQuotationList: ['Because I probably agree with you.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: It kills what is dreadful and makes what is beautiful live.
subQuotationList: ['It kills what is dreadful and makes what is beautiful live.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I do agree, But you said that the
house was dead not half an hour ago.
subQuotationList: ['I do agree,', 'But you said that the\nhouse was dead not half an hour ago.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Meaning that I was dead. I felt it.
subQuotationList: ['Meaning that I was dead. I felt it.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Yes, the house has a surer life than we, even if it was empty, and, as
it is, I can t get over that for thirty years the sun has never shone
full on our furniture. After all, Wickham Place was a grave. Meg, I ve a
startling idea.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, the house has a surer life than we, even if it was empty, and, as
it is, I can t get over that for thirty years the sun has never shone
full on our furniture. After all, Wickham Place was a grave. Meg, I ve a
startling idea.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: What is it?
subQuotationList: ['What is it?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Drink some milk to steady you.
subQuotationList: ['Drink some milk to steady you.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
No, I won t tell you yet, because you may laugh or be
angry. Let s go upstairs first and give the rooms an airing.
subQuotationList: ['No, I won t tell you yet,', 'because you may laugh or be\nangry. Let s go upstairs first and give the rooms an airing.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Then one would see really.
subQuotationList: ['Then one would see really.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
About my
idea. Couldn t you and I camp out in this house for the night?
subQuotationList: ['About my\nidea. Couldn t you and I camp out in this house for the night?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I don t think we could well do that,
subQuotationList: ['I don t think we could well do that,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Here are beds, tables, towels--
subQuotationList: ['Here are beds, tables, towels--']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I know; but the house isn t supposed to be slept in, and Henry s
suggestion was--
subQuotationList: ['I know; but the house isn t supposed to be slept in, and Henry s\nsuggestion was--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I require no suggestions. I shall not alter anything in my plans. But
it would give me so much pleasure to have one night here with you. It
will be something to look back on. Oh, Meg lovey, do let s!
subQuotationList: ['I require no suggestions. I shall not alter anything in my plans. But\nit would give me so much pleasure to have one night here with you. It\nwill be something to look back on. Oh, Meg lovey, do let s!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
But, Helen, my pet, we can t without getting Henry s
leave. Of course, he would give it, but you said yourself that you
couldn t visit at Ducie Street now, and this is equally intimate.
subQuotationList: ['But, Helen, my pet,', 'we can t without getting Henry s\nleave. Of course, he would give it, but you said yourself that you\ncouldn t visit at Ducie Street now, and this is equally intimate.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Ducie Street is his house. This is ours. Our furniture, our sort of
people coming to the door. Do let us camp out, just one night, and Tom
shall feed us on eggs and milk. Why not? It s a moon.
subQuotationList: ['Ducie Street is his house. This is ours. Our furniture, our sort of\npeople coming to the door. Do let us camp out, just one night, and Tom\nshall feed us on eggs and milk. Why not? It s a moon.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I feel Charles wouldn t like it, Even our furniture annoyed him, and I was going to clear it out when
Aunt Juley s illness prevented me. I sympathise with Charles. He feels
it s his mother s house. He loves it in rather an untaking way. Henry I
could answer for--not Charles.
subQuotationList:
['I feel Charles wouldn t like it,', 'Even our furniture annoyed him, and I was going to clear it out when
Aunt Juley s illness prevented me. I sympathise with Charles. He feels
it s his mother s house. He loves it in rather an untaking way. Henry I
could answer for--not Charles.']
speaker: Margaret
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Charles Wilcox']], [['Charles Wilcox'], ['Aunt Juley'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Henry'], ['Charles Wilcox']]]

quoteText:
I know he won t like it, But I am going to pass out of
their lives. What difference will it make in the long run if they say,
 And she even spent the night at Howards End ?
subQuotationList: ['I know he won t like it,', 'But I am going to pass out of\ntheir lives. What difference will it make in the long run if they say,\n And she even spent the night at Howards End ?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
How do you know you ll pass out of their lives? We have thought that
twice before.
subQuotationList: ['How do you know you ll pass out of their lives? We have thought that\ntwice before.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Because my plans--
subQuotationList: ['Because my plans--']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: --which you change in a moment.
subQuotationList: ['--which you change in a moment.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Then because my life is great and theirs are little, I know of things they can t know of, and so do you. We
know that there s poetry. We know that there s death. They can only take
them on hearsay. We know this is our house, because it feels ours. Oh,
they may take the title-deeds and the door-keys, but for this one night
we are at home.
subQuotationList:
['Then because my life is great and theirs are little,', 'I know of things they can t know of, and so do you. We
know that there s poetry. We know that there s death. They can only take
them on hearsay. We know this is our house, because it feels ours. Oh,
they may take the title-deeds and the door-keys, but for this one night
we are at home.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
It would be lovely to have you once more alone, It may
be a chance in a thousand.
subQuotationList: ['It would be lovely to have you once more alone,', 'It may\nbe a chance in a thousand.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes, and we could talk.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, and we could talk.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
It won t be a
very glorious story. But under that wych-elm--honestly, I see little
happiness ahead. Cannot I have this one night with you?
subQuotationList: ['It won t be a\nvery glorious story. But under that wych-elm--honestly, I see little\nhappiness ahead. Cannot I have this one night with you?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I needn t say how much it would mean to me.
subQuotationList: ['I needn t say how much it would mean to me.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Then let us.
subQuotationList: ['Then let us.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
It is no good hesitating. Shall I drive down to Hilton now and get
leave?
subQuotationList: ['It is no good hesitating. Shall I drive down to Hilton now and get\nleave?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Oh, we don t want leave.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, we don t want leave.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Charles may say no,
subQuotationList: ['Charles may say no,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: We shan t consult him.
subQuotationList: ['We shan t consult him.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Go if you like; I should have stopped without leave.
subQuotationList: ['Go if you like; I should have stopped without leave.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Expect me back before dark. I am looking forward to it so much. It is
like you to have thought of such a beautiful thing.
subQuotationList: ['Expect me back before dark. I am looking forward to it so much. It is\nlike you to have thought of such a beautiful thing.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Not a thing, only an ending,
subQuotationList: ['Not a thing, only an ending,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: But the diddums can t listen; he isn t nine months old,
subQuotationList: ['But the diddums can t listen; he isn t nine months old,']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: That s not what I was saying,
subQuotationList: ['That s not what I was saying,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Is it what we feared?
subQuotationList: ['Is it what we feared?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: It is.
subQuotationList: ['It is.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Dear girl, there is a troublesome business ahead of us,
and nothing but the most absolute honesty and plain speech will see
us through. I am obliged to question you on
subjects we d both prefer to leave untouched. As you know, I am not one
of your Bernard Shaws who consider nothing sacred. To speak as I must
will pain me, but there are occasions--We are husband and wife, not
children. I am a man of the world, and you are a most exceptional
woman.
subQuotationList:
['Dear girl,', 'there is a troublesome business ahead of us,
and nothing but the most absolute honesty and plain speech will see
us through.', 'I am obliged to question you on
subjects we d both prefer to leave untouched. As you know, I am not one
of your Bernard Shaws who consider nothing sacred. To speak as I must
will pain me, but there are occasions--We are husband and wife, not
children. I am a man of the world, and you are a most exceptional
woman.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I see that you feel as I felt when--My poor little wife! Oh, be brave!
Just one or two questions, and I have done with you. Was your sister
wearing a wedding-ring?
subQuotationList: ['I see that you feel as I felt when--My poor little wife! Oh, be brave!\nJust one or two questions, and I have done with you. Was your sister\nwearing a wedding-ring?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: No.
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Henry, I really came to ask a favour about Howards End.
subQuotationList: ['Henry, I really came to ask a favour about Howards End.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
One point at a time. I am now obliged to ask for the name of her
seducer.
subQuotationList: ['One point at a time. I am now obliged to ask for the name of her\nseducer.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Take your time, Remember that this is far worse
for me than for you.
subQuotationList: ['Take your time,', 'Remember that this is far worse\nfor me than for you.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Seducer? No; I do not know her seducer s name.
subQuotationList: ['Seducer? No; I do not know her seducer s name.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Would she not tell you?
subQuotationList: ['Would she not tell you?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I never even asked her who seduced her,
subQuotationList: ['I never even asked her who seduced her,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: That is singular.
subQuotationList: ['That is singular.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Natural perhaps, dear
girl, that you shouldn t ask. But until his name is known, nothing can
be done. Sit down. How terrible it is to see you so upset! I knew you
weren t fit for it. I wish I hadn t taken you.
subQuotationList:
['Natural perhaps, dear
girl, that you shouldn t ask. But until his name is known, nothing can
be done. Sit down. How terrible it is to see you so upset! I knew you
weren t fit for it. I wish I hadn t taken you.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I like to stand, if you don t mind, for it gives me
a pleasant view of the Six Hills.
subQuotationList: ['I like to stand, if you don t mind, for it gives me\na pleasant view of the Six Hills.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: As you like.
subQuotationList: ['As you like.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Have you anything else to ask me, Henry?
subQuotationList: ['Have you anything else to ask me, Henry?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Next you must tell me whether you have gathered anything. I have often
noticed your insight, dear. I only wish my own was as good. You may have
guessed something, even though your sister said nothing. The slightest
hint would help us.
subQuotationList:
['Next you must tell me whether you have gathered anything. I have often
noticed your insight, dear. I only wish my own was as good. You may have
guessed something, even though your sister said nothing. The slightest
hint would help us.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Who is  we ?
subQuotationList: ['Who is  we ?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I thought it best to ring up Charles.
subQuotationList: ['I thought it best to ring up Charles.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
That was unnecessary, This news will
give Charles disproportionate pain.
subQuotationList: ['That was unnecessary,', 'This news will\ngive Charles disproportionate pain.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: He has at once gone to call on your brother.
subQuotationList: ['He has at once gone to call on your brother.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: That too was unnecessary.
subQuotationList: ['That too was unnecessary.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Let me explain, dear, how the matter stands. You don t think that I and
my son are other than gentlemen? It is in Helen s interests that we are
acting. It is still not too late to save her name.
subQuotationList: ['Let me explain, dear, how the matter stands. You don t think that I and\nmy son are other than gentlemen? It is in Helen s interests that we are\nacting. It is still not too late to save her name.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Are we to make her seducer
marry her?
subQuotationList: ['Are we to make her seducer\nmarry her?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: If possible, yes.
subQuotationList: ['If possible, yes.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
But, Henry, suppose he turned out to be married already? One has heard
of such cases.
subQuotationList: ['But, Henry, suppose he turned out to be married already? One has heard\nof such cases.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
In that case he must pay heavily for his misconduct, and be thrashed
within an inch of his life.
subQuotationList: ['In that case he must pay heavily for his misconduct, and be thrashed\nwithin an inch of his life.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
May I ask you
my question now?
subQuotationList: ['May I ask you\nmy question now?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Certainly, my dear.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly, my dear.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: To-morrow Helen goes to Munich--
subQuotationList: ['To-morrow Helen goes to Munich--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Well, possibly she is right.
subQuotationList: ['Well, possibly she is right.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Henry, let a lady finish. To-morrow she goes; to-night, with your
permission, she would like to sleep at Howards End.
subQuotationList: ['Henry, let a lady finish. To-morrow she goes; to-night, with your\npermission, she would like to sleep at Howards End.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Why Howards End? Would she not be more comfortable,
as I suggested, at the hotel?
subQuotationList: ['Why Howards End?', 'Would she not be more comfortable,\nas I suggested, at the hotel?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
It is an odd request, but you
know what Helen is and what women in her state are.
subQuotationList: ['It is an odd request, but you\nknow what Helen is and what women in her state are.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
She has the idea that one night in your house would
give her pleasure and do her good. I think she s right. Being one of
those imaginative girls, the presence of all our books and furniture
soothes her. This is a fact. It is the end of her girlhood. Her last
words to me were,  A beautiful ending.
subQuotationList:
['She has the idea that one night in your house would
give her pleasure and do her good. I think she s right. Being one of
those imaginative girls, the presence of all our books and furniture
soothes her. This is a fact. It is the end of her girlhood. Her last
words to me were,  A beautiful ending.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: She values the old furniture for sentimental reasons, in fact.
subQuotationList: ['She values the old furniture for sentimental reasons, in fact.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Exactly. You have quite understood. It is her last hope of being with
it.
subQuotationList: ['Exactly. You have quite understood. It is her last hope of being with\nit.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I don t agree there, my dear! Helen will have her share of the goods
wherever she goes--possibly more than her share, for you are so fond
of her that you d give her anything of yours that she fancies, wouldn t
you? and I d raise no objection. I could understand it if it was her old
home, because a home, or a house,
subQuotationList:
['I don t agree there, my dear! Helen will have her share of the goods
wherever she goes--possibly more than her share, for you are so fond
of her that you d give her anything of yours that she fancies, wouldn t
you? and I d raise no objection. I could understand it if it was her old
home, because a home, or a house,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
because a house in which one has once
lived becomes in a sort of way sacred, I don t know why. Associations
and so on. Now Helen has no associations with Howards End, though I
and Charles and Evie have. I do not see why she wants to stay the night
there. She will only catch cold.
subQuotationList:
['because a house in which one has once
lived becomes in a sort of way sacred, I don t know why. Associations
and so on. Now Helen has no associations with Howards End, though I
and Charles and Evie have. I do not see why she wants to stay the night
there. She will only catch cold.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Leave it that you don t see, Call it fancy. But
realise that fancy is a scientific fact. Helen is fanciful, and wants
to.
subQuotationList: ['Leave it that you don t see,', 'Call it fancy. But\nrealise that fancy is a scientific fact. Helen is fanciful, and wants\nto.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
If she wants to sleep one night she may want to sleep two. We shall
never get her out of the house, perhaps.
subQuotationList: ['If she wants to sleep one night she may want to sleep two. We shall\nnever get her out of the house, perhaps.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Well? And suppose we
don t get her out of the house? Would it matter? She would do no one any
harm.
subQuotationList: ['Well?', 'And suppose we\ndon t get her out of the house? Would it matter? She would do no one any\nharm.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
No, Henry, I didn t mean that. We will
only trouble Howards End for this one night. I take her to London
to-morrow--
subQuotationList: ['No, Henry,', 'I didn t mean that. We will\nonly trouble Howards End for this one night. I take her to London\nto-morrow--']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Do you intend to sleep in a damp house, too?
subQuotationList: ['Do you intend to sleep in a damp house, too?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: She cannot be left alone.
subQuotationList: ['She cannot be left alone.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: That s quite impossible! Madness. You must be here to meet Charles.
subQuotationList: ['That s quite impossible! Madness. You must be here to meet Charles.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I have already told you that your message to Charles was unnecessary,
and I have no desire to meet him.
subQuotationList: ['I have already told you that your message to Charles was unnecessary,\nand I have no desire to meet him.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Margaret--my Margaret.
subQuotationList: ['Margaret--my Margaret.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
What has this business to do with Charles? If it concerns me little, it
concerns you less, and Charles not at all.
subQuotationList: ['What has this business to do with Charles? If it concerns me little, it\nconcerns you less, and Charles not at all.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: As the future owner of Howards End, I should say that it did concern Charles.
subQuotationList: ['As the future owner of Howards End,', 'I should say that it did concern Charles.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: In what way? Will Helen s condition depreciate the property?
subQuotationList: ['In what way? Will Helen s condition depreciate the property?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: My dear, you are forgetting yourself.
subQuotationList: ['My dear, you are forgetting yourself.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I think you yourself recommended plain speaking.
subQuotationList: ['I think you yourself recommended plain speaking.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Helen commands my sympathy, As your husband, I shall do
all for her that I can, and I have no doubt that she will prove more
sinned against than sinning. But I cannot treat her as if nothing has
happened. I should be false to my position in society if I did.
subQuotationList:
['Helen commands my sympathy,', 'As your husband, I shall do
all for her that I can, and I have no doubt that she will prove more
sinned against than sinning. But I cannot treat her as if nothing has
happened. I should be false to my position in society if I did.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
No, let us go back to Helen s
request, It is unreasonable, but the request of an unhappy
girl. Tomorrow she will go to Germany, and trouble society no longer.
To-night she asks to sleep in your empty house--a house which you do not
care about, and which you have not occupied for over a year. May she?
Will you give my sister leave? Will you forgive her as you hope to be
forgiven, and as you have actually been forgiven? Forgive her for one
night only. That will be enough.
subQuotationList:
['No, let us go back to Helen s
request,', 'It is unreasonable, but the request of an unhappy
girl. Tomorrow she will go to Germany, and trouble society no longer.
To-night she asks to sleep in your empty house--a house which you do not
care about, and which you have not occupied for over a year. May she?
Will you give my sister leave? Will you forgive her as you hope to be
forgiven, and as you have actually been forgiven? Forgive her for one
night only. That will be enough.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: As I have actually been forgiven--?
subQuotationList: ['As I have actually been forgiven--?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Never mind for the moment what I mean by that, Answer
my question.
subQuotationList: ['Never mind for the moment what I mean by that,', 'Answer\nmy question.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I seem rather
unaccommodating, but I have some experience of life, and know how one
thing leads to another. I am afraid that your sister had better sleep
at the hotel. I have my children and the memory of my dear wife to
consider. I am sorry, but see that she leaves my house at once.
subQuotationList:
['I seem rather
unaccommodating, but I have some experience of life, and know how one
thing leads to another. I am afraid that your sister had better sleep
at the hotel. I have my children and the memory of my dear wife to
consider. I am sorry, but see that she leaves my house at once.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: You have mentioned Mrs. Wilcox.
subQuotationList: ['You have mentioned Mrs. Wilcox.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I beg your pardon?
subQuotationList: ['I beg your pardon?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: A rare occurrence. In reply, may I mention Mrs. Bast?
subQuotationList: ['A rare occurrence. In reply, may I mention Mrs. Bast?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: You have not been yourself all day,
subQuotationList: ['You have not been yourself all day,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Not any more of this! You shall see the connection if it
kills you, Henry! You have had a mistress--I forgave you. My sister
has a lover--you drive her from the house. Do you see the connection?
Stupid, hypocritical, cruel--oh, contemptible!--a man who insults his
wife when she s alive and cants with her memory when she s dead. A man
who ruins a woman for his pleasure, and casts her off to ruin other men.
And gives bad financial advice, and then says he is not responsible.
These men are you. You can t recognise them, because you cannot connect.
I ve had enough of your unneeded kindness. I ve spoilt you long enough.
All your life you have been spoiled. Mrs. Wilcox spoiled you. No one has
ever told what you are--muddled, criminally muddled. Men like you use
repentance as a blind, so don t repent. Only say to yourself,  What
Helen has done, I ve done.
subQuotationList:
['Not any more of this!', 'You shall see the connection if it
kills you, Henry! You have had a mistress--I forgave you. My sister
has a lover--you drive her from the house. Do you see the connection?
Stupid, hypocritical, cruel--oh, contemptible!--a man who insults his
wife when she s alive and cants with her memory when she s dead. A man
who ruins a woman for his pleasure, and casts her off to ruin other men.
And gives bad financial advice, and then says he is not responsible.
These men are you. You can t recognise them, because you cannot connect.
I ve had enough of your unneeded kindness. I ve spoilt you long enough.
All your life you have been spoiled. Mrs. Wilcox spoiled you. No one has
ever told what you are--muddled, criminally muddled. Men like you use
repentance as a blind, so don t repent. Only say to yourself,  What
Helen has done, I ve done.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: The two cases are different,
subQuotationList: ['The two cases are different,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
In what way different? You have betrayed Mrs. Wilcox, Helen only
herself. You remain in society, Helen can t. You have had only pleasure,
she may die. You have the insolence to talk to me of differences,
Henry?
subQuotationList:
['In what way different? You have betrayed Mrs. Wilcox, Helen only
herself. You remain in society, Helen can t. You have had only pleasure,
she may die. You have the insolence to talk to me of differences,
Henry?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I perceive you are attempting blackmail. It is scarcely a pretty weapon
for a wife to use against her husband. My rule through life has been
never to pay the least attention to threats, and I can only repeat
what I said before: I do not give you and your sister leave to sleep at
Howards End.
subQuotationList:
['I perceive you are attempting blackmail. It is scarcely a pretty weapon
for a wife to use against her husband. My rule through life has been
never to pay the least attention to threats, and I can only repeat
what I said before: I do not give you and your sister leave to sleep at
Howards End.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I
suppose you realise that you are your sister s protector?
subQuotationList: ['I\nsuppose you realise that you are your sister s protector?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: In what sense?
subQuotationList: ['In what sense?']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
If a man played about with my sister, I d send a bullet through him,
but perhaps you don t mind.
subQuotationList: ['If a man played about with my sister, I d send a bullet through him,\nbut perhaps you don t mind.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: I mind very much,
subQuotationList: ['I mind very much,']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: Who d ye suspect, then? Speak out man. One always suspects some one.
subQuotationList: ['Who d ye suspect, then? Speak out man. One always suspects some one.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: No one. I don t think so.
subQuotationList: ['No one. I don t think so.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: You are hiding something,
subQuotationList: ['You are hiding something,']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
When you saw her last, did she mention any one s
name? Yes or no!
subQuotationList: ['When you saw her last, did she mention any one s\nname? Yes or no!']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: In my rooms she mentioned some friends, called the Basts.
subQuotationList: ['In my rooms she mentioned some friends, called the Basts.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: Who are the Basts?
subQuotationList: ['Who are the Basts?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: People--friends of hers at Evie s wedding.
subQuotationList: ['People--friends of hers at Evie s wedding.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText:
I don t remember. But, by great Scott, I do! My aunt told me about some
rag-tag. Was she full of them when you saw her? Is there a man? Did she
speak of the man? Or--look here--have you had any dealings with him?
subQuotationList: ['I don t remember. But, by great Scott, I do! My aunt told me about some\nrag-tag. Was she full of them when you saw her? Is there a man? Did she\nspeak of the man? Or--look here--have you had any dealings with him?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
I see--you are in his confidence. They met at your rooms. Oh, what a
family, what a family! God help the poor pater--
subQuotationList: ['I see--you are in his confidence. They met at your rooms. Oh, what a\nfamily, what a family! God help the poor pater--']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
One isolates, I isolated Mr. Wilcox from the other
forces that were pulling Leonard downhill. Consequently, I was full of
pity, and almost of revenge. For weeks I had blamed Mr. Wilcox only, and
so, when your letters came--
subQuotationList:
['One isolates,', 'I isolated Mr. Wilcox from the other
forces that were pulling Leonard downhill. Consequently, I was full of
pity, and almost of revenge. For weeks I had blamed Mr. Wilcox only, and
so, when your letters came--']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I need never have written them, They never shielded
Henry. How hopeless it is to tidy away the past, even for others!
subQuotationList: ['I need never have written them,', 'They never shielded\nHenry. How hopeless it is to tidy away the past, even for others!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I did not know that it was your own idea to dismiss the Basts.
subQuotationList: ['I did not know that it was your own idea to dismiss the Basts.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Looking back, that was wrong of me.
subQuotationList: ['Looking back, that was wrong of me.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Looking back, darling, I know that it was right. It is right to save
the man whom one loves. I am less enthusiastic about justice now. But we
both thought you wrote at his dictation. It seemed the last touch of his
callousness. Being very much wrought up by this time--and Mrs. Bast
was upstairs. I had not seen her, and had talked for a long time to
Leonard--I had snubbed him for no reason, and that should have warned me
I was in danger. So when the notes came I wanted us to go to you for an
explanation. He said that he guessed the explanation--he knew of it, and
you mustn t know. I pressed him to tell me. He said no one must know; it
was something to do with his wife. Right up to the end we were Mr. Bast
and Miss Schlegel. I was going to tell him that he must be frank with me
when I saw his eyes, and guessed that Mr. Wilcox had ruined him in two
ways, not one. I drew him to me. I made him tell me. I felt very lonely
myself. He is not to blame. He would have gone on worshipping me. I want
never to see him again, though it sounds appalling. I wanted to give him
money and feel finished. Oh, Meg, the little that is known about these
things!
subQuotationList:
['Looking back, darling, I know that it was right. It is right to save
the man whom one loves. I am less enthusiastic about justice now. But we
both thought you wrote at his dictation. It seemed the last touch of his
callousness. Being very much wrought up by this time--and Mrs. Bast
was upstairs. I had not seen her, and had talked for a long time to
Leonard--I had snubbed him for no reason, and that should have warned me
I was in danger. So when the notes came I wanted us to go to you for an
explanation. He said that he guessed the explanation--he knew of it, and
you mustn t know. I pressed him to tell me. He said no one must know; it
was something to do with his wife. Right up to the end we were Mr. Bast
and Miss Schlegel. I was going to tell him that he must be frank with me
when I saw his eyes, and guessed that Mr. Wilcox had ruined him in two
ways, not one. I drew him to me. I made him tell me. I felt very lonely
myself. He is not to blame. He would have gone on worshipping me. I want
never to see him again, though it sounds appalling. I wanted to give him
money and feel finished. Oh, Meg, the little that is known about these
things!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
The little, too, that is known about growth! Both times it was
loneliness, and the night, and panic afterwards. Did Leonard grow out of
Paul?
subQuotationList: ['The little, too, that is known about growth! Both times it was\nloneliness, and the night, and panic afterwards. Did Leonard grow out of\nPaul?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Leonard is a better growth
than madness, I was afraid that you would react against Paul
until you went over the verge.
subQuotationList: ['Leonard is a better growth\nthan madness,', 'I was afraid that you would react against Paul\nuntil you went over the verge.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I did react until I found poor Leonard. I am steady now. I shan t ever
like your Henry, dearest Meg, or even speak kindly about him, but all
that blinding hate is over. I shall never rave against Wilcoxes any
more. I understand how you married him, and you will now be very happy.
subQuotationList:
['I did react until I found poor Leonard. I am steady now. I shan t ever
like your Henry, dearest Meg, or even speak kindly about him, but all
that blinding hate is over. I shall never rave against Wilcoxes any
more. I understand how you married him, and you will now be very happy.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Yes, I do at last
understand.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'I do at last\nunderstand.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Except Mrs. Wilcox, dearest, no one understands our little movements.
subQuotationList: ['Except Mrs. Wilcox, dearest, no one understands our little movements.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Because in death--I agree.
subQuotationList: ['Because in death--I agree.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Not quite. I feel that you and I and Henry are only fragments of that
woman s mind. She knows everything. She is everything. She is the house,
and the tree that leans over it. People have their own deaths as well
as their own lives, and even if there is nothing beyond death, we shall
differ in our nothingness. I cannot believe that knowledge such as hers
will perish with knowledge such as mine. She knew about realities. She
knew when people were in love, though she was not in the room. I don t
doubt that she knew when Henry deceived her.
subQuotationList:
['Not quite. I feel that you and I and Henry are only fragments of that
woman s mind. She knows everything. She is everything. She is the house,
and the tree that leans over it. People have their own deaths as well
as their own lives, and even if there is nothing beyond death, we shall
differ in our nothingness. I cannot believe that knowledge such as hers
will perish with knowledge such as mine. She knew about realities. She
knew when people were in love, though she was not in the room. I don t
doubt that she knew when Henry deceived her.']
speaker: Margaret
