quoteText: Good-night, Mrs. Wilcox,
subQuotationList: ['Good-night, Mrs. Wilcox,']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText: Oh, good-night, Miss Avery.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, good-night, Miss Avery.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Why should Miss Avery work for us?
subQuotationList: ['Why should Miss Avery work for us?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Why, indeed?
subQuotationList: ['Why, indeed?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
This is not quite our house yet, When Miss Avery called,
I felt we are only a couple of tourists.
subQuotationList: ['This is not quite our house yet,', 'When Miss Avery called,\nI felt we are only a couple of tourists.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: We shall be that everywhere, and for ever.
subQuotationList: ['We shall be that everywhere, and for ever.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: But affectionate tourists.
subQuotationList: ['But affectionate tourists.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: But tourists who pretend each hotel is their home.
subQuotationList: ['But tourists who pretend each hotel is their home.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I can t pretend very long, Sitting under this tree one
forgets, but I know that to-morrow I shall see the moon rise out of
Germany. Not all your goodness can alter the facts of the case. Unless
you will come with me.
subQuotationList:
['I can t pretend very long,', 'Sitting under this tree one
forgets, but I know that to-morrow I shall see the moon rise out of
Germany. Not all your goodness can alter the facts of the case. Unless
you will come with me.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Are you serious in asking me, Helen? Should I get on with your Monica?
subQuotationList: ['Are you serious in asking me, Helen? Should I get on with your Monica?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: You would not, but I am serious in asking you.
subQuotationList: ['You would not, but I am serious in asking you.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Still, no more plans now. And no more reminiscences.
subQuotationList: ['Still, no more plans now. And no more reminiscences.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Sleep now,
subQuotationList: ['Sleep now,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Brute--you brute, I couldn t have--
subQuotationList: ['Brute--you brute, I couldn t have--']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Oh what SHALL I do, whatever
SHALL I do?
subQuotationList: ['Oh what SHALL I do, whatever\nSHALL I do?']
speaker: Leonard
referringExpression: He would sit at the edge of his bed holding his heart and moaning

quoteText: There is nothing to choose between us, after all.
subQuotationList: ['There is nothing to choose between us, after all.']
speaker: Leonard
referringExpression: he was to regard her with a strange new tenderness and to think

quoteText:
A letter from Leonard, and after all
this time.
subQuotationList: ['A letter from Leonard,', 'and after all\nthis time.']
speaker: Blanche

quoteText: A letter from Leonard!
subQuotationList: ['A letter from Leonard!']
speaker: Laura

quoteText:
She minds that! What would she say if
she knew the truth?
subQuotationList: ['She minds that! What would she say if\nshe knew the truth?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Excuse me, sir, but is your boss married?
subQuotationList: ['Excuse me, sir, but is your boss married?']
speaker: Leonard
referringExpression: He hung about outside Mr Wilcox s office at lunch time and as the clerks came out said

quoteText: Does Mrs. Wilcox live here?
subQuotationList: ['Does Mrs. Wilcox live here?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: She s out,
subQuotationList: ['She s out,']
speaker: The Parlourmaid

quoteText: When will she be back?
subQuotationList: ['When will she be back?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: I ll ask,
subQuotationList: ['I ll ask,']
speaker: The Parlourmaid

quoteText: I don t know. Hilton. Howards End. Who is it?
subQuotationList: ['I don t know. Hilton. Howards End. Who is it?']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: I ll ask, sir.
subQuotationList: ['I ll ask, sir.']
speaker: The Parlourmaid

quoteText: No, don t bother.
subQuotationList: ['No, don t bother.']
speaker: Tibby

quoteText: They have taken the car to Howards End,
subQuotationList: ['They have taken the car to Howards End,']
speaker: The Parlourmaid

quoteText: You appear to want to know a good deal,
subQuotationList: ['You appear to want to know a good deal,']
speaker: The Parlourmaid

quoteText: Is it a village, please?
subQuotationList: ['Is it a village, please?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Village! It s Mr. Wilcox s private house--at least, it s one of them.
Mrs. Wilcox keeps her furniture there. Hilton is the village.
subQuotationList: ['Village! It s Mr. Wilcox s private house--at least, it s one of them.\nMrs. Wilcox keeps her furniture there. Hilton is the village.']
speaker: The Parlourmaid

quoteText: Yes. And when will they be back?
subQuotationList: ['Yes. And when will they be back?']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Mr. Schlegel doesn t know. We can t know everything, can we?
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Schlegel doesn t know. We can t know everything, can we?']
speaker: The Parlourmaid

quoteText:
Why horrible? It s ordinary
light from the moon. But it moves. So does the moon. But it is a
clenched fist. Why not? But it is going to touch me. Let it. Is there life in the
moon? Of course. But I thought it was uninhabited. Not by Time,
Death, Judgment, and the smaller snakes.
subQuotationList:
['Why horrible? It s ordinary
light from the moon.', 'But it moves.', 'So does the moon.', 'But it is a
clenched fist.', 'Why not?', 'But it is going to touch me.', 'Let it.', 'Is there life in the
moon?', 'Of course.', 'But I thought it was uninhabited.', 'Not by Time,
Death, Judgment, and the smaller snakes.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Smaller snakes! What a notion!
subQuotationList: ['Smaller snakes!', 'What a notion!']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: I say, Jacky, I m going out for a bit.
subQuotationList: ['I say, Jacky, I m going out for a bit.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Hullo, Len! What ho, Len!
subQuotationList: ['Hullo, Len! What ho, Len!']
speaker: Jacky

quoteText: What ho, Jacky! see you again later.
subQuotationList: ['What ho, Jacky! see you again later.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText:
Oh, is he there? I am not surprised. I now thrash him within an inch of
his life.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, is he there? I am not surprised. I now thrash him within an inch of\nhis life.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox
referringExpression: a man whom he had never seen said

quoteText: Mrs. Wilcox, I have done wrong.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Wilcox,', 'I have done wrong.']
speaker: Leonard

quoteText: Bring me a stick.
subQuotationList: ['Bring me a stick.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox
referringExpression: The man took him by the collar and cried

quoteText:
Get some water, He s shamming. Of course I only used the blade. Here, carry him out
into the air.
subQuotationList: ['Get some water,', 'He s shamming. Of course I only used the blade. Here, carry him out\ninto the air.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: That s enough,
subQuotationList: ['That s enough,']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Yes, murder s enough,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, murder s enough,']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText:
I don t know where she is, pater Dolly kept back dinner
nearly an hour for her.
subQuotationList: ['I don t know where she is, pater', 'Dolly kept back dinner\nnearly an hour for her.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Tell me when she comes in.
subQuotationList: ['Tell me when she comes in.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I ll sit up for her as late as you like, but she can hardly be coming.
Isn t she stopping with her sister at the hotel?
subQuotationList: ['I ll sit up for her as late as you like, but she can hardly be coming.\nIsn t she stopping with her sister at the hotel?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Perhaps, perhaps.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps,', 'perhaps.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Can I do anything for you, sir?
subQuotationList: ['Can I do anything for you, sir?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Not to-night, my boy.
subQuotationList: ['Not to-night, my boy.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I can t sleep, I
had better have a talk with you and get it over.
subQuotationList: ['I can t sleep,', 'I\nhad better have a talk with you and get it over.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
She will feel differently in the morning, But I cannot let this kind of
thing continue without comment. I am morally certain that she is with
her sister at Howards End. The house is mine--and, Charles, it will be
yours--and when I say that no one is to live there, I mean that no one
is to live there. I won t have it. To my mind this question is connected with something far greater, the
rights of property itself.
subQuotationList:
['She will feel differently in the morning,', 'But I cannot let this kind of
thing continue without comment. I am morally certain that she is with
her sister at Howards End. The house is mine--and, Charles, it will be
yours--and when I say that no one is to live there, I mean that no one
is to live there. I won t have it.', 'To my mind this question is connected with something far greater, the
rights of property itself.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Undoubtedly,
subQuotationList: ['Undoubtedly,']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
I don t want you to conclude that my wife and I had
anything of the nature of a quarrel. She was only overwrought, as who
would not be? I shall do what I can for Helen, but on the understanding
that they clear out of the house at once. Do you see? That is a sine qua
non.
subQuotationList:
['I don t want you to conclude that my wife and I had
anything of the nature of a quarrel. She was only overwrought, as who
would not be? I shall do what I can for Helen, but on the understanding
that they clear out of the house at once. Do you see? That is a sine qua
non.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Then at eight to-morrow I may go up in the car?
subQuotationList: ['Then at eight to-morrow I may go up in the car?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
Eight or earlier. Say that you are acting as my representative, and, of
course, use no violence, Charles.
subQuotationList: ['Eight or earlier. Say that you are acting as my representative, and, of\ncourse, use no violence, Charles.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
It has been pretty horrible, They were there,
and they had the man up there with them too.
subQuotationList: ['It has been pretty horrible,', 'They were there,\nand they had the man up there with them too.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: What--what man?
subQuotationList: ['What--what man?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I told you last night. His name was Bast.
subQuotationList: ['I told you last night. His name was Bast.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
My God! is it possible? In your mother s house!
Charles, in your mother s house!
subQuotationList: ['My God! is it possible?', 'In your mother s house!\nCharles, in your mother s house!']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I know, pater. That was what I felt. As a matter of fact, there is
no need to trouble about the man. He was in the last stages of heart
disease, and just before I could show him what I thought of him he went
off. The police are seeing about it at this moment.
subQuotationList:
['I know, pater. That was what I felt. As a matter of fact, there is
no need to trouble about the man. He was in the last stages of heart
disease, and just before I could show him what I thought of him he went
off. The police are seeing about it at this moment.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
I got up there--oh, it couldn t have been more than half-past seven.
The Avery woman was lighting a fire for them. They were still upstairs.
I waited in the drawing-room. We were all moderately civil and
collected, though I had my suspicions. I gave them your message, and
Mrs. Wilcox said,
subQuotationList:
['I got up there--oh, it couldn t have been more than half-past seven.
The Avery woman was lighting a fire for them. They were still upstairs.
I waited in the drawing-room. We were all moderately civil and
collected, though I had my suspicions. I gave them your message, and
Mrs. Wilcox said,']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: in that way of hers.
subQuotationList: ['in that way of hers.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Nothing else?
subQuotationList: ['Nothing else?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I promised to tell you,  with her love,  that she was going to Germany
with her sister this evening. That was all we had time for.
subQuotationList: ['I promised to tell you,  with her love,  that she was going to Germany\nwith her sister this evening. That was all we had time for.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
Because by then I suppose the man got tired of hiding, for suddenly
Mrs. Wilcox screamed out his name. I recognised it, and I went for him
in the hall. Was I right, pater? I thought things were going a little
too far.
subQuotationList:
['Because by then I suppose the man got tired of hiding, for suddenly
Mrs. Wilcox screamed out his name. I recognised it, and I went for him
in the hall. Was I right, pater? I thought things were going a little
too far.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
Right, my dear boy? I don t know. But you would have been no son of
mine if you hadn t. Then did he just--just--crumple up as you said?
subQuotationList: ['Right, my dear boy? I don t know. But you would have been no son of\nmine if you hadn t. Then did he just--just--crumple up as you said?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
He caught hold of the bookcase, which came down over him. So I merely
put the sword down and carried him into the garden. We all thought he
was shamming. However, he s dead right enough. Awful business!
subQuotationList: ['He caught hold of the bookcase, which came down over him. So I merely\nput the sword down and carried him into the garden. We all thought he\nwas shamming. However, he s dead right enough. Awful business!']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
Sword? What sword? Whose
sword?
subQuotationList: ['Sword?', 'What sword? Whose\nsword?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: A sword of theirs.
subQuotationList: ['A sword of theirs.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: What were you doing with it?
subQuotationList: ['What were you doing with it?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Well, didn t you see, pater, I had to snatch up the first thing handy.
I hadn t a riding-whip or stick. I caught him once or twice over the
shoulders with the flat of their old German sword.
subQuotationList: ['Well, didn t you see, pater, I had to snatch up the first thing handy.\nI hadn t a riding-whip or stick. I caught him once or twice over the\nshoulders with the flat of their old German sword.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: Then what?
subQuotationList: ['Then what?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: He pulled over the bookcase, as I said, and fell,
subQuotationList: ['He pulled over the bookcase, as I said, and fell,']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: But the real cause was heart disease? Of that you re sure?
subQuotationList: ['But the real cause was heart disease? Of that you re sure?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
That or a fit. However, we shall hear more than enough at the inquest
on such unsavoury topics.
subQuotationList: ['That or a fit. However, we shall hear more than enough at the inquest\non such unsavoury topics.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: I think I ll go round to the police-station,
subQuotationList: ['I think I ll go round to the police-station,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: What for?
subQuotationList: ['What for?']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: Very well, sir. Which car will you have?
subQuotationList: ['Very well, sir. Which car will you have?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: I think I ll walk.
subQuotationList: ['I think I ll walk.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
It s a good half-mile, The
sun s very hot for April. Shan t I take you up, and then, perhaps, a
little spin round by Tewin?
subQuotationList: ['It s a good half-mile,', 'The\nsun s very hot for April. Shan t I take you up, and then, perhaps, a\nlittle spin round by Tewin?']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
You go on as if I didn t know my own mind, You young fellows  one idea is to get into
a motor. I tell you, I want to walk; I m very fond of walking.
subQuotationList: ['You go on as if I didn t know my own mind,', 'You young fellows  one idea is to get into\na motor. I tell you, I want to walk; I m very fond of walking.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Oh, all right; I m about the house if you want me for anything. I
thought of not going up to the office to-day, if that is your wish.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, all right; I m about the house if you want me for anything. I\nthought of not going up to the office to-day, if that is your wish.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText: It is, indeed, my boy,
subQuotationList: ['It is, indeed, my boy,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I expected that, I shall naturally be the most
important witness there.
subQuotationList: ['I expected that,', 'I shall naturally be the most\nimportant witness there.']
speaker: Charles Wilcox

quoteText:
No one ever told
the lad he ll have a child
subQuotationList: ['No one ever told\nthe lad he ll have a child']
speaker: Miss Avery

quoteText:
No
doubt Mr. Wilcox may have induced death, but if it wasn t
one thing it would have been another as you know.
subQuotationList: ['No\ndoubt Mr. Wilcox may have induced death,', 'but if it wasn t\none thing it would have been another as you know.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Is it the keys that Mr. Wilcox wants?
subQuotationList: ['Is it the keys that Mr. Wilcox wants?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: He didn t say, madam.
subQuotationList: ['He didn t say, madam.']
speaker: Crane

quoteText: You haven t any note for me?
subQuotationList: ['You haven t any note for me?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: He didn t say, madam.
subQuotationList: ['He didn t say, madam.']
speaker: Crane

quoteText:
I prefer to
discuss things with you outside.
subQuotationList: ['I prefer to\ndiscuss things with you outside.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: It will be more appropriate in the road, I am afraid, Did you get my message?
subQuotationList: ['It will be more appropriate in the road, I am afraid,', 'Did you get my message?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: What about?
subQuotationList: ['What about?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I am going to Germany with my sister. I must tell you now that I shall
make it my permanent home. Our talk last night was more important than
you have realised. I am unable to forgive you and am leaving you.
subQuotationList: ['I am going to Germany with my sister. I must tell you now that I shall\nmake it my permanent home. Our talk last night was more important than\nyou have realised. I am unable to forgive you and am leaving you.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I am extremely tired, I have been
walking about all the morning, and wish to sit down.
subQuotationList: ['I am extremely tired,', 'I have been\nwalking about all the morning, and wish to sit down.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Certainly, if you will consent to sit on the grass.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly, if you will consent to sit on the grass.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Here are your keys,
subQuotationList: ['Here are your keys,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I have something to tell you,
subQuotationList: ['I have something to tell you,']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
I don t want to hear it, My sister is going to be
ill. My life is going to be with her now. We must manage to build up
something, she and I and her child.
subQuotationList: ['I don t want to hear it,', 'My sister is going to be\nill. My life is going to be with her now. We must manage to build up\nsomething, she and I and her child.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Where are you going?
subQuotationList: ['Where are you going?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Munich. We start after the inquest, if she is not too ill.
subQuotationList: ['Munich. We start after the inquest, if she is not too ill.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: After the inquest?
subQuotationList: ['After the inquest?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Have you realised what the verdict at the inquest will be?
subQuotationList: ['Have you realised what the verdict at the inquest will be?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Yes, heart disease.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, heart disease.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: No, my dear; manslaughter.
subQuotationList: ['No, my dear; manslaughter.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Manslaughter, Charles may go to prison. I dare
not tell him. I don t know what to do--what to do. I m broken--I m
ended.
subQuotationList: ['Manslaughter,', 'Charles may go to prison. I dare\nnot tell him. I don t know what to do--what to do. I m broken--I m\nended.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I haven t any idea, Do you suppose baby may, Meg?
subQuotationList: ['I haven t any idea,', 'Do you suppose baby may, Meg?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: What was that?
subQuotationList: ['What was that?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Tom wants to know whether baby is old enough to play with hay?
subQuotationList: ['Tom wants to know whether baby is old enough to play with hay?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I haven t the least notion,
subQuotationList: ['I haven t the least notion,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Now, Tom, baby is not to stand; he is not to lie on his face; he is not
to lie so that his head wags; he is not to be teased or tickled; and he
is not to be cut into two or more pieces by the cutter. Will you be as
careful as all that?
subQuotationList:
['Now, Tom, baby is not to stand; he is not to lie on his face; he is not
to lie so that his head wags; he is not to be teased or tickled; and he
is not to be cut into two or more pieces by the cutter. Will you be as
careful as all that?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: That child is a wonderful nursemaid,
subQuotationList: ['That child is a wonderful nursemaid,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: He is fond of baby. That s why he does it! They re going to be lifelong friends.
subQuotationList: ['He is fond of baby. That s why he does it!', 'They re going to be lifelong friends.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Starting at the ages of six and one?
subQuotationList: ['Starting at the ages of six and one?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Of course. It will be a great thing for Tom.
subQuotationList: ['Of course. It will be a great thing for Tom.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: It may be a greater thing for baby.
subQuotationList: ['It may be a greater thing for baby.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
What a time they all are! What can they be doing inside? I wish Henry was out to enjoy this, This lovely weather
and to be shut up in the house! It s very hard.
subQuotationList: ['What a time they all are!', 'What can they be doing inside?', 'I wish Henry was out to enjoy this,', 'This lovely weather\nand to be shut up in the house! It s very hard.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
It has to be, The hay fever is his chief objection
against living here, but he thinks it worth while.
subQuotationList: ['It has to be,', 'The hay fever is his chief objection\nagainst living here, but he thinks it worth while.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Meg, is or isn t he ill? I can t make out.
subQuotationList: ['Meg, is or isn t he ill? I can t make out.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Not ill. Eternally tired. He has worked very hard all his life, and
noticed nothing. Those are the people who collapse when they do notice a
thing.
subQuotationList: ['Not ill. Eternally tired. He has worked very hard all his life, and\nnoticed nothing. Those are the people who collapse when they do notice a\nthing.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I suppose he worries dreadfully about his part of the tangle.
subQuotationList: ['I suppose he worries dreadfully about his part of the tangle.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Dreadfully. That is why I wish Dolly had not come, too, to-day. Still,
he wanted them all to come. It has to be.
subQuotationList: ['Dreadfully. That is why I wish Dolly had not come, too, to-day. Still,\nhe wanted them all to come. It has to be.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Why does he want them?
subQuotationList: ['Why does he want them?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Meg, may I tell you something? I like Henry.
subQuotationList: ['Meg, may I tell you something? I like Henry.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: You d be odd if you didn t,
subQuotationList: ['You d be odd if you didn t,']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I usen t to.
subQuotationList: ['I usen t to.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Usen t!
subQuotationList: ['Usen t!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I like Henry because he does worry.
subQuotationList: ['I like Henry because he does worry.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: And he likes you because you don t.
subQuotationList: ['And he likes you because you don t.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: About love,
subQuotationList: ['About love,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I mean a woman s love for a man. I supposed I should hang my life on
to that once, and was driven up and down and about as if something was
worrying through me. But everything is peaceful now; I seem cured. That
Herr Forstmeister, whom Frieda keeps writing about, must be a noble
character, but he doesn t see that I shall never marry him or anyone. It
isn t shame or mistrust of myself. I simply couldn t. I m ended. I used
to be so dreamy about a man s love as a girl, and think that for good
or evil love must be the great thing. But it hasn t been; it has been
itself a dream. Do you agree?
subQuotationList:
['I mean a woman s love for a man. I supposed I should hang my life on
to that once, and was driven up and down and about as if something was
worrying through me. But everything is peaceful now; I seem cured. That
Herr Forstmeister, whom Frieda keeps writing about, must be a noble
character, but he doesn t see that I shall never marry him or anyone. It
isn t shame or mistrust of myself. I simply couldn t. I m ended. I used
to be so dreamy about a man s love as a girl, and think that for good
or evil love must be the great thing. But it hasn t been; it has been
itself a dream. Do you agree?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: I do not agree. I do not.
subQuotationList: ['I do not agree. I do not.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
I ought to remember Leonard as my lover, I tempted him, and killed him, and it is surely the
least I can do. I would like to throw out all my heart to Leonard on
such an afternoon as this. But I cannot. It is no good pretending. I
am forgetting him. How nothing seems to
match--how, my darling, my precious--
subQuotationList:
['I ought to remember Leonard as my lover,', 'I tempted him, and killed him, and it is surely the
least I can do. I would like to throw out all my heart to Leonard on
such an afternoon as this. But I cannot. It is no good pretending. I
am forgetting him.', 'How nothing seems to
match--how, my darling, my precious--']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Tommy!
subQuotationList: ['Tommy!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Yes, please?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, please?']
speaker: Tom

quoteText:
Baby s not to try and stand.--There s something wanting in me. I see
you loving Henry, and understanding him better daily, and I know
that death wouldn t part you in the least. But I--Is it some awful,
appalling, criminal defect?
subQuotationList:
['Baby s not to try and stand.--There s something wanting in me. I see
you loving Henry, and understanding him better daily, and I know
that death wouldn t part you in the least. But I--Is it some awful,
appalling, criminal defect?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
It is only that people are far more
different than is pretended. All over the world men and women are
worrying because they cannot develop as they are supposed to develop.
Here and there they have the matter out, and it comforts them. Don t
fret yourself, Helen. Develop what you have; love your child. I do not
love children. I am thankful to have none. I can play with their beauty
and charm, but that is all--nothing real, not one scrap of what there
ought to be. And others--others go farther still, and move outside
humanity altogether. A place, as well as a person, may catch the glow.
Don t you see that all this leads to comfort in the end? It is part of
the battle against sameness. Differences, eternal differences, planted
by God in a single family, so that there may always be colour; sorrow
perhaps, but colour in the daily grey. Then I can t have you worrying
about Leonard. Don t drag in the personal when it will not come. Forget
him.
subQuotationList:
['It is only that people are far more
different than is pretended. All over the world men and women are
worrying because they cannot develop as they are supposed to develop.
Here and there they have the matter out, and it comforts them. Don t
fret yourself, Helen. Develop what you have; love your child. I do not
love children. I am thankful to have none. I can play with their beauty
and charm, but that is all--nothing real, not one scrap of what there
ought to be. And others--others go farther still, and move outside
humanity altogether. A place, as well as a person, may catch the glow.
Don t you see that all this leads to comfort in the end? It is part of
the battle against sameness. Differences, eternal differences, planted
by God in a single family, so that there may always be colour; sorrow
perhaps, but colour in the daily grey. Then I can t have you worrying
about Leonard. Don t drag in the personal when it will not come. Forget
him.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes, yes, but what has Leonard got out of life?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, yes, but what has Leonard got out of life?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Perhaps an adventure.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps an adventure.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Is that enough?
subQuotationList: ['Is that enough?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Not for us. But for him.
subQuotationList: ['Not for us. But for him.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Is it sweetening yet?
subQuotationList: ['Is it sweetening yet?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: No, only withered.
subQuotationList: ['No, only withered.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: It will sweeten to-morrow.
subQuotationList: ['It will sweeten to-morrow.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Oh, Meg, you are a person, Think of the
racket and torture this time last year. But now I couldn t stop unhappy
if I tried. What a change--and all through you!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Meg, you are a person,', 'Think of the\nracket and torture this time last year. But now I couldn t stop unhappy\nif I tried. What a change--and all through you!']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Oh, we merely settled down. You and Henry learnt to understand one
another and to forgive, all through the autumn and the winter.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, we merely settled down. You and Henry learnt to understand one\nanother and to forgive, all through the autumn and the winter.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Yes, but who settled us down?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, but who settled us down?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
You! You did it all, sweetest, though you re too stupid
to see. Living here was your plan--I wanted you; he wanted you; and
everyone said it was impossible, but you knew. Just think of our lives
without you, Meg--I and baby with Monica, revolting by theory, he handed
about from Dolly to Evie. But you picked up the pieces, and made us a
home. Can t it strike you--even for a moment--that your life has been
heroic? Can t you remember the two months after Charles s arrest, when
you began to act, and did all?
subQuotationList:
['You!', 'You did it all, sweetest, though you re too stupid
to see. Living here was your plan--I wanted you; he wanted you; and
everyone said it was impossible, but you knew. Just think of our lives
without you, Meg--I and baby with Monica, revolting by theory, he handed
about from Dolly to Evie. But you picked up the pieces, and made us a
home. Can t it strike you--even for a moment--that your life has been
heroic? Can t you remember the two months after Charles s arrest, when
you began to act, and did all?']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
You were both ill at the time, I did the obvious
things. I had two invalids to nurse. Here was a house, ready furnished
and empty. It was obvious. I didn t know myself it would turn into a
permanent home. No doubt I have done a little towards straightening the
tangle, but things that I can t phrase have helped me.
subQuotationList:
['You were both ill at the time,', 'I did the obvious
things. I had two invalids to nurse. Here was a house, ready furnished
and empty. It was obvious. I didn t know myself it would turn into a
permanent home. No doubt I have done a little towards straightening the
tangle, but things that I can t phrase have helped me.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: I hope it will be permanent,
subQuotationList: ['I hope it will be permanent,']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
I think so. There are moments when I feel Howards End peculiarly our
own.
subQuotationList: ['I think so. There are moments when I feel Howards End peculiarly our\nown.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: All the same, London s creeping.
subQuotationList: ['All the same, London s creeping.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
You see that in Surrey and even Hampshire now, I can
see it from the Purbeck Downs. And London is only part of something
else, I m afraid. Life s going to be melted down, all over the world.
subQuotationList: ['You see that in Surrey and even Hampshire now,', 'I can\nsee it from the Purbeck Downs. And London is only part of something\nelse, I m afraid. Life s going to be melted down, all over the world.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText:
Because a thing is going strong now, it need not go strong for ever, This craze for motion has only set in during the last hundred
years. It may be followed by a civilisation that won t be a movement,
because it will rest on the earth. All the signs are against it now, but
I can t help hoping, and very early in the morning in the garden I feel
that our house is the future as well as the past.
subQuotationList:
['Because a thing is going strong now, it need not go strong for ever,', 'This craze for motion has only set in during the last hundred
years. It may be followed by a civilisation that won t be a movement,
because it will rest on the earth. All the signs are against it now, but
I can t help hoping, and very early in the morning in the garden I feel
that our house is the future as well as the past.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: Oh, take care--!
subQuotationList: ['Oh, take care--!']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: The conclave s breaking at last. I ll go.
subQuotationList: ['The conclave s breaking at last. I ll go.']
speaker: Helen

quoteText: My father has asked for you,
subQuotationList: ['My father has asked for you,']
speaker: Paul

quoteText:
We have been talking business, but I dare say you knew
all about it beforehand.
subQuotationList: ['We have been talking business,', 'but I dare say you knew\nall about it beforehand.']
speaker: Paul

quoteText: Yes, I did.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I did.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Is this going to suit everyone? Because I
don t want you all coming here later on and complaining that I have been
unfair.
subQuotationList: ['Is this going to suit everyone?', 'Because I\ndon t want you all coming here later on and complaining that I have been\nunfair.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: It s apparently got to suit us,
subQuotationList: ['It s apparently got to suit us,']
speaker: Paul

quoteText:
I beg your pardon, my boy. You have only to speak, and I will leave the
house to you instead.
subQuotationList: ['I beg your pardon, my boy. You have only to speak, and I will leave the\nhouse to you instead.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
As I ve
given up the outdoor life that suited me, and I have come home to look
after the business, it s no good my settling down here, It s not really the country, and it s not the town.
subQuotationList: ['As I ve\ngiven up the outdoor life that suited me, and I have come home to look\nafter the business, it s no good my settling down here,', 'It s not really the country, and it s not the town.']
speaker: Paul

quoteText: Very well. Does my arrangement suit you, Evie?
subQuotationList: ['Very well. Does my arrangement suit you, Evie?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Of course, father.
subQuotationList: ['Of course, father.']
speaker: Evie

quoteText: And you, Dolly?
subQuotationList: ['And you, Dolly?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Perfectly splendidly, I thought Charles wanted
it for the boys, but last time I saw him he said no, because we cannot
possibly live in this part of England again. Charles says we ought
to change our name, but I cannot think what to, for Wilcox just suits
Charles and me, and I can t think of any other name.
subQuotationList:
['Perfectly splendidly,', 'I thought Charles wanted
it for the boys, but last time I saw him he said no, because we cannot
possibly live in this part of England again. Charles says we ought
to change our name, but I cannot think what to, for Wilcox just suits
Charles and me, and I can t think of any other name.']
speaker: Dolly
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Charles Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Charles', 'Dolly'], ['Charles Wilcox']]]

quoteText:
Then I leave Howards End to my wife absolutely, And let
everyone understand that; and after I am dead let there be no jealousy
and no surprise. In consequence, I leave my wife no money, That is her own
wish. All that she would have had will be divided among you. I am also
giving you a great deal in my lifetime, so that you may be independent
of me. That is her wish, too. She also is giving away a great deal of
money. She intends to diminish her income by half during the next ten
years; she intends when she dies to leave the house to her nephew, down
in the field. Is all that clear? Does everyone understand?
subQuotationList:
['Then I leave Howards End to my wife absolutely,', 'And let
everyone understand that; and after I am dead let there be no jealousy
and no surprise.', 'In consequence, I leave my wife no money,', 'That is her own
wish. All that she would have had will be divided among you. I am also
giving you a great deal in my lifetime, so that you may be independent
of me. That is her wish, too. She also is giving away a great deal of
money. She intends to diminish her income by half during the next ten
years; she intends when she dies to leave the house to her nephew, down
in the field. Is all that clear? Does everyone understand?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
Down in the field? Oh, come! I think we might have had the whole
establishment, piccaninnies included.
subQuotationList: ['Down in the field? Oh, come! I think we might have had the whole\nestablishment, piccaninnies included.']
speaker: Paul

quoteText: Don t, Paul. You promised you d take care.
subQuotationList: ['Don t, Paul. You promised you d take care.']
speaker: Evie

quoteText:
Good-bye, old girl, don t you worry
about me.
subQuotationList: ['Good-bye, old girl,', 'don t you worry\nabout me.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Good-bye, dad.
subQuotationList: ['Good-bye, dad.']
speaker: Evie

quoteText:
Good-bye, Mr. Wilcox. It does seem curious that Mrs. Wilcox
should have left Margaret Howards End, and yet she get it, after all.
subQuotationList: ['Good-bye, Mr. Wilcox. It does seem curious that Mrs. Wilcox\nshould have left Margaret Howards End, and yet she get it, after all.']
speaker: Dolly

quoteText: Goodbye,
subQuotationList: ['Goodbye,']
speaker: Evie

quoteText: Good-bye.
subQuotationList: ['Good-bye.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Good-bye, Dolly.
subQuotationList: ['Good-bye, Dolly.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: So long, father.
subQuotationList: ['So long, father.']
speaker: Paul

quoteText: Good-bye, my boy; always take care of yourself.
subQuotationList: ['Good-bye, my boy; always take care of yourself.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: Good-bye, Mrs. Wilcox.
subQuotationList: ['Good-bye, Mrs. Wilcox.']
speaker: Paul

quoteText: Good-bye.
subQuotationList: ['Good-bye.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Could you tell me,
Henry, what was that about Mrs. Wilcox having left me Howards End?
subQuotationList: ['Could you tell me,\nHenry, what was that about Mrs. Wilcox having left me Howards End?']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText:
Yes, she did. But that is a very old story.
When she was ill and you were so kind to her she wanted to make you some
return, and, not being herself at the time, scribbled  Howards End  on
a piece of paper. I went into it thoroughly, and, as it was clearly
fanciful, I set it aside, little knowing what my Margaret would be to me
in the future.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, she did. But that is a very old story.
When she was ill and you were so kind to her she wanted to make you some
return, and, not being herself at the time, scribbled  Howards End  on
a piece of paper. I went into it thoroughly, and, as it was clearly
fanciful, I set it aside, little knowing what my Margaret would be to me
in the future.']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: I didn t do wrong, did I?
subQuotationList: ['I didn t do wrong, did I?']
speaker: Henry

quoteText: You didn t, darling. Nothing has been done wrong.
subQuotationList: ['You didn t, darling. Nothing has been done wrong.']
speaker: Margaret

quoteText: Here they are at last!
subQuotationList: ['Here they are at last!']
speaker: Henry

quoteText:
The field s cut! the big meadow! We ve seen to
the very end, and it ll be such a crop of hay as never!
subQuotationList: ['The field s cut!', 'the big meadow! We ve seen to\nthe very end, and it ll be such a crop of hay as never!']
speaker: Helen
